hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻahu ʻili kao.
english_phrase: Wearer of goat hide.
meaning_phrase: An expression of contempt for a person who is so lazy he uses goat hides instead of mats, which require work to make, for his bedding. Such a person is recognized by his goaty odor.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻa i ka hula, waiho ka hilahila i ka hale.
english_phrase: When one wants to dance the hula, bashfulness should be left at home.
meaning_phrase: Also expressed Aʻo i ka hula,....

hawaiian_phrase: A ʻai ka manu i luna.
english_phrase: The birds feed above.
meaning_phrase: An attractive person is compared to a flower-laden tree that attracts birds.

hawaiian_phrase: A aloha wale ʻia kā hoʻi o Kaunuohua, he puʻu wale nō.
english_phrase: Even Kaunuohua, a hill, is loved.
meaning_phrase: If a hill can be loved, how much more so a human?

hawaiian_phrase: Aʻeaʻe mōhala i luna o ke kukui.
english_phrase: Whiteness unfolds on the kukui trees.
meaning_phrase: Used in reference to a person who grays, comparing him to a blooming kukui tree laden with white flowers.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻĀhaʻi akula i ka welowelo.
english_phrase: Took off into the breeze.
meaning_phrase: Rose in triumph, as a kite rises into the sky; hastened away with great speed.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻĀhaʻi lā i ka pupuhi.
english_phrase: Away like a gust [of wind].
meaning_phrase: Travel with the speed of wind.

hawaiian_phrase: Ahē nō ka manu o Kaʻula, he lā ʻino.
english_phrase: When the birds of Kaʻula appear wild, it denotes a stormy day.
meaning_phrase: Signs of trouble keep people away.

hawaiian_phrase: A hewa no he hale kanaka, ʻaʻohe hewa o ka hale kanaka ʻole.
english_phrase: Fault can he found in an inhabited house and none in an uninhabited one.
meaning_phrase: Mistakes and weakness are always found in humanity.

hawaiian_phrase: A hīkapalalē, hinolue o walawala ki pohā!
english_phrase: This is what the Hawaiians thought the first white men to visit the islands said.
meaning_phrase: It is untranslatable gibberish repeated with laughter when one is told something utterly incomprehensible.

hawaiian_phrase: A hua a pane; a pane ka waha, he hoʻolono ko neʻi.
english_phrase: A word in reply; open the mouth and speak, for a listener is here.
meaning_phrase: A command to speak up and tell what one has come for. Used in hoʻopāpā riddling.

hawaiian_phrase: Ahu a lālā kukui.
english_phrase: The kukui branches lay about in heaps.
meaning_phrase: Strewn about in every direction. An expression that refers to an untidy place or the strewing of dead bodies after a battle.

hawaiian_phrase: Ahu ka ʻalaʻala palu.
english_phrase: A heap of relish made of octopus liver.
meaning_phrase: Nothing worth troubling about. Octopus liver (ʻalaʻala) was not a choice food. It was mashed and used as bait.

hawaiian_phrase: Ahu ka hoka i Kapākai.
english_phrase: A heap of disappointment at Kapākai.
meaning_phrase: Fooled and left stranded. In ancient times, two fishermen sailed from Kapākai, a small canoe landing between ʻUpolu Point and the heiau of Moʻokini in Kohala. As they were about to leave for Maui, a stranger asked permission to accompany them, and it was granted. Late that night one of the fishermen signaled to the other to toss the passenger overboard because he was doing nothing to help with the canoe. The passenger guessed what they were up to and cried, “Oh! I forgot my cowry sinkers at the canoe landing.” Cowry sinkers were valuable, so they turned about and retumed to Kapākai. Upon landing, the passenger leaped ashore. When asked where the sinkers were, he pointed to two half-buried rocks nearby. The fishermen were disappointed (hoka) in not obtaining the coveted cowry sinkers. In another version the saying originated at the birth of Kamehameha I on a canoe. At the landing at Kapākai his mother pretended illness, whieh drew attention to herself and gave Naeʻole the opportunity to seize the newborn baby and flee with him into hiding.

hawaiian_phrase: Ahu ka pala naio.
english_phrase: A heap of excretal residue where pinworms are found.
meaning_phrase: A rude remark. Said of something unworthy of attention or to show disbelief in a statement.

hawaiian_phrase: Ahu kāpeku i ka nalu o Puhili.
english_phrase: Much thrashing about in the surf of Puhili.
meaning_phrase: Signifying an abundance of food. Thrashing about in the water drives fish into the nets.

hawaiian_phrase: Ahu ke pilo.
english_phrase: A heap of stinks.
meaning_phrase: Said of a delusion. Mānā, Kauaʻi, is a place where mirages were once seen.

hawaiian_phrase: Ahu kupanaha ka lā i Mānā.
english_phrase: Peculiar is the action of the sun in Mānā.
meaning_phrase: Said of a delusion. Mānā, Kauaʻi, is a place where mirages were once seen.

hawaiian_phrase: Ahulau ka Piʻipiʻi i Kakanilua.
english_phrase: A slaughter of the Piʻipiʻi at Kakanilua.
meaning_phrase: In the battle between Kahekili of Maui and Kalaniʻōpuʻu of Hawaiʻi, on the sand dunes of Wailuku, Maui, there was a great slaughter of Hawaiʻi warriors who were called the Piʻipiʻi. Any great slaughter might be compared to the slaughter of the Piʻipiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ahuwale ka nane hūnā.
english_phrase: The hidden answer to the riddle is seen.
meaning_phrase: That which was a secret is no longer hidden.

hawaiian_phrase: Ahuwale nā pae puʻu o Hāʻupukele.
english_phrase: The row of Hāʻupukele’s hills are in full view.
meaning_phrase: Said of anything that is exposed or very obvious.

hawaiian_phrase: Ahuwale nā pali kahakai o Kamilo.
english_phrase: Exposed are the sea cliffs at Kamilo Beach.
meaning_phrase: Said of a woman who sits carelessly and exposes herself. Kamilo Beach is in Kaʻū.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia a kau ka iʻa i ka waʻa, manaʻo ke ola.
english_phrase: One can think of life after the fish is in the canoe.
meaning_phrase: Before one feels elated and makes plans he should first secure his “fish.”

hawaiian_phrase: Aia akula i kula panoa wai ʻole.
english_phrase: Gone to the dry, waterless plain.
meaning_phrase: Gone where one may find himself stranded or deserted.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia akula nō i Kiʻilau.
english_phrase: He is gone to Kiʻilau.
meaning_phrase: Said of senseless chatter, aimless talk. A play on kiʻi (fetch) and lau (many), meaning to fetch much; that is, to fetch a lot to talk about. Kiʻilau is a place in ʻEwa, Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia akula paha i Kiolakaʻa.
english_phrase: Perhaps it is gone to Kiolakaʻa.
meaning_phrase: Gone to the place of thrown-away things. Used when something is thrown away and later wanted. A play on kiola, to throw away. Kiolakaʻa is a place in Kaʻū.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia akula paha i Waikīkī i ka ʻimi ʻahuʻawa.
english_phrase: Perhaps gone to Waikīkī to seek the ʻahuʻawa sedge.
meaning_phrase: Gone where disappointment is met. A play on ahu (heap) and ʻawa (sour).

hawaiian_phrase: Aia aku nei paha i Kaiholena.
english_phrase: Perhaps gone to Kaiholena.
meaning_phrase: Perhaps gone to loaf somewhere. A play on lena (lazy).

hawaiian_phrase: Aia anei ka maka i ke kua o ʻike ʻole iho?
english_phrase: Are the eyes on the back that one cannot see what is being done?
meaning_phrase: Said of one who declares that he doesn’t know how to do a certain thing and perhaps will not be able to learn.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia a ola hou ʻo Kupanea.
english_phrase: When Kupanea comes to life again.
meaning_phrase: When Kupanea died, Kaona, a false prophet who lived during the reign of Kamehameha III, suggested that the family leave him unburied and that Kaona’s prayers would restore the corpse to life again. Instead Kupanea’s corpse became decomposed and had to be buried. Thus, this humorous saying — meaning never! — came into being.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia a paʻi ʻia ka maka, haʻi ʻia kupuna nāna ʻoe.
english_phrase: Only when your face is slapped should you tell who your ancestors are.
meaning_phrase: Hawaiians were taught never to boast of illustrious ancestors. But when one is slandered and called an offspring of worthless people, he should mention his ancestors to prove that the statement is wrong.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia a pohā ka leo o ka ʻaʻo, kāpule ke momona o ka ʻuwaʻu i ka puapua.
english_phrase: When the ʻaʻo birds’ voices are distinctly heard, the ʻuwaʻu birds are fat even to the very tails.
meaning_phrase: The ʻao bird was not heard during the nesting season. When the fledglings emerged and their cries were heard, the season had come when young ʻuwaʻu were best for eating, and the people went to snare them.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia a wela ke poʻo o ke keiki i ka lā.
english_phrase: When the head of the child is warmed by the sun.
meaning_phrase: When he is old enough to toddle or creep by himself into the sunlight.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia a wini kākala, a ʻula ka lepe o ka moa, a laila kau i ka haka.
english_phrase: When the spur is sharp and the comb red, then shall the cock rest on a perch.
meaning_phrase: When a boy becomes a man, then shall he take a mate.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia iā Kaʻaikiola.
english_phrase: Kaʻaikiola has it.
meaning_phrase: Mr. Throw-away has it. A play on the name Ka-ʻai-kiola (Throw-away-food). Said when an article is carelessly mislaid.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia i Hiʻikua; i Hiʻialo.
english_phrase: Is borne on the back; is borne in the arms.
meaning_phrase: When one has gone to a far place where he cannot be seen by loved ones, he is said to be in Hiʻikua; and when one is where he can be seen daily, he is said to be in Hiʻialo. Also said of a favorite child, who is carried in the arms or on the back. Also said of the ʻaumākua.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia i Hilo ʻo Alanaio; aia i Puna ʻo Kapoho; aia i Laupāhoehoe ʻo Ulekiʻi.
english_phrase: In Hilo is Alanaio; in Puna is Kapoho; in Laupāhoehoe is Ulekii.
meaning_phrase: A vulgar play on place names, calling attention to private parts, which are omens of disappointment when seen in dreams. An expression of contempt for one who brings bad luck. Alanaio (Way-of-the-pinworm), the anus, is in Hilo; Kapoho (The Container), the vagina, is in Puna; and Ulekiʻi (Rigid Penis) is in Laupāhoehoe.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia i ka huki nehu, ka iʻa kaulana o ka ʻāina.
english_phrase: Gone to haul in the nehu, the well-known fish of the land.
meaning_phrase: Gone to get nehu for bait. Gone to get her man; that is, gone to get the bait that will get him.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia i ka huki ulua.
english_phrase: Gone to haul ulua fish.
meaning_phrase: Gone to get her man. The ulua fish signifies a man.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia i ka mole kamaliʻi, ʻaʻohe i oʻo ka iwi.
english_phrase: Still rooted in childhood when the bones have not matured.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who is still a child, either physically or mentally.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia i ka mole o Lehua.
english_phrase: At the taproot of Lehua.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is out of sight for a long time, neither seen nor heard of. Lehua is an island beyond Niʻihau.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia i ka ʻōpua ke ola: he ola nui, he ola laulā, he ola hohonu, he ola kiʻekiʻe.
english_phrase: Life is in the clouds: great life, broad life, deep life, elevated Iife.
meaning_phrase: The reader of omens knows by their shape and color whether clouds promise rain and prosperity, or warn of disaster.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia i Kaʻū i Kaʻaluʻalu.
english_phrase: There in Kaʻū is a place named Kaʻalu alu.
meaning_phrase: When seen from the ocean, Kaʻaluʻalu appears creased. This saying is applied jokingly to the wrinkles of a person, or to wrinkled clothing.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia i Keaʻā.
english_phrase: He is in Keaʻā.
meaning_phrase: A Kaʻū saying applied to a wilfully inattentive person who hears no more than a deaf-mute. A play on aʻā.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia i ke au a ka hewahewa.
english_phrase: Gone on a crazy current.
meaning_phrase: Gone on his own wandering way.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia i Kohala, i Puehuehu.
english_phrase: Gone to Kohala, to Puehuehu.
meaning_phrase: Nothing more is left. Used about someone who has lost everything. A play on puehu (to scatter like fine dust). Also expressed Hoʻi i Kohala i Puehuehu.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia i Kōloa.
english_phrase: Is at Kōloa.
meaning_phrase: A play on kō (drawn) and loa (long)— drawn a long way under. Drunk.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia i Kona i Honalo.
english_phrase: It is in Kona, in Honalo.
meaning_phrase: A play on nalo (lost). You’ve lost it and it is gone.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia i kula i ka ʻalaʻalapūloa.
english_phrase: Gone on the plain to gather ʻalaʻalapūloa.
meaning_phrase: Gone on a wild goose chase. A play on ʻalaʻala (octopus liver), meaning nothing worthwhile. ʻAlaʻalapūloa is another name for the weed commonly known as ʻuhaloa.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia i luna o ʻUalakaʻa.
english_phrase: He is up on ʻUalakaʻa.
meaning_phrase: A play on ʻUala-kaʻa (Rolling-potato-hill). Said of one who, like a rolling potato, has nothing to hold fast to. The hill was said to have been named for a sweet potato that broke loose from its vine on a field above and rolled down to a field below in Mānoa.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia i Pāʻula ka waha o nei kauwā; aia i Alanaio ka waha o nei kauwā; aia i Paukū-nui ka waha o nei kauā.
english_phrase: The mouth of this slave is at Pāʻula; the mouth of this slave is at Alanaio; the mouth of this slave is at Paukū-nui.
meaning_phrase: An insulting saying. It began when Keawe, ruler of Hawaiʻi, went on a visit to Kauaʻi and while in a crowd of chiefs silently broke wind. None knew the source, but it was Keawe’s servant who made this insulting remark. Pāʻula (Red Dish) signifies that the rectal opening shows red; Alanaio (Way-of-the-pinworm) also refers to the anus; and Paukū-nui (Large Segments) refers to large stools. Hence, a red, worm-infested anus that produces large stools. It was not until Keawe returned to Hawaiʻi that his servant learned that his own chief had been the culprit. Pāʻula, Paukū-nui, and Alanaio are place names in Hilo.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia ka ʻike iā Polihua a lei i ka mānewanewa.
english_phrase: One proves a visit to Polihua by wearing a lei of mānewanewa.
meaning_phrase: A person proves his visit to a place by bringing back something native to the area. Refers to Polihua, Lānaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia ka ʻoʻoleʻa o ka pāpaʻi i ka niho.
english_phrase: The strength of the crab is in the claw.
meaning_phrase: All noise but no action. Said of one who makes threats but doesn’t carry them out.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia ka puʻu nui i ke alo.
english_phrase: A big hill stands right before him.
meaning_phrase: He has a problem.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia ka wai i ka maka o ka ʻōpua.
english_phrase: Water is in the face of the ʻōpua clouds.
meaning_phrase: In Kona, when the ʻōpua clouds appear in the morning, it’s a sign that rain is to be expected.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia kēkē nā hulu o ka umauma hoʻi ke kōlea i Kahiki e hānau ai.
english_phrase: When the feathers on the breast darken [because of fatness] the plover goes back to Kahiki to breed.
meaning_phrase: A person comes here, grows prosperous, and goes away without a thought to the source of his prosperity.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia ke ola i ka hana.
english_phrase: Life is in labor.
meaning_phrase: Labor produces what is needed.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia ke ola i Kahiki.
english_phrase: Life is in Kahiki.
meaning_phrase: Life and prosperity are in the care of the gods, and the gods are said to reside in Kahiki.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia ke ola i ka ihu o ka lio.
english_phrase: Life is where the horse’s nose points.
meaning_phrase: The scent of food leads one toward sustenance.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia ke ola i ka waha; aia ka make i ka waha.
english_phrase: Life is in the mouth; death is in ihe mouth.
meaning_phrase: Spoken words can enliven; spoken words can destroy.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia kinaina i Kahiki.
english_phrase: The snuffing out of the light is up to Kahiki.
meaning_phrase: The ending of a human life is decided by the gods, whose dwelling is in realms far away.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia ko kāne i ka lawaiʻa, hoʻi mai he ʻōpeʻa ka iʻa.
english_phrase: Your husband has gone fishing and returns with bats for meat.
meaning_phrase: This saying comes from a children’s chant of amusement for coaxing a sea animal to crawl from its shell.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia ma kahi hāiki.
english_phrase: Is in a nanow place.
meaning_phrase: Said of an unborn infant. No plans are made for it until puka na maka i ke ao (the eyes are seen in the daylight).

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAi a manō, ʻaʻohe nānā i kumu pali.
english_phrase: When the shark eats, he never troubles to look toward the foot of the cliff.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who eats voraciously with no thought of those who provided the food, shows no appreciation for what has been done for him, nor has a care for the morrow.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia me Milu, kēlā mea i lalo lilo loa.
english_phrase: Is with Milu, that person away down helow.
meaning_phrase: Dead. Milu is the god of the underworld.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia me Niolopua.
english_phrase: Is with Niolopua.
meaning_phrase: Is fast asleep. Niolopua is the god of sleep.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia nō i ka mea e mele ana.
english_phrase: Let the singer select the song.
meaning_phrase: Let him think for himself.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia nō i ke au a ka wāwae.
english_phrase: Whichever current the feet go in.
meaning_phrase: It was felt that discussing any business such as fishing or birdcatching before-hand results in failure.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia nō i ke kō a ke au.
english_phrase: Whichever way the current goes.
meaning_phrase: Time will tell.

hawaiian_phrase: "Aia nō i ʻō," wahi ʻo Pahia.
english_phrase: “Yet to come,” says Pahia.
meaning_phrase: To be returned in kind later. Pahia, an honest, kindly native of Hilo, always noticed what was given him and always said in gratitude, “Yet to come, says Pahia,” meaning that he would respond in kind. People noticed that when he was given pork, he gave pork in return, and he served fish to those from whom he received fish. His friends and their friends learned to say, “ʻYet to come,’ says Pahia,” when they intended to return a kind favor.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia nō ka pono — o ka hoʻohuli i ka lima i lalo, ʻaʻole o ka hoʻohuli i luna.
english_phrase: That is what it should be — to turn the hands palms down, not palms up.
meaning_phrase: No one can work with the palms of his hands turned up. When a person is always busy, he is said to keep his palms down.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia nō ka pua i luna.
english_phrase: The flower is still on the tree.
meaning_phrase: A compliment to an elderly woman. Her beauty still remains.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia nō ke ea i ka puka ihu.
english_phrase: The breath is still in the nostrils.
meaning_phrase: A facetious reply when someone asks how a friend or relative is.

hawaiian_phrase: Aia paha iā Lima-ʻāpā.
english_phrase: Perhaps Touch-hand has taken it.
meaning_phrase: Somebody with very quick hands must have taken it.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAi a puʻu ka nuku.
english_phrase: Eat till the lips protrude.
meaning_phrase: Eat until one can take no more.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAi kū, ʻai hele.
english_phrase: Eat standing, eat walking.
meaning_phrase: Said of anything done without ceremony, or of anything unrestrained by kapu.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAi kū, ʻai noa.
english_phrase: Eat standing, eat freely.
meaning_phrase: Said by one about to leave a religious feast, when he must depart before it is over.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAi manu Koʻolau.
english_phrase: Eat of the birds of Koʻolau.
meaning_phrase: Said of a feast where delicious foods are eaten.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻĀina i ka houpo o Kāne.
english_phrase: Land on the bosom of Kāne.
meaning_phrase: Puna, Hawaiʻi. It is said that before Pele migrated there from Kahiki, no place in the islands was more beautiful than Puna.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻĀina koi ʻula i ka lepo.
english_phrase: Land reddened by the rising dust.
meaning_phrase: Said of ʻEwa, Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAina kō kiola wale ʻia i ka nahele.
english_phrase: Sugar-cane trash thrown in the wilderness.
meaning_phrase: A derogatory expression applied to a person of no consequence.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAi nō i ka ʻape he maneʻo no ko ka nuku.
english_phrase: He who eats ʻape is bound to have his mouth itch.
meaning_phrase: He who indulges in something harmful will surely reap the result.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAi nō i kalo moʻa.
english_phrase: One can eat cooked taro.
meaning_phrase: The work is done; one can sit at ease and enjoy himself.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAi nō ka ʻīlio i kona luaʻi.
english_phrase: A dog eats his own vomit.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who says nasty things of others and then has those very things happen to himself.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAi nō ka ʻiole a haʻalele i kona kūkae.
english_phrase: A rat eats, then leaves its droppings.
meaning_phrase: Said of an ungrateful person.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAi nō ke kōlea a momona hoʻi i Kahiki.
english_phrase: The plover eats until fat, then returns to the land from which it came.
meaning_phrase: Said of a foreigner who comes to Hawaiʻi, makes money, and departs to his homeland to enjoy his wealth.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAi pilau.
english_phrase: Eater of filth.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who practiced the sorcery that destroyed others. His god was referred to as akua ʻai pilau (filth-eating god).

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAi puaʻa a Kukeawe.
english_phrase: The pork-eating of Kukeawe.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who is not satisfied with the number of his own pigs and so robs his neighbors of theirs. Kukeawe was a friend of Kahekili who was allowed to help himself to any of Kahekili’s pigs in Kula, Maui. But Kukeawe also took the pigs belonging to the people of Kula, Honuaʻula, and Kahikinui and plundered their possessions. These people rose in rebellion, led by ʻOpū, and surprised the followers of Kukeawe while they were ascending Haleakalā on the way to Kula. Kukeawe’s party retreated but found their way blocked by other parties led by Kawehena, Kahoʻoluhina, and Kuheana. Kukeawe was killed and his body set up at Palauea for all to see.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAi pūhiʻu.
english_phrase: Eats while breaking wind.
meaning_phrase: Said of a bad-mannered person with no regard for ceremony.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAkahi a komo ke anu iaʻu, ua nahā ka hale e malu ai.
english_phrase: Cold now penetrates me, for the house that shelters is broken.
meaning_phrase: Fear enters when protection is gone. Said by ʻAikanaka of Kauaʻi when two of his war leaders were destroyed by Kawelo.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAkahi au a ʻike i ka ʻino o Hilo.
english_phrase: It is the first time I have seen a Hilo storm.
meaning_phrase: For the first time I have met with evil people who wish to harm me.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAkahi hoʻi kuʻu ʻono i ka uhu kāʻalo i kuʻu maka.
english_phrase: Now I long for the uhu fish that passes before my eyes.
meaning_phrase: How I would like that handsome fellow for a sweetheart. The uhu is a bright-colored fish, beautiful to look at, and tasty.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAkahi ka hoʻi ka paoa, ke kau nei ka mākole pua heʻo.
english_phrase: Here is a sign of ill luck, for the red-eyed bright-hued one rests above.
meaning_phrase: Said when a rainbow appears before the path of one who was on a business journey. Such a rainbow is regarded the same as meeting a red-eyed person — a sign of bad luck. Better to turn about and go home.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAkahi ka neo.
english_phrase: Now a barrenness.
meaning_phrase: Said by one who encounters bad luck. He makes no gain, or he loses all.

hawaiian_phrase: Akāka wale nō ʻo Kaumaikaʻohu.
english_phrase: Very clearly appears Kaumaikaʻohu.
meaning_phrase: One can very well see what the whole matter is about. Kaumaikaʻohu is a hill in Punaluʻu, Kaʻū.

hawaiian_phrase: Akāka wale ʻo Haleakalā.
english_phrase: Haleakalā stands in full view.
meaning_phrase: Said of anything that is very obvious or clearly understood.

hawaiian_phrase: A ka lae o Kalaʻau, pau ka pono o Kakina.
english_phrase: After Kalaʻau Point is passed, the virtues taught by Thurston end.
meaning_phrase: So sang a girl after leaving Thurston’s missionary school. After sailing past Molokaʻi on her way home to Honolulu, she resolved to forget his teachings and have her fling. Used today to refer to anything that will not work or cannot be used.

hawaiian_phrase: A Keaʻau holo ka ʻōlohelohe.
english_phrase: At Keaʻau ran the naked one.
meaning_phrase: Said of a state of destitution; to have nothing. A play on ʻau (swim) and ʻōlohelohe (naked).

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAkekeke kiʻo pahulu.
english_phrase: ʻAkekeke that excretes in worn-out food patches.
meaning_phrase: An expression of contempt referring to an idle vagabond who eats and departs, thinking nothing of those who have helped him. The ʻakekeke, or ruddy turnstone, is a winter visitor to Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ako ʻē ka hale a paʻa, a i ke komo ʻana mai o ka hoʻoilo, ʻaʻole e kulu i ka ua o Hilinehu.
english_phrase: Thatch the house beforehand so when winter comes it will not leak in the shower of Hilinehu.
meaning_phrase: Do not procrastinate; make preparations for the future now.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻĀko Nuʻuanu i ka hālau loa a ka makani; ʻāko Mānoa i ka hale a ke ʻehu.
english_phrase: Gathered in Nuuanu is the longhouse of the wind; gathered in Mānoa is the house of rainy sprays.
meaning_phrase: Perhaps gone to loaf somewhere. A play on lena (lazy).

hawaiian_phrase: Akua lehe ʻoi.
english_phrase: Sharp-lipped goddess.
meaning_phrase: An epithet for Pele, who devoured even the rocks and trees.

hawaiian_phrase: Akua nō hoʻi nā hana!
english_phrase: Such extraordinary behavior!
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who is mean and willful, with no thought for anyone but himself. He is compared to the heroic figures of old (akua) who were born deformed and abandoned as infants, then rescued and raised to adulthood. Such persons were often belligerent by nature.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAlaʻalawa ka maka o ka ʻaihue.
english_phrase: The eyes of a thief glance about.
meaning_phrase: An expression of suspicion toward a shifty-eyed person.

hawaiian_phrase: Alahula Puʻuloa, he alahele na Kaʻahupāhau.
english_phrase: Everywhere in Puʻuloa is the trail of Kaʻahupāhau.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who goes everywhere, looking, peering, seeing all, or of a person familiar with every nook and corner of a place. Kaʻahupāhau is the shark goddess of Puʻuloa (Pearl Harbor) who guarded the people from being molested by sharks. She moved about, constantly watching.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAla ke kai o kaʻanae.
english_phrase: Fragrant is the soup of a big mullet.
meaning_phrase: A well-to-do person is attractive because of his prosperity. A fat mullet was well liked for broth.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAlamihi ʻai kupapaʻu.
english_phrase: Corpse-eating ʻalamihi.
meaning_phrase: The ʻalamihi (mud crab) is a scavenger. In localities where they are not eaten, they are referred to contemptuously as corpse eaters.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAlamihi kakani pōʻeleʻele.
english_phrase: Black crab that makes a noise in the dark.
meaning_phrase: An expression of annoyance toward one who disturbs the night with noise.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAle mai ke aloha kau i ka maka.
english_phrase: Love comes like a billow and rests before the eyes.
meaning_phrase: Said of an overwhelming love that leaves a constant yearning, with the image of one’s affections ever before one.

hawaiian_phrase: Alia e ʻoki ka ʻāina o Kahewahewa, he ua.
english_phrase: Wait to cut the land of Kahewahewa, for it is raining.
meaning_phrase: Let us not rush. Said by Kaweloleimakua as he wrestled with an opponent at Waikīkī.

hawaiian_phrase: A! Like akula me ke kāmaʻa o Keawe.
english_phrase: Ah! Like Keawe’s sandals.
meaning_phrase: Said of a forgetful person who looks everywhere and then finds the article at hand. Keawe and his servant once went to Kaʻū by canoe and then traveled upland from Kalae. When they came to a small stretch of lava rocks, Keawe wanted his sandals. The servant looked at his empty hands and asked the chief to wait while he ran back to see if he had dropped them along the way. The servant met some travelers and asked if they had by any chance seen the chief’s sandals. They pointed to his chest. He had tied them together with a string and was wearing them around his neck.

hawaiian_phrase: A! Loaʻa akula iā ʻoe nā niu o Kaunalewa.
english_phrase: Ah! Now you have the coconuts of Kaunalewa.
meaning_phrase: Your worldly possessions are gone. An impolite saying with a play on Kau-nā-lewa (Hang-suspended), as if to say, “Now all you have is a hanging scrotum.” Kaunalewa was a famous coconut grove on Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Aloha mai nō, aloha aku; ʻo ka huhiā ka mea e ola ʻole ai.
english_phrase: When love is given, love should he returned; anger is the thing that gives no life.
meaning_phrase: Nothing can change a bad situation into a good one.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻĀluka ka ʻina i kai o Kamaʻole.
english_phrase: Thick with sea urchins in the sea of Kamaʻole.
meaning_phrase: Applied to a person laden with somebody else’s work. A chief was once traveling along the beach at Kamaʻole, Kula, Maui. A woman, not recognizing him as a chief, asked him to carry her bundle of sea urchins, which he did. Other women came along and did likewise until the chief was loaded with them.

hawaiian_phrase: Alu ka pule i Hakalau.
english_phrase: Concentrate your prayers on Hakalau.
meaning_phrase: Whenever concentration and united effort are required, this saying is used. A sorcerer at Hakalau once created havoc in his own and other neighborhoods. Many attempts to counter-pray him failed until a visiting kahuna suggested that all of the others band together to concentrate on the common enemy. This time they succeeded.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAmakihi ʻawaʻawa.
english_phrase: A sour ʻamakihi.
meaning_phrase: Applied to a person with a sour disposition. The ʻamakihi is a Hawaiian honeycreeper.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAnihinihi ke ola.
english_phrase: Life is in a precarious position.
meaning_phrase: Life hangs by a thread.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAno kaikoʻo lalo o Kealahula, ua puhia ke ʻala ma Puahinahina.
english_phrase: It is somewhat rough down at Kealahula, for the fragrance [of seaweed] is being wafted hither from the direction of Puahinahina.
meaning_phrase: There is a disturbance over there, and we are noticing signs of it here. The breeze carries the smell of seaweed when the water is rough.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAno lani; ʻano honua.
english_phrase: A heavenly nature; an earthly nature.
meaning_phrase: Said of some ʻaumākua who make themselves visible to loved ones by assuming an earthly form, such as fish, fowl, or animal, yet retain the nature of a god.

hawaiian_phrase: Anu hewa i ka pō, he kuʻuna iʻa ʻole.
english_phrase: Feeling the cold air of the night was all in vain; no fish was caught in the net.
meaning_phrase: A wasted effort.

hawaiian_phrase: A nui mai ke kai o Waialua, moe pupuʻu o Kalena i Haleʻauʻau.
english_phrase: When the sea is rough at Waialua, Kalena curls up to sleep in Haleʻauʻau.
meaning_phrase: Applied to a person who prefers to sleep instead of doing chores. A play on lena (lazy), in Kalena, who was a fisherman, and hale (house) in Haleʻauʻau.

hawaiian_phrase: Anu koʻū ka hale, ua hala ka makamaka.
english_phrase: Cold and damp is the house, for the host is gone.
meaning_phrase: A house becomes sad and forlorn when it is no longer occupied by the host whose welcome was always warm.

hawaiian_phrase: Anu ʻo ʻEwa i ka iʻa hāmau leo e. E hāmau!
english_phrase: ʻEwa is made cold by the fish that silences the voice. Hush!
meaning_phrase: A warning to keep still. First uttered by Hiʻiaka to her friend Wahineʻomaʻo to warn her not to speak to Lohiʻau while they were in a canoe near ʻEwa.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe ʻai pani ʻia o ka ʻamo.
english_phrase: No particular food blocks the anus.
meaning_phrase: All food is good; there is none that hinders evacuation. A rude remark to a very finicky person.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe ʻai waiwai ke hiki mai ka makahiki.
english_phrase: No food is of any value when the Makahiki festival comes.
meaning_phrase: Enjoy what you have now lest it not be of much use later. Gifts were given to the priests who came in the Makahiki procession of the god Lono. Then all trading and giving ceased. The farmers and fishermen received no personal gain until it was over.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe ʻalae nāna e keʻu ka ʻaha.
english_phrase: No mudhens cry to disturb the council meeting.
meaning_phrase: There is no one to create a disturbance. The cry of a mudhen at night is an omen of death in the neighborhood.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe ʻalawa wale iho iā Maliʻo.
english_phrase: Not even a glance at Maliʻo.
meaning_phrase: Said of a haughty person. Pele was once so annoyed with Maliʻo and her brother Halaaniani that she turned them both into stone and let them lie in the sea in Puna, Hawaiʻi. It was at the bay named after Halaaniani that clusters of pandanus were tossed into the sea with tokens to loved ones. These were borne by the current to Kamilo in Kaʻū.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe aʻu ʻala ʻinamona iā ʻoukou.
english_phrase: I do not find even the fragrance of roasted kukui nuts in you.
meaning_phrase: I don’t find the least bit of good in you. First uttered by Pele to her sisters, who refused to go to Kauaʻi for her lover, Lohi’au.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe ʻauwaʻa paʻa i ka hālau i ka mālie.
english_phrase: No canoes remain in the sheds in calm weather.
meaning_phrase: Everybody goes fishing in good weather. Also used when people turn out in great numbers to share in work or play.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe e hōʻike ana ka mea hewa ua hewa ia.
english_phrase: The wrongdoer does not tell on himself.
meaning_phrase: The fire of anger or of love will burn as long as it has something to feed upon.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe e loaʻa, he uhu pakelo.
english_phrase: He will not be caught, for he is a parrotfish, slippery with slime.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person too wily and wise to be caught.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe e loaʻa Niu-a-Kāne iā ʻoe.
english_phrase: Youll never be able to reach Kāne’s coconuts.
meaning_phrase: Said of something unattainable. Niu-a-Kāne is a rock islet in the sea at Hāna, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe e nalo, he haupeʻepeʻe na kamaliʻi.
english_phrase: Not well hidden, for it is the hiding of little children.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person of outstanding achievement. Also used in praise of Hāʻupu, Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe e nalo, he noʻa na kamaliʻi.
english_phrase: It will not be hidden, for it is a noʻa hidden by children.
meaning_phrase: Said of a secret that cannot remain hidden. Noʻa is the hidden object in the game of pūhenehene.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe e nalo ka iwi o ke aliʻi ʻino, o ko ke aliʻi maikaʻi ke nalo.
english_phrase: The bones of an evil chief will not be concealed, but the bones of a good chief will.
meaning_phrase: When an evil chief died, the people did not take the trouble to conceal his bones.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe e pulu, he waʻa nui.
english_phrase: One will not be wet on a large canoe.
meaning_phrase: One is safe in the protection of an important person.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe hala ʻula i ka pō.
english_phrase: No hala fruit shows its color in the darkness of night.
meaning_phrase: Beauty must be seen to be enjoyed.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe hale i piha i ka hoihoi; hāʻawi mai a lawe aku nō.
english_phrase: No house has a perpetual welcome; it is given and it is taken away.
meaning_phrase: A warning not to wear out one’s welcome.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe hana a Kauhikoa; ua kau ka waʻa i ke ʻaki.
english_phrase: Kauhikoa has nothing more to do; his canoe is resting on the block.
meaning_phrase: His work is all done.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe hana a Kauhikoa, ua kau ke poʻo i ka uluna.
english_phrase: Kauhikoa has nothing more to do but rest his head on the pillow.
meaning_phrase: Everything is done and one can take his ease. Kauhikoa, a native of Kohala, was a clever person who could quickly accomplish what others would take months to do.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe hana i nele i ka uku.
english_phrase: No deed lacks a reward.
meaning_phrase: Every deed, good or bad, receives its just reward.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe hana nui ke alu ʻia.
english_phrase: No task is too big when done together by all.
meaning_phrase: A call to come together to tackle a given task.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe hua o ka maiʻa i ka lā hoʻokahi.
english_phrase: Bananas do not fruit in a single day.
meaning_phrase: A retort to an impatient person.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe hua waiho i Kahiki.
english_phrase: Not even the eggs should be left in Kahiki.
meaning_phrase: Used when inviting all to come — even the little children are welcome. Also, bring everything and leave nothing.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe ia e loaʻa aku, he ulua kāpapa no ka moana.
english_phrase: He cannot be caught for he is an ulua fish of the deep ocean.
meaning_phrase: Said in admiration of a hero or warrior who will not give up without a struggle.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe i hiki i Hakalauʻai, pae ʻē i Keolewa.
english_phrase: Hakalauʻai was never reached, for he landed at Keolewa instead.
meaning_phrase: Before one could receive sufficient food for all his requirements, he found his efforts suspended. A play on Haka-lau-ʻai (Rack-for-much-food) and Ke-olewa (Suspend-in-space).

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe ʻike o ka puaʻa nona ka imu e hōʻā ʻia nei.
english_phrase: The pig does not know that the imu is being lighted for it.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who is unaware that he is being victimized.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe ʻike wale iho iā Maliʻo, i ka huhuki laweau a Uwēkahuna.
english_phrase: Malio is not recognized because Uwēkahuna is drawing her away.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who refuses to recognize old friends and associates or is snubbed by friends because they have interests elsewhere. Maliʻo was a mythical woman of Puna whom Pele once snubbed. Uwēkahuna is the bluff overlooking the crater of Kīlauea.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe ʻike wale iho i ke kinikini o Kolokini, i ka wawalo o ke kai o Kahalahala.
english_phrase: [He] does not deign to recognize the multitude of Kolokini, nor the roaring of the sea of Kahalahala.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who deliberately refuses to recognize kith or kin and goes about with a haughty air.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe i maneʻo iho ke kumu pepeiao i kau hīmeni.
english_phrase: Even the base of the ear isn’t tickled by your song.
meaning_phrase: A rude remark to one whose song or story is not appealing.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe ʻīnaʻi komo ʻole o ka ʻai.
english_phrase: There is no meat that doesnt taste good with poi.
meaning_phrase: Let it go at that. Used especially with regard to genealogy to mean: Even if one claims kinship with me, it doesn’t matter whether the connection is genuine. My life will continue; I can still eat poi.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe i nalo ka ʻulaʻula o ka lepo, loaʻa hou nō ka wahine.
english_phrase: The redness of the earth hasnt even vanished when a new wife is obtained.
meaning_phrase: Said in scorn of a person who takes a new mate shortly after the death of the old one.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe inoa komo ʻole o ka ʻai.
english_phrase: No name prevents food from entering the mouth.
meaning_phrase: Similar to the saying, “Sticks and stones may break my bones but names will never hurt me.”

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe i pala ke kope.
english_phrase: The coffee berries arent ripe yet.
meaning_phrase: Said to or about a child who is not old enough to attract the opposite sex.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe ipu ʻōpio e ʻole ka mimino i ka lā.
english_phrase: No immature gourd can withstand withering in the sun [without care].
meaning_phrase: No child can get along without adult supervision.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe kā he lohe o ko pepeiao huluhulu?
english_phrase: Don’t your hairy ears hear?
meaning_phrase: Said in annoyance or disgust for disobedience or heedlessness. The ears are too full of fuzz to let sounds enter.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe kahe o ka hou i ka ʻōʻō kōhi paʻōʻō a kamaliʻi.
english_phrase: With the digging implement used by children to dig up leftover potatoes, no perspiration is shed.
meaning_phrase: Said of a task requiring little effort.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe kahua o nā manu.
english_phrase: There is no place for the birds to light.
meaning_phrase: It is very crowded.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe kanaka i ʻeha ʻole i ke aloha.
english_phrase: Nobody has ever missed feeling the pang of love.
meaning_phrase: Marriage.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe kanaka kū ākiʻi i ke alo o nā aliʻi.
english_phrase: No idleness or standing about with hands on hips in the presence of chiefs.
meaning_phrase: Do not procrastinate; make preparations for the future now.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe kanaka o kauhale, aia i Mānā, ua haohia i ka iʻa iki.
english_phrase: No one is at home, for all have gone to Mānā, attracted there by small fishes.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is distracted by an insignificant matter or goes away on any excuse.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe kana mai o ka holo o ka lio ia Hanalē; pākahi a ka lio, pālua a ka lio.
english_phrase: How Henry made the horses run; one on a horse or two on a horse.
meaning_phrase: How hunger (Henry) made the fingers work in conveying poi to the mouth — with one fmger and with two.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe kāne hānai nalo.
english_phrase: No husband feeds his wife flies.
meaning_phrase: All husbands have some good qualities.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe kio pōhaku nalo i ke alo pali.
english_phrase: On the slope of a cliff, not one jutting rock is hidden from sight.
meaning_phrase: All is distinctly seen or known; there isn’t any use in being secretive or finding a place to hide.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe kolopā nānā e une.
english_phrase: No crowbar can pry him loose.
meaning_phrase: Said of a very obstinate person.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe komo o kā haʻi puaʻa ke paʻa i ka pā.
english_phrase: Other people’s pigs would not come in if the fence were kept in good repair.
meaning_phrase: Be prepared always, and you’ll find yourself free of trouble. Also, evil influence cannot enter when one keeps his own mental realm fortified from within.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe laka o kā haʻi ʻīlio.
english_phrase: Other people’s dogs do not mind you.
meaning_phrase: Said as a warning to beware of the gods of others.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe lau komo ʻole.
english_phrase: Any leaf goes in.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who does not care whether food is clean or unclean, as long as it suppresses hunger.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe lele ka nalo i kamaliʻi.
english_phrase: A fly isn’t made to depart by children.
meaning_phrase: Said in derision of a person who has no more sense than a child.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe lihi i ka pāpaʻa.
english_phrase: Absolutely burned to a crust.
meaning_phrase: Completely destroyed.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe lihi ʻike aku i ka nani o Punahoa.
english_phrase: Hasn’t known the beauty of Punahoa.
meaning_phrase: Used when the charms of a person or place are unknown. Punahoa is an unusually attractive place.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe like o ka ʻili.
english_phrase: The skin is not alike.
meaning_phrase: Some Hawaiians have an aversion to wearing someone else’s clothing, not knowing whether they are equals in bloodline, rank, or background. This saying does not express that they are of a different race, only of different family backgrounds.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe loaʻa i ka noho wale.
english_phrase: Nothing is gained by idleness.
meaning_phrase: Consider the living, who may be kindly host or friend.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe loa i ka hana a ke aloha.
english_phrase: Distance is ignored by love.
meaning_phrase: Marriage.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe loa i ka leo.
english_phrase: A command [of a chief] disregards distance.
meaning_phrase: Distance means nothing when the chief gives his command. First said by Hiʻiaka to her sister Kapo in a chant.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe loea i ka wai ʻōpae.
english_phrase: It is no feat to catch shrimps in a freshet.
meaning_phrase: You don’t need experience to do that job. Shrimps were often taken in great numbers by means of wicker platforms placed across mountain streams. In time of freshets they would be swept onto these platforms and gathered.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe lokomaikaʻi i nele i ka pānaʻi.
english_phrase: No kind deed has ever lacked its reward.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who helps a lost person find his way home. The goddess Kaiona, who lived in the Waiʻanae Mountains of Oʻahu, was said to have pet birds who could guide anyone lost in the forest back to his companions.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe lolena i ka wai ʻōpae.
english_phrase: There must he no slackness when one gathers shrimp in time of a freshet.
meaning_phrase: Let there be no slackers when there is work to be done. Lazy people don’t get anywhere.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe māʻalo kanaka o Hoʻokū.
english_phrase: No one passes at Hoʻokū.
meaning_phrase: Said of a place that is avoided by people fearing trouble. At Hoʻokū, the smoke and heat of Pele were feared.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe mālama pau i ka ʻiole.
english_phrase: No one who takes care of his possessions has ever found them eaten by rats.
meaning_phrase: When one takes care of his goods he will not suffer losses.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe ma mua, ʻaʻohe ma hope, ʻaʻohe i ka ʻākau, ʻaʻohe i ka hema.
english_phrase: Nothing before, nothing behind, nothing at the right, nothing at the left.
meaning_phrase: Utter, absolute poverty.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe māna ʻai loaʻa i ka mea make.
english_phrase: Not even a mouthful of food can be obtained from the dead.
meaning_phrase: Consider the living, who may be kindly host or friend.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe manu noho i ka lipo e pakele i ke kāpiʻo.
english_phrase: No bird of the deep forest can escape his snare.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who can win the love of anyone he chooses.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe mea e mānalo ai.
english_phrase: Nothing can sweeten it.
meaning_phrase: Nothing can change a bad situation into a good one.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe mea ʻimi a ka maka.
english_phrase: Nothing more for the eyes to search for.
meaning_phrase: Everything one desires is in his presence.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe mea koe aku iā Makaliʻi; pau nō ka liko me ka lāʻele.
english_phrase: Makaliʻi left nothing, taking [everything] from buds to old leaves.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who selfishly takes all, or of a lecherous person who takes those of the opposite sex of all ages. From a legend surrounding a chief, Makaliʻi, who took from his people until they faced starvation.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe mea koe ma kūʻono.
english_phrase: Nothing remains in the corners.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is extremely generous, giving freely without reservation.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe mea make i ka hewa; make nō i ka mihi ʻole.
english_phrase: No one has ever died for the mistakes he has made; only because he didn’t repent.
meaning_phrase: Urges repentance to one’s aumākua. Later came to include the idea of repentance before the Christian God.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe mea nāna e hoʻopuhili, he moho no ka lā makani.
english_phrase: There is no one to interfere, for he is a messenger of a windy day.
meaning_phrase: Said in admiration of a person who lets nothing stop him from carrying out the task entrusted to him.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe mea nāna e paʻi i ke poʻo.
english_phrase: No one to slap his head.
meaning_phrase: He has no equal in his accomplishments.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe na ia mau mea e uē iā ʻoe, na ke kanaka ʻoe e uē.
english_phrase: Things will not mourn you, but people will.
meaning_phrase: Said to one who thinks more of his possessions than of his kinfolk or friends.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe nānā; he holoholona ia he mea ʻuhane ʻole; o ke kanaka nō ka nānā, he mea ʻuhane.
english_phrase: Never mind; it is an animal, a soulless creature; take heed of man, for he is a creature with a soul.
meaning_phrase: A retort by one who is criticized for raising animals instead of children.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe nānā i ko lalo ʻai i ke pāpaʻa; e nānā i ko luna o ahulu.
english_phrase: Never mind if the food underneath burns; see that the food at the top is not half-cooked.
meaning_phrase: Never mind the commoners; pay attention to the chiefs.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe nao ʻai i ka pāpaʻa.
english_phrase: Nothing at all but burnt food to eat.
meaning_phrase: A terrible situation.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe nō hoʻi ou ʻī mai ʻaʻohe wai o lalo.
english_phrase: You didn’t tell me that there wasn’t any water below.
meaning_phrase: Why didn’t you warn me? Two men, one totally and one partially blind, wanted to cross Punaluʻu Stream in Kaʻū. The blind one didn’t know his companion was unable to see well. When they reached the bank he asked his companion, “Is there water down there?” The partly blind one replied, “Yes, there is.” So they jumped in with the intention of swimming across. But the stream was dry, and both men suffered broken bones and bruises.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe ʻoe no koʻu hālau.
english_phrase: You are not of my shed.
meaning_phrase: Why do you presume to know who my ancestors are?

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe o kahi nānā o luna o ka pali; iho mai a lalo nei; ʻike i ke au nui ke au iki, he alo a he alo.
english_phrase: The top of the cliff isnt the place to look at us; come down here and learn of the big and little current, face to face.
meaning_phrase: Learn the details. Also, an invitation to discuss something. Said by Pele to Pāʻoa when he came to seek the lava-encased remains of his friend Lohiʻau.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe ola o ka ʻāina i ke aliʻi haipule ʻole.
english_phrase: The land cannot live under an irreligious chief.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who avoids his friends or relatives.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe ōpū malumalu e kanaho ai.
english_phrase: Not even a clump of weeds in which to be sheltered.
meaning_phrase: There is nothing to relieve this unpleasant situation.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe paha he ʻuhane.
english_phrase: Perhaps [he has] no soul.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who behaves in a shameful manner.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe pahuna ihe hala a ka Maluakele.
english_phrase: The Maluakele wind never misses with its spear-like thrusts.
meaning_phrase: Said in praise of one who always gets what he is after.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe pala naio.
english_phrase: There isn’t even any excretal residue to feed a pinworm with.
meaning_phrase: It is not worth anything.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe pau ka ʻike i ka hālau hoʻokahi.
english_phrase: All knowledge is not taught in the same school.
meaning_phrase: One can learn from many sources.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe pilipili ʻāina wale mai, aia ka iʻa i ke kai.
english_phrase: The fish remain at sea and come nowhere near the shore.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who avoids his friends or relatives.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe pilo uku.
english_phrase: No reward is a trife.
meaning_phrase: Even a small gift is appreciated.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe puaʻi leo.
english_phrase: Not a sound gushed forth.
meaning_phrase: Not a single word was spoken.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe pueo keʻu, ʻaʻohe ʻalae kani, ʻaʻohe ʻūlili holoholo kahakai.
english_phrase: No owl hoots, no mudhen cries, no ʻūlili runs on the beach.
meaning_phrase: There is perfect peace.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe puʻu, ʻaʻohe keʻe.
english_phrase: No humps, no bends.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who is physically perfect.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe puʻu kiʻekiʻe ke hoʻāʻo ʻia e piʻi.
english_phrase: No cliff is so tall that it cannot be scaled.
meaning_phrase: No problem is too great when one tries hard to solve it.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe sananā, he mauʻu Hilo.
english_phrase: Nothing to shout about, it is only Hilo grass.
meaning_phrase: Said of a trifling matter that is not worth fussing over.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe uʻi hele wale o Kohala.
english_phrase: No youth of Kohala goes empty-handed.
meaning_phrase: Said in praise of people who do not go anywhere without a gift or a helping hand. The saying originated at Honomakaʻu in Kohala. The young people of that locality, when on a journey, often went as far as Kapua before resting. Here, they made lei to adorn themselves and carry along with them. Another version is that no Kohala person goes unprepared for any emergency.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe ʻuku lele nāna e ʻaki.
english_phrase: Not even flea to bite one.
meaning_phrase: Perfect comfort.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe ʻulu e loaʻa i ka pōkole o ka lou.
english_phrase: No breadfruit can be reached when the picking stick is too short.
meaning_phrase: There is no success without preparation.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe ulu ka hoi.
english_phrase: The hoi vine does not grow.
meaning_phrase: There is no interest in that. Said by one who lacks interest, or is bored with what is being said or done. A play on hoi (bitter yam) and hoihoi (interest).

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe umu moʻa i ka makani.
english_phrase: No umu can be made to cook anything by the wind.
meaning_phrase: Talk will not get the umu lighted and the food cooked. This saying originated in Olowalu, Maui, where it was very windy and hard to light an umu.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe waʻa hoʻohoa o ka lā ʻino.
english_phrase: No canoe is defiant on a stormy day.
meaning_phrase: It doesn’t pay to venture into the face of danger.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻohe wāwae o ka iʻa; ʻo ʻoe ka mea wāwae, kiʻi mai.
english_phrase: Fish have no feet; you who have feet must come and get it.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who asks for, but doesn’t come to get, what he wants. Any footless creature might be used as an example.

hawaiian_phrase: Aʻo i ka hoʻopunipuni, aʻo aku nō i ka ʻaihue.
english_phrase: Learn to lie and the next thing will be to steal.
meaning_phrase: Theft is accompanied by fear.

hawaiian_phrase: Aʻo i ke koa, e aʻo nō i ka holo.
english_phrase: When one learns to be a warrior, one must also learn to run.
meaning_phrase: It is no disgrace to run when there is danger of being destroyed; perhaps there may be another day when one can fight and win.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻole, ʻaʻole i pau koʻu loa.
english_phrase: No, my height is not reached.
meaning_phrase: A remark made when there is a reference to killing by sorcery. While drowning a victim to be offered as a sacrifice, the kahuna who did the drowning held his victim down as he repeated, “No, my height is not reached,” meaning that the water covers only the victim, who was advised to “Moe mālie i ke kai o ko haku’ (“Lie still in the sea of your lord”), meaning “Don’t struggle because you are bound to die.”

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻole e ʻai ʻia he maunu ʻino.
english_phrase: It will not be taken by the fish; it is poor bait.
meaning_phrase: People will pay no attention to poor production. When it is good, it will attract attention.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻole e ʻike ʻia ke kākala o ka moa ma kāna ʻoʻō ʻana.
english_phrase: One cannot tell by his crowing what the cock’s spur can do.
meaning_phrase: One cannot judge by his bragging what a person can really do.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻole e kū ka ikaika i kēia pākela nui; ke pōʻai mai nei ka ʻohu ma uka, ma kai, ma ʻō a ma ʻaneʻi.
english_phrase: One cannot show his strength against such odds; the rain clouds are circling from the upland, the lowland, and from all sides.
meaning_phrase: Said by Maheleana, a warrior of Kualiʻi, when he saw his small company surrounded by the enemy.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻole e make ko ke kahuna kanaka, ʻo ko ke aliʻi kanaka ke make.
english_phrase: The servant of the kahuna will not be put to death, but the chief’s servant will.
meaning_phrase: A warning not to antagonize the friend of an influential man. A kahuna will do his best to protect his own servant.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻole e ʻōlelo mai ana ke ahi ua ana ia.
english_phrase: Fire will never say that it has had enough.
meaning_phrase: The fire of anger or of love will burn as long as it has something to feed upon.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻole hiki i ka iʻa liʻiliʻi ke ale i ka iʻa nui.
english_phrase: A small fish cannot swallow a big one.
meaning_phrase: A commoner cannot do anything to a chief.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻole i ʻenaʻena ka imu i ka māmane me ka ʻūlei, i ʻenaʻena i ka laʻolaʻo.
english_phrase: The imu is not heated by māmane and ʻūlei wood alone, but also by the kindling.
meaning_phrase: To be powerful, a ruler must have the loyalty of the common people as well as the chiefs.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻole i keʻehi kapuaʻi i ke one o Hauiki.
english_phrase: Has not set foot on the sands of Hauiki.
meaning_phrase: One does not know much about a place until one has been there.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻole make ka waʻa i ka ʻale o waho, aia no i ka ʻale o loko.
english_phrase: A canoe is not swamped by the billows of the ocean, but by the billows near the land.
meaning_phrase: Trouble often comes from one’s own people rather than from outsiders.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻole nō i ʻike ke kanaka i nā nani o kona wahi i hānau ʻia ai.
english_phrase: A person doesn’t see all the beauties of his birthplace.
meaning_phrase: One doesn’t see how beautiful his birthplace is until he goes away from home.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAʻole ʻoe koʻu hoa ʻōlelo.
english_phrase: You are not the companion to talk with.
meaning_phrase: You are not my equal.

hawaiian_phrase: Ao ʻōpiopio.
english_phrase: Young cloud.
meaning_phrase: A cloud that rises from sea level or close to the cloud banks and is as white as steam. When seen in Kona, Hawaiʻi, this is a sign of rain.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻĀpiki Puna i Leleʻapiki, ke nānā lā i Nānāwale.
english_phrase: Puna is concerned at Leleʻapiki and looks about at Nānāwale.
meaning_phrase: The people are but followers and obedient to their rulers. The people of Puna were not anxious to go to war when a battle was declared between Kiwalaʻō and Kamehameha; it was the will of their chief. Lele-ʻapiki (Tricky-leap) and Nānā-wale (Just-looking) are places in Puna.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAu ana ka Lae o Maunauna i ka ʻino.
english_phrase: Point Maunauna swims in the storm.
meaning_phrase: Said of a courageous person who withstands the storm of life. Point Maunauna (Battered) is at Waimea, Oʻahu, where high seas are common.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAuhea nō hoʻi kou kanaka uʻi a ʻimi ʻoe i wahine nāu?
english_phrase: Why is it that you do not show how handsome you are by seeking your own woman ?
meaning_phrase: A woman might say, under the same circumstances, “ʻAuhea nō hoʻi kou wahine uʻi a ʻimi ʻoe i kāne nau?’

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAu i ke kai loa.
english_phrase: Swims the distant seas.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who travels afar.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAu i ke kai me he manu ala.
english_phrase: Cross the sea as a bird.
meaning_phrase: To sail across the sea. Also applied to a hill that juts out into the sea or is seen from far out at sea.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAukuʻu hāpapa i ka haʻi loko.
english_phrase: Heron groping in somebody else’s fishpond.
meaning_phrase: A man groping for somebody else’s woman.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAukuʻu kiaʻi awa.
english_phrase: Heron that watches the harbor.
meaning_phrase: A spy.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAukuʻu kiaʻi loko.
english_phrase: Heron who watches the [fish in the] pond.
meaning_phrase: A person who spies on others.

hawaiian_phrase: A ʻula! Kolekole!
english_phrase: Red! Red exposed!
meaning_phrase: Said while drawing down the lid of the eye in contempt. Also, a vulgar expression arising from the following story: On Hawaiʻi lived a man who was dim-sighted but not entirely blind, though he liked to pretend to be so. One day, two women saw him coming with a friend, and one said to the other, “One of those men can see, and the other is not as blind as he pretends to be.” Her companion disagreed. “I am sure he is blind,” she said. Then the first woman replied, “I will expose myself and we shall see.” When the men drew near, the woman sat down and facing the “blind” man, exposed herself. He looked and exclaimed, “A ‘ula! Kolekole!” Because of this, his friend and the two women knew that he was not totally blind.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAu umauma o Hilo i ka wai.
english_phrase: Hilo has breasted the water.
meaning_phrase: To weather the storm. The district of Hilo had many gulches and streams and was difficult to cross.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAwaʻawa Ahuna.
english_phrase: Sour Ahuna.
meaning_phrase: Said of a sour situation. Ahuna was a Chinese who lived on Hawaiʻi in the 1880s. His favorite expression for anything he did not like was ʻawaʻawa (sour).

hawaiian_phrase: A waho au o ka poe pele, pau kou palena e ka hoa.
english_phrase: After I’ve passed the bell buoy, your limit is reached, my dear.
meaning_phrase: A sailor’s saying used in an old hula song. When the ship passes the bell buoy on its way out to sea, the girl on the shore is forgotten.

hawaiian_phrase: Awaiāulu ke aloha.
english_phrase: Love made fast by tying together.
meaning_phrase: Marriage.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAwa kau lāʻau o Puna.
english_phrase: Tree-growing ʻawa of Puna.
meaning_phrase: Tree-grown ʻawa of Puna was famous for its potency. It was believed that birds carried pieces of ʻawa up into the trees where it would grow.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻAwapuhi lau pala wale.
english_phrase: Ginger leaves yellow quickly.
meaning_phrase: Said of a weakling who withers easily, or of anything that passes too soon.

hawaiian_phrase: E aha ʻia ana o Hakipuʻu i ka palaoa lāwalu ʻono a Kaʻehu?
english_phrase: What is happening to Hakipuu, with dough cooked in ti leaves, of which Kaehu is so fond?
meaning_phrase: This is a line of a chant composed by Kaʻehu, a poet and hula instructor from Kauaʻi. It refers to a part-white woman with whom he flirted. Used in humor when referring to Hakipuʻu, a place on the windward side of Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: E aho ka make i ke kaua, he nui nā moepuʻu.
english_phrase: Better to die in battle where one will have companions in death.
meaning_phrase: Uttered by Kaʻeokulani, a chief of Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: E ʻai ana ʻoe i ka poi paua o Keaiwa.
english_phrase: Now you are eating poi made from the paua taro of Keaiwa.
meaning_phrase: A boast from the district of Kaʻū: “Now you are seeing the very best that we have.” Also used to say, “Now you will find out how fine a girl (or boy) can be in making love.” The paua was the best taro in Kaʻū and the only variety that grew on the plains.

hawaiian_phrase: E ʻai i ka mea i loaʻa.
english_phrase: What you have, eat.
meaning_phrase: Be satisfied with what you have.

hawaiian_phrase: E ʻai i kekahi, e kāpī kekahi.
english_phrase: Eat some, salt some.
meaning_phrase: Said to young people: Eat some now and save some for another time.

hawaiian_phrase: E akahele i ka mamo a ʻĪ, o kolo mai ka mole uaua.
english_phrase: Beware the descendant of ʻĪ, lest the tough roots crawl forth.
meaning_phrase: A warning uttered by Palena, a chief of Kohala, who saw Kuaʻana-a-ʻĪ cruelly treated by the chiefs of Kona. Kuaʻana later went to see the people of his mother, Hoʻoleialiʻi, in Hāna, and to help the chiefs of Hilo in fighting those of Kona.

hawaiian_phrase: E akahele ka mea ʻakahi akahi.
english_phrase: Let the person who is inexperienced watch his step.
meaning_phrase: Fear enters when protection is gone. Said by ʻAikanaka of Kauaʻi when two of his war leaders were destroyed by Kawelo.

hawaiian_phrase: E ake ana e inu i ka wai hū o Koʻolihilihi.
english_phrase: Eager to drink of the gushing spring of Koʻolihilihi.
meaning_phrase: Eager to make love. Koʻolihilihi (Prop-eyelashes) is a spring in Puna. When royal visitors were expected, the people attached lehua blossoms to the makaloa sedge that grew around the spring so that when their guests stooped to drink, the lehua fringes touched their cheeks and eyelashes. The last person for whom the spring was bedecked was Keohokalole, mother of Liliʻuokalani.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻEā! Ke kau mai nei ke ao panopano i uka. E ua mai ana paha.
english_phrase: Say! A black cloud appears in the upland. Perhaps it is going to rain.
meaning_phrase: A favorite joke uttered when a black-skinned person is seen.

hawaiian_phrase: E ʻaki maka o ka lauhue.
english_phrase: Nip off the bud of the poison gourd.
meaning_phrase: Uttered by some chiefs of the court of Alapaʻi, ruler of Hawaiʻi, who wanted Kamehameha destroyed at birth.

hawaiian_phrase: E ala! E alu! E kuilima!
english_phrase: Up! Together! Join hands!
meaning_phrase: A call to come together to tackle a given task.

hawaiian_phrase: E ala, e hoa i ka malo.
english_phrase: Get up and gird your loincloth.
meaning_phrase: A call to rise and get to work.

hawaiian_phrase: E ala e Kaʻū, kahiko o Mākaha; e ala e Puna, Puna Kumākaha; e ala e Hilo naʻau kele!
english_phrase: Arise, O Kaʻū of ancient descent; arise, O Puna of the Kumākaha group; arise, O Hilo of the water-soaked foundation!
meaning_phrase: A rallying call. These names are found in Kaʻū and Puna chants of the chiefs. The Mākaha and Ku-mākaha (Like-the-Mākaha) were originally one. Some moved to Puna and took the name Kumākaha.

hawaiian_phrase: E ala kākou e ʻai o hiki mai kaumahalua.
english_phrase: Let us rise and eat before the doubly-weighted ones arrive.
meaning_phrase: Let’s get going and eat before company comes. The people of Honokaneiki, in Kohala, were not noted for their hospitality. Travelers to Honokaneiki were called “doubly-weighted” because they had to swim to get there from the cliff of Kakaʻauki. With bundles, and being soaked by the sea, the weight of a person was doubled. In order to finish their morning meal before others arrived, the people of Honokaneiki awoke early, ate, and went about their work.

hawaiian_phrase: E aʻo i ka hana o pā i ka leo o ka makua hūnōai.
english_phrase: Learn to work lest you be struck by the voice of the parent-in-law.
meaning_phrase: Advice to a son or daughter before marriage.

hawaiian_phrase: E ʻao lūʻau a kualima.
english_phrase: Offer young taro leaves to the gods five times.
meaning_phrase: Advice to one who has erred and wishes to rectify his mistake. Young taro leaves often were substituted for pigs when making an offering to the gods. To remove sickness of mind or body, one made five separate offerings of young taro leaves.

hawaiian_phrase: E ao, o kā i ka waha.
english_phrase: Watch out lest it smite the mouth.
meaning_phrase: A warning not to be too free in using rude and insulting words toward others lest someday one must take them back. Also, things said of others may happen to the person who says them.

hawaiian_phrase: E ao o miki aku o Ka-ʻili-pehu.
english_phrase: Watch out or Swell-skin will get at you.
meaning_phrase: Beware lest you get a pummeling that will cause a swelling.

hawaiian_phrase: E ao o pau poʻo, pau hiʻu ia manō.
english_phrase: Be careful lest you go head and tail into the shark.
meaning_phrase: A warning to be on one’s guard. Nanaue, of Waipiʻo, Hawaiʻi, had two forms — that of a man and that of a shark. As people passed his farm to go to the beach, he would utter this warning. After they had passed, he would run to the river, change into a shark, and swim under the water to the sea where he would catch and eat those he had warned. No one knew that it was Nanaue who was eating the people until someone pulled off the shoulder covering he always wore and discovered a shark’s mouth between his shoulder blades. After he was put to death the people were safe again.

hawaiian_phrase: E ʻau mālie i ke kai pāpaʻu, o pakī ka wai a pula ka maka.
english_phrase: Swim quietly in shallow water lest it splash into the eyes.
meaning_phrase: A cautioning to go carefully where one isn’t sure of conditions.

hawaiian_phrase: E! E pololei ana ke kua o mea.
english_phrase: Say! The back [of a hunchhacked person] will surely he straightened.
meaning_phrase: Said to one who is always correcting others, as if to say, “Why correct my mistakes? Let’s see if you can straighten a crooked back!”

hawaiian_phrase: E ʻEwa e — e kuʻi nā lima!
english_phrase: O ʻEwa — join hands!
meaning_phrase: This cry was a call of the men of Kona, Oʻahu, when they went with their chief to destroy his brother, the ʻEwa chief.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻEha ana ʻoe lā i ka makani kuʻi o ka Ulumano.
english_phrase: You will he hurt by the pounding of the Ulumano breeze.
meaning_phrase: One is hurt by the sharp words spoken. This is a line from an old chant.

hawaiian_phrase: E hahai ana nō ke kolekole i kahi nui a ka wahie, a e hahai ana no ke ʻino i kahi nui o ka paʻakai.
english_phrase: Underdone meat follows along even where wood is plentiful, and decomposition follows along even where much salt is found.
meaning_phrase: Even where good is found, evil creeps in.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻEha i ka ʻeha lima ʻole a ke aloha.
english_phrase: He is smitten by love, with a pain administered without hands.
meaning_phrase: He is deeply in love.

hawaiian_phrase: E hakoko ana ʻo Heneli me Keoni Pulu; ua lilo ke eo iā Keoni Pulu.
english_phrase: Henry and John Bull wrestle; John Bull wins.
meaning_phrase: Hunger is routed by filling the stomach. Henry (Hunger) and John Bull (Fullness) wrestle until John Bull wins the match.

hawaiian_phrase: E hamau o makani mai auaneʻi.
english_phrase: Hush, lest the wind arise.
meaning_phrase: Hold your silence or trouble will come to us. When the people went to gather pearl oysters at Puʻuloa, they did so in silence, for they believed that if they spoke, a gust of wind would ripple the water and the oysters would vanish.

hawaiian_phrase: E hānai ʻawa a ikaika ka makani.
english_phrase: Feed with ʻawa that the spirit may gain strength.
meaning_phrase: One offers ʻawa and prayers to the dead so that their spirits may grow strong and be a source of help to the family.

hawaiian_phrase: E hana mua a paʻa ke kahua ma mua o ke aʻo ana aku iā haʻi.
english_phrase: Build yourself a firm foundation before teaching others.
meaning_phrase: Do all of your teaching at home. First uttered by Pupuakea, half-brother of Lonoikamakahiki, when his instructor advised him as they were preparing for battle. The instructor’s teaching was all done at home; from then on the warrior chief was on his own. Also directed toward parents who noisily scold their children in public.

hawaiian_phrase: E hea i ke kanaka e komo ma loko e hānai ai a hewa ka waha.
english_phrase: Call to the person to enter; feed him until he can take no more.
meaning_phrase: Originally a reply to a password into a hula school. Used later in songs and in speech to extend hospitality.

hawaiian_phrase: E hele aku ana i ka māla a Kamehameha, o Kuahewa.
english_phrase: The proportion is reaching the size of Kuahewa, Kamehameha’s food patch.
meaning_phrase: The project is becoming too big. Kamehameha’s food patch was so huge that one border could not be seen from the other.

hawaiian_phrase: E hele ana i ka ʻauwaeʻāina o lākou nei.
english_phrase: Going with them to look over the best in their land.
meaning_phrase: Hawaiians didn’t like to be questioned as to where they were going and would sometimes give this answer. Paʻe was a moʻo woman who often assumed the form of a dog and went wherever she willed. One day, while disguised as a dog, she was caught by some men who didn’t know of her supernatural powers, and they roasted her. This roasted dog was to be a gift to their chief’s wife and was put in a calabash, covered with a carrying net, and carried up the pali. Just below the Nuʻuanu Pali, the men saw a pretty woman sitting at the edge of a pool. She called, “Oh Paʻe, where are you going?” From out of the calabash leaped the dog, well and whole, who answered, “I am going with them to look over the best in their land.” The men fled in terror, leaving Paʻe behind with the other woman, who was a moʻo relative.

hawaiian_phrase: E hele ka ʻelemakule, ka luahine, a me nā kamaliʻi a moe i ke ala ʻaʻohe mea nāna e hoʻopilikia.
english_phrase: Let the old men, the old women, and the children go and sleep on the wayside; let them not be molested.
meaning_phrase: Said by Kamehameha I.

hawaiian_phrase: E hinu auaneʻi nā nuku, he pōmaikaʻi ko laila.
english_phrase: Where the mouths are shiny [with fat food], prosperity is there.
meaning_phrase: The prosperous have the richest food to eat.

hawaiian_phrase: E hiolo ana nā kapu kahiko; e hina ana nā heiau me nā lele; e hui ana nā moku; he iho mai ana ka lani a e piʻi ana ka honua.
english_phrase: The ancient kapu will be abolished; the heiau and altars willfall; the islands will be united; the heavens will descend and the earth ascend.
meaning_phrase: A prophecy uttered by Kapihe, a kahuna in Kamehameha’s time. The last part of the saying means that chiefs will come down to humble positions and commoners rise to positions of honor.

hawaiian_phrase: E hoʻāʻo nō i pau kuhihewa.
english_phrase: Try it and rid yourself of illusions.
meaning_phrase: Said of an attractive person.

hawaiian_phrase: E hoʻi e peʻe i ke ōpū weuweu me he moho lā. E ao o haʻi ka pua o ka mauʻu iā ʻoe.
english_phrase: Go back and hide among the clumps of grass like the wingless rail. Be careful not to break even a blade of grass.
meaning_phrase: Retum to the country to live a humble life and leave no trace to be noticed and followed. So said the chief Keliʻiwahamana to his daughter when he was dying. Later used as advice to a young person not to be aggressive or show off.

hawaiian_phrase: E hoʻi ka uʻi o Mānoa, ua ahiahi.
english_phrase: Let the youth of Mānoa go home, for it is evening.
meaning_phrase: Refers to the youth of Mānoa who used to ride the surf at Kalehuawehe in Waikīkī. The surfboards were shared among several people who would take turns using them. Those who finished first often suggested going home early, even though it might not be evening, to avoid carrying the boards to the hālau where they were stored. Later the expression was used for anyone who went off to avoid work.

hawaiian_phrase: E hoʻi ka waʻa; mai hoʻopaʻa aku i ka ʻino.
english_phrase: Make the canoe go back; do not insist on heading into a storm.
meaning_phrase: A plea not to do something or associate with someone that will lead to serious trouble.

hawaiian_phrase: E hōʻike mai ana ka lāʻau a ke kia manu.
english_phrase: The stick of the birdcatcher will tell.
meaning_phrase: We will know how successful one is by what he produces. One knew whether a birdcatcher was successful by counting the birds on his gummed stick.

hawaiian_phrase: E hoʻi nā keiki oki uaua o nā pali.
english_phrase: Home go the very tough lads of the hills.
meaning_phrase: These lads of the hills were the cowboys of Puʻuwaʻawaʻa and Puʻuanahulu, who were well known for their endurance.

hawaiian_phrase: E hoʻoipo ana me Niolopua.
english_phrase: Making love with Niolopua.
meaning_phrase: Asleep. Niolopua is the god of sleep.

hawaiian_phrase: E hoʻokanaka.
english_phrase: Be a man.
meaning_phrase: Good weather comes in the month of Nana.

hawaiian_phrase: E hoʻōki i ka hoʻina wale o hōʻino ʻia mai ke kumu.
english_phrase: One should never go home without [some knowledge] lest his teacher be criticized.
meaning_phrase: Kāne was the god of fresh water and life.

hawaiian_phrase: E hoʻomanaʻo i ka lua o ka ʻōhiki.
english_phrase: Remember the hole dug by the sand crab.
meaning_phrase: A vulgar expression. A woman may be petite but she can be sexually “deep.”

hawaiian_phrase: E hoʻopiha i ka lua o ka inaina.
english_phrase: Fill the pit of wrath.
meaning_phrase: Fill the stomach.

hawaiian_phrase: E hoʻopiha i ka mākālua i hakahaka.
english_phrase: Fill the hole from which the plant has been removed.
meaning_phrase: Find someone to replace one who has gone away or died.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻEhu ahiahi.
english_phrase: Evening twilight.
meaning_phrase: Old age.

hawaiian_phrase: Ehuehu kai, noho ka moi.
english_phrase: Where the sea broils, there the moi fish dwell.
meaning_phrase: People gather out of curiosity when trouble arises.

hawaiian_phrase: Ehuehu kai piʻi ka ʻaʻama.
english_phrase: When the sea is rough, the ʻaʻama crabs climb up [on the rocks].
meaning_phrase: People gather out of curiosity when trouble arises.

hawaiian_phrase: E huʻe mai ʻoe i ke koaiʻe o Makawao!
english_phrase: Try uprooting the koaiʻe tree of Makawao!
meaning_phrase: I defy you to tackle a lad of Makawao! A boast from a native of Makawao, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: E hume i ka malo, e hoʻokala i ka ihe.
english_phrase: Gird the loincloth, sharpen the spear.
meaning_phrase: A call to prepare for war or to prepare for the project at hand.

hawaiian_phrase: Eia aʻe ka makani Kona.
english_phrase: Here comes the Kona wind.
meaning_phrase: An angry person approaches.

hawaiian_phrase: Eia iho ko hoa like o Malelewaʻa.
english_phrase: Here is a suitable companion for you, Malelewaʻa.
meaning_phrase: Remark about an untidy person. A play on malele (strewn about) in Malelewaʻa, a place on Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Eia ʻiʻo nō, ke kolo mai nei ke aʻa o ka wauke.
english_phrase: Truly now, the root of the wauke creeps.
meaning_phrase: It was not destroyed while it was small; now it’s too big to cope with. Said by Keaweamaʻuhili’s warriors of Kamehameha. They were at the court of Alapaʻi when the order was given to “Nip off the leaf bud of the wauke plant while it is tender” [E ʻōʻū i ka maka o ka wauke oi ʻōpiopio). This attempt to kill the baby didn’t succeed, and the child grew into a powerful warrior who quelled all of his foes.

hawaiian_phrase: Eia ka iki nowelo a ka mikioi.
english_phrase: Here is the clever and dainty little one.
meaning_phrase: A boast, meaning “I may be little, but....”

hawaiian_phrase: Eia ka lua hūnā o nā aliʻi: ʻo ka waha.
english_phrase: Here is the secret cave of the chiefs: the mouth.
meaning_phrase: We refuse to discuss our chiefs too freely.

hawaiian_phrase: Eia ke kānaenae a ka mea hele: he leo, he leo wale nō.
english_phrase: Here is an offering from a traveler: a voice in greeting, simply a voice.
meaning_phrase: Said in affection by a passerby who, seeing a friend, greets him but doesn’t stop to visit.

hawaiian_phrase: Eia nō kahi koe o ka moamoa.
english_phrase: Here is the only space left, the moamoa.
meaning_phrase: Said when offering a small space or seat to a friend when every other place is occupied. As Paʻao was leaving from Kahiki with a canoe filled to capacity, a priest, Makuakaumana, called out, asking to come along. He was offered the only available space — the sharp point at the stem of the canoe, the moamoa.

hawaiian_phrase: Eia ʻo Kuʻiʻaki me Huanu ke hana nei i ka lāua hana o ka ʻohi ʻiʻo pūpū.
english_phrase: Here are Kuʻiʻaki and Huanu doing their work gathering shellfish.
meaning_phrase: An intense cold. A play on Kuʻi-ʻaki (Gritting-the-molars) and Hu-anu (Overflowing-cold). Huanu is Hawaiian for Juan.

hawaiian_phrase: Eia ua lani a Hāloa i pili ai ka hanu i ke kapu.
english_phrase: Here is a chief descended from Hāloa, whose kapu makes one hold his breath in dread.
meaning_phrase: A compliment to a chief. To be able to trace descent from Hāloa, an ancient chief, was to be of very high rank from remote antiquity.

hawaiian_phrase: E ʻike ana ʻoe i ke liʻi nui o Oʻahu, o Kakuhihewa.
english_phrase: You will meet with the great chief of Oʻahu, Kakuhihewa.
meaning_phrase: You shall find out how wrong you are. A play on kuhihewa (erroneous).

hawaiian_phrase: E ʻike i ka hoa kanaka, o kipa hewa ke aloha i ka ʻīlio.
english_phrase: Recognize your fellow man lest your love be wasted on a dog.
meaning_phrase: Love man above animals.

hawaiian_phrase: E ʻimi i ke ola ma waho.
english_phrase: Seek life outside.
meaning_phrase: Consult a kahuna to see what is causing the delay in healing. Said when a person lies sick, and recovery is slow.

hawaiian_phrase: E ʻimi wale nō i ka lua o ka ʻuwaʻu ʻaʻole e loaʻa.
english_phrase: Seek as you will the burrow of the ʻuwaʻu, it cannot be found.
meaning_phrase: A boast of one’s skill in lua fighting, of the depth of one’s knowledge, or of a skill that isn’t easily acquired. A play on lua, a burrow, a pit, or an art of fighting.
