The burrow of the ʻuwaʻu bird is often deep. Birdcatchers inserted a piece of aerial root of the ʻieʻie, gummed at one end, to catch the fledglings.

hawaiian_phrase: E kā i ka pōhuehue.
english_phrase: Smite with the pōhuehue.
meaning_phrase: Do harm to another in order to destroy him.

hawaiian_phrase: E kalani e, kiʻi mai i ka iʻa, ua komo i ka mākāhā!
english_phrase: O heavenly one, come and get the fish for it has entered the sluice gate!
meaning_phrase: Used by one who has his hands full and needs help quickly. In a battle, Ahia caught Kameʻeiamoku and lifted him with the intention of dashing him to the ground. Kameʻeiamoku twisted himself about, grasped Ahia by the calf of the leg and held fast so that it was impossible for him to run. Seeing Kamehameha a short distance away, Kameʻeiamoku called to him to come and take the fish. Thus was Ahia killed.

hawaiian_phrase: E kāmau iho i ka hoe a pae aku i ke kula.
english_phrase: Dip in the paddle till you reach the shore.
meaning_phrase: Keep dipping your finger into the poi until you’ve had your fill.

hawaiian_phrase: E kanu i ka huli ʻoi hāʻule ka ua.
english_phrase: Plant the taro stalks while there is rain.
meaning_phrase: Do your work when opportunity affords.

hawaiian_phrase: E kanu mea ʻai o nānā keiki i ka haʻi.
english_phrase: Plant edible food plants lest your children look with longing at someone else’s.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is very popular with the opposite sex.

hawaiian_phrase: E Kaululāʻau, ʻakahi nō pō i pipili ai nā maka.
english_phrase: O Kaululāʻau, it is the first night that the eyelids have stuck so.
meaning_phrase: Used in derision of one who doesn’t use his eyes. Kaululāʻau was a Maui chief who, because of his mischief, was banished to the island of Lānaʻi by his father. There he destroyed the evil inhabitants of that island by applying gum to their eyelids after they had fallen asleep.

hawaiian_phrase: E kaupē aku nō i ka hoe a kō mai.
english_phrase: Put forward the paddle and draw it back.
meaning_phrase: Go on with the task that is started and finish it.

hawaiian_phrase: E keʻekeʻehi kūlana i paʻa. ʻO ʻoe hoʻokahi, ʻo wau hoʻokahi, kū mai i mua.
english_phrase: Take a firm stand. You, by yourself, and I, by myself, let us step forth.
meaning_phrase: A challenge to one to step out of a crowd and fight man to man.

hawaiian_phrase: E kipi ana lākou nei. ʻAʻole naʻe ʻo lākou ponoʻī akā ʻo kā lākou mau keiki me nā moʻopuna. ʻO ke aliʻi e ola ana i ia wā e kū ʻōlohelohe ana ia, a ʻo ke aupuni e kūkulu ʻia aku ana, ʻo ia ke aupuni paʻa o Hawaiʻi nei.
english_phrase: These people [the missionaries] are going to rebel; not they themselves, but their children and grandchildren. The ruler at that time will be stripped of power, and the government established then will be the permanent government of Hawaiʻi.
meaning_phrase: Prophesied by David Malo.

hawaiian_phrase: E kolo ana nō ke ēwe i ke ēwe.
english_phrase: The rootlet will creep toward the rootlets.
meaning_phrase: Of the same origin, kinfolk will seek and love each other.

hawaiian_phrase: E kuahui like i ka hana.
english_phrase: Let everybody pitch in and work together.
meaning_phrase: An expression used by one who cannot guess the answer to a riddle, meaning,“I give up!” If the riddler doesn’t want to tell the answer, he may reply tartly: ʻEu nō ka ilo, make! (Maggots move, death!) [kūāilo = be devoured by worms (PE)]

hawaiian_phrase: E kuhi aku ana i Kuhiau.
english_phrase: Pointing out Kuhiau.
meaning_phrase: You are making a mistake in your ideas. A play on kuhi (to point, to be mistaken). Kuhiau is a place on Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: E kuhikuhi pono i nā au iki a me nā au nui o ka ʻike.
english_phrase: Instruct well in the little and the large currents of knowledge.
meaning_phrase: In teaching, do it well; the small details are as important as the large ones.

hawaiian_phrase: E kuʻi ka māmā a loaʻa ʻo Kaʻohele.
english_phrase: Let your fastest runners run in relay to catch Kaʻohele.
meaning_phrase: Let us make every effort to attain our goal. Kaʻohele was a chief and warrior and in his day there was none swifter than he. It was only by running after him in relay that he was caught and killed.

hawaiian_phrase: E lauhoe mai nā waʻa; i ke kā, i ka hoe; i ka hoe, i ke kā; pae aku i ka ʻāina.
english_phrase: Everybody paddle the canoes together; bail and paddle, paddle and bail, and the shore is reached.
meaning_phrase: Pitch in with a will, everybody, and the work is quickly done.

hawaiian_phrase: E lawe i ke aʻo a mālama, a e ʻoi mau ka naʻauao.
english_phrase: He who takes his teachings and applies them increases his knowledge.
meaning_phrase: Do all of your teaching at home. First uttered by Pupuakea, half-brother of Lonoikamakahiki, when his instructor advised him as they were preparing for battle. The instructor’s teaching was all done at home; from then on the warrior chief was on his own. Also directed toward parents who noisily scold their children in public.

hawaiian_phrase: E lawe i ke ō, he hinana ka iʻa kuhi lima.
english_phrase: Take vegetable food; the hinana is a fish that can be caught in the hand.
meaning_phrase: A suggestion to take taro, poi, potato, or breadfruit along on the journey and not worry about meats, which can be found along the way. First uttered by Pele in a chant about the winds of Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻEleʻele Hilo, panopano i ka ua.
english_phrase: Dark is Hilo, clouded with the rain.
meaning_phrase: Hilo is always rainy.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻEleʻelepī ka waha o kānaka.
english_phrase: The mouths of people make noises like mud crabs.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who talks too much — all noise and no sense. The ʻelepī is a small black crab that makes a loud noise resembling a smacking sound made by the mouth.

hawaiian_phrase: E lei kau, e lei hoʻoilo i ke aloha.
english_phrase: Love is worn like a wreath through the summers and the winters.
meaning_phrase: Love is everlasting.

hawaiian_phrase: E lei nō au i ko aloha.
english_phrase: I will wear your love as a wreath.
meaning_phrase: I will cherish your love as a beautiful adornment.

hawaiian_phrase: E Lēkia e, ʻonia i paʻa.
english_phrase: O Lēkia, move that you may hold fast.
meaning_phrase: Make a move to give yourself a secure holel. Lēkia and Pōhaku-o-Hanalei are stones in Puna. When the demigod Kaleikini came to the district, he dug around Lēkia with the intention of toppling it off the hill. Before he could uproot it, he got hungry and departed. It was then that the other stone, Pōhaku-o-Hanalei, cried out, “E Lēkia e, ʻonia i paʻa.” Lēkia moved downward and held fast. Kaleikini tried in vain after that and was unable to remove Lēkia.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻElelū kea.
english_phrase: White cockroach.
meaning_phrase: A term of insult applied to a white person.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻElemakule ʻauwae lenalena.
english_phrase: Yellow-chinned old man.
meaning_phrase: Said of an old man whose teeth are gone and whose chin wags toothlessly.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻElemakule kamaʻole moe i ke ala.
english_phrase: An oldster who has never reared children sleeps by the roadside.
meaning_phrase: Caring for and rearing children results in being cared for in old age.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻElepaio kahea iʻa.
english_phrase: Fish-calling ʻelepaio.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who talks about his wants and does nothing to obtain them. Sometimes the call of the ʻelepaio sounds like “ ʻOno ka iʻa! ʻOno ka iʻa!” (“Fish is tasty! Fish is tasty!”) A person hearing it may answer, “Why don’t you go and catch some yourself?” A similar expression is ʻElepaio puni iʻa (ʻElepaio, fond of fish).

hawaiian_phrase: ʻEliʻeli kūlana o ʻĀinaʻike.
english_phrase: Profound is the nature of ʻĀinaʻike.
meaning_phrase: Refers to a person respected for the depth of his knowledge. A play on ʻeliʻeli (profound, deep) and ʻĀina-ʻike (Land of Knowledge). ʻĀinaʻike is a place on Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: E! Loaʻa akula ke kalo, ʻo ka ʻapowale.
english_phrase: Say! You’ll obtain a taro, the ʻapowale.
meaning_phrase: You are wasting your time. A play on ʻapo-wale (grasp-at-nothing), a variety of taro.

hawaiian_phrase: E loaʻa ana iā ʻoe ka mea a Paʻahao.
english_phrase: Youll get what Paʻahao has.
meaning_phrase: Paʻahao, a native of Kaʻiā, was often teased by his neighbors because when annoyed he would snap, “Naio!” (“Pinworms!”) This amused his tormentors. When annoyed, one might say, “You’ll get what Paʻahao has.” Paʻahao lived in Waiōhinu, Kaʻū, during the late 1800s and early 1900s.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻEloʻelo i ka wai o Kulanihākoʻi.
english_phrase: Drenched by the water of Kulanihākoʻi.
meaning_phrase: Said of a heavy downpour. Kulanihākoʻi is the name of a mythical pond in the sky.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻElo ke kuāua o Ualoa; puaʻi i ka lani, kū kele ke one.
english_phrase: Drenching is the shower of Ualoa; the heavens overflow to soak the sands.
meaning_phrase: Very wet weather. A play on ua (rain) and loa (very much). Ualoa is a place name.

hawaiian_phrase: E mālama i ka iki kanaka, i ka nuʻa kanaka. O kākou nō kēia hoʻākua.
english_phrase: Take care of the insignificant and the great man. That is the duty of us gods.
meaning_phrase: Said by Hiʻiaka to Pele in a chant before she departed for Kauaʻi to seek Lohiʻau.

hawaiian_phrase: E mālama i ka leo o ke aliʻi, o hāʻule wale i ka weuweu.
english_phrase: Take care of the chief’s voice, lest it drop among the grass.
meaning_phrase: Heed the chief’s voice; do not ignore his commands.

hawaiian_phrase: E mālama i ka mākua, he mea laha ʻole; ʻo ke kāne he loaʻa i ka lā hoʻokahi.
english_phrase: Take care of parents for they are choice; a husband can he found in a day.
meaning_phrase: Parents should be cared for, for when they are gone, there are none to replace them. One can marry again and again.

hawaiian_phrase: E mālama i ka mākua, o hoʻomakua auaneʻi i ka haʻi.
english_phrase: Take care of [your] parents lest [the day come when] you will be caring for someone else’s.
meaning_phrase: Mākua includes all relatives of the parents’ generation, including their siblings and cousins.

hawaiian_phrase: E mālama i ka ʻōlelo, i kuleana e kipa mai ai.
english_phrase: Remember the invitation, for it gives you the privilege of coming here.
meaning_phrase: A person feels welcome when accepting an invitation and friendly promises.

hawaiian_phrase: E mālama o loaʻa i ka niho.
english_phrase: Be careful or you’ll be caught by the teeth.
meaning_phrase: A warning to watch out lest one become a victim of sorcery. A person who practices sorcery is said to have teeth; that is, his sorcery “bites.”

hawaiian_phrase: E mālama o pā i ka leo.
english_phrase: Be careful lest you he struck by the voice.
meaning_phrase: Be careful not to do something that will lead to a scolding.

hawaiian_phrase: E mānalo ka hala o ke kanaka i ka imu o ka puaʻa.
english_phrase: The wrongs done by man are atoned for by a pig in the imu.
meaning_phrase: When a person has committed a wrong against others or against the gods, he makes an offering of a hog with prayers of forgiveness.

hawaiian_phrase: E manaʻo aʻe ana e lei i ka lehua o Mokaulele.
english_phrase: A wish to wear the lehua of Mokaulele in a lei.
meaning_phrase: A wish to win the maiden. Lei symbolizes sweetheart, and lehua, a pretty girl.

hawaiian_phrase: E moni i ke koko o ka inaina, ʻumi ka hanu o ka hoʻomanawanui.
english_phrase: Swallow the blood of wrath and hold the breath of patience.
meaning_phrase: Said by Kaʻiana, who led an army in battle under Kamehameha I. When the Puna fighters refused to battle against Keouakuahuʻula because of the close kinship between their own district and Kaʻū, Kaʻiana said this to urge them to think of themselves and their own lives. Encouraged, the warriors resumed fīghting and won the victory for Kamehameha.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻEna akula manu o Kaʻula.
english_phrase: Untamed is the bird of Kaʻula.
meaning_phrase: Said of a shy person. Kaʻula is a small island beyond Niʻihau inhabited by many birds.

hawaiian_phrase: E naʻi wale nō ʻoukou i koʻu pono, ʻaʻole e pau.
english_phrase: You can seek out all the benefits I have produced and find them without number.
meaning_phrase: Said by Kamehameha I when he was dying.

hawaiian_phrase: E nānā ana i ka ʻopua o ka ʻāina.
english_phrase: Observing the horizon clouds of the land.
meaning_phrase: Seeking to discover future events by observing the cloud omens.

hawaiian_phrase: E nānā mai a uhi kapa ʻeleʻele ia Maui, a kau ka puaʻa i ka nuku, kiʻi mai i ka ʻāina a lawe aku.
english_phrase: Watch until the black tapa cloth covers Maui and the sacrificial hog is offered, then come and take the land.
meaning_phrase: Said by Kahekili, ruler of Maui, to a messenger sent by Kamehameha I with a question whether to have war or peace. Kahekili sent back this answer — “Wait until I am dead and all the rites performed, then invade and take the island of Maui.”

hawaiian_phrase: E nānā wāhine aʻe nō, ʻaʻole ʻoe e loaʻa.
english_phrase: Women can be observed, [but] you cannot be matched.
meaning_phrase: One may look at other women but none can be compared to you.

hawaiian_phrase: E niʻaupiʻo ka lani.
english_phrase: May the chief remain of highest rank.
meaning_phrase: A blessing on a high chief: may he and his descendants live on in purity of rank.

hawaiian_phrase: E nihi ka helena i ka uka o Puna; mai pūlale i ka ʻike a ka maka.
english_phrase: Go quietly in the upland of Puna; do not let anything you see excite you.
meaning_phrase: Watch your step and don’t let the things you see lead you into trouble. There is an abundance of flowers and berries in the uplands of Puna and it is thought that picking any on the trip up to the volcano will result in being caught in heavy rains; the picking is left until the return trip. Also said to loved ones to imply, “Go carefully and be mindful.”

hawaiian_phrase: E noho iho i ke ōpū weuweu, mai hoʻokiʻekiʻe.
english_phrase: Remain among the clumps of grasses and do not elevate yourself.
meaning_phrase: Do not put on airs, show off, or assume an attitude of superiority.

hawaiian_phrase: E noho ma lalo o ka lāʻau maka, iho mai ka huihui, māʻona ka ʻōpū.
english_phrase: Sit under a green tree. When the cluster comes down, the stomach is filled.
meaning_phrase: Serve a worthy person. When your reward comes you will never be hungry.

hawaiian_phrase: E nui ke aho, e kuʻu keiki, a moe i ke kai, no ke kai lā hoʻi ka ʻāina.
english_phrase: Take a deep breath, my son, and lay yourself in the sea, for then the land shall belong to the sea.
meaning_phrase: Uttered by the priest Kaʻopulupulu at Waiʻanae. Weary with the cruelty and injustice of Kahāhana, chief of Oʻahu, Kaʻopulupulu walked with his son to Waiʻanae, where he told his son to throw himself into the sea. The boy obeyed, and there died. Kaʻopulupulu was later slain and taken to Waikīkī where he was laid on the sacrificial altar at Helumoa.

hawaiian_phrase: E ola au i ke akua.
english_phrase: May I live by God.
meaning_phrase: An oath. God is witness that one is not guilty of the misdeed of which he is accused.

hawaiian_phrase: E ola koa.
english_phrase: Live like a koa tree.
meaning_phrase: Live a long time, like a koa tree in the forest.

hawaiian_phrase: E, ʻolohaka! I ke ʻehu nō o ka lāʻau pālau, kulana; hākālia nō a pāpā lāʻau aku o ka make nō ia.
english_phrase: Say! The person is hollow. With just the passing breeze of a brandished club, he falls. As soon as a spear touches him, he dies.
meaning_phrase: Said by Pupukea, a chief of Kaʻū, of Makakuikalani, chief of Maui, in an exchange of insults. Later commonly used to refer to weaklings.

hawaiian_phrase: E ʻoluʻolu i ka mea i loaʻa.
english_phrase: Be contented with what one has.
meaning_phrase: Tears spill.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻEono moku a Kamehameha ua noa iā ʻoukou, akā ʻo ka hiku o ka moku ua kapu ia naʻu.
english_phrase: Six of Kamehameha’s islands are free to you, but the seventh is kapu, and is for me alone.
meaning_phrase: This was uttered by Kamehameha after Oʻahu was conquered. The islands from Hawaiʻi to Oʻahu, which included Maui, Molokaʻi, Lānaʻi, and Kahoʻolawe, belonged to his people. But the seventh “island,” Kaʻahumanu, was his alone. Anyone who attempted to take her from him would be put to death.

hawaiian_phrase: E ʻōpū aliʻi.
english_phrase: Have the heart of a chief.
meaning_phrase: Have the kindness, generosity, and even temper of a chief.

hawaiian_phrase: E pale lauʻī i ko akua ke hiki aku i Kona.
english_phrase: Place a shield of ti leaves before your god when you arrive in Kona.
meaning_phrase: A message sent by Kaʻahumanu to Liholiho requesting him to free the kapu of his god Kūkāʻilimoku. Kaʻahumanu was at that time striving to abolish the kapu system.

hawaiian_phrase: E paneʻe ka waʻa ʻoi moe ka ʻale.
english_phrase: Set the canoes moving while the billows are at rest.
meaning_phrase: Said by Holowae, a kahuna, to suggest that Kalaniʻōpuʻu retum to Hawaiʻi while there was peace. Later used to stir one to action.

hawaiian_phrase: E piʻi ana kahi poʻe, e iho ana kahi poʻe.
english_phrase: Some folks go up, some go down.
meaning_phrase: While the fingers of some are in the poi bowl, the fingers of others are at the mouth.

hawaiian_phrase: E pili mai auaneʻi ia pupuka iaʻu!
english_phrase: That homeliness will not attach itself to me!
meaning_phrase: Ugliness is not contagious. Said by a good-looking person in answer to, “I wonder why a handsome person like you should have such a homely mate.”

hawaiian_phrase: E pule wale nō i ka lā o ka make, ʻaʻole e ola.
english_phrase: Prayers uttered on the day of death will not save one.
meaning_phrase: Said by Lohiʻau to Hiʻiaka.

hawaiian_phrase: E pū paʻakai aku a paʻa ka houpo.
english_phrase: Take a bit of salt till the diaphragm is solid.
meaning_phrase: Said by one whose fare is humble, consisting mostly of poi with salt or kukui relish. “Eat till you are satisfied of this humble fare.”

hawaiian_phrase: E pūpūkahi.
english_phrase: Be of one clump.
meaning_phrase: Be united in thought.

hawaiian_phrase: E puʻu auaneʻi ka lae i ka ua o Kawaupuʻu, i ka hoʻopaʻa a ka hōʻakamai.
english_phrase: The forehead is likely to be lumped by the rain of Kawaupuu if one insists on being a smarty.
meaning_phrase: A warning not to get cocky or smart lest one be hurt. A play on puʻu (lump).

hawaiian_phrase: E uhaʻi i ka maka o ka ihe.
english_phrase: Break off the point of the spear.
meaning_phrase: Cease warfare and resume friendly relations.

hawaiian_phrase: E uhi ana ka wā i hala i nā mea i hala.
english_phrase: Passing time obscures the past.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is off-course mentally or is off gadding somewhere; a blunderer. A play on lalau (to go astray).

hawaiian_phrase: E uhi wale nō ʻaʻole e nalo, he imu puhi.
english_phrase: No matter how much one covers a steaming imu, the smoke will rise.
meaning_phrase: The secret will get out.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻEu kōlea i kona puapua; ʻeu ke kanaka i kona hanu.
english_phrase: A plover stirs its tail; a man stirs because of the breath within.
meaning_phrase: Said by Kaʻiana, who led an army in battle under Kamehameha I. When the Puna fighters refused to battle against Keouakuahuʻula because of the close kinship between their own district and Kaʻū, Kaʻiana said this to urge them to think of themselves and their own lives. Encouraged, the warriors resumed fīghting and won the victory for Kamehameha.

hawaiian_phrase: E uku ʻia ke kanaka kiʻi lāʻau, he luhi kona i ka hele ʻana.
english_phrase: The man who goes to fetch medicinal herbs is to be paid — the trip he makes is labor.
meaning_phrase: The person sent by the kahuna to gather herbs for a patient’s medicine was always paid by the patient’s family. If they faiied to pay, and the gatherer grumbled, the medicine would do no good. A person who was paid couldn’t grumble without hurting himself.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻEu nō ka ilo, make!
english_phrase: The maggot creeps, it dies!
meaning_phrase: Similar to the saying, “There’s a skeleton in every closet.”

hawaiian_phrase: E waikahi ka pono i mānalo.
english_phrase: It is well to be united in thought that all may have peace.
meaning_phrase: Whenever a new canoe was launched, a pig was baked as an offering to the gods. If the skin of the roasted pig cracked, misfortune would come to the canoe; but if it cooked to perfection the canoe would last a long time.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻEwa kai lumalumaʻi.
english_phrase: ʻEwa of the drowning sea.
meaning_phrase: An epithet applied to ʻEwa, where kauā were drowned prior to offering their bodies in sacrifice.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻEwa nui a Laʻakona.
english_phrase: Great ʻEwa of Laʻakona.
meaning_phrase: Laʻakona was a chief of ʻEwa, which was prosperous in his day.

hawaiian_phrase: Ēwe hānau o ka ʻāina.
english_phrase: Natives of the land.
meaning_phrase: People who were born and dwelt on the land.

hawaiian_phrase: E wehe i ka umauma i ākea.
english_phrase: Open out the chest that it may be spacious.
meaning_phrase: Be generous and kind to all.

hawaiian_phrase: Haʻahaʻa haka, pau i ka ʻīlio.
english_phrase: The contents of a low shelf can he stolen by dogs.
meaning_phrase: Things carelessly left about can be stolen. First said by Kamalalawalu to Lonoikamakahiki in making fun of the short stature of the latter’s half-brother and chief steward, Pupukea.

hawaiian_phrase: Haʻa hoʻi ka papa; ke kāhuli nei.
english_phrase: Unstable is the foundation; it is turning over.
meaning_phrase: Said of an unstable person or situation. First used by Hiʻiaka in a chant while playing kilu at the residence of Peleʻula.

hawaiian_phrase: Haʻa ka wai o Kemamo i ka mālie.
english_phrase: The water of Kemamo dances in calm weather.
meaning_phrase: Said humorously of the swish of ladies’ dresses as they walk along.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāʻaleʻale i ka puʻuwai.
english_phrase: A heart full to the brim [with love].
meaning_phrase: Said of an ungrateful person.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāʻale i ka wai a ka manu.
english_phrase: The rippling water where birds gather.
meaning_phrase: A beautiful person. The rippling water denotes a quiet, peaceful nature which attracts others.

hawaiian_phrase: Haʻalele ʻia i muliwaʻa.
english_phrase: Left on the very last canoe.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is left behind.

hawaiian_phrase: Haʻalele i ka lā ka mea mahana.
english_phrase: Has left the warmth of the sun.
meaning_phrase: Has died.

hawaiian_phrase: Haʻalele i ka ʻulaʻula waiwai a koho i ka ʻulaʻula waiwai ʻole.
english_phrase: Leaves the valuable red and chooses the worthless red.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who rejects a suitor of rank in favor of one of lesser station.

hawaiian_phrase: Haʻalele i Puna nā hoaloha ʻē.
english_phrase: Left in Puna are the friends.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who has deserted his friends. Originally said of Hiʻiaka when she left Puna.

hawaiian_phrase: Haʻalele koa waʻa i koa kanaka.
english_phrase: Thc koa canoe has departed leaving the warriors behind.
meaning_phrase: Said when a canoe goes off and leaves the people behind, either in the water or on land.

hawaiian_phrase: Haʻalele ʻo Makanikeoe.
english_phrase: Makanikeoe has departed.
meaning_phrase: Peace and love are no longer here.

hawaiian_phrase: Haʻalele wale iho nō i ke kula o Pūʻula.
english_phrase: For no reason he leaves the plain of Pūʻula.
meaning_phrase: He goes off in a huff for no reason at all. A play on puʻu, or puʻu ka nuku (to pout). Pūʻula is a place in Puna, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāʻawe i ke kua; hiʻi i ke alo.
english_phrase: A burden on the back; a babe in the arms.
meaning_phrase: Said of a hard-working woman who carries a load on her back and a baby in her arms.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāʻawi ka ʻākau, lū ka hema.
english_phrase: The right hand gives, the left hand scatters.
meaning_phrase: Said of an extravagant person.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāʻawi papa heʻe nalu.
english_phrase: A surfboard giving.
meaning_phrase: To give a thing and later ask for its return. A surfboard is usually lent, not given outright.

hawaiian_phrase: Haehae ka manu, ke ʻale nei ka wai.
english_phrase: Tear up the birds, the water is surging.
meaning_phrase: Let us hurry, as there is no time for niceties. Kaneʻalohi and his son lived near the lake of Halulu at Waiʻaleʻale, Kauaʻi. They were catchers of ʻuwaʻu birds. Someone falsely accused them of poaching on land belonging to the chief of Hanalei, who sent a large company of warriors to destroy them. The son noticed agitation in the water of Halulu and cried out a warning to his father, who tore the birds to hasten cooking.

hawaiian_phrase: Hahai nō ka ua i ka ululāʻau.
english_phrase: Rains always follow the forest.
meaning_phrase: The rains are attracted to forest trees. Knowing this, Hawaiians hewed only the trees that were needed.

hawaiian_phrase: Hahana ka wela.
english_phrase: The heat was intense.
meaning_phrase: He or she was very angry.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāhā pōʻele ka pāpaʻi o Kou.
english_phrase: The crabs of Kou are groped for in the dark.
meaning_phrase: Applied to one who goes groping in the dark. The chiefs held kōnane and other games at the shore of Kou (now central Honolulu), and people came from everywhere to watch. Very often they remained until it was too dark to see and had to grope for their companions.

hawaiian_phrase: Haiamū ka manu i ka pua o ka māmane.
english_phrase: The birds gather ahout the māmane blossom.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is very popular with the opposite sex.

hawaiian_phrase: Haʻi ʻē nā pua i ke kula.
english_phrase: The flowers of the field look coy and coquettish.
meaning_phrase: Said of a young person who wears a coquettish look when in the presence of one who rouses interest.

hawaiian_phrase: Haʻihaʻi nā iwi o ke kolohe.
english_phrase: Broken are the bones of the mischiefmaker.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is caught in mischief and given a trouncing.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāiki Kaʻula i ka hoʻokē a nā manu.
english_phrase: There isn’t room enough on the island of Kaʻula, for the birds are crowding.
meaning_phrase: It is overcrowded. Kaʻula is a bird-inhabited island beyond Niʻihau.

hawaiian_phrase: Haʻikū umauma, haʻi kū e!
english_phrase: Follow together, follow shouting!
meaning_phrase: An expression used by chiefs meaning, “Let us launch our canoes and go to war whether the other side is willing or not.” This is part of a chant used while transporting newly made canoes from the upland to the sea. A group of men walking abreast carried their burden and shouted this chant.

hawaiian_phrase: Haka kau a ka manu.
english_phrase: Perch on which birds rest.
meaning_phrase: A promiscuous woman.

hawaiian_phrase: Hakanū i nā luina Rusini.
english_phrase: Struck dumb in the presence of the Russian sailors.
meaning_phrase: Speechless with awe. When the early Russian ships came, some of the Hawaiians observed them in awed silence.

hawaiian_phrase: Haka ʻula a Kāne.
english_phrase: Kāne’s red perch.
meaning_phrase: A rainbow with red colors predominating.

hawaiian_phrase: Hakē ka paʻi ʻai o ka Malulani.
english_phrase: The Malulani is overloaded with bundles of hard poi.
meaning_phrase: An impolite reference to a pregnant woman. The Malulani was an inter-island ship.

hawaiian_phrase: Haki kākala o Piʻilani, ʻike pono ʻo luna iā lalo.
english_phrase: Roughness breaks in Piʻilani, those above recognize those below.
meaning_phrase: A storm breaks loose and those above — rain, lightning, thunder, wind — show their effects to the people below.

hawaiian_phrase: Hākoʻi wai a ka neki.
english_phrase: Water agitated among the rushes.
meaning_phrase: The throbbing of the heart of one in love at the sight of the object of his affection.

hawaiian_phrase: Hala i Kauaʻi i Kalalau.
english_phrase: Gone to Kalalau, on Kauaʻi.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is off-course mentally or is off gadding somewhere; a blunderer. A play on lalau (to go astray).

hawaiian_phrase: Hala i ke ala hoʻi ʻole mai.
english_phrase: Gone on the road from which there is no returning.
meaning_phrase: Death.

hawaiian_phrase: Hala i ke ala koʻiʻula a Kāne.
english_phrase: Gone on the sacred red trail of Kāne.
meaning_phrase: Death.

hawaiian_phrase: Hala i ke ala polihua a Kāne.
english_phrase: Gone on the trail to the bosom of Kāne.
meaning_phrase: Death.

hawaiian_phrase: Hala ka hoʻoilo; ua pau ka ua.
english_phrase: Winter is gone, the rain has ceased.
meaning_phrase: Hard times are over; weeping has stopped.

hawaiian_phrase: Hala ka Puʻulena aia i Hilo ua ʻimi akula iā Papalauahi.
english_phrase: The Puʻulena breeze is gone to Hilo in search of Papalauahi.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who has gone away or of one who finds himself too late to do anything.

hawaiian_phrase: Hala ka ua, ka mea makaʻu.
english_phrase: The rain we feared is gone.
meaning_phrase: The person we are afraid of is absent; we have nothing to worry about.

hawaiian_phrase: Halakau ka inanu i ka lāʻau.
english_phrase: The bird perches way up high in the tree.
meaning_phrase: Said of a man or woman who is not easily ensnared.

hawaiian_phrase: Hala nā lā ʻino o ka hoʻoilo.
english_phrase: Gone are the stormy days of winter.
meaning_phrase: Troublesome days are over.

hawaiian_phrase: Hala nō ia lā o ka pōloli.
english_phrase: A hungry day passes.
meaning_phrase: An expression of thankfulness that there was food for another day.

hawaiian_phrase: Hālau ka hale; ʻohā ka ʻai.
english_phrase: A big house; small taro to eat.
meaning_phrase: A large house brings so many visitors that to feed them all, even immature taro must be used.

hawaiian_phrase: Hālau Lahaina, malu i ka ʻulu.
english_phrase: Lahaina is like a large house shaded by breadfruit trees.
meaning_phrase: Said in scom to or of a person of low rank who assumes the air of a chief. A true chief (niu) is welcome every-where he goes; a pretender is only welcome in his own circle.

hawaiian_phrase: Hālāwai ke kila me ka paea.
english_phrase: Steel and flint meet.
meaning_phrase: When steel and flint come together, sparks result; so it is with two persons who cannot get along.

hawaiian_phrase: Hālawa, inu wai kūkae.
english_phrase: Hālawa drinker of excreta water.
meaning_phrase: An insult applied to the kauā of Hālawa, Molokaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Halemano honi palai o uka.
english_phrase: Halemano smells the ferns of the upland.
meaning_phrase: At Halemano, Oʻahu, the breezes bring the fragrance of ferns from the upland.

hawaiian_phrase: Hālō aku ma ʻō, he maka helei; kiʻei mai ma ʻaneʻi, he ʻoʻopa.
english_phrase: Peer over there and there is someone with a drawn-down eyelid; peep over here and here is a lame one.
meaning_phrase: No matter which way one turns there is a sign of bad luck.

hawaiian_phrase: Haluku ka ʻai a ke aku.
english_phrase: The aku rush to eat.
meaning_phrase: Said of those who boisterously rush to eat.

hawaiian_phrase: Halulu me he kapuaʻi kanaka lā ka ua o Hilo.
english_phrase: The rain of Hilo makes a rumbling sound like the treading of feet.
meaning_phrase: Be silent if you don’t want to be rebuked. The Waikoloa is a cold wind.

hawaiian_phrase: Hamahamau ka leo o ka Waikoloa.
english_phrase: Hush the voice of the Waikoloa wind.
meaning_phrase: Be silent if you don’t want to be rebuked. The Waikoloa is a cold wind.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāmākua ʻāina pali loa.
english_phrase: Hāmākua, land of tall cliffs.
meaning_phrase: Praise of Hāmākua, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāmākua i ka wakawaka.
english_phrase: Irregular and rough Hāmākua.
meaning_phrase: Praise of Hāmākua, a district of gulches and valleys.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāmākua i ke ala ʻūlili.
english_phrase: Hāmākua of the steep trails.
meaning_phrase: Praise of Hāmākua, a land of precipices and gulches where the old trails were often steep and difficult to travel on.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāmākua kihi loa.
english_phrase: Hāmākua with a long corner.
meaning_phrase: One corner of Hāmākua touches every district of Hawaiʻi except Puna. Also, a play on kihi loa. A native of Hāmākua is said to avoid meeting strangers. Because of bashfulness or disinclination to share his possessions, he will turn aside (kihi) and go a long way away (loa).

hawaiian_phrase: Hāmama ka waha he pō iʻa ʻole.
english_phrase: When the mouth yawns, it is a night on which no fish are caught.
meaning_phrase: A sleepy, yawning person isn’t likely to be out catching fish.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāmama nā paniwai o Kulanihākoʻi.
english_phrase: The lids of Kulanihākoʻi are removed.
meaning_phrase: Said about the home of a hospitable person. The food can be eaten without hearing a complaint from the owners, and the door is never closed to any visitor.

hawaiian_phrase: Hamohamo i ke kualā o Puna.
english_phrase: Pats the dorsal fin of Puna.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is verbally ambitious but does nothing to attain his goal, or of one who is full of flattery and false promises.

hawaiian_phrase: Hana a ke kama ʻole, hele ʻopeʻope i ke ala loa.
english_phrase: A person who has not raised a child may go along with his bundles on the road.
meaning_phrase: Said of an aged person who has no one to care for him. Had he troubled to rear children they could take care of him when he was old.

hawaiian_phrase: Hana a lau a lau ke aho, a laila loaʻa ka iʻa kāpapa o ka moana.
english_phrase: Make four hundred times four hundred fish lines before planning to go after the fighting fish of the sea.
meaning_phrase: Be well prepared for a big project.

hawaiian_phrase: Hana a mikioi, lawe a ʻauliʻi.
english_phrase: Be deft and dainty.
meaning_phrase: Said to young people: Be neat, sweet and clever — not crude and blundering.

hawaiian_phrase: Hana Hilo i ka poʻi a ka ua.
english_phrase: Hilo works on the lid of the rain.
meaning_phrase: Refers to the constant showers typical of Hilo district on Hawaiʻi. This is the first line of a chant.

hawaiian_phrase: Hānai ʻia i ka ʻiao.
english_phrase: Fed with ʻiao fish.
meaning_phrase: One is given small gifts to interest him until, like the deep-sea fish, he takes the hook and is landed. The ʻiao is a small fish used as a bait for large, deep-sea fish.

hawaiian_phrase: Hānai ʻia i ka poli o ka lima.
english_phrase: Fed in the palm of the hand.
meaning_phrase: Said of a child reared with constant attention.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāna i ka iʻa iki.
english_phrase: Hāna of the little fish.
meaning_phrase: Believing slanderous tales about Kuʻula and his wife, Hinahele, the ruling chief of Hāna ordered them destroyed. Having mana over the fish of the sea, the two caused a scarcity until their son ʻAiʻai brought them back to life. Kuʻula and Hinahele were worshipped as deities by fishermen.

hawaiian_phrase: Hānai holoholona, ʻaʻohe lohe i ka ʻohumu.
english_phrase: Feed animals and no complaints are heard.
meaning_phrase: A retort by one who is criticized for raising animals instead of children.

hawaiian_phrase: Hānai kanaka, hiki ke hoʻoūnauna.
english_phrase: Feed humans and one can send them on errands.
meaning_phrase: Said to people who adopt or take in children to raise. Children can be helpful.

hawaiian_phrase: Hana ʻino i ka ke kino ʻelemakule a hoʻomakua aku i ka haʻi.
english_phrase: Mistreat your own oldsters and the day may come when youll be caringfor someone else’s.
meaning_phrase: Said to a rude or ungrateful child. You should think of your own elder first, while he is alive, lest after his death you must take care of someone who had no part in rearing you.

hawaiian_phrase: Hana ʻiʻo ka haole!
english_phrase: The white man does it in earnest!
meaning_phrase: Hawaiians were generally easygoing and didn’t order people off their lands or regard them as trespassers. When the whites began to own lands, people began to be arrested for trespassing and the lands were fenced in to keep the Hawaiians out.

hawaiian_phrase: Hānai puaʻa wahine, ma loko ka uku.
english_phrase: Raise a sow, for her reward is inside of her.
meaning_phrase: A sow will bear young.

hawaiian_phrase: Hana ka iwi a kanaka makua, hoʻohoa.
english_phrase: First get some maturity into the bones before challenging.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who begins with much enthusiasm but soon loses interest.

hawaiian_phrase: Hana kāpulu ka lima, ʻai ʻino ka waha.
english_phrase: Careless work with the hands puts dirty food in the mouth.
meaning_phrase: He is a good worker but you have treated him with such thoughtlessness.

hawaiian_phrase: Hana ka uluna i ka paka ua.
english_phrase: Prepare the pillow when the raindrops appear.
meaning_phrase: Get ready for a period of rest. When a storm came, farming and fishing were suspended and the worker remained at home, either resting or doing little chores.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāna, mai Koʻolau a Kaupō.
english_phrase: Hāna, from Koʻolau to Kaupō.
meaning_phrase: The extent of the district of Hāna, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Hana mai nō a kā mai nō i ka ʻino.
english_phrase: He does for us, then he strikes us with evil.
meaning_phrase: Said of a kahuna who helps to heal and then, annoyed with the patient or patient’s family, asks the ʻaumakua to return the sickness.

hawaiian_phrase: Hana mao ʻole ka ua o Hilo.
english_phrase: Endlessly pours the rain of Hilo.
meaning_phrase: Said of anything that goes on and on, as the pouring rain, or of havoc such as that produced by a torrent. Names of other places are sometimes substituted for Hilo.

hawaiian_phrase: Hananeʻe ke kīkala o ko Hilo kini; hoʻi luʻuluʻu i ke one o Hanakahi.
english_phrase: The hips of Hilo’s multitude were sagging as they returned, laden, to Hanakahi.
meaning_phrase: Used to express the weight of grief, or to mean that a person has a heavy load to carry. Lines from a chant entitled, “Hoe Puna i ka Waʻa.”

hawaiian_phrase: Hānau ʻia i ka pō Lāʻau, lāʻau nā iwi, he koa.
english_phrase: Born was he on a Lāʻau night for his bones are hard and he is fearless.
meaning_phrase: Said of a bold, fearless person. Lāʻau nights are a group of nights in the lunar month. The days following each of these nights are believed to be good for planting trees.

hawaiian_phrase: Hānau ʻia i Kaulua, he koa wiwo ʻole.
english_phrase: Born in Kaulua, a warrior brave is he.
meaning_phrase: Said of one born in the month of Kaulua.

hawaiian_phrase: Hānau ka ʻāina, hānau ke aliʻi, hānau ke kanaka.
english_phrase: Born was the land, born were the chiefs, born were the common people.
meaning_phrase: The land, the chiefs, and the commoners belong together.

hawaiian_phrase: Hānau ke aliʻi i loko o Holoholokū, he aliʻi nui; hānau ke kanaka i loko o Holoholokū, he aliʻi nō; hānau ke aliʻi ma waho aʻe o Holoholokū, ʻaʻohe aliʻi, he kanaka ia.
english_phrase: The child of a chief born in Holoholokū is a high chief; the child of a commoner born in Holoholokū is a chief; the child of a chief born outside of the borders of Holoholokū is a commoner.
meaning_phrase: Holoholokū, sacred birthplace of the chiefs, is in Wailua, Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Haneoʻo amo one.
english_phrase: Sand-carrying Haneoʻo.
meaning_phrase: An epithet applied to the kauwā of Haneoʻo, Hāna, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Hanini ka wai o Kulanihākoʻi.
english_phrase: The water of Kulanihākoʻi spills.
meaning_phrase: It’s raining.

hawaiian_phrase: Hanohano nā pali kiʻekiʻe o Wailau.
english_phrase: Majestic are the tall cliffs of Wailau.
meaning_phrase: An expression of admiration for a stately and regal person. Refers to Wailau, Molokaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Hanohano Paliuli i ka ua noe.
english_phrase: Majestic is Paliuli in the misty rain.
meaning_phrase: An expression of admiration for a person. Paliuli is a mythical place in the mountain region back of the Panaʻewa forest, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Hanopilo ka leo o ka ʻalae.
english_phrase: Hoarse is the voice of the muelhen.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who talks himself hoarse.

hawaiian_phrase: Hanuʻu ke kai i Mokuola.
english_phrase: The sea recedes at Mokuola.
meaning_phrase: Now is the opportune time to venture forth. Mokuola, now known as Coconut Island, is a small island in Hilo Bay believed to have curative influences. The sick who swam around it recovered, and a person who could swim around it three times under water would have a long life. When the sea receded, one could swim part way around with little effort.

hawaiian_phrase: Haoʻe nā ʻale o Hōpoe i ka ʻino.
english_phrase: The billows of Hōpoe rise in the storm.
meaning_phrase: His anger is mounting. Hōpoe, Puna, has notoriously high seas.

hawaiian_phrase: Hao ka Inuwai, maloʻo ka lau lāʻau.
english_phrase: The Inuwai breeze blew, withering the leaves of the trees.
meaning_phrase: Along he came and nothing was left. The Inuwai (Drink-water) breeze is very drying.

hawaiian_phrase: Hao kōʻala ka makani lā, pau loa.
english_phrase: With one great sweep of wind, all is gone.
meaning_phrase: Said of the rise of temper.

hawaiian_phrase: Haole kī kōlea!
english_phrase: Plover-shooting haole!
meaning_phrase: Blundering Caucasian. Said in exasperation of a white person. The haole, in going plover hunting, shoots with his gun, killing some, maiming others. The maimed can fly elsewhere to die or become victims of some other animal. But the Hawaiian goes quietly at night with a net. He takes what he wants and lets the others escape unharmed.

hawaiian_phrase: Hao mai ka makani kuakea ka moana; hao mai ke kai kū ke koʻa i uka.
english_phrase: When the gales blow, the sea is white-backed; when the sea rises, corals are washed ashore.
meaning_phrase: Said of the rise of temper.

hawaiian_phrase: Hao nā kēpā o Līhuʻe i ke anu.
english_phrase: The spurs of Līhue dig in with cold.
meaning_phrase: Lihuʻe, Oʻahu, often gets very cold.

hawaiian_phrase: Hapa haole ʻiʻo ʻoniʻoni.
english_phrase: Half-white with quivering flesh.
meaning_phrase: What restless, active people these part-Caucasians are!

hawaiian_phrase: Hāpai ke kuko, hānau ka hewa.
english_phrase: When covetousness is conceived, sin is born.
meaning_phrase: It is applied to a conceited, proud, and self-centered person.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāpai kiʻekiʻe i ke aka o ʻAina-kō, kewekewe i ke ālia o Malaekoa.
english_phrase: Lified high is the shadow of ʻAina-kō, making crooked patterns on the salt-encrusted land of Malaekoa.
meaning_phrase: It is applied to a conceited, proud, and self-centered person.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāpala ʻia aʻela i ka hāwena.
english_phrase: Daubed with lime.
meaning_phrase: His hair may be gray, as one whose hair is bleached with lime, but he has no more wisdom than an inexperienced youth.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāpapa hewa ka malihini makamaka ʻole.
english_phrase: A stranger without a friend feels lost.
meaning_phrase: This was first uttered in a chant by Hiʻiaka, who, upon arriving at Kauaʻi to seek Lohiʻau, found no friendliness from his sister Kahuanui and her people.

hawaiian_phrase: Hapawalu liʻiliʻi, hāmani wale nō.
english_phrase: A small eighth of a dollar, very smooth to handle.
meaning_phrase: An eighth of a dollar is not a high price so one should not mind spending it.

hawaiian_phrase: Hauhili ka ʻai a ke kaweleʻā.
english_phrase: The kaweleʻā fish takes the hook in such a way as to tangle the lines.
meaning_phrase: Said of a tangled situation.

hawaiian_phrase: Haʻu ka makani, hāʻule ke onaona, pili i ka mauʻu.
english_phrase: When the wind puffs, the fragrant blossoms fall upon the grass.
meaning_phrase: When there is an explosion of wrath, people quail before it.

hawaiian_phrase: Haʻu ka waha i ka makani.
english_phrase: The mouth puffs at the wind.
meaning_phrase: Loud talk. Like the braying of an ass.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāʻule i ka hope waʻa.
english_phrase: Left in the aft of the canoe.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who comes last or is tardy.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāʻulelau i Kalalau, ʻo Lūaliʻi lā i Kauliʻiliʻi.
english_phrase: Hāʻulelau is at Kalalau, and Lūalii is at Kauliʻiliʻi.
meaning_phrase: Such a scattering all over the place, like fallen leaves, with bits and pieces all strewn about. A play on haule-lau (fallen leaves), kalalau (wander around), lū-aliʻi (scatter in pieces), and kau-liʻiliʻi (a little here and a little there).

hawaiian_phrase: Hāʻule nō i kāna ʻauwaha i ʻeli ai.
english_phrase: Fell into the ditch that he himself dug.
meaning_phrase: Caught in his own trap.

hawaiian_phrase: Haumanumanu ka ipu ʻinoʻino.
english_phrase: A misshapen gourd makes an ugly container.
meaning_phrase: Said of an ugly person. Also said in warning to a mother to be careful with the body of her baby — to mold it lest it be imperfect and ugly.

hawaiian_phrase: Haunaele ʻEwa i ka Moaʻe.
english_phrase: ʻEwa is disturbed by the Moaʻe wind.
meaning_phrase: Used about something disturbing, like a violent argument. When the people of ʻEwa went to gather the pipi (pearl oyster), they did so in silence, for if they spoke, a Moaʻe breeze would suddenly blow across the water, rippling it, and the oysters would disappear.

hawaiian_phrase: Hauna ke kai o ka moa liʻiliʻi.
english_phrase: Unsavory is the soup made of little chickens.
meaning_phrase: Said of or to a boy or girl who desires to make love when too young to know anything about it.

hawaiian_phrase: Hauna ke kai o ka palani.
english_phrase: The palani makes a strong-smelling soup.
meaning_phrase: A person of unsavory reputation imparts it to all he does.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāʻupu mauna kilohana i ka laʻi.
english_phrase: Hāʻupu, a mountain outstanding in the calm.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person of outstanding achievement. Also used in praise of Hāʻupu, Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Hau wawā ka nahele.
english_phrase: A din in the forest.
meaning_phrase: Rumors and gossip abroad.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāwaʻe kai nui.
english_phrase: Hāwaʻe full of liquid.
meaning_phrase: An ignoramus. Hāwaʻe is a short-spined sea urchin that is full of liquid and has no meat. Also expressed as Hāwaʻe ʻiʻo ʻole (meatless hāwaʻe).

hawaiian_phrase: Hawahawa ka lima.
english_phrase: The hand is smeared with filth.
meaning_phrase: From a children’s game in which one made a number of sand piles and buried filth in one of them. When a child dug into the sand and drew out a hand smeared with filth, the others shouted this. Also used to imply that one is taking part in a shady deal.

hawaiian_phrase: Hawahawa ka lima i ka haʻi kūkae.
english_phrase: The hand is only soiled by the excreta of others.
meaning_phrase: Sometimes said when an adopted child proves ungrateful or is taken away by its own parents. All one gets are soiled hands.

hawaiian_phrase: Hawaiʻi kuauli.
english_phrase: Hawaiʻi with the verdant country.
meaning_phrase: Keawe (Keawe-i-kekahi-aliʻi-o-ka-moku) was a ruler of Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Hawaiʻi nui a Keawe.
english_phrase: Hawaiʻi, great island of Keawe.
meaning_phrase: Keawe (Keawe-i-kekahi-aliʻi-o-ka-moku) was a ruler of Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Hawaiʻi palu lāʻī.
english_phrase: Ti-leaf lickers of Hawaii.
meaning_phrase: This saying originated after Kamehameha conquered the island of Oʻahu. The people of Kailua, Oʻahu, gave a great feast for him, not expecting him to bring such a crowd of people. The first to arrive ate up the meat, so the second group had to be content with licking and nibbling at the bits of meat that adhered to the ti leaves. In derision, the people of Oʻahu called them “ti-leaf lickers.”

hawaiian_phrase: Hāwāwā ka heʻe nalu haki ka papa.
english_phrase: When the surf rider is unskilled, the board is broken.
meaning_phrase: An unskilled worker bungles instead of being a help. There is also a sexual connotation: When the man is unskilled, the woman is dissatisfied.

hawaiian_phrase: Hāwele kīlau i ka lemu, ʻāhaʻi ka puaʻa i ka waha; ke hele nei ʻo Poʻokea.
english_phrase: Draw the fine loincloth under the buttocks; the pork finds its way into the mouth; Poʻokea now departs.
meaning_phrase: Poʻokea was a very clever thief during the reign of Kahekili of Maui. Whenever he eluded his pursuers, this was his favorite boast. Any reference to one as being a descendant or relative of Poʻokea implies that he is a thief who steals and runs.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻā ʻaki maunu.
english_phrase: An ʻā fish that takes the bait off the hooks.
meaning_phrase: A petty thief.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻaʻaliʻi kū makani mai au; ʻaʻohe makani nāna e kulaʻi.
english_phrase: I am a wind-resisting ʻaʻaliʻi; no gale can push me over.
meaning_phrase: A boast meaning “I can hold my own even in the face of difficulties.” The ʻaʻaliʻi bush can stand the worst of gales, twisting and bending but seldom breaking off or falling over.

hawaiian_phrase: He aha aku nei kau i Konahuanui?
english_phrase: What were you at Konahuanui for?
meaning_phrase: To dream of seeing the private parts exposed is a sign that there will be no luck on the following day.

hawaiian_phrase: He aha ka hala i kapuhia ai ka leo, i hoʻokuli mai ai?
english_phrase: What was the wrong that forbade the voice, that caused the deafness?
meaning_phrase: What causes you to refuse to speak or listen to me?

hawaiian_phrase: He aha ka puana o ka moe?
english_phrase: What is the answer to the dream?
meaning_phrase: What will the result of this be?

hawaiian_phrase: He aha kāu o ka lapa manu ʻole?
english_phrase: What are you doing on a ridge where no birds are found?
meaning_phrase: That is a wild goose chase.

hawaiian_phrase: He ahi ke kapa e mehana ai.
english_phrase: Fire is the garment for warmth.
meaning_phrase: Said of warmth received from a bonfire.

hawaiian_phrase: He āhole ka iʻa, hole ke aloha.
english_phrase: Āhole is the fish, love is restless.
meaning_phrase: Said of the āhole fish when used in hana aloha sorcery to arouse love.

hawaiian_phrase: Hea ʻia mai kēia kanaka, malia he inoa i loaʻa iā ʻoe.
english_phrase: Call an invitation to this person, perhaps you know the name.
meaning_phrase: A request to be called into someone’s home, usually uttered by a passing relative or friend who would like to pause and rest but is not sure that he is recognized by the others.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻai e kāhela ai ka uha.
english_phrase: An eating that spreads the intestines.
meaning_phrase: The enjoyment of a good meal when labor is finished and all is at peace.

hawaiian_phrase: He aikāne, he pūnana na ke onaona.
english_phrase: A friend, a nest of fragrance.
meaning_phrase: Sweet indeed is a good friend.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻai kuli ke aloha mai nā kūpuna mai.
english_phrase: Love has had a deaf way of its own since the days of the ancestors.
meaning_phrase: A person who is very much in love often does not heed counsel.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻai leo ʻole, he ʻīpuka hāmama.
english_phrase: Food unaccompanied by a voice; a door always open.
meaning_phrase: Said about the home of a hospitable person. The food can be eaten without hearing a complaint from the owners, and the door is never closed to any visitor.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻai make ka uhi.
english_phrase: The yam is the food of death.
meaning_phrase: The yam grows downward in the ground, instead of upward like the taro. When a person digs for yams, he has to be on the watch lest while digging with head down low an enemy strike him on the back of the neck and kill him.

hawaiian_phrase: He akua ʻai kahu ka lawena ʻōlelo.
english_phrase: Gossip is a god that destroys its keeper.
meaning_phrase: Pele was said to be fond of swimming and surfing. While doing so she would pause to eat seafood.

hawaiian_phrase: He akua ʻai ʻopihi ʻo Pele.
english_phrase: Pele is a goddess who eats limpets.
meaning_phrase: Pele was said to be fond of swimming and surfing. While doing so she would pause to eat seafood.

hawaiian_phrase: He akua ʻai pilau.
english_phrase: A filth-eating god.
meaning_phrase: Said of a god who heeds the voice of a sorcerer and goes on errands of destruction.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻakupa.
english_phrase: A black goby.
meaning_phrase: A derogatory epithet for a person with very dark skin.

hawaiian_phrase: He ala ʻehu aku kēnā.
english_phrase: That is an uncertain path.
meaning_phrase: The rain, the rainbow, and other signs seen when a chief is abroad are tokens of his recognition by the gods.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻalaʻihi kalaloa e pau ai nā lima i ke ʻekeʻeke.
english_phrase: An ʻalaʻihi kalaloa fish that makes one draw back his hands.
meaning_phrase: A person that is not to be trifled with. The ʻalaihi have spiny fins that can pierce the hands.

hawaiian_phrase: He ala iki ko kahuna.
english_phrase: A kahuna has a narrow trail.
meaning_phrase: A kahuna should mind and be careful of what he does.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻalalā, he manu leo nui.
english_phrase: It is the crow, a loud-voiced bird.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who talks too loud.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻalā makahinu i ke alo o ke aliʻi.
english_phrase: A shiny stone in the presence of a chief.
meaning_phrase: A person who assumes a bright or vivacious look in hypocrisy. A play on maka (eye) and hinu (bright).

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻalamihi no ka lae ʻiliʻili.
english_phrase: A mud crab on a rocky point.
meaning_phrase: Just a noisemaker.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻale kua loloa no ka moana.
english_phrase: A long-backed wave of the ocean.
meaning_phrase: The boast of a strong man who likens his back to the waves of the sea.

hawaiian_phrase: He aliʻi ka ʻāina; he kauā ke kanaka.
english_phrase: The land is a chief; man is its servant.
meaning_phrase: Land has no need for man, but man needs the land and works it for a livelihood.

hawaiian_phrase: He aliʻi ka laʻi, he haku na ke aloha.
english_phrase: Peace is a chief the lord of love.
meaning_phrase: Where peace is, there love abides also.

hawaiian_phrase: He aliʻi ka maʻi, he aliʻi ke kahuna.
english_phrase: The patient is a chief; the kahuna is a chief.
meaning_phrase: The medical kahuna usually had a servant to do the work of fetching and preparing the herbs he prescribed for his patient. Thus the servant served both kahuna and patient. Often the person who gathered the herbs was an apprentice learning the art from the kahuna.

hawaiian_phrase: He aliʻi ka manu.
english_phrase: A bird is a chief.
meaning_phrase: A bird flies and perches higher than any human.

hawaiian_phrase: He aliʻi ka moa.
english_phrase: The rooster is a chief.
meaning_phrase: His feathers are used in kāhili, which are the symbols of chiefs.

hawaiian_phrase: He aliʻi ke aloha, he kilohana e paʻa ai.
english_phrase: Love is like a chief: the best prize to hold fast to.
meaning_phrase: Said in admiration of a tall, well-formed person.

hawaiian_phrase: He aliʻi ke aloha, he ʻohu no ke kino.
english_phrase: Love is chiefy, an adornment for the person.
meaning_phrase: Uttered by Hiʻiaka in a chant to the sister of Lohiʻau.

hawaiian_phrase: He aliʻi kia manu.
english_phrase: A chief that catches birds with a gummed pole.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who draws people to him. From a song for Kalākaua, who was known to attract people.

hawaiian_phrase: He aliʻi no ka malu kukui.
english_phrase: A chief of the kukui shade.
meaning_phrase: A chief who has something shady in his genealogy that he doesn’t care to discuss.

hawaiian_phrase: He aliʻi nō mai ka paʻa a ke aliʻi; he kanaka nō mai ka paʻa a ke kanaka.
english_phrase: A chief from the foundation of chiefs; a commoner from the foundation of commoners.
meaning_phrase: A chief is a chief because his ancestors were; a commoner is a commoner because his ancestors were. Often said to a young person of chiefly lineage to warn that if he wishes to preserve the rank of his descendants, he should see that his mate is of chiefly rank and not a commoner.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻaloʻalo kuāua no kuahiwi.
english_phrase: One who faced the mountain showers.
meaning_phrase: A brave person.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻāloʻiloʻi, ka iʻa waha iki o ke kai.
english_phrase: An ʻāloʻiloʻi, a fish of the sea that has a small mouth.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who always has little to say.

hawaiian_phrase: He ana ka manaʻo o ke kanaka, ʻaʻole ʻoe e ʻike iā loko.
english_phrase: The thoughts of man are like caves whose interiors one cannot see.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who helps a lost person find his way home. The goddess Kaiona, who lived in the Waiʻanae Mountains of Oʻahu, was said to have pet birds who could guide anyone lost in the forest back to his companions.

hawaiian_phrase: He ao hākumakuma wale nō, ʻaʻohe ua.
english_phrase: It is only a lowering, and there will not be any rain.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who frowns and glowers but does nothing to hurt.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻaʻo ka manu noho i ka lua, ʻaʻole e loaʻa i ka lima ke nao aku.
english_phrase: It is an ʻaʻo, a bird that lives in a burrow and cannot he caught even when the arm is thrust into the hole.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who is too smart to be caught.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻaʻo kani kohā ke aliʻi.
english_phrase: The chief is like a loud-voiced ʻaʻo.
meaning_phrase: Said of the mother of an only child.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻapu ʻauhuhu kōheoheo.
english_phrase: A poisonous concoction made of ʻauhuhu.
meaning_phrase: A person of poisonous nature.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻauhau kōʻele na ka Hawaiʻi.
english_phrase: A taxing of small fields by the Hawaii chiefs.
meaning_phrase: After Kamehameha united the islands, even the smallest food patch was taxed.

hawaiian_phrase: He au holo a ka ʻōlohelohe.
english_phrase: A running place for the naked one.
meaning_phrase: Used when one is disappointed in an undertaking. To dream of nakedness is an omen of bad luck.

hawaiian_phrase: He au Koʻolau aku ia.
english_phrase: That is Koʻolau weather.
meaning_phrase: The Koʻolau, or windward, side of an island is often storm-beaten. This expression was first used in a chant to Hiʻiaka by Wahineʻomaʻo, who pleaded with her not to let her wrath lead to destruction. Later used as a warning that headstrong wilfulness leads to distress.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻaumakua hoʻoluhi, hōʻapaʻapa i ke kahuna.
english_phrase: An ʻaumakua that does not help is a burden to the kahuna.
meaning_phrase: Prophesied by David Malo.

hawaiian_phrase: He aupuni ko Kamehameha.
english_phrase: Kamehameha has a government.
meaning_phrase: A warning not to steal. Kamehameha united the islands and made laws that gave everyone peace and safety. Killing and stealing were utterly prohibited.

hawaiian_phrase: He aupuni palapala koʻu; ʻo ke kanaka pono ʻo ia koʻu kanaka.
english_phrase: Mine is the kingdom of education; the righteous man is my man.
meaning_phrase: Uttered by Kamehameha III.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻauwai ka manaʻo o nā aliʻi, ʻaʻohe maopopo kahi e kahe ai.
english_phrase: The minds of chiefs are like a ditch — no one knows whither they flow.
meaning_phrase: No one knows whom or what the chiefs will favor.

hawaiian_phrase: Hea wawalo ke kai o ʻOʻokala.
english_phrase: The sea of ʻOʻokala sends forth an echoing call.
meaning_phrase: Said in humor of any loud call. A play on ʻO (hail) and kala (proclaim).

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻeʻepa ke aloha, he kulaʻilua.
english_phrase: Love is peculiar; it pushes in opposite directions.
meaning_phrase: Love goes two ways — to love and to be loved.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻehu wāwae no kalani.
english_phrase: A trace of the heavenly one’s footsteps.
meaning_phrase: The rain, the rainbow, and other signs seen when a chief is abroad are tokens of his recognition by the gods.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻelele ka moe na ke kanaka.
english_phrase: A dream is a bearer of messages to man.
meaning_phrase: A letter. It brings messages but does not speak.

hawaiian_phrase: He hāʻawe pili.
english_phrase: Carriers of bundles of pili grass.
meaning_phrase: A derogatory saying by the followers of Kamehameha for the people of Kaʻū, who covered the road of Kapaukua with pili grass for their chief Keouakuahuʻula.

hawaiian_phrase: He hālau a hālau ko ka niu, hoʻokahi nō hālau o ka niuniu.
english_phrase: The coconut tree has many shelters to go to; but the person who merely aspires has but one.
meaning_phrase: Said in scom to or of a person of low rank who assumes the air of a chief. A true chief (niu) is welcome every-where he goes; a pretender is only welcome in his own circle.

hawaiian_phrase: He hālau loa na ʻĪ.
english_phrase: A longhouse belonging to ʻĪ.
meaning_phrase: ʻĪ was a wise and generous chief and because he was an ancestor of many, he was referred to as the owner of the longhouse in which all were sheltered. ʻĪ also had a large longhouse in Hilo called ʻĪ-hālau, and a fish station at sea called ʻĪ-koʻa. It is said that when those of ʻĪ-hālau closed their food bowls all at once after eating, the sound could be heard at ʻĪ-koʻa.

hawaiian_phrase: He hale kanaka, ke ʻalalā ala no keiki, ke hae ala no ka ʻīlio.
english_phrase: It is an inhabited house, for the wail of children and the bark of a dog are heard.
meaning_phrase: The signs of living about a home are the voices of humanity and animals. Used in answer to someone’s apology over their children crying or dogs barking.

hawaiian_phrase: He hale ke kino no ka manaʻo.
english_phrase: The body is a house for the thoughts.
meaning_phrase: Said of a weakling.

hawaiian_phrase: He hale kipa nō lā hoʻi ko ke kōlea haʻihaʻi ʻē ʻia nā iwi.
english_phrase: The house of a plover might have been that of a friend if one hadn’t broken his bones.
meaning_phrase: A stranger might have been a friend if he hadn’t been treated so shamefully.

hawaiian_phrase: He hamo hulu puna ma waho.
english_phrase: A brushing on the outside with whitewash.
meaning_phrase: A friendly exterior only.

hawaiian_phrase: He hānai aliʻi, he ʻai ahupuaʻa.
english_phrase: The rearing of a chief is the ruling of an ahupuaʻa.
meaning_phrase: A person in whose care a young chief was placed was often rewarded with a large tract of land.

hawaiian_phrase: He hana maka ʻenaʻena.
english_phrase: A work that causes red, hot eyes.
meaning_phrase: A task that requires so much work it deprives one of sleep.

hawaiian_phrase: He hāpuʻu ka ʻai he ʻai make.
english_phrase: If the hāpuʻu is the food, it is the food of death.
meaning_phrase: When famine came many depended on hāpuʻu to sustain life, but it required much work to prepare. There was the cutting, the preparation of the imu, and three whole days during which the hāpuʻu cooked. If the food was done then, hunger was stayed; if not, there was another long delay, and by that time someone may have starved to death.

hawaiian_phrase: He hauʻoli ka ukali o ka lanakila.
english_phrase: Gladness follows in the wake of victory.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person of outstanding achievement. Also used in praise of Hāʻupu, Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: He Hawaiʻi ʻuala Kahiki.
english_phrase: An Irish-potato Hawaiian.
meaning_phrase: A term of derision applied to a native Hawaiian who apes the ways of the whites instead of appreciating the culture of his own people. Also said to one who is absolutely ignorant of his own culture.

hawaiian_phrase: He heʻe hōlua.
english_phrase: One who rides a hōlua sled.
meaning_phrase: Said proudly of being a descendant of the chiefly families of Waipiʻo, Hawaiʻi, who were well known for their skill in hōlua sledding.

hawaiian_phrase: He heʻe ka iʻa, he iʻa kino palupalu.
english_phrase: It is an octopus, a soft-bodied creature.
meaning_phrase: Said of a weakling.

hawaiian_phrase: He heʻe nui, ke ʻula ala.
english_phrase: It is a large octopus because it shows a red color.
meaning_phrase: A man went to farm one day and met another squatting carelessly as he worked. He made this remark, often used later to refer to a man who exposes himself.

hawaiian_phrase: He hele pīlali ʻāina maoli nō.
english_phrase: A sticky going, as if stuck fast to the land.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is preoccupied and forgets to go home.

hawaiian_phrase: He hiʻi alo ua milimili ʻia i ke alo, ua hāʻawe ʻia ma ke kua, ua lei ʻia ma ka ʻāʻī.
english_phrase: A beloved one, fondled in the arms, carried on the back, whose arms have gone ahout the neck as a lei. Said of a beloved child.
meaning_phrase: Refers to food containers that were carried suspended from poles.

hawaiian_phrase: Hehi i ka pili.
english_phrase: Trample on the relationship.
meaning_phrase: To abolish or disown the relationship.

hawaiian_phrase: He hikuhiku nā kini akua.
english_phrase: The host of gods are many, many.
meaning_phrase: There are none higher than the gods.

hawaiian_phrase: He hilu na ke aliʻi.
english_phrase: A hilu belonging to a chief.
meaning_phrase: When a pregnant woman longed for hilu fish, the child born to her would be a very quiet, well-behaved person. Because chiefs liked reserved, well-mannered people, such persons were often found in the royal courts, and were referred to as the chief’s hilu fish.

hawaiian_phrase: He hina na ka ʻaʻaliʻi kūmakani, he ʻulaʻa pū me ka lepo.
english_phrase: When the wind-resisting ʻaʻaliʻi falls, it lifts the sod up with its roots.
meaning_phrase: A boast: When I, a powerful man, fall, others will fall with me.

hawaiian_phrase: He hōʻailona ke ao i ʻike ʻia.
english_phrase: Clouds are recognized signs.
meaning_phrase: The glory of the land has departed. Also, the person is dead.

hawaiian_phrase: He hoa ʻai waiū paha no Kauahoa.
english_phrase: Perhaps he shared the breast with Kauahoa.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is indifferent to the problems of others. A play on uahoa (hard) in Kauahoa, a warrior of Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: He hoa ka ua no Alakaʻi.
english_phrase: The rain is a companion to Alakaʻi.
meaning_phrase: Alaka’i, Kauaʻi, does not lack rain.

hawaiian_phrase: He hoa kuilima no Lāʻauhaele.
english_phrase: A companion to walk hand in hand with at Lāʻauhaele.
meaning_phrase: An interesting, friendly companion. A play on haele (go together). Refers to Lāʻauhaele, Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: He hoa manu nēnē, he hoʻi nō a paumāʻele i ka hale.
english_phrase: A goose mate returns to pollute the house.
meaning_phrase: Said to a mate whose relative disgraces the family by committing fornication or adultery with another member.

hawaiian_phrase: He hoa ʻōhumuhumu.
english_phrase: A companion to whom one can voice one’s woes.
meaning_phrase: An expression of admiration for a good-looking person.

hawaiian_phrase: He hoapili o Mākālei.
english_phrase: A companion of Mākālei.
meaning_phrase: Said of an attractive person.

hawaiian_phrase: He hōʻike na ka pō.
english_phrase: A revelation of the night.
meaning_phrase: A revelation from the gods in dreams, visions, and omens.

hawaiian_phrase: He hoʻīlina ka make no ke kino.
english_phrase: Death is an inheritance for the hody.
meaning_phrase: Kāne was the god of fresh water and life.

hawaiian_phrase: He honu ka ʻāina he mea paneʻe wale.
english_phrase: Land is like a turtle: it moves on.
meaning_phrase: Land passes slowly but inexorably from owner to heir.

hawaiian_phrase: He honu maeaea akula ia.
english_phrase: It is a māeaea variety of turtle.
meaning_phrase: He is a stinker. A play on māeaea (unpleasant smelling).

hawaiian_phrase: He hoʻokahi no wai o ka like.
english_phrase: All dyed with the same color.
meaning_phrase: Identical.

hawaiian_phrase: He hoʻokele waʻa no ka lā ʻino.
english_phrase: A canoe steersman for a stormy day.
meaning_phrase: A courageous person.

hawaiian_phrase: He hoʻolua pikaʻo.
english_phrase: Food that has to be recooked.
meaning_phrase: Similar to the expression “half-baked.”

hawaiian_phrase: He hou moe kāheka.
english_phrase: A hou fish that sleeps in a sea pool.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who snores. The hou when sleeping makes a snoring sound.

hawaiian_phrase: He hou ʻoe, he iʻa moe ahiahi.
english_phrase: You are a hou, a fish that sleeps in the evening.
meaning_phrase: A small, inoffensive fellow — but one who will fight when annoyed.

hawaiian_phrase: He hua kahi.
english_phrase: A single seed.
meaning_phrase: An only child.

hawaiian_phrase: He huakaʻi paoa, he pili i ka iwi.
english_phrase: An unlucky journey in which the body was wagered.
meaning_phrase: Suffering.

hawaiian_phrase: He huewai ola ke kanaka na Kāne.
english_phrase: Man is Kāne’s living water gourd.
meaning_phrase: Water is life and Kāne is the keeper of water. To dream of a well-filled water gourd that breaks and spills its contents is a warning of death for someone in the family.

hawaiian_phrase: He hulu aliʻi.
english_phrase: Royal feathers.
meaning_phrase: Said of the adornment of a chief, or of an elderly chief himself who is one of a few survivors of his generation and therefore precious.

hawaiian_phrase: He huluhulu kau i ka puka ihu.
english_phrase: Hair growing inside of the nostril.
meaning_phrase: Said in envy of a person who is regarded as a favorite by a superior — he is so closely allied to the person that he is likened to a hair in the other’s nostril. Also said in criticism of one who is made too much of.

hawaiian_phrase: He hulu makua.
english_phrase: A feather parent.
meaning_phrase: When most of the relatives of the parents’ generation were gone, the few left were referred to as hulu mākua and considered as precious and choice as feathers. Hulu can refer to relatives as far back as three generations.

hawaiian_phrase: He hupo no ka waʻa pae.
english_phrase: A stupid one belonging to the canoe landing.
meaning_phrase: Little skill is required to get a canoe out of the water at a landing. Said of one whose knowledge is very shallow and whose skill is practically nil.

hawaiian_phrase: He iʻa ia no Kahoʻolawe, he uku.
english_phrase: It is the fish of Kahoʻolawe, the uku.
meaning_phrase: He shall be made to pay. A play on uku (reward or recompense).

hawaiian_phrase: He iʻa i pā i ka makau.
english_phrase: A fish that had once taken a hook.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person made wary by an unpleasant experience.

hawaiian_phrase: He iʻa kokoke kā ka lawaiʻa.
english_phrase: A fisherman always finds fish nearby.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who can get what he wants because he is smart.

hawaiian_phrase: Hei akula i ka ʻupena kuʻu a ka Lawakua.
english_phrase: Caught in the drawnet of the Lawakua breeze.
meaning_phrase: Ensnarled by beguiling words.

hawaiian_phrase: He iʻa laka ka loli kaʻe, he loaʻa wale i kāheka.
english_phrase: The loli kaʻe is easy enough to gather, for it is found in sea pools.
meaning_phrase: Said of a cross, dissatisfied person who becomes grumpy. A play on kaʻe (grumpy) in loli kaʻe (sea cucumber).

hawaiian_phrase: He iʻa laka nō lā hoʻi ka ʻina.
english_phrase: The ʻina is easily gathered.
meaning_phrase: A retort to a person who frequently says, “If I had this” or “If I had that.” A play on ʻina (sea egg) and inā (if).

hawaiian_phrase: He iʻa loaʻa wale nō hoʻi ka poʻopaʻa.
english_phrase: A poʻopaʻa is a fish easy to catch.
meaning_phrase: Hard-headed people are fairly common. A play on poʻopaʻa (hard-headed).

hawaiian_phrase: He iʻa make ka ʻopihi.
english_phrase: The ʻopihi is a fish of death.
meaning_phrase: The ʻopihi is usually found on rocks where the sea is rough. There is always danger of being washed away by the waves when gathering ʻopihi.

hawaiian_phrase: He iʻa moʻa ʻole i kālua.
english_phrase: A fish that can never he cooked.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person of low rank. Nothing can change his genealogy.

hawaiian_phrase: He iʻa no ka moana, he aho loa kū i ke koʻa.
english_phrase: A fish of the deep sea requires a long line that reaches the sea floor.
meaning_phrase: In order to obtain a good position, one must prepare.

hawaiian_phrase: He iʻa no ka pāpaʻu, he loaʻa wale i ka hopu lima; he iʻa no ka hohonu, noho i kaʻeaʻea.
english_phrase: Fish of the shallows are easy to catch with the hands; but fish of the depths keep the fisherman wet with sea sprays.
meaning_phrase: Ordinary folks are easy to find but an outstanding one is not.

hawaiian_phrase: He iʻa no ke kai kohola.
english_phrase: A fish of the shallow sea.
meaning_phrase: A person easy to woo.

hawaiian_phrase: He iʻa pae wale no kaʻuwīʻuwī.
english_phrase: The ʻuwīʻuwī is a fish that washes ashore.
meaning_phrase: Said of a ne’er-do-well who goes from house to house and depends on others for his livelihood.

hawaiian_phrase: He iʻa ua nipoa i ka ʻauhuhu.
english_phrase: A fish stunned by ʻauhuhu juice.
meaning_phrase: Said of one under the influence of sorcery or other evils.

hawaiian_phrase: He ihona, he piʻina, he kaolo.
english_phrase: A going down, a going up, a going on a level road.
meaning_phrase: So it is with life.

hawaiian_phrase: He ikaika ke kanaka kaena i ka wā pilikia ʻole, akā he hōhē wale i ka lā o ka pilikia.
english_phrase: A braggart is strong when there is no trouble, but flees when there is.
meaning_phrase: Said of friends who will laugh and play in the moonlight but who will not lend a hand when daylight and labor come.

hawaiian_phrase: He ikaika nō nā ʻehu kakahiaka no nā ʻōpio, a piʻi aʻe ka lā heha mai a holo.
english_phrase: The morning is full of strength for youth, but when the sun is high they become tired and run.
meaning_phrase: Said of the young who do not work as persistently as their parents — they start well but soon quit.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻike ʻana ia i ka pono.
english_phrase: It is a recognizing of the right thing.
meaning_phrase: One has seen the right thing to do and has done it.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻike nāwele.
english_phrase: A scanty vision.
meaning_phrase: To be hardly able to see or to have very scanty knowledge of anything.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻike pāpālua.
english_phrase: Dual knowledge.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is gifted with extra-sensory perception or second sight.

hawaiian_phrase: He iki ʻaʻaliʻi kū makani o Piʻiholo.
english_phrase: A small, wind-resisting ʻaʻaliʻi bush of Piʻiholo.
meaning_phrase: A small but powerful person.

hawaiian_phrase: He iki hala au no Keaʻau, ʻaʻohe pōhaku ʻalā e nahā ai.
english_phrase: I am a small hala fruit of Keaʻau, but there is no rock hard enough to smash me.
meaning_phrase: The boast of a Puna man — I am small, perhaps, but mighty.

hawaiian_phrase: He iki huna lepo mai kēia e pula ai ka maka.
english_phrase: This is a small speck of dust that causes a roughness in the eye.
meaning_phrase: One may be small but he can still cause distress. This was the retort of Kaʻehuiki, a shark-god of Puna, when he was taunted for his small size by Kaiʻanuilalawalu, shark-god of Kīpahulu, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: He iki moʻolelo na ke kuhi wale.
english_phrase: A small tale told by a guesser.
meaning_phrase: Said in contempt of a fabricator of stories.

hawaiian_phrase: He iki nīoi no Pakaʻalana.
english_phrase: A small nīoi of Pakaʻalana.
meaning_phrase: A small but very powerful person. The nīoi, the ʻohe, and the kauila were the kinds of trees entered by the poison gods Kāneikaulanaʻula and Kahuilaokalani, and Kapo, a goddess, at Maunaloa, Molokaʻi. The trees were later cut down and made into images.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻīlio kawaū.
english_phrase: A damp, cold dog.
meaning_phrase: Used disparagingly or humorously of a person who shivers and is afraid of the cold. Dogs in old Hawaiʻi were rarely pampered and petted and were often seen shivering in cold, damp weather.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻīlio welu moe poli.
english_phrase: A well-fed dog that sleeps in the bosom.
meaning_phrase: Said of a well-fed pet dog or of a person who is able to work but is too pampered to want to.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻili puakea.
english_phrase: Skin like a white blossom.
meaning_phrase: Said of a white person.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻimi aliʻi, he aliʻi nō ke loaʻa; he ʻimi kanaka, he kanaka no ke loaʻa.
english_phrase: When a chief is sought, a chief is begotten; when a commoner is sought, a commoner is begotten.
meaning_phrase: A reminder to a chief seeking a mate to consider the rank of his offspring.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻimi haku.
english_phrase: A person who seeks a lord.
meaning_phrase: Priests and others were known to go in search of a worthy chief to serve.

hawaiian_phrase: He imu pale ʻole; huikau ka nohona.
english_phrase: An uncovered oven; abiding in confusion.
meaning_phrase: Like an imu in which each kind of food is not set apart in its own place, but piled in helter skelter, so is a promiscuous and careless family.

hawaiian_phrase: He imu puhi na ka lā o Kalaʻe.
english_phrase: Kalaʻe is made a steaming oven by the sun.
meaning_phrase: At Kalaʻe, Molokaʻi, stood an imu that was said to have baked the rain, making it a dry place.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻīnaʻi na ka wela a ka lā.
english_phrase: Meat consumed by the heat of the sun.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who has a severe case of sunburn.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻiniki me ka wawalu ka ʻeha a kamaliʻi.
english_phrase: All the hurt that a child can infict is by pinching and scratching.
meaning_phrase: An expression of ridicule said to or of one considered to be no stronger than a child.

hawaiian_phrase: He inoa ʻala.
english_phrase: A fragrant name.
meaning_phrase: Said of a chief whose reputation is good.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻio au, ʻaʻohe lālā kau ʻole.
english_phrase: I am a hawk; there is no branch on which I cannot perch.
meaning_phrase: I can go anywhere I please; I am a chief.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻio au, he manu i ka lewa lani.
english_phrase: I am an ʻio, the bird that soars in the heavenly space.
meaning_phrase: A boast. The highest chiefs were often called ʻio (hawk), king of the Hawaiian birds.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻio ʻoe, he ʻio au, he ʻio nā ʻānela o ke akua, kiʻi maila nō iā ʻoe a lawe.
english_phrase: You are a hawk, I am a hawk, and the angels of God are hawks.
meaning_phrase: Uttered by Hitchcock, a missionary, over the coffin of a sorcerer who had threatened to pray him to death and referred to himself as an ʻio, the bird that flies the highest.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻio poʻi moa.
english_phrase: Chicken-catching hawk.
meaning_phrase: Said of a clever thief or of one who steals the sweetheart of another.

hawaiian_phrase: He ipu hoʻoilina mai nā kupuna mai.
english_phrase: An inherited container from the remotest ancestress.
meaning_phrase: Said of the womb, the container by which the family line continues.

hawaiian_phrase: He ipu kāʻeo.
english_phrase: A full calabash.
meaning_phrase: A knowledgeable person. Also expressed ʻUmeke kaeo.

hawaiian_phrase: He ipu pala ʻole.
english_phrase: A calabash without a dah [of poi ] in it.
meaning_phrase: An ignoramus. Also expressed ʻUmeke pala ʻole.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻiwa hoʻohaehae nāulu.
english_phrase: An ʻiwa that teases the rain clouds.
meaning_phrase: A beautiful maiden or handsome youth who rouses jealous envy in others.

hawaiian_phrase: He iwi koko.
english_phrase: Blooded bones.
meaning_phrase: A living person.

hawaiian_phrase: He iwi koko ʻole.
english_phrase: Bloodless bones.
meaning_phrase: A dead person.

hawaiian_phrase: He iwi maloʻo.
english_phrase: Dried bones.
meaning_phrase: Said of one long dead. Sometimes when it was felt that a dead person was the cause of trouble for a living one, the kahuna or person in charge would so refer to the deceased.

hawaiian_phrase: He kāʻeʻaʻeʻa pulu ʻole no ka heʻe nalu.
english_phrase: An expert on the surfboard who does not get wet.
meaning_phrase: Praise of an outstanding surfer.

hawaiian_phrase: He kaha luʻu ke ala, mai hoʻokolo aku.
english_phrase: The trail leads to a diving place; do not follow after.
meaning_phrase: A warning to leave well enough alone.

hawaiian_phrase: He kāhiko hoʻokahakaha nō ia kula.
english_phrase: Finery belonging to the plain, put on display.
meaning_phrase: Said of a place when the blooming season arrives, or of a person dressed in fine array.

hawaiian_phrase: He kai ʻaʻai ko Kaʻaʻawa.
english_phrase: Kaʻaʻawa has a sea that wears away the land.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person whose loyalty is doubtful — he can be swayed to desert his chief.

hawaiian_phrase: He kai ʻāhiu ko Kahana.
english_phrase: A wild sea has Kahana.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Kahana, Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: He kai ʻalamihi ko Leleiwi.
english_phrase: A sea for black crabs has Leleiwi.
