meaning_phrase: Leleiwi Point in Hilo was said to be a good place to find ʻalamihi.

hawaiian_phrase: He kai heʻe nalu ko Kahaloa.
english_phrase: Kahaloa has a sea for surfng.
meaning_phrase: Also said of the rain of Hilo.

hawaiian_phrase: He kai hele kohana ko Māmala.
english_phrase: A sea for going naked is at Māmala.
meaning_phrase: The entrance to Honolulu Harbor was known as Māmala. In time of war the people took off their clothes and traveled along the reef to avoid meeting the enemy on land.

hawaiian_phrase: He kai hului ko Kālia.
english_phrase: A sea for fishing with a draw net is the sea of Kālia.
meaning_phrase: The water at Kālia is very shallow.

hawaiian_phrase: He kai kapu ia na ke konohiki.
english_phrase: A forbidden beach reserved for the konohiki.
meaning_phrase: A maiden who is spoken for.

hawaiian_phrase: He kai lū lehua ko Panaʻewa.
english_phrase: Panaʻewa shakes down the lehua fringes into the sea.
meaning_phrase: Once, when the forest of Panaʻewa extended to the sea, fringes of lehua blossoms were seen floating about in the water.

hawaiian_phrase: He kai ʻō heʻe ko Kapapa.
english_phrase: A sea for octopus fishing has Kapapa.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Kapapa, Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: He kai puhi nehu, puhi lala ke kai o ʻEwa.
english_phrase: A sea that blows up nehu fish, blows up a quantity of them, is the sea of ʻEwa.
meaning_phrase: Said of an unkept promise of food, fish, etc. Oʻahu was once peopled by evil beings who invited canoe travelers ashore with promises of food and other things. When the travelers asked when these things were coming, this was the reply. When the visitors were fast asleep at night, the evil ones would creep in and kill them.

hawaiian_phrase: He kaikamahine ke keiki, ola nā iwi; ʻo ke keiki kāne he hānai mākua hūnōai.
english_phrase: A girl child brings life to the bones [of her parents], but a boy child supports his parents-in-law.
meaning_phrase: In old Hawaiʻi, a man went to live with his wife’s parents, while a woman remained with her own.

hawaiian_phrase: He kākalaioa.
english_phrase: A kākalaioa plant.
meaning_phrase: An unpleasant person. The kākalaioa (gray nickers) is a thorny plant.

hawaiian_phrase: He Kākea, ka makani kulakulaʻi kauhale o Mānoa.
english_phrase: It is the Kākea, the wind that pushes over the houses of Mānoa.
meaning_phrase: Applied to one who goes about shoving others around. The Kākea was the strongest wind of the valley.

hawaiian_phrase: He Kalaʻe au, he ʻaʻe kū.
english_phrase: I am a native of Kalaʻe, I step over.
meaning_phrase: Molokaʻi, who would not take second place to a visiting chief, no matter how much higher his rank. If a visiting chief lay down in his way, the Kalaʻe chief would step over him, disregarding the visitor’s kapu.

hawaiian_phrase: He kalo paʻa.
english_phrase: Unpounded taro.
meaning_phrase: A spinster or a bachelor.

hawaiian_phrase: He kama na ka pueo.
english_phrase: Offspring of an owl.
meaning_phrase: A child whose sire is unknown, so called because the owl flies at night.

hawaiian_phrase: He kanaka no ka malu kukui.
english_phrase: A person from the kukui tree shade.
meaning_phrase: A person of uncertain parentage; one who has in his veins the blood of chiefs as well as commoners. Similar to Kūkae pōpolo (Excreta of the pōpolo berries [that have been eaten]).

hawaiian_phrase: He kanaka no kaulu hānai.
english_phrase: A man from the top of the cliff.
meaning_phrase: Praise of a hero.

hawaiian_phrase: He kāne ʻeha ʻole o ka ʻili.
english_phrase: A husband who does not inflict pain on his wife.
meaning_phrase: Said by a wife in appreciation for a husband who never beats her.

hawaiian_phrase: He kanu Mahoemua, he kalo pūʻali.
english_phrase: When one plants in [the month of] Mahoemua, he will have irregularly shaped taro.
meaning_phrase: Said of an imperfect or defective task, or of a person whose ideas are “half-baked.”

hawaiian_phrase: He kapa maloʻo wale ka ʻili.
english_phrase: The skin is a garment that dries easily.
meaning_phrase: Being wet is nothing to worry about.

hawaiian_phrase: He kāpili manu no ka uka o ʻŌlaʻa he pipili mamau i ka ua nui.
english_phrase: A birdcatching gum of the upland of ʻŌlaʻa that sticks and holds fast in the pouring rain.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who holds the interest and love of a sweetheart at all times.

hawaiian_phrase: He kapu nā pōhaku hānau aliʻi.
english_phrase: A [sign of[ kapu are the stones at the birth of a chief.
meaning_phrase: The peal of thunder heralds the birth of a high chief. Thunder (pōhaku) was likened to the sound of stones rolling.

hawaiian_phrase: He kaua kaikamahine.
english_phrase: A girl’s battle.
meaning_phrase: A battle that ends quickly. A kaua keikikāne (boy’s battle) requires a lot of skill and strength to bring it to an end.

hawaiian_phrase: He kaua kamaliʻi, he hoʻohē wale.
english_phrase: A battle by children shows much fear.
meaning_phrase: When fighting, children give up too soon and cry.

hawaiian_phrase: He kau auaneʻi i ka lae ʻaʻā.
english_phrase: Watch out lest the canoe land on a rocky reef.
meaning_phrase: Watch out for trouble.

hawaiian_phrase: He kauā ke kanaka na ke aloha.
english_phrase: Man is a slave of love.
meaning_phrase: Kāʻana is a place between Keaʻau and ʻŌlaʻa where travelers used to rest and make lei of lehua. It took many blossoms and much patience to complete a lei. The lei was later given to a loved one.

hawaiian_phrase: He kawa ia naʻu i lele a ʻopu.
english_phrase: That is a diving place in which I dived without making a splash.
meaning_phrase: Said of something that is easy to do because one is accustomed to doing it.

hawaiian_phrase: He kā waiho hoʻohemahema.
english_phrase: A bail left unnoticed.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who could be of help because of his skill and knowledge but is overlooked, like an unused canoe bail.

hawaiian_phrase: He keʻa puaʻa maka ʻolelepā.
english_phrase: A fierce rooting hog.
meaning_phrase: A warrior fierce in battle.

hawaiian_phrase: He Keʻei ʻoe no lalo lilo.
english_phrase: You are a person of Keʻei, from far below.
meaning_phrase: You are of no consequence. Two chiefesses peered into a pool together at Keʻei, in Kona, Hawaiʻi. The reflection of the one from Hanauma appeared above that of the one from Keʻei, so she made this remark.

hawaiian_phrase: He kēhau hoʻomaʻemaʻe ke aloha.
english_phrase: Love is like cleansing dew.
meaning_phrase: Love removes hurt.

hawaiian_phrase: He keiki aloha nā mea kanu.
english_phrase: Beloved children are the plants.
meaning_phrase: It is said of farmers that their plants are like beloved children, receiving much attention and care.

hawaiian_phrase: He keiki e nānā ana, he keiki e nānā ʻole ana.
english_phrase: One child may care, and another may not.
meaning_phrase: Said to one who raises a family — some may take care of the senior members of the family and some may not.

hawaiian_phrase: He keiki kālai hoe na ka uka o Puʻukapele.
english_phrase: A paddle-making youth of Puuʻkapele.
meaning_phrase: A complimentary expression. He who lives in the uplands, where good trees grow, can make good paddles Puʻukapele is a place above Waimea Canyon on Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: He keiki kāmehaʻi.
english_phrase: A wonder child.
meaning_phrase: Said of a child whose father is unknown — people wonder who the sire is.

hawaiian_phrase: He keiki mea kupuna.
english_phrase: [It shows] that the child has a grandparent.
meaning_phrase: Said in admiration of a child whose grandparents show affection by making beautiful things for his use or compose songs and chants in his honor. A similar expression is He keiki mea makua: [It shows] that the child has a parent.

hawaiian_phrase: He kekē niho wale iho nō.
english_phrase: Just an exposing of teeth.
meaning_phrase: Just threats.

hawaiian_phrase: He keu a ka hoʻomaoe!
english_phrase: Such hinting!
meaning_phrase: Said to a person who hinted his liking for another’s possessions; one was obliged to say, “Take it, I give it to you.” Such a hinting person was disliked, and favorite possessions were hidden away when he approached.

hawaiian_phrase: He keʻu na kaʻalae a Hina.
english_phrase: A croaking by Hina’s mudhen.
meaning_phrase: A warning of trouble. The cry of a mudhen at night is a warning of distress.

hawaiian_phrase: He kīhei loloa.
english_phrase: A long shoulder covering.
meaning_phrase: A person who gads about with no thought of going home. The speaker envisions a person constantly running with his cape fluttering high in the breeze.

hawaiian_phrase: He kiʻi ke kanaka noho wale o kahi aliʻi.
english_phrase: Only an image sits [and does no work] in the household of a chief.
meaning_phrase: In the house of a chief, everybody but the chief himself works.

hawaiian_phrase: He kino pāpālua.
english_phrase: A dual-formed person.
meaning_phrase: Said of a supernatural being having two or more forms, or of one who is “possessed” by intoxicants.

hawaiian_phrase: He kiu ka pua kukui na ka makani.
english_phrase: The kukui blossoms are a sign of wind.
meaning_phrase: When the kukui trees shed their blossoms, a strong wind is blowing.

hawaiian_phrase: He koaʻe, manu o ka pali kahakō.
english_phrase: It is the koaʻe, bird of the sheer cliffs.
meaning_phrase: An expression of admiration for an outstanding person. The koaʻe build their nests on cliffs.

hawaiian_phrase: He koa ka mea hele hoʻokahi i ʻOʻopuloa.
english_phrase: Only a warrior dares to go alone to ʻOʻopuloa.
meaning_phrase: Said of a venture fit only for the brave. The way to ʻOʻopuloa, Maui, was feared because of robbers.

hawaiian_phrase: He koaiʻe.
english_phrase: A koaiʻe tree.
meaning_phrase: A humorous epithet for an upland country person.

hawaiian_phrase: He koʻe ka pule a kahuna, he moe nō a ʻoni mai.
english_phrase: The prayer of a kahuna is like a worm; it may lie dormant but it will wriggle along.
meaning_phrase: Though the prayer of a kahuna may not take effect at once, it will in time.

hawaiian_phrase: He koholua ʻoi ke aliʻi.
english_phrase: A sharp-pointed piercing implement is the chief.
meaning_phrase: A warning that one who tampers with a chief will be hurt.

hawaiian_phrase: He kohu puahiohio i ka hoʻolele i ka lepo i luna.
english_phrase: Like a whirlwind, whirling the dust upward.
meaning_phrase: Said of a commoner who makes an attempt to elevate himself so he will be regarded as a chief.

hawaiian_phrase: He koʻokoʻo haki wale.
english_phrase: A staff that breaks easily.
meaning_phrase: A weak leader.

hawaiian_phrase: He koali, he pākaʻawili.
english_phrase: He is like a morning-glory vine, twisting this way and that.
meaning_phrase: Said of an unstable, changeable person who says one thing now and another thing later.

hawaiian_phrase: He kua ʻā.
english_phrase: An ignited back.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person whose back is so kapu that no one is permitted to walk behind him.

hawaiian_phrase: He kuapuʻu no a he kuapuʻu, like ka ʻōlelo ana.
english_phrase: A hunchback and a hunchback have the same things to talk ahout.
meaning_phrase: Equals speak the same language and understand each other.

hawaiian_phrase: He kui nao hemo ʻole i ke kala.
english_phrase: A screw that a screwdriver can not remove.
meaning_phrase: A fixed idea in a stubbom mind; something that nothing can undo.

hawaiian_phrase: He kūkae kā ke kahu hānai.
english_phrase: Excrement belongs to foster parents.
meaning_phrase: Said in anger when a foster child shows ingratitude or when his own parents take him away from those who reared him.

hawaiian_phrase: He kū kahi au, he wauke no Kūloli.
english_phrase: I stand alone, for I am a wauke plant of Kūloli.
meaning_phrase: A boast — “Like the lone wauke plant of Kūloli, I stand alone in my battles.” At Kūloli, in Kona, Hawaiʻi, grew a lone wauke plant around which none other grew.

hawaiian_phrase: He kukuluaeʻo.
english_phrase: A stilt.
meaning_phrase: A thin, long-legged person.

hawaiian_phrase: He kūmū ka iʻa, muʻemuʻe ke aloha.
english_phrase: Kūmū is the fish, bitter is love.
meaning_phrase: An expression used in hana aloha sorcery. It was uttered with the hope that the intended victim would be as conscious of love as of a bitter drop on the tongue.

hawaiian_phrase: He kumu kukui i heʻe ka pīlali.
english_phrase: A kukui tree oozing with gum.
meaning_phrase: A prosperous person.

hawaiian_phrase: He kumu kukui palahuli wale i ka makani Kona.
english_phrase: A kukui tree, easily toppled over by the Kona wind.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is easily vanquished by a stronger opponent.

hawaiian_phrase: He kumu lehua muimuia i ka manu.
english_phrase: A lehua tree covered with birds.
meaning_phrase: An attractive person. A lehua tree in bloom attracts birds as an attractive person draws the attention of others.

hawaiian_phrase: He lāʻau kū hoʻokahi, he lehua no Kaʻala.
english_phrase: A lone tree, a lehua of Kaʻala.
meaning_phrase: An expression of admiration for an outstanding person, unequaled in beauty, wisdom, or skill.

hawaiian_phrase: He lāʻau maka no ka nāhelehele.
english_phrase: A green wood of the forest.
meaning_phrase: An inexperienced person.

hawaiian_phrase: He lā koa, he lā heʻe.
english_phrase: A day to be brave, a day to flee.
meaning_phrase: In life, there is triumph and defeat. In war, there is winning and losing.

hawaiian_phrase: He lālā kamahele no ka lāʻau kū i ka pali.
english_phrase: A far-reaching branch of the tree standing on the cliff.
meaning_phrase: A boast of a strong person who, like the tree on the cliff, can withstand gales and pouring rain.

hawaiian_phrase: He lani i luna, he honua i lalo.
english_phrase: Heaven above, earth beneath.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who owns his own property, or of one who is sure of his security. The sky above him and the earth beneath his feet are his.

hawaiian_phrase: He lani ke keiki, he milimili na ka makua.
english_phrase: The child is a chief to be fondled by the parents.
meaning_phrase: A child requires as much care as a chief.

hawaiian_phrase: He lauhala lana.
english_phrase: Floating pandanus Ieaves.
meaning_phrase: Said of people who drift from place to place; worthless vagabonds.

hawaiian_phrase: He lauhau, he iʻa hōkake kāheka.
english_phrase: It is a lauhau, the fish that creates disturbances in sea pools. Said of a boisterous person.
meaning_phrase: Said when one tries to find out something about another and meets with failure at every turn. A play on place names: ʻū (a grunt of contempt) in Kaʻū; hemo (to get away) in Palahemo; kā (to run along like a vine) in Manukā; and leinapueo (owl’s leaping place) in Kaleinapueo.

hawaiian_phrase: He laukona ke kō, konākonā ke aloha.
english_phrase: Laukona is the sugar cane; love is despised.
meaning_phrase: Laukona sugar cane was often used to force the victim of hana aloha sorcery. Instead of falling madly in love, the victim grew to dislike the subject.

hawaiian_phrase: He lau maiʻa pala ka wahine, hou aku nō ʻoe, pōhae.
english_phrase: A woman is like a yellowed banana leaf that tears when one pokes at it.
meaning_phrase: A woman does not have the strength of a man.

hawaiian_phrase: He lawaiʻa Kaukini na ke kia manu.
english_phrase: Kaukini is a fishing place for the birdcatchers.
meaning_phrase: Kaukini at Waipiʻo, Hawaiʻi, was a place where in ancient times bird-catchers caught birds in nets. This was called lawaiʻa manu (bird-fishing).

hawaiian_phrase: He lawaiʻa no ke kai pāpaʻu, he pōkole ke aho; he lawaiʻa no ke kai hohonu he loa ke aho.
english_phrase: A fisherman of the shallow sea uses only a short line; a fisherman of the deep sea has a long line.
meaning_phrase: A person whose knowledge is shallow does not have much, but he whose knowledge is great, does.

hawaiian_phrase: He lawaiʻa no ke kai pāpaʻu, he poʻopaʻa ka iʻa e loaʻa.
english_phrase: A fisherman in the shallow sea can only catch poʻopaʻa.
meaning_phrase: An untrained, unskilled person is limited in what he can do.

hawaiian_phrase: He lawaiʻa paoa.
english_phrase: A luckless fisherman.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is unlucky in fishing or in gaining the attention of a desired member of the opposite sex.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele a ʻīlio pīʻalu ka uka o Hāmākua i ka lā.
english_phrase: Like a wrinkled dog is the upland of Hāmākua in the sunlight.
meaning_phrase: An uncomplimentary remark about an aged, wrinkled person. Line from a chant.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele a kahu ka ʻena.
english_phrase: He has gone into [the state of] tending the red-hot stones.
meaning_phrase: He is very angry.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele akula a ahu, hoʻi mai nō e omo i ka waiū o ka makua.
english_phrase: He goes away and, gaining nothing by it, returns to nurse at his mother’s breast.
meaning_phrase: Said of a grown son or daughter who, after going away, returns home for support.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele aku nei e ʻimi i ka ʻiliʻili hānau o Kōloa.
english_phrase: Went to seek the pebbles that give birth at Kōloa.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who goes and forgets to come home. These pebbles were found at a small beach called Kōloa, in Punaluʻu, Kaʻū.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele aku ʻoe ma ʻaneʻi, he waʻa kanaka; hoʻi mai ʻoe ma ʻō he waʻa akua.
english_phrase: When you go from here, the canoe will contain men; when you return, it will be a ghostly canoe.
meaning_phrase: Warning to Keouakuahuʻula by his kahuna not to go to meet Kamehameha at Kawaihae. He went anyway and was killed.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele a luhiehu i ka ua noe.
english_phrase: Is made bright by the misty rain.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person dressed gaily.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele a nono i ka wai.
english_phrase: He looks red in the water.
meaning_phrase: He is as attractive as the fringes of lehua floating in the water.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele ʻē ka pila, hele ʻē ka leo.
english_phrase: The music is in one pitch and the voice in another.
meaning_phrase: Said of a lack of harmony.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele ʻē ka waʻa.
english_phrase: The speed of a canoe.
meaning_phrase: Said of a fast traveler.

hawaiian_phrase: He leho hou kēia, ke ola nei nō ka ʻiʻo.
english_phrase: This is a fresh cowry; the flesh is still alive.
meaning_phrase: A warning that a new idea or plan may turn out badly. When the animal in a shell dies, a stench results.

hawaiian_phrase: He lehua neneʻe wale i Hōpoe.
english_phrase: A low spreading lehua tree at Hōpoe.
meaning_phrase: A petite person, as pretty as a small, flower-laden tree.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele huhū ke ahi me ka momoku.
english_phrase: Angrily goes the fire and the firebrand.
meaning_phrase: Said of lightning and thunder.

hawaiian_phrase: He lei poina ʻole ke keiki.
english_phrase: A lei never forgotten is the beloved child.
meaning_phrase: Kohala is a windy place.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele ke poʻo a pōnaʻanaʻa.
english_phrase: The head moves in a confused manner.
meaning_phrase: In a state of having so much to do one doesn’t know where to start.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele i Kaunakakai i Hikauhi.
english_phrase: Go to Kaunakakai to seek Hikauhi.
meaning_phrase: After a time she returned with their daughter, whom they named Hikauhi.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele i ke ala maʻawe iki.
english_phrase: Gone on the barely visible trail.
meaning_phrase: Dead.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele ka hoʻi a hiki i Kealia, ua napoʻo ka lā.
english_phrase: When one reaches Kealia at last, the sun is set.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who procrastinates. A play on alia (to wait).

hawaiian_phrase: Hele ka makuahine, ʻalalā keiki i kauhale.
english_phrase: When the mother goes out, the children cry at home.
meaning_phrase: Said of a neglectful mother.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele kapalulu ke ahi me ka momoku a kukupaʻu i ke kai o Nuʻalolo.
english_phrase: The crackling firebrands make a great display over the sea of Nualolo.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who makes himself very conspicuous.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele kīkaha aʻela ka ua.
english_phrase: The rain goes sneaking along.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who goes out of his way to avoid an acquaintance.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele kīkaha ka ua o Hokukoʻa.
english_phrase: The rain of Hokukoʻa goes quietly by.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who goes by without dropping in to see his friends.

hawaiian_phrase: He lele pā iki kau ka manaʻo; ke aloha kamaliʻi he lālau nō.
english_phrase: [An adult] lets his fancy take fight and touches lightly while a child lover reaches out directly.
meaning_phrase: An adult lover dreams, plans, and gently woos; a child is clumsy in his lovemaking.

hawaiian_phrase: He lele pā iki — ke aloha kamaliʻi.
english_phrase: A light touch — so is love among children.
meaning_phrase: Children may imagine themselves in love, but it is only a passing fancy — puppy love. Not so is the love of a mature person.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele nō i ka hola iʻa i ka lā.
english_phrase: Fish poison should he used in the daytime.
meaning_phrase: Greater efficiency is achieved in the daytime. [cf 1158]

hawaiian_phrase: Hele nō ka ʻalā, hele nō ka lima.
english_phrase: The rock goes, the hand goes.
meaning_phrase: To make good poi, the free hand must work in unison with the poi pounder. Keep both hands going to do good work.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele nō ka lima; hele nō ka ʻāwihi; ʻaʻohe loaʻa i ke onaona maka.
english_phrase: The hand goes; the wink goes; nothing is gained by just looking sweet.
meaning_phrase: Keep the hands occupied with work, then one can afford to make eyes at the opposite sex. Just looking attractive isn’t enough.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele nō ka pilau a ke ālia, i kahi nui o ka paʻakai.
english_phrase: Decomposition can also he found where there is so much salt that the earth is encrusted.
meaning_phrase: Scandal is found even in the best of families.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele nō ka wai, hele nō ka ʻalā, wali ka ʻulu o Halepuaʻa.
english_phrase: The water flows, the smooth stone [pounder] works, and the breadfruit of Halepuaʻa is well mixed [into poi].
meaning_phrase: Everything goes smoothly when one is prosperous. A play on wai (water) and ʻalā (smooth stone). ʻAlā commonly refers to cash. In later times, Hele nō ka wai, hele nō ka ʻalā came to refer to a generous donation. Halepuaʻa is a place in Puna, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele nō ke aliʻi; hele nō ke kanaka.
english_phrase: Where the chief goes, his attendant goes.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who goes in circles and gets nowhere. Waimea, Hawaiʻi, is a cold place and when foggy, it is easy for one unfamiliar with the place to lose his way.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele pōʻala i ke anu o Waimea.
english_phrase: Going in a circle in the cold of Waimea.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who goes in circles and gets nowhere. Waimea, Hawaiʻi, is a cold place and when foggy, it is easy for one unfamiliar with the place to lose his way.

hawaiian_phrase: He lepo ka ʻai a Oʻahu, a māʻona nō i ka lepo.
english_phrase: Earth is the food of Oʻahu, and it is satisfied with its earth.
meaning_phrase: Said in derision of Oʻahu, which was said to be an earth-eating land. In olden times, an edible mud like gelatine was said to fill Kawainui Pond. The mud, which was brought hither from Kahiki in ancient days, was once served to the warriors and servants of Kamehameha as a replacement for poi.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele pū nō me ka lima.
english_phrase: Take the hands along in going traveling.
meaning_phrase: Be willing to help others when going traveling and not make a burden of yourself.

hawaiian_phrase: Hele wale a lulu i nā manu.
english_phrase: The birds are so numerous that they cast a shade.
meaning_phrase: Said of a great crowd of people.

hawaiian_phrase: He lihi nō paha i laila, ke ʻeuʻeu nei ka puapua.
english_phrase: Perhaps [he] has some rights there, to wag his tail feathers [the way he does].
meaning_phrase: He wouldn’t be acting with such confidence if he weren’t related to or a friend of the person higher up.

hawaiian_phrase: He liʻiliʻi ka ʻuku lele, naue naʻe kino nui.
english_phrase: A flea may be small but it can make a big body squirm.
meaning_phrase: Never belittle anyone because of his small body; he may be able to do big things.

hawaiian_phrase: He like nō ke koʻele, ʻo ka pili naʻe he like ʻole.
english_phrase: The thumping sounds the same, but the fitting of the parts is not.
meaning_phrase: Some do good work, others do not; but the hustle and bustle are the same.

hawaiian_phrase: He liko aliʻi.
english_phrase: A royal leaf bud.
meaning_phrase: An offspring of a chief.

hawaiian_phrase: He limu ke aloha, he pakika i ke one o Mahamoku.
english_phrase: Love is like the slippery moss on the sand of Mahamoku.
meaning_phrase: One can fall in love before he realizes it.

hawaiian_phrase: He lohe ke ola, he kuli ka make.
english_phrase: To hear is life, to turn a deaf ear is death.
meaning_phrase: It pays to heed sound advice.

hawaiian_phrase: He lohe ʻōlelo iā Kalehuawehe, he ʻike maka iā Kuaokalā.
english_phrase: Have only heard of Kalehuawehe, but have seen Kuaokalā.
meaning_phrase: That is only hearsay so I do not know much about it; but this I have seen and know about.

hawaiian_phrase: He lōʻihi ʻo ʻEwa; he pali ʻo Nuʻuanu; he kula ʻo Kulaokahuʻa; he hiki mai koe.
english_phrase: ʻEwa is a long way off; Nuuanu is a cliff; Kulaokahu a is a dry plain; but all will be here before long.
meaning_phrase: Said of an unkept promise of food, fish, etc. Oʻahu was once peopled by evil beings who invited canoe travelers ashore with promises of food and other things. When the travelers asked when these things were coming, this was the reply. When the visitors were fast asleep at night, the evil ones would creep in and kill them.

hawaiian_phrase: He loko kapu ia, he awa ka iʻa noho; eia kā ua komo ʻia e ke ʻā kōkokī.
english_phrase: It was a pond reserved only for awa fish, but now a bait-stealing ʻā fish has gotten into it.
meaning_phrase: A woman who is the wife of a fine man of chiefly rank is now having an affair with a worthless scamp.

hawaiian_phrase: He lokomaikaʻi ka manu o Kaiona.
english_phrase: Kind is the bird of Kaiona.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who helps a lost person find his way home. The goddess Kaiona, who lived in the Waiʻanae Mountains of Oʻahu, was said to have pet birds who could guide anyone lost in the forest back to his companions.

hawaiian_phrase: He loli ka iʻa, ʻīloli ke aloha.
english_phrase: Loli is the sea creature, passionate is the love.
meaning_phrase: An expression used in hana aloha sorcery when loli was secured as an offering.

hawaiian_phrase: He lolo nō a he lolo, paʻi wale.
english_phrase: One is from the zenith, the other is from the zenith; therefore equals.
meaning_phrase: They are equally high in rank.

hawaiian_phrase: He lono ma mua, he kulina ma hope; kulikuli wale ka makani o Kaʻū!
english_phrase: Report went first, heedlessness followed; what a din the wind of Kaʻū raised!
meaning_phrase: From a chant for Kaumualiʻi of Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: He luelue ka ʻupena e kuʻu ai.
english_phrase: The fine-meshed net is the one to let down into the sea.
meaning_phrase: A fine-meshed net misses nothing, big or small. In seeking wealth, the small things are just as important as the big ones.

hawaiian_phrase: He lupe lele a pulu i ka ua ʻawa.
english_phrase: A kite that flies till it is dampened by icy cold raindrops.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person whose station has risen very high.

hawaiian_phrase: He luʻu no ke kai paeaea, ʻaʻohe he luʻu no kai mālolo.
english_phrase: [He is] a diver of the sea where pole fishing is done and not a diver of the sea where fiying fishes are caught.
meaning_phrase: He does have some knowledge but it is not deep enough to show greater skill.

hawaiian_phrase: Hemahema Kahuwā me Waimea.
english_phrase: Kahuwā and Waimea are awkward.
meaning_phrase: These places are in the upland, where people are said to be awkward in handling canoes.

hawaiian_phrase: Hemahema nō ka ʻiole, mikimiki ka ʻowau.
english_phrase: When the rat is careless, the cat comes around.
meaning_phrase: Be on guard.

hawaiian_phrase: He maiʻa ke kanaka a ka lā e hua ai.
english_phrase: A man is like a banana tree on the day it bears its fruit.
meaning_phrase: When a man’s body was removed from a grave, a banana stalk was laid in to take its place.

hawaiian_phrase: He maiʻa līlā, ʻaʻohe ʻiʻo.
english_phrase: A thin banana without substance.
meaning_phrase: Not worth troubling about. Maiʻa can refer to either the fruit or the plant.

hawaiian_phrase: He maiʻa ua paʻa i ke koʻo.
english_phrase: A banana tree well supported by props.
meaning_phrase: A man well supported by his followers.

hawaiian_phrase: He maʻi makamaka ʻole.
english_phrase: The disease that deprives one of relatives and friends.
meaning_phrase: Leprosy.

hawaiian_phrase: He maʻi nui ka hilahila.
english_phrase: Humiliation is a great disease.
meaning_phrase: Shame and humiliation can make one sick at heart.

hawaiian_phrase: He maʻi ola ʻole i kahuna.
english_phrase: A sickness that no kahuna can heal.
meaning_phrase: A play on maʻi, which refers to either a sickness or the genitals. Diseases can be cured by a kahuna, but gender is something that no kahuna can change.

hawaiian_phrase: He maʻi piʻi aliʻi ke aloha.
english_phrase: Love is a disease that does not even spare the chiefs.
meaning_phrase: A term of ridicule for a small boy who acts like a grownup. Until a boy was old enough to enter the mua (men’s eating house), he wore no malo.

hawaiian_phrase: He maka lehua no kona one hānau.
english_phrase: One who has the face of a warrior [loyal and honored] in his birthplace.
meaning_phrase: An expression of humbleness acknowledging the superiority of another.

hawaiian_phrase: He makamaka, ke pā lā kāhea.
english_phrase: That is a friend, for he calls out an invitation.
meaning_phrase: It was the custom to call out an invitation as a visitor approached.

hawaiian_phrase: He makani Kona, ke kū lā ke aʻe i ka moana.
english_phrase: It is the Kona wind, for the sprays are flying at sea.
meaning_phrase: Said of a raging temper.

hawaiian_phrase: He makau hala ʻole.
english_phrase: A fishhook that never fails to catch.
meaning_phrase: A boast of a person who attracts the opposite sex and holds his or her attention.

hawaiian_phrase: He mālama pūʻolo.
english_phrase: A keeper of bundles.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who keeps objects of worship, such as human bones, pieces of wood, stones, etc., and sends them in spirit to do his bidding.

hawaiian_phrase: He Malanai wale nō kēia.
english_phrase: It is only the gentle Malanai breeze.
meaning_phrase: It is only a superficial thing.

hawaiian_phrase: He mālolo.
english_phrase: A flyng fish
meaning_phrase: A person who goes from lover to lover.

hawaiian_phrase: He mamo na Hālō me Kiʻei.
english_phrase: A descendant of Peep and Peer.
meaning_phrase: Said of a snoopy person.

hawaiian_phrase: He mamo na Kamapuaʻa.
english_phrase: A descendant of Kamapuaʻa.
meaning_phrase: Said of a man who behaves like a beast, especially where women are concemed. Kamapuaʻa was the hog god of Kaliuwaʻa. There are many stories about his pursuit of women.

hawaiian_phrase: He mamo na Lohiʻau.
english_phrase: A descendant of Lohiʻau.
meaning_phrase: A slowpoke.

hawaiian_phrase: He mamo na Waʻawaʻa mā.
english_phrase: A descendant of the Waʻawaʻa brothers.
meaning_phrase: A fool.

hawaiian_phrase: He mamo paha na ka poʻe o Kahuwā he maʻa i ka hoe ma ke kūnihi.
english_phrase: Perhaps they are descendants of the people of Kahuwā who were in the habit of paddling with the edge of the paddle blade.
meaning_phrase: They are stupid people who never do things right.

hawaiian_phrase: He manini ka iʻa mai hōʻā i ke ahi.
english_phrase: The fish is just a manini, so do not light a fire.
meaning_phrase: Said to one who suffers defeat in a practice session: “This occasion is a mere manini, a small fish, so do not let your temper be kindled.”

hawaiian_phrase: He manō holo ʻāina ke aliʻi.
english_phrase: The chief is a shark that travels on land.
meaning_phrase: The chief, like a shark, is not to be tampered with.

hawaiian_phrase: He manō ka iʻa hoʻomano ke aloha.
english_phrase: Shark is the fish; may love be persistent.
meaning_phrase: An expression used in hana aloha sorcery. A play on manō and hoʻomano (persistent).

hawaiian_phrase: He mano kuli, he iʻa kāhala.
english_phrase: It is a reckless and heedless kāhala fish.
meaning_phrase: Said of a disobedient person. The kāhala is a deep-sea fish that is difficult to land.

hawaiian_phrase: He manu hānai ke kanaka na ka moe.
english_phrase: Man is like a pet bird belonging to the realm of sleep.
meaning_phrase: Dreams are very important. By them, one is guided to good fortune and warned of misfortune. Like a pet bird, man is taken care of.

hawaiian_phrase: He manu hulu.
english_phrase: A feathered bird.
meaning_phrase: A prosperous person.

hawaiian_phrase: He manu ke aloha, ʻaʻohe lālā kau ʻole.
english_phrase: Love is like a bird — there is no branch that it does not perch upon.
meaning_phrase: Love is an emotion shared by all.

hawaiian_phrase: He maoli pua lehua i ka wēkiu.
english_phrase: An attractive lehua blossom on the topmost branch.
meaning_phrase: An attractive person.

hawaiian_phrase: He māʻona ʻai a he māʻona iʻa ko ka noanoa.
english_phrase: The commoner is satisfed with food and fish.
meaning_phrase: The commoner has no greater ambition than success in farming and fishing.

hawaiian_phrase: He māʻona moku.
english_phrase: A satisfaction with the land.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person contented with what he has, as a chief is satisfied with his domain.

hawaiian_phrase: He mau iwi māmā ko ke kanaka o ke aliʻi.
english_phrase: The servant of a chief has bones that are light of weight.
meaning_phrase: He who serves the chief must be active and alert.

hawaiian_phrase: He māʻukaʻuka hoe hewa.
english_phrase: An uplander, unskilled in wielding the paddle.
meaning_phrase: Said of an awkward person who blunders along, or of a man who is clumsy in lovemaking.

hawaiian_phrase: He mau maka laha ʻole.
english_phrase: Faces that are rare.
meaning_phrase: Said by members of the royal court in speaking of their chiefs with appreciation for the privilege of serving. The faces of the aliʻi were rarely seen.

hawaiian_phrase: He maunu ʻekaʻeka; pāpaʻi ka iʻa e hoʻi ai.
english_phrase: With foul bait one can only catch crabs.
meaning_phrase: Poor output makes poor income.

hawaiian_phrase: He mea ʻai ʻia kahi pilipili maunu kāpae ʻia.
english_phrase: The bit of bait set to one side is edible still.
meaning_phrase: A man or woman who has been the mate of another can still be a good mate to have.

hawaiian_phrase: He mea aloha ʻia ke kāne i ka ʻili.
english_phrase: The husband of the skin is to be loved.
meaning_phrase: One’s husband, who is as close as the skin of one’s body, should always be loved. The term for a husband who is always near, in joy and in sorrow, is “Kāne i ka ʻili.” Such a wife is “ Wahine i ka ʻili.”

hawaiian_phrase: He mea ʻao lūʻau ʻia ke kānāwai.
english_phrase: A law [of an ʻaumakua] can be removed with an offering of cooked taro leaves.
meaning_phrase: An ʻaumakua could be propitiated by offering taro leaves and prayers for forgiveness.

hawaiian_phrase: He mea laha ʻole.
english_phrase: Not spread everywhere.
meaning_phrase: A thing rare. A not uncommon expression in songs and chants.

hawaiian_phrase: He mea mahamahana no ka lehelehe.
english_phrase: Something warm for the lips.
meaning_phrase: A tasty morsel for gossip.

hawaiian_phrase: He meheuheu mai nā kūpuna.
english_phrase: Habits acquired from ancestors.
meaning_phrase: Do not discuss your ancestors too freely with strangers, for it is like exposing their bones for all to see.

hawaiian_phrase: He milo ka lāʻau, mimilo ke aloha.
english_phrase: Milo is the plant; love goes round and round.
meaning_phrase: Said of the milo tree when its leaves, blossoms, or seeds were used by a kahuna who practices hana aloha sorcery.

hawaiian_phrase: He moa kani ao ia, a pō kau i ka haka.
english_phrase: He is a cock that crows in the daytime, but when night comes he sits on a perch.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who brags of what he can do, but when difficulties come he is the first to remove himself from the scene.

hawaiian_phrase: He moʻa no ka ʻai i ka pūlehu ʻia; he ahi nui aha ia e hoʻā ai?
english_phrase: Food can be cooked in the embers; why should a big fire be lighted?
meaning_phrase: A small love affair will do; why assume the responsibilities of a permanent mating? Said by those who prefer to love and leave.

hawaiian_phrase: He moe kai no Kaʻaʻawa.
english_phrase: A sleeper in the sea of Kaʻaʻawa.
meaning_phrase: Applied to a lawbreaker who was to be put to death. When Kualiʻi was ruler of Oʻahu, he punished lawbreakers by drowning them in the sea of Kaʻaʻawa.

hawaiian_phrase: He moena ʻuki hehi wāwae.
english_phrase: A mat of ʻuki made for the feet to walk on.
meaning_phrase: A person of little consequence.

hawaiian_phrase: He moe waʻa.
english_phrase: A canoe dream.
meaning_phrase: When one dreams of a canoe there will be no luck the next day.

hawaiian_phrase: Hemo ka pili a ka makemake.
english_phrase: The companionship of liking has separated.
meaning_phrase: Said of the cessation of mutual affection.

hawaiian_phrase: Hemo ke alelo o Kaumaka i ka wai.
english_phrase: The tongue of Kaumaka came out in the water.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who has had a good trouncing. Kaumaka, a defeated chief, was put to death by drowning.

hawaiian_phrase: He moku ʻāleuleu.
english_phrase: District of ragamuffns.
meaning_phrase: Said by Kamehameha’s followers of Kaʻū and Puna because the people there, being hard-working farmers, lived most of the time in old clothes.

hawaiian_phrase: He momoku pī.
english_phrase: A green fire brand.
meaning_phrase: An unpopular person, who is like green wood that will not burn.

hawaiian_phrase: He moʻo, he pili pōhaku, he pili lāʻau a he pili lepo.
english_phrase: It is a lizard, for it clings to rocks, clings to trees, clings to the earth.
meaning_phrase: Said in derision of one who spies, hiding behind rocks, trees, and so forth. Also said of one who likes climbing over rocks and trees like a lizard.

hawaiian_phrase: He moʻopuna na Pālau o Hamohamo.
english_phrase: A grandchild of Pālau, resident of Hamohamo.
meaning_phrase: A braggart. A play on Pālau (Idle talk) and Hamohamo (Flatter).

hawaiian_phrase: He mūheʻe ka iʻa hololua.
english_phrase: A cuttlefish is a creature that moves two ways.
meaning_phrase: Said of a two-faced person.

hawaiian_phrase: He nahā ipu auaneʻi o paʻa i ka hupau humu.
english_phrase: It isn’t a break in a gourd container that can he easily mended by sewing the parts together.
meaning_phrase: A broken relationship is not as easily mended as a broken gourd. Also, the breaking up of the family brought a stop to the support each gave the other.

hawaiian_phrase: He naho manini mai kēia e loaʻa ai ka lima i kōkala.
english_phrase: This is a ledge under which the manini hides [and one should not be hasty lest] the hand be poked by the sharp points on the dorsal fin.
meaning_phrase: A boast. Also, a warning not to make trouble.

hawaiian_phrase: He naiʻa, he iʻa lele.
english_phrase: It is the naiʻa, a leaping fish.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who jumps to conclusions.

hawaiian_phrase: He naio ka loaʻa.
english_phrase: Pinworms are all one will get.
meaning_phrase: One will get nothing worthwhile.

hawaiian_phrase: He nanea nō ka lawaiʻa kole.
english_phrase: It is interesting to fish for kole.
meaning_phrase: It is interesting to gather and tell stories. The English word “story” was Hawaiianized to kole, which is also the name of a thick-skinned fish.

hawaiian_phrase: He nane hūnā ia.
english_phrase: A riddle whose answer is well hidden.
meaning_phrase: Said of a god, who is invisible. Also expressed He poʻo hūnā i ke aoūli.

hawaiian_phrase: He nani hulali ka hao.
english_phrase: A beauty like the shine of steel.
meaning_phrase: Not applied to persons. From the chorus of a song of the 1800s.

hawaiian_phrase: He nani wale nō o Puna mai ʻō a ʻō.
english_phrase: There is only beauty from one end of Puna to the other.
meaning_phrase: There is nothing to complain about. Refers to Puna, Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: He Napoʻopoʻo i ʻikea ke poʻo, he Napoʻopoʻo nō i ʻikea ka pepeiao.
english_phrase: A [person of] Napoʻopoʻo whose head is seen; a Napoʻopoʻo whose ears are seen.
meaning_phrase: A play on napoʻo (to sink), as the sun sinks in the west. No matter what your claim to rank may be, we can see that your head is low and that your mindfulness of etiquette is equally low.

hawaiian_phrase: He niho haʻi wale ko ka pāpaʻi.
english_phrase: A crab has claws that break off easily.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who offers to fight but backs down when the challenge is accepted.

hawaiian_phrase: He niuhi ʻai holopapa o ka moku.
english_phrase: The niuhi shark that devours all on the island.
meaning_phrase: A powerful warrior. The niuhi shark was dreaded because of its ferociousness. It was believed that a chief or warrior who captured this vicious denizen of the deep would acquire something of its nature.

hawaiian_phrase: He nohona huikau, noho aku a noho mai.
english_phrase: A life of confusion, living this way and that.
meaning_phrase: Referring to promiscuous people who share each other’s mates.

hawaiian_phrase: He nohona ʻihiʻihi ko ke alo aliʻi.
english_phrase: Life in the presence of a chief is very rigid in strictness.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who declares that he doesn’t know how to do a certain thing and perhaps will not be able to learn.

hawaiian_phrase: He noio ʻaʻe ʻale no ke kai loa.
english_phrase: A noio that treads over the billows of the distant sea.
meaning_phrase: An expression of admiration for a person outstanding in wisdom and skill. The noio is a small tern.

hawaiian_phrase: He noni no Kaualehu, he pūhai aʻa.
english_phrase: It is a noni tree of Kaualehu whose roots are in shallow ground.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person whose knowledge is shallow. The noni root from shallow ground does not make as good a dye as that from deep ground.

hawaiian_phrase: He nōpili ka iʻa, pili paʻa ke aloha.
english_phrase: The nōpili is the fish; love clings fast.
meaning_phrase: Said of the freshwater goby (ʻoʻopu) of the nōpili variety, known to climb waterfalls by clinging fast to the wet stones. It was used by kāhuna in hana aloha sorcery.

hawaiian_phrase: He nuku uila.
english_phrase: Lightning snout.
meaning_phrase: An incessant talker.

hawaiian_phrase: He nuku uli ʻūmiʻi.
english_phrase: Dark lips hold fast.
meaning_phrase: A vulgar expression. One with very dark lips is said to be sexually potent.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻohana kiko moa.
english_phrase: Family that hatches like chickens.
meaning_phrase: An expression of derision. Inter-marriage was encouraged only among high chiefs. When commoners inter-married, they were declared to be like chickens, mating with no regard to relationship.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻohā pili wale.
english_phrase: A young taro that attaches itself to an older corm.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who attaches himself to another in order to receive care. He is like a young taro that grows beside the parent plant but does not belong to it.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻōheke wale ko ke kanaka kuaʻāina a he ʻōheke ʻole ko ke kanaka o kahi aliʻi.
english_phrase: A country man is very shy, but a man of the royal court is not.
meaning_phrase: Proud were the people of Kaʻū of the surf of Kuaʻana, where chiefs used to ride the waves to the shore of Paiaha’a.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻohu ke aloha; ʻaʻohe kuahiwi kau ʻole.
english_phrase: Love is like mist; there is no mountain top that it does not settle upon.
meaning_phrase: Love comes to all.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻohu kolo ka makani, haʻukeke kamahele.
english_phrase: The wind that brings the creeping fog causes the traveler to shiver.
meaning_phrase: Anger and squabbles in the home of a host chill the spirit of the guest.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻohu poʻi wale iho nō.
english_phrase: Only a covering of mist.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who is a mere figurehead in a high position and has no authority to act. Like the mist, he merely nestles on the peak.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻō ʻia ka mea hāwāwā e ka heʻe nalu.
english_phrase: The unskilled surf rider falls back into the water.
meaning_phrase: A person who fails to watch out often loses.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻoiʻo kuhihewa; he kākā ola i ʻike ʻia e ka makāula.
english_phrase: The thought of a ghost is an error; it is a living person identifed by a prophet.
meaning_phrase: Don’t blame ghosts and spirits for one’s troubles; a human being is responsible.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻoi wale aku nō ʻo Huaʻā.
english_phrase: Great indeed was Huaʻā.
meaning_phrase: A sarcasm. Huaʻā was a chief of Puna on Hawaiʻi. When the chief of another district threatened to war against him, he hastily sent word to Kamehameha for protection. The latter ordered the war-minded chief to cease his threats.

hawaiian_phrase: He ola i ka leo kāhea.
english_phrase: There is life in a [hospitable] call.
meaning_phrase: A call of friendly hospitality gives cheer to the traveler.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻōlali ia he iʻa paheʻe.
english_phrase: It is an ʻōlali fish, a slippery one.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who is too wily and wise to be caught.

hawaiian_phrase: He ola na ka ʻōiwi, lawe aʻe nō a ʻai haʻaheo.
english_phrase: When one has earned his own livelihood he can take his food and eat it with pride.
meaning_phrase: A question asked of a runner, and his reply. It means that the way is clear, with no robbers or unpleasant experiences, and no rains to swell the streams and make traveling difficult.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻolena wale aʻe no ka Kiʻilau; he neʻeneʻe wale aʻe no ka Kāʻiliahu.
english_phrase: Kiʻilau merely gazes under his brow; Kāʻiliahu simply moves up close.
meaning_phrase: Said of a lazy person who watches others work and then moves up to get a large share. A play on kiʻi-lau (fetch-much) and kaili-ahu (snatch-a-heap).

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻolina leo kā ke aloha.
english_phrase: A joyousness is in the voice of love.
meaning_phrase: Love speaks in a gentle and joyous voice, not in harshness or gruffness.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻonipaʻa ka ʻoiaʻiʻo.
english_phrase: Truth is not changeable.
meaning_phrase: Truth is revealed by the gods.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻoʻopu ʻapohā.
english_phrase: A black, large-mouthed goby fish.
meaning_phrase: A term of derision for a very dark-skinned person.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻoʻopu-hue, ka iʻa ʻōpū kēkē.
english_phrase: An ʻoʻopu-hue, the fish with a distended belly.
meaning_phrase: A term of derision for a pot-bellied person.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻoʻopu kuʻia, ka iʻa hilahila o Kawainui.
english_phrase: A bashful ʻoʻopu, the shy fish of Kawainui.
meaning_phrase: Said of a bashful person. Kawainui at Kailua was one of the largest ponds on Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻōpae, he panau.
english_phrase: A shrimp that moves with a flip of its tail.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who gads about. He is compared to a shrimp who with one flip of its tail is over here, and with another flip is over there.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻōpelu ʻoe, he iʻa lomi.
english_phrase: You are an ʻōpelu fish, easily broken into small pieces by working with the fingers.
meaning_phrase: You are a weak person, easily subdued.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻōpū hālau.
english_phrase: A house-like stomach.
meaning_phrase: A heart as big as a house. Said of a person who is kind, gracious, and hospitable.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻōpū lepo ko ka mahiʻai.
english_phrase: A farmer has a dirty stomach.
meaning_phrase: A farmer is not always able to keep his hands and fingemails perfectly clean, even if he washes them. Because he eats with his fingers he is said to have a dirty stomach.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻōpuʻu ʻoe, he kākala kēlā.
english_phrase: You are a bud, he is spurred.
meaning_phrase: You are a cock whose spurs are just budding; he is a cock with spurs that are already strong. Said as a warning to a youngster not to challenge one stronger than he.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻōʻū naʻau nui.
english_phrase: Big-gutted ʻōʻū bird.
meaning_phrase: Said of a lazy person who shirks hard work and seeks something easy to do.

hawaiian_phrase: He pā ʻai ʻia, ke piʻi ala ke aku.
english_phrase: It is a good mother-of-pearl hook, for the aku fish are coming up.
meaning_phrase: Said of an attractive person who has no trouble attracting the opposite sex, or of a lucky person who never fails to get what he wants.

hawaiian_phrase: He paʻakai auaneʻi ke kanaka o heheʻe.
english_phrase: Man isn’t salt that melts.
meaning_phrase: Said to encourage someone to venture out into the rain.

hawaiian_phrase: He pāʻā kō kea no Kohala, e kole ai ka waha ke ʻai.
english_phrase: A resistant white sugar cane of Kohala that injures the mouth when eaten.
meaning_phrase: A person that one does not tamper with. This was the retort of Pupukea, a Hawaiʻi chief, when the Maui chief Makakuikalani made fun of liis small stature. Later used in praise of the warriors of Kohala, who were known for valor.

hawaiian_phrase: He paepae wāwae koʻu ʻili no kona kapuaʻi.
english_phrase: My skin is like the soles of his feet.
meaning_phrase: An expression of humbleness acknowledging the superiority of another.

hawaiian_phrase: He pahu nā aliʻi, a pā ʻia kani.
english_phrase: A chief is like a drum; there is no sound unless played upon.
meaning_phrase: Chiefs seldom stir to action unless incited by others.

hawaiian_phrase: He pālaulau moena.
english_phrase: A small mat.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is of very low rank — like a floor mat.

hawaiian_phrase: He pali lele a koaʻe.
english_phrase: A cliff reached only by tropic birds.
meaning_phrase: Said of a high chief or of a hill too steep to climb.

hawaiian_phrase: He pali mania nā aliʻi.
english_phrase: The chiefs are like sheer cliffs.
meaning_phrase: The chiefs are not easily approached.

hawaiian_phrase: He pali nui ka make e hoʻokaʻawale ana.
english_phrase: Death is a sheer cliff that separates.
meaning_phrase: Death divides the living from the dead.

hawaiian_phrase: He paluhē wale ka palu.
english_phrase: Mashed fish for bait goes to pieces readily.
meaning_phrase: Said of a weakling.

hawaiian_phrase: He palupalu nā hewa liʻiliʻi i ka wā kolo, lolelua i ka wā kamaliʻi, loli ʻole i ka wā oʻo, ʻoni paʻa i ka wā ʻelemakule.
english_phrase: Small sins are weak in the creeping stage, changeable in childhood, unchanging when an adult, and firmly fixed in age.
meaning_phrase: Bad habits can be changed in the early stages but eventually become firmly implanted.

hawaiian_phrase: He pane makamaka ʻole.
english_phrase: An answer that keeps no friends.
meaning_phrase: A rude retort.

hawaiian_phrase: He paoʻo ka iʻa ʻaʻohe kāheka lēhei ʻole ʻia.
english_phrase: There is no sea pool that a pāoʻo fish does not leap into.
meaning_phrase: An active person is found everywhere

hawaiian_phrase: He pāoʻo lēkei.
english_phrase: A leaping pāoʻo fish.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is never idle.

hawaiian_phrase: He pāpaʻa ke kō, paʻa ke aloha.
english_phrase: The pāpaʻa is the sugar cane that holds fast to love.
meaning_phrase: Said of the pāpaa variety of sugar cane, used in hana aloha sorcery.

hawaiian_phrase: He pāpaʻi niho mole.
english_phrase: A crab minus a claw.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person with a missing tooth.

hawaiian_phrase: He peʻe makaloa.
english_phrase: A hider among makaloa sedge.
meaning_phrase: A stingy person who keeps his eyes downcast while eating lest he see a passerby and be obliged to call him to come and share the meal.

hawaiian_phrase: He pihaʻekelo.
english_phrase: Mynah bird.
meaning_phrase: One who chatters all the time.

hawaiian_phrase: He piko pau ʻiole.
english_phrase: An umbilical cord taken by a rat.
meaning_phrase: A chronic thief. The umhilical cords of infants were taken to special places where the cords of other family members were kept for many generations. If a rat took a cord before it was hidden away safely, the child became a thief.

hawaiian_phrase: He pili kauawe paha ke kumu i moʻa ʻole ai ke kalo.
english_phrase: Perhaps the reason for the partly cooked condition of the taro is because it is the one closest to the leaves that cover over the imu.
meaning_phrase: Said of an imperfect or defective task, or of a person whose ideas are “half-baked.”

hawaiian_phrase: He pili kua, he pili alo.
english_phrase: Close to the back, close to the front.
meaning_phrase: The husband, standing back of his wife as her protector; the wife, the protected one.

hawaiian_phrase: He pili nakekeke.
english_phrase: A relationship that [fits so loosely it] rattles.
meaning_phrase: Said of a questionable claim of relationship.

hawaiian_phrase: He pili pāpākole.
english_phrase: A backside relationship.
meaning_phrase: A rude reference to in-laws, used only in anger.

hawaiian_phrase: He pili wehena ʻole.
english_phrase: A relationship that cannot be undone.
meaning_phrase: A blood relationship.

hawaiian_phrase: He poʻe hoʻopiha waʻa.
english_phrase: Canoe fillers.
meaning_phrase: A derogatory remark pertaining to useless people who do nothing to help, like riders in a canoe who wield no paddle, no fishnet, and no pole.

hawaiian_phrase: He poʻe kao ʻāhiu o ka wao nahele.
english_phrase: Wild goats of the wilderness.
meaning_phrase: A wild, unruly people.

hawaiian_phrase: He poʻe koa hoe.
english_phrase: Canoe-paddling warriors.
meaning_phrase: A disparaging remark about warriors who are not good fighters.

hawaiian_phrase: He poʻe ʻuʻu maunu palu ʻalaʻala na kekahi poʻe lawaiʻa.
english_phrase: Those who draw out the liver of the octopus, to prepare bait for fishermen.
meaning_phrase: Said of those who do the dirty work by which others reap the benefit.

hawaiian_phrase: He pōhaku hekau waʻa.
english_phrase: The stone anchor of a canoe.
meaning_phrase: An indolent person.

hawaiian_phrase: He pōhaku ʻolokaʻa pali o Kaholokuaiwa.
english_phrase: A stone that rolls down the precipice of Kaholokuaiwa.
meaning_phrase: Said when there is much ado and little accomplished.

hawaiian_phrase: He pō hīhīwai.
english_phrase: A night for the hīhīwai.
meaning_phrase: A gainful night. The hīhīwai are freshwater shellfish. On starry nights, they climb upon the rocks where they can be seen and gathered.

hawaiian_phrase: He pohō na ka pohō, ʻo ke akamai no ke hana a nui.
english_phrase: Sinking is to be expected where it is naturally found, but one should use as much skill as possible [to avoid it].
meaning_phrase: Losses come easily; it requires skill and wisdom to avoid them.

hawaiian_phrase: He poʻi na kai uli, kai koʻo, ʻaʻohe hina pūkoʻa.
english_phrase: Though the sea he deep and rough, the coral rock remains standing.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who remains calm in the face of difficulty.

hawaiian_phrase: He poʻi ʻumeke o Keawe.
english_phrase: A calabash lid is Keawe.
meaning_phrase: Said by Kekuʻiapoiwa Liliha, mother of Keopuolani, to mean that the island of Hawaiʻi had no chief of pure blood; at some point the blood of commoners had come in.

hawaiian_phrase: He pō Kāloa kēia, ua ʻeʻe pūpū.
english_phrase: This is the night of Kāloa, for the shellfish climbs.
meaning_phrase: The nights of Kāloa, when the shellfish climb onto the wet stones, are good for shellfish hunting.

hawaiian_phrase: He pō Kāne kēia, he māʻau nei nā ʻeʻepa o ka pō.
english_phrase: This is the night of Kāne, for supernatural beings are wandering about in the dark.
meaning_phrase: Said of those who go wandering about at night. It is believed that on the night of Kāne, ghosts, demigods, and other beings wander about at will.

hawaiian_phrase: He pōkiʻi no Makoa.
english_phrase: Makoa’s younger brother.
meaning_phrase: Said in admiration of a speedy athlete. Makoa was a speedy runner in Kamehameha’s day whose swiftness gained him fame.

hawaiian_phrase: He pōloli kali ko kahi o nā aliʻi.
english_phrase: At the place of a chief one must wait for hunger to be appeased.
meaning_phrase: One must abide by the will and favor of the chief. No one is independent in his presence.

hawaiian_phrase: He pō moe ko nā makaʻāinana, he pō ala ko nā aliʻi.
english_phrase: Commoners sleep at night, chiefs remain awake.
meaning_phrase: Commoners rest at night to be ready for the day’s labor. Chiefs can well afford to spend the night in pleasure, for they can sleep during the day.

hawaiian_phrase: He pono ka pākiko ma mua o ka hoʻokelakela wale aku.
english_phrase: Better to be economical than too liberal.
meaning_phrase: A courageous person.

hawaiian_phrase: He poʻo hūnā i ka lewa.
english_phrase: A head hidden in the sky.
meaning_phrase: Said of a god, who is invisible. Also expressed He poʻo hūnā i ke aoūli.

hawaiian_phrase: He poʻo ulu ko nā mea kanu.
english_phrase: Plants have heads that grow again.
meaning_phrase: An assurance that if you break off the top of a plant, it will put forth a new one.

hawaiian_phrase: He pōpō ʻauhuhu.
english_phrase: A ball of ʻauhuhu.
meaning_phrase: Said of a sorcerer who prays others to death, or of anything that would cause serious trouble. The ʻauhuhu is a poisonous plant used for stunning fish.

hawaiian_phrase: He pōpoki nāwaliwali.
english_phrase: A weak cat.
meaning_phrase: A weakling.

hawaiian_phrase: He pō walea, he ao walea i ka laʻi.
english_phrase: A night enjoyed, a day enjoyed in the calm.
meaning_phrase: Peace brings undisturbed nights and days.

hawaiian_phrase: He puaʻa ʻimi aliʻi.
english_phrase: A chief-seeking pig.
meaning_phrase: When a kahuna wished to find a chief with whom he was not well acquainted, he took a pig, prayed to his gods for guidance, and went on his quest. Upon arrival at his destination, the pig was released. It would go to the chief that was sought and lie down before him. In this way the chief was identified.

hawaiian_phrase: He puaʻa laho.
english_phrase: A boar.
meaning_phrase: An oversexed man.

hawaiian_phrase: He pua laha ʻole.
english_phrase: A flower not common.
meaning_phrase: One who is as choice and highly prized as a very rare blossom. An expression much used in chants and songs.

hawaiian_phrase: He pua na Pipine.
english_phrase: A descendant of Pipine.
meaning_phrase: A stingy person. Pipine was a miser of Kaʻū.

hawaiian_phrase: He pua no ka wēkiu.
english_phrase: A blossom on the topmost branch.
meaning_phrase: Praise of an outstanding person.

hawaiian_phrase: He pū hala aʻa kiolea.
english_phrase: A hala tree with thin, hanging roots.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is not strong, like a tree with aerial roots that are not yet imbedded in the earth.

hawaiian_phrase: He pū hala uoʻo.
english_phrase: A tough [old] pandanus tree.
meaning_phrase: Said of a stingy person. A play on pū hala in Puhala-hua, the name of a man in the 1800s who was known for his thrift and diligence in saving for old age.

hawaiian_phrase: He puheʻe miki.
english_phrase: A gripping cuttlefish.
meaning_phrase: A thief.

hawaiian_phrase: He puhi ka iʻa ʻoni i ka lani.
english_phrase: The eel is a fish that moves skyward.
meaning_phrase: Niuloahiki, god of coconut trees, had three forms — eel, man, and coconut tree, which reaches skyward. This expression can refer to Niuloahiki or to any influence that rises and becomes overwhelming. When used in hana aloha sorcery, it means that the squirming of love is like the movement of an eel. Also used as a warning — “Beware of that ambitious person who will let nothing stand in his way.”

hawaiian_phrase: He puhi ke aloha, he iʻa noho i ke ale.
english_phrase: Love is like an eel, the creature that dwells in the sea cavern.
meaning_phrase: Love makes one restless in the mind, like the writhing of an eel.

hawaiian_phrase: He puhi kumu one, he iʻa ʻino.
english_phrase: An eel of the sand bank is a dangerous creature.
meaning_phrase: Said of eels that can travel on the sand and rocks. Tales are told of eels climbing pandanus trees and dropping on persons resting or sleeping under them. Also said of a dangerous person.

hawaiian_phrase: He puhi makani.
english_phrase: Just wind blowing.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who makes promises and never keeps them, or makes threats and never carries them out.

hawaiian_phrase: He puhi ʻuʻu maunu; a he ʻā aki maunu.
english_phrase: An eel that pulls off the bait; an ʻā fish that nibbles it off.
meaning_phrase: A person who interferes with the work of others and makes a nuisance of himself.

hawaiian_phrase: He puhi wale nō na ka makani.
english_phrase: Only a blowing of the wind.
meaning_phrase: All talk.

hawaiian_phrase: He pūkoʻa kani ʻāina.
english_phrase: A coral reef that grows into an island.
meaning_phrase: A person beginning in a small way gains steadily until he becomes firmly established.

hawaiian_phrase: He pūkoʻa kū no ka moana.
english_phrase: A large rock standing in the sea.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who is unchangeable and very determined.

hawaiian_phrase: He pula, ʻo ka ʻānai ka mea nui.
english_phrase: A speck of dust in the eye causes a lot of rubbing because of irritation.
meaning_phrase: Let one member of a family do wrong and, like the resultant irritation, he is a shame to all.

hawaiian_phrase: He pūmaiʻa: loaʻa i ke kīkīao, hina.
english_phrase: A banana stump: when a gust of wind comes, it falls.
meaning_phrase: A weakling who is blown down by every trouble that comes.

hawaiian_phrase: He pūnāwai kahe wale ke aloha.
english_phrase: Love is a spring that flows freely.
meaning_phrase: Love is without bounds and exists for all.

hawaiian_phrase: He puni kauoha.
english_phrase: A fondness by request.
meaning_phrase: A dying person might will to a relative his fondness for a certain food or activity. After his death, the relative would eat or do the thing until he grew to be as fond of it as the dead person had been. This was called a puni kauoha.

hawaiian_phrase: He puʻupā hiolo wale nō i ka leo.
english_phrase: An obstructing wall falling down at the sound of the voice.
meaning_phrase: Said of stubbornness and obstinacy that are removed by gentle coaxing.

hawaiian_phrase: He puʻu pale ia lae na ka hoʻokele.
english_phrase: The cape is just something to be passed by the canoeman.
meaning_phrase: A boast — difficulties are mere trifles to an expert.

hawaiian_phrase: He puwalu, ke kū nei ka lāhea.
english_phrase: It is a puwalu fish, for a strong odor is noticed.
meaning_phrase: A rude remark about a person with strong body odor. Sometimes the palani fish is mentioned instead of puwalu.

hawaiian_phrase: He ua.
english_phrase: It is raining.
meaning_phrase: An expression used to begin a game, meaning “Ready, go!”

hawaiian_phrase: He ua heʻe nehu no ka lawaiʻa.
english_phrase: It is rain that brings nehu for the fishermen.
meaning_phrase: Refers to the rain that precedes the run of nehu fish.

hawaiian_phrase: He uahi ʻai pū nō ko ʻŌlaʻa kini.
english_phrase: Smoke that is also eaten by those of ʻŌlaʻa.
meaning_phrase: In ancient times, birdcatchers went to the forest of ʻŌlaʻa (then known as Laʻa) to ply their trade. Crude shelters were built for sleeping and cooking, and meals were often eaten beside a smoky fire. So anyone who shares a meal by a smoky fire is said to eat smoke like the people of ʻŌlaʻa.

hawaiian_phrase: He uahoa, he lima na ka makani.
english_phrase: Ruthless, with the hands of a gale.
meaning_phrase: Said of a ruthless person who strikes and hurries away.

hawaiian_phrase: He ua iki.
english_phrase: A light shower.
meaning_phrase: A chief of low rank.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻuala ka ʻai hoʻōla koke i ka wī.
english_phrase: The sweet potato is the food that ends famine quickly.
meaning_phrase: The sweet potato is a plant that matures in a few months.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻuhā kapu.
english_phrase: A sacred lap.
meaning_phrase: Said of one whose kapu prohibited him or her from carrying a baby lest it wet the lap. An infant who wet the lap of such a person might be put to death. Such a woman was often unable to rear her own children.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻuhā leo ʻole.
english_phrase: A lap without protest.
meaning_phrase: Said of a woman who is willing to have intercourse with any man who asks her.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻiāhini ka iʻa o kahi maloʻo.
english_phrase: The locust is the meat of dry places.
meaning_phrase: Said of a type of locust, now extinct, that was easy to catch and much eaten when fish were scarce.

hawaiian_phrase: He uʻi lolena kū i kiʻona.
english_phrase: A lazy beauty is fit for the dung hill.
meaning_phrase: Said of a beautiful person who is worth nothing.

hawaiian_phrase: He ukana ko ka houpo.
english_phrase: A burden on ihe diaphragm.
meaning_phrase: A problem in the mind.

hawaiian_phrase: He uku maoli ia, he iʻa no Kahoʻolawe.
english_phrase: He is an uku, a fish of Kahoʻolawe.
meaning_phrase: He is a rebel. Said by Keopuolani of Kekuaokalani when she suspected him of rebellion at the time of ʻai-noa (the abolishing of the kapu).

hawaiian_phrase: He ula, he iʻa noho i ka naele.
english_phrase: A lobster, the creature that stays in sea caves.
meaning_phrase: Said of a shy person who remains at home.

hawaiian_phrase: He ula, ke paneʻe ala ka huelo.
english_phrase: It is a lobster, for it flips its tail.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who is always moving about.

hawaiian_phrase: He ula no ka naele, panau no ka hiʻu komo i ke ale.
english_phrase: That is a lobster of a sea cave, with one flip of the tail he is in the rocky cavern.
meaning_phrase: Said of an independent person who knows how to take care of himself.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻūlei kolo.
english_phrase: A creeping ʻūlei.
meaning_phrase: An expression applied to a tough, strong person. The wood of the ʻūlei plant is very strong and was used as a fishing spear in olden times.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻūlili holoholo kahakai, pā i ke kai nui, hina.
english_phrase: A sandpiper running about on the beach, when struck by a big wave, falls.
meaning_phrase: A disparaging remark applied to a weakling who cannot fight.

hawaiian_phrase: He uli na ka heʻe pūloa.
english_phrase: It is ink from the long-headed octopus.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person clever at getting away with mischief. The ink of the octopus is its camouflage.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻulu ʻaʻai ʻole; he hāʻule wale i ka makani.
english_phrase: It is a breadfruit that does not hold to the tree; it falls easily with the wind.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person whose loyalty is doubtful — he can be swayed to desert his chief.

hawaiian_phrase: He ulūlu ka makani Kona!
english_phrase: The Kona wind storms!
meaning_phrase: What wrath!

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻumi a puaʻa.
english_phrase: A pig-strangling.
meaning_phrase: An act of a traitor; treachery.

hawaiian_phrase: He unu ʻoe no ka waʻa pae.
english_phrase: You are a rock for beaching a canoe.
meaning_phrase: You are worth nothing but to be stepped on.

hawaiian_phrase: He uouoa pili kahakai.
english_phrase: An uouoa fish that remains close to shorc.
meaning_phrase: A quiet stay-at-home person.

hawaiian_phrase: He ʻupena nae; ʻaʻohe iʻa hei ʻole.
english_phrase: It is a fine-meshed net; there is no fish that it does not fail to catch.
meaning_phrase: Said of a woman who never fails to attract the opposite sex.

hawaiian_phrase: He waʻa auaneʻi ka ipu e pau ai nā pipi me nā ʻōpae.
english_phrase: A gourd container is not a canoe to take all of the oysters and shrimps.
meaning_phrase: The container is not too large and cannot deplete the supply. A reply to one who views with suspicion another’s food container, or who balks at sharing what he has.

hawaiian_phrase: He waʻa holo honua.
english_phrase: A land-sailing canoe.
meaning_phrase: A horse, mule, or donkey used for transportation.

hawaiian_phrase: He waʻa holo nō ka hoʻi, kālai kāpulu ʻia iho.
english_phrase: After all, it is a worthy canoe, but you hewed it so carelessly.
meaning_phrase: He is a good worker but you have treated him with such thoughtlessness.

hawaiian_phrase: He waha ʻawa.
english_phrase: Sour-mouthed.
meaning_phrase: Said when a person wishes trouble on another, and the trouble comes.

hawaiian_phrase: He waha kou o ka heʻe.
english_phrase: Yours is the mouth of an octopus.
meaning_phrase: You are a liar. A play on waha and heʻe in wahaheʻe (to falsify).

hawaiian_phrase: He waha nina.
english_phrase: A small, tight-mouthed person.
meaning_phrase: A finicky eater.

hawaiian_phrase: He wahi limu pae.
english_phrase: Seaweed washed ashore.
meaning_phrase: An insignificant person who, like the seaweed, merely drifts.

hawaiian_phrase: He wahī paʻakai.
english_phrase: Just a package of salt.
meaning_phrase: Something good; a gift of anything one has grown or made.

hawaiian_phrase: He wai ʻauʻau ia no ke kanaka.
english_phrase: Bathing water for the man.
meaning_phrase: Said of a hero who is expert in dodging spears. Spears are like bathing water to a warrior who loves to fight.

hawaiian_phrase: Hewa i ka wai.
english_phrase: Great as a body of water.
meaning_phrase: A great multitude; so many that one cannot count.

hawaiian_phrase: Hewa i ke ala a ka hewahewa.
english_phrase: Goes amiss on the trail of the mentally deranged.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is careless of results.

hawaiian_phrase: He wai makamaka ʻole.
english_phrase: Water that recognizes no friend.
meaning_phrase: Said of flooded streams that are dangerous.

hawaiian_phrase: He waiwai nui ka lōkahi.
english_phrase: Unity is a precious possession.
meaning_phrase: Trouble often comes from one’s own people rather than from outsiders.

hawaiian_phrase: He waiwai nui ke aloha; o kaʻu nō ia e pulama nei.
english_phrase: Love is a great treasure which I cherish.
meaning_phrase: A common expression in chants and songs.

hawaiian_phrase: Hewa ka iʻa a ʻUmiamaka, he okea loko.
english_phrase: Wrong was the “fish” of ʻUmiamaka for it had sand inside.
meaning_phrase: Said of anything that is bad, or when one has been cheated. ʻUmiamaka was a young trickster who desired the daughter of a certain man who was very fond of lobster. But the father would not let his daughter go with a man who was not a fisherman. To win the father over, ʻUmiamaka filled a lobster shell he found on the beach with white sand. After stuffing the crack carefully with limu so it would appear freshly caught, he presented it to the father. After receiving the lobster, the father allowed his daughter to go out with ʻUmiamaka. But when the man gave his attention to the lobster, he discovered that it was just a sand-filled shell, and cried out these words. When the impudent youth returned, he claimed innocence, saying, “That was your fish, not mine.’

hawaiian_phrase: Hewa ka lima.
english_phrase: The hand is at fault.
meaning_phrase: It was believed that when one had done wrong, the hand was smitten with a disease that remained until he asked for the pardon of the person he had injured. Sometimes said in jest to a friend with an injured hand.

hawaiian_phrase: Hewa kumu waiho i keiki.
english_phrase: Faults of the source are left to the children.
meaning_phrase: Children suffer the consequences of the wrongs committed by their parents.

hawaiian_phrase: He weke, he iʻa pahulu.
english_phrase: It is a weke, the fish that produces nightmares.
meaning_phrase: The head of the weke fish is said to contain something that produces nightmares. The nearer to Lānaʻi the fish is caught, the worse the effects of the nightmares. Pahulu was the chief of evil beings (akua) who peopled the island of Lānaʻi. When Kaululaʻau, son of Kakaʻalaneo, ruler of Maui, was a boy, he was banished to Lānaʻi because of his mischief. By trickery, he rid the island of evil beings, and the spirit of Pahulu fled to the sea and entered a weke fish. From that time on, nightmares have been called pahulu, and a person who has had a nightmare is said to have been under the influence of Pahulu.

hawaiian_phrase: He weo ke kanaka; He pano ke aliʻi.
english_phrase: A commoner is dark; a chief is darker still.
meaning_phrase: A commoner is reddened in the sunlight and is as approachable as day; but a chief surrounded by kapu is as unapproachable as the black of night.

hawaiian_phrase: Hihia ka ʻōpae ma ka ʻumiʻumi.
english_phrase: The shrimp is entangled by the feelers.
meaning_phrase: Like a shrimp whose feelers are entangled by some weeds trailing in the water, so is a person who is caught in an affair he cannot get out of.

hawaiian_phrase: Hihia nā aho a ke kaweleʻā.
english_phrase: The lines used in catching the kaweleʻā are entangled.
meaning_phrase: Said of any entanglement.

hawaiian_phrase: Hihi kaunaʻoa, hihi i Mānā; aloha wale ia lāʻau kumu ʻole.
english_phrase: The dodder vine creeps, creeps at Mānā; beloved indeed is the trunkless plant.
meaning_phrase: This saying comes from two lines of a chant. Said of a person with no family background, or to a parasitical person. The kaunaʻoa (dodder vine) is a parasite.

hawaiian_phrase: Hiʻikua waha ka ʻopeʻope, hiʻi ke keiki ma ke alo, uē ʻalalā i ka nahele.
english_phrase: A bundle borne on the back, a baby in the arms, wailing in the forest.
meaning_phrase: Said of mothers fleeing in terror.

hawaiian_phrase: Hiʻolani ana me Niolopua.
english_phrase: Sleeping with Niolopua.
meaning_phrase: Just dozing.

hawaiian_phrase: Hiki akula i nā ʻOle.
english_phrase: It has reached the ʻOle nights.
meaning_phrase: The ʻOle nights refer to certain moon phases that were not good for fishing, planting, or starting any business. To reach the ʻOle nights is to face a bad time.

hawaiian_phrase: Hiki mai ka lā ma Haʻehaʻe, ma luna mai o Kukiʻi.
english_phrase: The sun rises at Haʻehaʻe, above Kukiʻi.
meaning_phrase: Haʻehaʻe, in Puna, Hawaiʻi, is often called the gateway of the sun. Kukiʻi is a place in Puna.

hawaiian_phrase: Hiki mai ka mālie, a hiki mai nō ka ʻino.
english_phrase: Good weather comes and bad weather comes, too.
meaning_phrase: Weather changes.

hawaiian_phrase: Hiki maila nā hoaloha, ʻo Keʻolohaka lāua ʻo Hanalē.
english_phrase: The friends Keʻolohaka and Hanalē have come.
meaning_phrase: The friends Vacancy and Hunger are here. Said in fun when one is very hungry.

hawaiian_phrase: Hili hewa ka manaʻo ke ʻole ke kūkākūkā.
english_phrase: Ideas run wild without discussion.
meaning_phrase: Discussion brings ideas together into a plan.

hawaiian_phrase: Hilinaʻi Puna, kālele iā Kaʻū.
english_phrase: Puna leans and reclines on Kaʻū.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who leans or depends on another. The ancestors of these two districts were originally of one extended family. The time came when those of each district decided to have a name of their own, without breaking the link entirely. Those in Kaʻū referred to themselves as the Mākaha and those in Puna as the Kumākaha. These names are mentioned in the chants of the chiefs of Kaʻū.

hawaiian_phrase: Hilinaʻi Puna kālele ia Kaʻū, hilinaʻi Kaʻū kālele ia Puna.
english_phrase: Puna trusts and leans on Kaʻū, Kaʻū trusts and leans on Puna.
meaning_phrase: The people of Puna and Kaʻū are related.

hawaiian_phrase: Hilinehu ka malama, kū ka nehu.
english_phrase: Hilinehu is the month when the nehu fish appears.
meaning_phrase: Held in the bond of affection.

hawaiian_phrase: Hilo ʻai lūʻau.
english_phrase: Hilo, eater of taro greens.
meaning_phrase: The people of Hilo were said to be fond of cooked taro greens. When storms came to Hilo it was impossible to obtain fish from the streams or the sea. The people had to be content with taro greens.

hawaiian_phrase: Hilo ʻāina ua lokuloku.
english_phrase: Hilo of the pouring rain.
meaning_phrase: Bad habits can be changed in the early stages but eventually become firmly implanted.

hawaiian_phrase: Hilo Hanakahi.
english_phrase: Hilo, land of Hanakahi.
meaning_phrase: Hanakahi was the name of a chief of Hilo in ancient times.

hawaiian_phrase: Hilo i ka ua Kanilehua.
english_phrase: Hilo of the Kanilehua rain.
meaning_phrase: The Kanilehua rain, or the rain that patters in the lehua forest, is frequently referred to in the chants and songs of Hilo.

hawaiian_phrase: Hilo i ka ua kinakinai, ka ua mao ʻole.
english_phrase: Hilo of the constant rain, where it never clears up.
meaning_phrase: Said in fun of a person who goes in search of another. This is a line from a hula song.

hawaiian_phrase: Hilo iki, pali ʻeleʻele.
english_phrase: Little Hilo of the dark cliffs.
meaning_phrase: Hilo-pali-kū, or Hilo-of-the-standing-cliffs, is always green because of the rain and mists.

hawaiian_phrase: Hilo mahi haʻaheo.
english_phrase: Hilo of the proud farmers.
meaning_phrase: The climate makes the soil of Hilo very easy to till, so the farmers used to make a game of planting. They used long digging sticks to make the holes and wore lei to work. Working in unison, they made a handsome picture.

hawaiian_phrase: Hilo, mai Mawae a ka pali o Maulua.
english_phrase: Hilo, from Mawae to the cliff of Maulua.
meaning_phrase: The extent of the Hilo district is from Mawae on the Puna side to Maulua on the Hāmākua side.

hawaiian_phrase: Hilo, nahele paoa i ke ʻala.
english_phrase: Hilo, where the forest is imbued with fragrance.
meaning_phrase: Hilo’s forest is fragrant with hala and lehua blossoms.

hawaiian_phrase: Hilo pāʻele kū.
english_phrase: Hilo is dark all over.
meaning_phrase: The rain, mist, and mud make Hilo dark.

hawaiian_phrase: Hilu ka iʻa, he iʻa noʻenoʻe.
english_phrase: The fish is the hilu, an attractive one.
meaning_phrase: A quiet, well-behaved person. When a pregnant woman longed for hilu fish, the child born to her would be well-mannered, quiet, and unobtrusive.

hawaiian_phrase: Hinuhinu ka ihu, pohā ka ʻauwae.
english_phrase: When the nose shines, the chin gets a blow.
meaning_phrase: Said of a drunken person who gets into a fight.

hawaiian_phrase: Hiohio ka makani i lima o Kapaliwaiʻole.
english_phrase: The wind whistles on Kapaliwaiʻole.
meaning_phrase: How ignorance speaks! Kapaliwaiʻole is in Kaʻū.

hawaiian_phrase: Hiʻolani i ka noe.
english_phrase: Sleeping in the fog.
meaning_phrase: Sleeping off a drunken stupor.

hawaiian_phrase: Hiolo ka pali kū, nahā ka pali paʻa.
english_phrase: The standing precipice falls, the solid clff breaks.
meaning_phrase: The resistance is broken down at last.

hawaiian_phrase: Hiu a wela, lawe a lilo!
english_phrase: Strike while hot, and take it away!
meaning_phrase: Make passionate love and take possession. Win the game and take the prize.

hawaiian_phrase: Hō aʻe ka ʻike heʻe nalu i ka hokua o ka ʻale.
english_phrase: Show [your] knowledge of surfing on the back of the wave.
meaning_phrase: Talking about one’s knowledge and skill is not enough; let it be proven.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻahewa nā niuhi iā Kaʻahupāhau.
english_phrase: The man-eating sharks blamed Kaʻahupāhau.
meaning_phrase: Evil-doers blame the person who safeguards the rights of others. Kaʻahupāhau was the guardian shark goddess of Puʻuloa (Pearl Harbor) who drove out or destroyed all the man-eating sharks.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻakaka wale nō ka Kiʻilau.
english_phrase: Kiʻilau merely explains.
meaning_phrase: A play on Kii-lau (Fetch-many), meaning one whose tongue knows where to fetch a lot to say. When words offend, the speaker responds that they are merely explanations not meant to hurt anyone.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻā ke ahi, kōʻala ke ola. O nā hale wale nō kai Honolulu; ʻo ka ʻai a me ka iʻa i Nuʻuanu.
english_phrase: Light the fire for there is life-giving suhstance. Only the houses stand in Honolulu; the vegetable food and meat are in Nuuanu.
meaning_phrase: An expression of affection for Nuʻuanu. In olden days, much of the taro lands were found in Nuʻuanu, which supplied Honolulu with poi, taro greens, ʻoʻopu, and freshwater shrimp. So it is said that only houses stand in Honolulu. Food comes from Nuʻuanu.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoa kīhei pili.
english_phrase: A coverlet companion.
