meaning_phrase: Said of a person with whom one is having an affair.

hawaiian_phrase: Hōʻaleʻale Mānā i ke kaha o Kaunalewa.
english_phrase: Mānā ripples over the land of Kaunalewa.
meaning_phrase: Said of the movements of a dance. A play on ʻaleale (to ripple like water), referring to the gestures of the hands, and lewa (to sway), referring to the movement of the hips.

hawaiian_phrase: Hōʻale i ka wai ua lana mālie.
english_phrase: Stirring up still waters.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who stirs up controversies.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoa pupuʻu o ka pō anu.
english_phrase: A companion to crouch with on a cold night.
meaning_phrase: A sweetheart or spouse.

hawaiian_phrase: Hōhē wale ka mea hewa.
english_phrase: There is cowardice in the wrongdoer.
meaning_phrase: The person who wrongs another is often afraid to face him.

hawaiian_phrase: Hohonu nō ke kawa.
english_phrase: A deep diving place indeed.
meaning_phrase: A topic that requires deep thinking.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi akula kaʻōpua i ke awa lau o Puʻuloa.
english_phrase: The horizon cloud has gone back to the lochs of Puuloa.
meaning_phrase: He has gone home to stay, like the horizon clouds that settle in their customary places.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi hou i ka iwi kuamoʻo.
english_phrase: Return to the backbone.
meaning_phrase: To return to the homeland or family after being away.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi hou i ka mole.
english_phrase: Return to the taproot.
meaning_phrase: The return to love and loyalty for kith and kin after a severing of relationship.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi hou i ke ʻehu me he moi lā.
english_phrase: Returns to the broiling sea like a moi fish.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who leaves home for a better chance of advancing but eventually comes back.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi hou ka iʻa i ke ʻehu kai.
english_phrase: The fish returns to the foamy sea.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who returns to a previous home or former habit.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi hou ka paʻakai i Waimea.
english_phrase: The salt has gone back to Waimea.
meaning_phrase: Said when someone starts out on a journey and then comes back again. The salt of Waimea, Kauaʻi, is known for its reddish brown color.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi hou ka wai i uka o Ao.
english_phrase: The water returns again to the upland of Ao.
meaning_phrase: The people had to travel far inland to find uncontaminated water.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi i Hīlea i kalo ʻekaʻeka.
english_phrase: Go to Hīlea of the dirty taro.
meaning_phrase: Said of a careless person. Once, Kohāikalani, a chief of Kaʻū, was living at Punaluʻu. Poi was brought for him from various parts of the district, and a tiny speck of taro peeling was found in the poi from Hīlea. The makers of the poi were put to death. To say that someone hails from Hīlea is to say that he is unclean.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi iho ka lehelehe a ka ʻauwae, noho.
english_phrase: The lip goes down to the chin and there it sits.
meaning_phrase: Said of a pouting person.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi i Kālia i ka ʻai ʻalamihi.
english_phrase: Gone to Kālia to eat ʻalamihi crabs.
meaning_phrase: He is in a repentant mood. A play on ʻala-mihi (path-of-repentance). Kālia, Oʻahu, is a place where ʻalamihi crabs were once plentiful.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi i Waolani i kahi o ka ʻeʻepa.
english_phrase: Go to Waolani where the supernatural beings dwell.
meaning_phrase: Said to one who can’t be fathomed. It is the equivalent of, “Go and join your peculiar kind of people.” Waolani, in Nuʻuanu, Oʻahu, was once the home of gods, menehune, Nāwā (Noisy beings), Nāmū (Silent beings), and all manner of disgruntled, misshapen, and joyous characters who were grouped under the term ʻeʻepa.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi ka ʻoʻopu ʻai lehua i ka māpunapuna.
english_phrase: The lehua-eating ʻoʻopu has gone back to the spring.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who has gone back to the source.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi ka ua a uka noho mai.
english_phrase: The rain goes to the upland and there it stays.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who leaves and stays away.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi ka wai a ka puna noho mai.
english_phrase: The water returns to the spring and there remains.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who withdraws.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi ke ao o ke kuahiwi, hoʻi ka makani iā Kumukahi.
english_phrase: The cloud returns to the mountain, the wind returns to Kumukahi.
meaning_phrase: Said of a group of people dispersed, each going to his own abode.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi mai ʻo Makanikeoe.
english_phrase: Makanikeoe is back again.
meaning_phrase: Peace and love are here once more.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi nele i ke kula o Kaneoneo.
english_phrase: Return empty-handed on the plain of Kaneoneo.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who retums with nothing. A play on neoneo (nothing).

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi nō a nanahu i kona alelo.
english_phrase: He turns to bite his own tongue.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who criticizes others and later does just as they. Also expressed Nahu nō ʻo ia i kona alelo.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi nō ka moʻala i kona lua.
english_phrase: The moʻala crab returns to its burrow.
meaning_phrase: He goes where he belongs.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi no ka pono i ka makua.
english_phrase: Returns to the parent for benefts.
meaning_phrase: Said of a grown person who returns to his parents for support or help, thus becoming a dependent once again.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi nō kāu me ʻoe.
english_phrase: May yours return to you.
meaning_phrase: A reply to a person who utters a curse. It means “I do not accept your curse,” and frees the speaker from trouble.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi ʻolohelohe i ke kula o Hamohamo.
english_phrase: Going home destitute on the plain of Hamohamo.
meaning_phrase: Going home empty-handed. A play on hamo (rub), as in the act of rubbing the hands together to indicate that one is empty-handed. Hamohamo is a place in Waikīkī.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻi pūʻolo nō o kahi aliʻi.
english_phrase: One returns with a bundle from the place of the chief.
meaning_phrase: When one visits the home of a generous chief, one always receives a gift.

hawaiian_phrase: Hōkai ʻo Wawaia ke kūkini holo lalau.
english_phrase: The runner, Wawaia, who ran out of his course, caused hindrance and delay.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who does not concentrate and wastes considerable time. Wawaia was a runner who, instead of running on the errand assigned to him by his chief, went on a visit before completing the errand, thus causing delay and rousing the ire of his chief.

hawaiian_phrase: Hōkai ua lawaiʻa makapaʻa.
english_phrase: A one-eyed fsherman spoils the luck.
meaning_phrase: To meet a one-eyed man on the way is a sign of bad luck; to fish with him is worse still.

hawaiian_phrase: Hōkai ua lawaiʻa o ke kai pāpaʻu, he poʻopaʻa ka iʻa e hoʻi ai.
english_phrase: A fisherman who fools around in shallow water takes home poʻopaʻa fsh.
meaning_phrase: The poʻopaʻa (hard-headed) fish is easily caught with hook and line.

hawaiian_phrase: Holāholā wale ʻia aʻe nō a pau ka pupuka.
english_phrase: It will all he stripped away until all the ugliness is gone.
meaning_phrase: Said in answer to a remark that a small child is ugly.

hawaiian_phrase: Hōlapu ke ahi, koe iho ka lehu.
english_phrase: The fire blazed up, then only ashes were left.
meaning_phrase: After a blaze of temper, the ashes of remorse are left.

hawaiian_phrase: Holehole iwi.
english_phrase: To strip the flesh of the bones.
meaning_phrase: To speak evil of one’s kith and kin, or to reveal confidences that will result in trouble for another.

hawaiian_phrase: Holo iʻa ka papa, kau ʻia e ka manu.
english_phrase: When the shoals are full of fish, birds gather over them.
meaning_phrase: Where there is food, people gather.

hawaiian_phrase: Holu ka pua o ka mauʻu, kapalili ka lau o ka lāʻau, māewa ka lau o ke ʻuki.
english_phrase: The grass blossoms sway, the leaves on the trees flutter, the leaves of the ʻuki grass wave to and fro.
meaning_phrase: Said of speed in traveling. The traveler went so fast he was like a passing gust of wind that caused the leaves to sway or flutter.

hawaiian_phrase: Holu ka wai o Kaʻulili i ka makani.
english_phrase: The water of Kaʻulili ripples in the wind.
meaning_phrase: A humorous saying applied to one whose proud swagger is like the movement of the ʻūlili (wandering tattler).

hawaiian_phrase: Hō mai ka ihu, a hele aʻe au.
english_phrase: Give hither the nose ere I go.
meaning_phrase: Kiss me ere I depart.

hawaiian_phrase: Honokōhau ʻōpae lele.
english_phrase: Honokōhau’s leaping shrimp.
meaning_phrase: An epithet for the kauā of Honokōhau, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Honolua kōhi lae.
english_phrase: Honolua of the weighted hrow.
meaning_phrase: Said of the fishermen of Honolua, Maui, who never raised their heads lest they be expected to share their catch of fish.

hawaiian_phrase: Honuaʻula, e pāluku ʻia ana nā kihi poʻohiwi e nā ʻale o ka Moaʻe.
english_phrase: Honuaʻula whose shoulders are pummelled by the Moaʻe wind.
meaning_phrase: A poetical expression for a person being buffeted by the wind. Honuaʻula, Maui, is a windy place.

hawaiian_phrase: Honuaʻula kua laʻolaʻo.
english_phrase: Callous-backed Honuaʻula.
meaning_phrase: Said of the people of Honuaʻula, Maui, who were hard workers. The loads they carried often caused callouses on their backs.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻohaka kai; hoʻohaka uka.
english_phrase: Nothing from the shore; nothing for the upland.
meaning_phrase: A rough sea when fish cannot be caught gives the uplander no fish to eat.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻohewahewa ke aloha, aia i Puna i Nānāwale.
english_phrase: Love failed to recognize him, for it is gone to Puna, to Nānāwale.
meaning_phrase: Said when an acquaintance or friend merely looks at another and offers no greeting. A play on nānā-wale (merely look).

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻohoihoi makua hūnōai.
english_phrase: A pleasing of a parent-in-law.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who begins with much enthusiasm but soon loses interest.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻohui ʻāina pala ka maiʻa.
english_phrase: Annexation [is] ripe bananas.
meaning_phrase: A saying that cropped up when talk of the annexation of Hawaiʻi began. It was a sign of bad luck to encounter someone with a bunch of bananas while on a business trip. Hence this warning that annexation will bring bad luck to Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻohū ka ua i ka moana, pilipili ʻāina ʻole mai.
english_phrase: The rain driving out to the ocean does not come near the land.
meaning_phrase: Said when a person snubs his old friends.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokaʻawale i ka ʻōʻō mai ka lima aku.
english_phrase: [To] take the digging stick out of the hand.
meaning_phrase: To deprive someone of work.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokahi e pōʻino, pau pū i ka pōʻino.
english_phrase: One meets misfortune, all meet misfortune.
meaning_phrase: Said of those who are important to the community — when misfortune befalls one, it is a misfortune for all. The fall of an able war leader is a disaster to his followers just as the fall of a good warrior is a disaster to the leader. Every member of the group is important.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokahi ʻiliwai o ka like.
english_phrase: The likeness is all on one level.
meaning_phrase: One is just like the other.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokahi kaʻilau like ana.
english_phrase: Wield the paddles together.
meaning_phrase: Work together.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokahi kī, ʻelua pahu.
english_phrase: One key, two trunks.
meaning_phrase: A reference to children of the same father and different mothers. ʻElua ki, hoʻokāhi pahu (two keys, one trunk) implies that they have the same mother but diflferent fathers.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokahi mea manaʻo nui a ka ʻōhua o ka hale: ʻo kahi mea mai ka lima mai o ke aliʻi.
english_phrase: There is one thing all members of the household look to: whatever they are given by the hands of the chief.
meaning_phrase: All members of the chief’s household are dependent on him.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokahi no hana a Palapala ʻo ka ʻohi i ka iʻa.
english_phrase: All that Palapala does is gather fish.
meaning_phrase: Although we do all the hard work, another comes along and reaps the harvest. Palapala was a noted warrior of Kāʻanapali, Maui. When the fishermen went deep-sea fishing with hook and line, he accompanied them. Whenever a fish would become unfastened and float to the surface, Palapala would take it, uttering these words.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokahi no Hāwaʻe, lauhue Kona.
english_phrase: Only one Hāwaʻe, and poisonous gourds grow all over Kona.
meaning_phrase: In Kona, Hawaiʻi, a priest named Hāwaʻe lived during the reign of Ehukaipo. In every important heiau in that district, an image named for this priest was kept. Many people were sacrificed to these evil namesakes of Hāwaʻe.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokahi no hua a ka ʻaʻo.
english_phrase: The ʻaʻo bird lays but a single egg.
meaning_phrase: Said of the mother of an only child.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokahi no hulu like o ia poʻe.
english_phrase: Those people are all of the same feather.
meaning_phrase: Said of a weakling.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokahi nō kaunu like ana i Waialoha.
english_phrase: Together there will he friendliness at Waialoha.
meaning_phrase: The enjoyment of friendliness by all. Waialoha (Water-of-love) is a place on Kauaʻi. When mentioned in poetry it refers to love and friendliness.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokahi no lāʻau a ka uʻi.
english_phrase: Let the youth use but a single stroke.
meaning_phrase: Let it be once and for all. First uttered by the instructor of the chief Puapuakea, advising him to strike his enemy with a single, fatal blow.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokahi no lāʻau lapaʻau, ʻo ka mihi.
english_phrase: There is one remedy — repentance.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who had offended a family ʻaumakua and suffered the penalty, or of one who was unhappy over a wrong he had done to others.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokahi no lā o ka malihini.
english_phrase: A stranger only for a day.
meaning_phrase: After the first day as a guest, one must help with the work.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokahi no leo o ke alo aliʻi.
english_phrase: A command is given only once in the presence of a chief.
meaning_phrase: A chief’s command is to be obeyed the first time.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokahi no makani ʻino o ke Kalakalaʻihi Kalaloa, he hoʻonuinui ʻōlelo.
english_phrase: There is only one bad wind, the Kalakalaʻihi Kalaloa, which creates too much talk.
meaning_phrase: Said of nasty words that start dissension and argument. A play on kalakala (rough) and kala loa (very rough). First uttered by the lizard-goddess Kilioe, who was trying to stir Pele to wrath by her insults.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokahi no ʻōlelo lohe a ke kuli.
english_phrase: The deaf hear but one kind of speech.
meaning_phrase: That is, the bad odor that results from breaking wind. The deaf, unable to hear, smell the foul odor and turn to see who the culprit is.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokahi no ʻōpae, ʻula ka paʻakai.
english_phrase: One shrimp can redden the salt.
meaning_phrase: Said of a poor fare of food due to a bad crop. A single shrimp and some salt will do for the time being, as long as the shrimp flavors and colors the salt.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokahi wai o ka like.
english_phrase: All of one color.
meaning_phrase: All the same; harmonious; in unity.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokē a maka.
english_phrase: Deny the eyes.
meaning_phrase: Said of a very selfish person who eats without sharing, no matter who looks on with longing; or of one who does his own work only, without lifting a finger to help another. Also said of one who gives to his own children but refuses to share with the children of neighbors and relatives.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokohu Kauaʻula, ka makani o ʻUlupaʻu.
english_phrase: The Kauaula wind ofʻUlupaʻu claims honors that do not belong to it.
meaning_phrase: Said in derision of one who steals, then boasts of possessions that are not rightly his. Also said of one who claims illustrious relatives. The Kauaʻula wind is a wind of Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokolo aku i ka nui manu.
english_phrase: Go inquire of the other birds.
meaning_phrase: Go and consult others. From the following story: One day a man went up to a mountain spring for water. On the way down he paused to rest, then fell asleep. An ʻelepaio lighted and, seeing the man’s gourd bottle, pecked a hole in the gourd. The sound of the pecking woke the man, who saw the water running out. In anger he threw a stone at the ʻelepaio and injured its leg. It flew away and met an ʻio. “O! ʻIo, I was stoned by a man,” ʻElepaio cried. “What did you do?” asked ʻIo. “Pecked the man’s bottle.” “Then the fault is yours,” answered ʻIo. ʻElepaio flew on and met Pueo. The same words were exchanged between them. So it was with ʻIʻiwi, ʻŌʻō, and all the others. ʻElepaio’s disgust grew greater with ʻAmakihi, who laughed at him in derision. Receiving no sympathy, ʻElepaio sat and thought and finally admitted to himself that he, indeed, was to blame.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokomo i ko waho i ko loko.
english_phrase: Put inside that which is outside.
meaning_phrase: Eat.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻokuʻi a kole ka lae.
english_phrase: Bumped and made a raw sore on the brow.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is really in trouble.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻolaʻi maka ma waho, ʻoʻoleʻa loko.
english_phrase: A friendly face outside, a hardness inside.
meaning_phrase: A hypocrite.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻolaʻi nā manu i ke aheahe.
english_phrase: The birds poise quietly in the gentle breeze.
meaning_phrase: Said of those who are at peace with the world, undisturbed and contented.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻolalau ka helena i Kualoa, piʻi ana i ka pali o Kānehoalani.
english_phrase: In wandering about Kualoa, he ascends the cliff of Kānehoalani.
meaning_phrase: He goes off his course and thereby gets nothing. On the cliff of Kānehoalani stands a phallic stone, a symbol of bad luck when seen in a dream.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻolale a ka ua ʻūkiu.
english_phrase: A suggestion of the ʻūkiu rain.
meaning_phrase: Go ahead and do what was suggested. The ʻūkiu rain is cold enough to make one hurry and scurry.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻolale i ka ʻai a ka uʻi.
english_phrase: Show what youth can do.
meaning_phrase: Let the youth show us what he can do.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻolaukanaka i ka leo o nā manu.
english_phrase: The voices of birds give the place a feeling of being inhabited.
meaning_phrase: Used by those who live, work, or travel in lonely places — life is made happy by the voices of many birds. Common in songs.

hawaiian_phrase: Hōʻole akua, hōʻole mana.
english_phrase: Deny the gods, deny their power.
meaning_phrase: Said of an unbeliever who denies the power of the gods.

hawaiian_phrase: Hōʻole ka waha, holehole ʻia nō ka iwi.
english_phrase: Though the mouth denies one’s guilt, his bones are stripped anyway.
meaning_phrase: Said of those who deny guilt but are punished anyway. This saying originated in the time of Kamehameha I, when thieves and murderers were severely punished even though they claimed innocence.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻolele ka uila o Makaweli.
english_phrase: Sending the lightning of Makaweli flying.
meaning_phrase: A play on maka-weli (terrifying eyes), this saying refers to the sending of a god on an errand of destruction.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻolike ka manaʻo i Wailohia.
english_phrase: Make your minds alike at Wailohia.
meaning_phrase: Turn your minds onto the same channel with bright thoughts. A play on wai (water) and lohia (sparkle).

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻolua nui.
english_phrase: Big Hoʻolua wind.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who talks boisterously.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻomaha ʻole ke kai a Mokupaoa.
english_phrase: The sea of Mokupaoa never rests.
meaning_phrase: Said of anything or anyone who goes on and on without resting. Mokupaoa is a place name.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻomau ʻia aku, wahi a ka nūpepa.
english_phrase: To be continued, according to the newspaper.
meaning_phrase: Many Hawaiian newspaper articles were continued from week to week. This was said of anything put off to be finished later.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻomoe wai kahi ke kāoʻo.
english_phrase: Let all travel together like water flowing in one direction.
meaning_phrase: The gods help man.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻonā ke ola i ka hale o ke akua.
english_phrase: The distresses of life are relieved in the house of the god.
meaning_phrase: The gods help man.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻonohonoho i Waineki kauhale o Limaloa.
english_phrase: Set in order at Waineki are the houses of Limaloa.
meaning_phrase: Limaloa, the god of mirages, made houses appear and disappear on the plains of Mānā. This saying applies to the development of ideas, the setting of plans, or the arranging of things in order.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻonuʻa Hilo i ka lehua.
english_phrase: Hilo produces the lehua in abundance.
meaning_phrase: To come together for a gay time and bring whatever you have to add to the fun. There is a play on lewa, whieh refers to the swinging of the hips in hula.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻonuʻu ihola a kū kahauli.
english_phrase: Ate with eagerness until he stood up with excitement.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who tries to please by eagerly heeding everyone’s advice and commands, and by so doing receives approval and advancement.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻopāpā i Waipā ka Lūpua.
english_phrase: The Lūpua wind touches at Waipā.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who cannot refrain from touching or pawing. Waipā is the name of a wind and location on Kauaʻi

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻopau kaʻā, he lawaiʻa paoa; hoʻānuānu ʻili o ka hele maunu.
english_phrase: An unlucky fisherman wastes time in wetting his line; he merely gets his skin cold in seeking bait.
meaning_phrase: Said of an unlucky person who, in spite of every effort, gets nothing.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻopau maunu i ka iʻa liʻiliʻi; e kiʻi nō ma ka iʻa nunui.
english_phrase: A waste of bait to go for the small fish; go for the big ones.
meaning_phrase: A play on ka pō loa (the long night). Said when one waits wearily for the night to pass, when there is nothing to do to shorten the hours.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻopiʻipiʻi kai.
english_phrase: Causing the sea to rise.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who stirs up wrath.

hawaiian_phrase: Hoʻopio ʻia e ka noho aliʻi a ka ua.
english_phrase: Made prisoner by the reign of the rain.
meaning_phrase: When the rainy season comes, one is kept indoors.

hawaiian_phrase: Hopo ana i ka wai poniponi o Waipuhi.
english_phrase: Fearful of the dark water of Waipuhi.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is fearful of getting into trouble.

hawaiian_phrase: Hōpoe, ka wahine lewa i ke kai.
english_phrase: Hōpoe, the woman who dances in the sea.
meaning_phrase: Hōpoe was a dancer of Keaʻau, Puna, in that long ago day when gods mingled with men. Because of her dancing and her kindly nature, Hōpoe was taken by the goddess Hiʻiaka as a favorite friend. When Pele sent Hiʻiaka to Kauaʻi to fetch Lohiʻau, the first request Hiʻiaka made to Pele was to be kind to her friend, Hōpoe. After a time, when Hiʻiaka did not return as expected, Pele in a fit of rage destroyed Hiʻiaka’s grove and the beloved Hōpoe. The latter was changed into a balancing stone that seemed to dance in the sea.

hawaiian_phrase: Hopu hewa i ka ʻāhui hala o Kekele.
english_phrase: [One] grasps the pandanus cluster of Kekele by mistake.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who meets with disappointment. A play on hala (to miss or to be gone). The hala cluster is often used figuratively to refer to the scrotum. Kekele is a grove at the base of Nuʻuanu Pali.

hawaiian_phrase: Hopu hewa i ka loli, i ka iʻa maka ʻole.
english_phrase: Grasped the eyeless fish by mistake.
meaning_phrase: Met with disappointment. The loli (sea cucumber) is known as the fish without eyes.

hawaiian_phrase: Hou hewa i ka lua o ka ʻōhiki.
english_phrase: [He] poked by mistake into the hole of a sand crab.
meaning_phrase: An expression of derision for a man who marries a very young woman and later realizes it would be better to have a more settled, mature wife.

hawaiian_phrase: Huaʻi ka ʻulu o Lele i ka makani Kona.
english_phrase: The breadfruit of Lele is exposed by the Kona wind.
meaning_phrase: Hidden matters are exposed in time of anger. When the Kona wind blows, the leaves of the trees are blown off to expose the fruit.

hawaiian_phrase: Hua kanawao ka liko o ke kapu.
english_phrase: Kanawao seeds produce sacred leaf buds.
meaning_phrase: The seeds of the kanawao, a small tree, were believed to help in making a woman fertile. In royal chants, large families of chiefs were sometimes compared to kanawao trees and their seeds.

hawaiian_phrase: Hū akula i kula.
english_phrase: Lost on the plain.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who goes off-course.

hawaiian_phrase: Huʻea i kai nā pihaʻā moe wai o uka.
english_phrase: Washed down to the sea are the stones and debris of the upland stream beds.
meaning_phrase: Said of a cloudburst that washes the stones from the stream beds, or of a person who, like the torrents, leaves no scandal untold.

hawaiian_phrase: Huʻe a kaua, moe i ke awakea.
english_phrase: A battle attack, then sleep at midday.
meaning_phrase: The sleep of death. When Kawelo fought Kauahoa, the latter uttered this, meaning that he would fight back until his opponent was dead.

hawaiian_phrase: Huʻea pau ʻia e ka wai.
english_phrase: All scooped up by rushing water.
meaning_phrase: Everything is told, no secrets are kept.

hawaiian_phrase: Huewai maka.
english_phrase: Unripe water gourd.
meaning_phrase: A small water hole, which is nearly too small to be of value. Not applied to people.

hawaiian_phrase: Hū hewa ʻia paha ke Kinaʻu, a ke Kalaukina e huli hele nei.
english_phrase: Perhaps the Kinaʻu is off her course, to have the Claudine go in search of her.
meaning_phrase: Said in fun of a person who goes in search of another. This is a line from a hula song.

hawaiian_phrase: Hū hewa i Kapua ka ʻauwaʻa pānānā ʻole.
english_phrase: The fleet of canoes without a compass landed at Kapua by mistake.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is off his course, mentally or otherwise. A saying from Kohala.

hawaiian_phrase: Huhui nā ʻōpua i Awalau.
english_phrase: The clouds met at Pearl Harbor.
meaning_phrase: Said of the mating of two people.

hawaiian_phrase: Hui aku, hui mai, hui kalo me ka nāwao.
english_phrase: Mixed there, mixed here, all mixed together are the cultivated and the wild taros.
meaning_phrase: Said of a great mix-up.

hawaiian_phrase: Hui aku na maka i Kou.
english_phrase: The faces will meet in Kou.
meaning_phrase: We will all meet there. Kou (now central Honolulu) was the place where the chiefs played games, and people came from everywhere to watch.

hawaiian_phrase: Huihui pāipu a Lono.
english_phrase: Lono’s cluster of gourd vessels.
meaning_phrase: Lono was a woman who had a large family of children and an indolent, pleasure-seeking husband. Hers was a life of drudgery. Tired of it, she sought a home on the sun. But when she tried to go up to it, she grew so uncomfortably warm that she came down again. Then she tried to go to a star, but the twinkling of the stars made her feel that they were laughing at her plight. Then, when the full moon rose, she changed her children into gourds and traveled up a rainbow toward the moon. Her husband saw her and ran to grasp her ankle as she went up. Her foot slipped off like a lizard’s tail. So Lono entered the moon and remained there. On full-moon nights, the people would point out the shadows in the moon and say, “There is Lono and her gourds.” Today a mother who goes about with her flock of children is compared to Lono and her gourds.

hawaiian_phrase: Huikau nā makau a ka lawaiʻa i Wailua, lou mai ʻo Kawelowai iā Waiehu.
english_phrase: The fishhooks of the fishers became entangled at Wailua and caught Kawelowai at Waiehu.
meaning_phrase: An entangling love affair. The first line of a chant.

hawaiian_phrase: Hū i kula ka make o ka ʻaiā.
english_phrase: The wicked dead is washed up by the sea.
meaning_phrase: In ancient times, certain priests would take charge of a chief’s corpse. The flesh and viscera, called pela, were sometimes taken out to sea where they were deposited. It was said that the viscera of a good chief was accepted by the sea and hidden in its depth, but that of a wicked chief was washed ashore and left there.

hawaiian_phrase: Hū ka ʻalaʻala.
english_phrase: The aerial bulbs appeared.
meaning_phrase: A lot of nothing worth troubling about. Here, ʻalaʻala refers to the aerial bulbs on the hoi vine. ʻAlaʻala is also the term applied to the liver of the octopus in songs and sayings, regarded as a symbol for something unimportant.

hawaiian_phrase: Hū ka makani.
english_phrase: The wind blows a gale.
meaning_phrase: Said of great speed. There is a hū (hum) and one is gone like the wind.

hawaiian_phrase: Hū ka wai i ke pili.
english_phrase: The water overflows to the pili grass.
meaning_phrase: Said of anything that overflows its boundaries, including a person whose behavior goes beyond the bounds of propriety.

hawaiian_phrase: Huki kū i luna ka lae o Kalaʻau.
english_phrase: The point of Kalaʻau holds itself high.
meaning_phrase: Said of an uncooperative person who wants his own way or of an egotistic, self-centered person. A Molokaʻi expression.

hawaiian_phrase: Huleilua i nā nalu o Launiupoko.
english_phrase: The waves of Launiupoko toss this way and that.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is unsure of himself. From Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Huli ka lau o ka ʻamaʻu i uka, nui ka wai o kahawai.
english_phrase: When the leaves of the ʻamaʻu turn toward the upland, it is a sign of a flood.
meaning_phrase: When the wind blows the leaves of the ʻamau fern so that they bend toward the mountains it is also blowing clouds inland, which will produce rain.

hawaiian_phrase: Huli ka malau, ka ʻiako a ka lawaiʻa.
english_phrase: The malau that serves as an outrigger of the canoe is turned over.
meaning_phrase: Work is done. The malau is a live-bait carrier attached to the canoe. When the fishing was done the empty malau was tumed over. First used by Hiʻiaka in a chant when she saw two shark men flee at the sight of her, though she intended no harm.

hawaiian_phrase: Huli ke alo i ka paia.
english_phrase: Turn the face to the wall.
meaning_phrase: There is nothing to fear. To go to sleep with one’s face to the wall is an indication of confidence in one’s safety.

hawaiian_phrase: Huli ke alo i luna.
english_phrase: Facing upward.
meaning_phrase: Said of a baby not yet able to sit up or a person too sick to rise.

hawaiian_phrase: Huli ke alo i luna, helu i ka ʻaʻaho.
english_phrase: Lying face up and counting the rafters.
meaning_phrase: Lazy.

hawaiian_phrase: Huli kua nā ʻale o ka moana.
english_phrase: The billows of the ocean turn their backs on each other.
meaning_phrase: Said of friends who are not on speaking terms.

hawaiian_phrase: Hulili ka lā i ke kula o Makahuʻena, he huakaʻi ʻoiʻo.
english_phrase: When the sunlight vibrates over the plain of Makahuena, a procession of ghosts is going through.
meaning_phrase: A saying used when the heat of the sun appears to vibrate. The huakaʻi ʻoiʻo is a procession of departed chiefs and their followers.

hawaiian_phrase: Hulili wela ka lā o Maunaloa.
english_phrase: The sun shining on Maunaloa makes it vibrate with heat.
meaning_phrase: Maunaloa, Moloka’i, is a very warm place.

hawaiian_phrase: Hului kōkō a Makaliʻi a kau i luna.
english_phrase: The carrying net of Makaliʻi takes all and suspends them on high.
meaning_phrase: Said of a stingy person. Makaliʻi was a supernatural chief of ancient times who gathered all the food plants in a net and hung them in the sky among the stars of the Pleiades. The result was famine.

hawaiian_phrase: Hupō-e-nui.
english_phrase: Extremely stupid.
meaning_phrase: Applied to those whose blood was mingled with that of kauā.

hawaiian_phrase: I ʻaʻa nō i ka lā o ka ikaika.
english_phrase: He can be daring as long as his strength lasts.
meaning_phrase: Said of a cocky person. As long as he has more strength than others, he acts the bully; but it soon ends when someone superior shows up.

hawaiian_phrase: Iā ia a hiki, make ka puaʻa.
english_phrase: As soon as he arrived, the pig died.
meaning_phrase: It was the custom to kill and roast a pig when a very welcome guest arrived.

hawaiian_phrase: I ʻāina nō ka ʻāina i ke aliʻi, a i waiwai nō ka ʻāina i ke kānaka.
english_phrase: The land remains the land because of the chiefs, and prosperity comes to the land because of the common people.
meaning_phrase: Chiefs are needed to hold the land, and commoners are needed to work the land.

hawaiian_phrase: I aliʻi nō ke aliʻi i ke kanaka.
english_phrase: A chief is a chief because of the people who serve him.
meaning_phrase: This was often used as a reminder to a chief to consider his people.

hawaiian_phrase: I ʻauheʻe ʻo Kaʻuiki i ka wai ʻole.
english_phrase: Kaʻuiki was defeated for the lack of water.
meaning_phrase: When ʻUmi, ruler of Hawaiʻi, went to Hāna to battle against Lono-a-Piʻilani of Kaʻuiki, thirst weakened the Maui warriors. Often used later to mean “without water or the needed supplies we cannot win.”

hawaiian_phrase: I haʻaheo nō ka lawaiʻa i ka lako i ka ʻupena.
english_phrase: The fisherman may well be proud when well supplied with nets.
meaning_phrase: Good tools help the worker to succeed.

hawaiian_phrase: I Halapē aku nei.
english_phrase: He has been to Halapē.
meaning_phrase: He’s drunk. A play on pē (gone under) in Halapē, a place at the Puna-Kaʻū boundary.

hawaiian_phrase: I hāna ka pō, i hāna ke ao.
english_phrase: Alert by night, alert by day.
meaning_phrase: Said of a fisherman or farmer who begins work before sunrise and continues into the daylight hours.

hawaiian_phrase: I hea nō ka lima a ʻau mai?
english_phrase: Where are the arms with which to swim ?
meaning_phrase: Don’t complain, use your limbs to do what you need to do.

hawaiian_phrase: I hea ʻoe i ka wā a ka ua e loku ana?
english_phrase: Where were you when the rain was pouring ?
meaning_phrase: A reply to one who asks his neighbor for some of his crop. If he answered that he had been away during the rains, he would be given some food; but if he said that he had been there, he would be refused. It was due to his own laziness that he did not have a crop as fine as his industrious neighbor’s.

hawaiian_phrase: I hele i kauhale, paʻa pūʻolo i ka lima.
english_phrase: In going to the houses of others, carry a package in the hand.
meaning_phrase: Take a gift.

hawaiian_phrase: I hele no ka hola iʻa i ka lā.
english_phrase: Poison fish while it is day.
meaning_phrase: It is better to work during the day. [cf 751]

hawaiian_phrase: I hewa i ka lele mua, i ka hoʻoūlu i ka lā ʻino.
english_phrase: The fault lies in leaping first, in inspiring a bad day.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who starts a fight or an argument, especially after he has been worsted.

hawaiian_phrase: I hewa nō i ka waha.
english_phrase: The fault lies in the mouth.
meaning_phrase: Trouble results from speaking the wrong words.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻIhi ke kua, meha ke alo; ka hua i ka umauma hōʻike ʻia.
english_phrase: Sacred is the back, silent the front; the word on the chest, reveal.
meaning_phrase: An expression often used by chiefs. No one stands behind and no one else is here in my presence, so deliver your message to me.

hawaiian_phrase: I Hikauhi, i Kaumanamana.
english_phrase: At Hikauhi, at Kaumanamana.
meaning_phrase: A man and his wife lived at Kaunakakai, Molokaʻi. While he was gone fishing one day, she felt the beginning of labor pains and went to her mother’s home in another village. When the husband arrived home and his wife was not there, he began to search for her. After he had searched fruitlessly for several days, his wife returned with their baby daughter, whom they named Hikauhi. Ever since that day, hikauhi has meant “in vain,” and when a person loses something and goes in search, one says, “I Hikauhi, i Kaumanamana.”

hawaiian_phrase: Iho ihola ka puna palaʻai.
english_phrase: Down goes the pumpkin spoon.
meaning_phrase: Said in derision to one who pouts, whose pouting lips are compared to a spoon.

hawaiian_phrase: I hole ʻia nō ka iʻe i ke kau o ka lā.
english_phrase: The time to cut designs in a tapa beater is when the sun is high.
meaning_phrase: Do your work when you can do your best.

hawaiian_phrase: I hoʻokahi kahi ke aloha.
english_phrase: Be one in love.
meaning_phrase: Be united in the bond of affection.

hawaiian_phrase: I hoʻokahi ka umauma, hoʻokahi ke aloha.
english_phrase: All abreast together, one in love.
meaning_phrase: All united in harmony and love.

hawaiian_phrase: I hoʻokauhua i ke kōlea, no Kahiki ana ke keiki.
english_phrase: When there is a desire for plovers, the child-to-be will travel to Kahiki.
meaning_phrase: Said of a pregnant woman. If she craves plovers, her child will someday travel to foreign lands.

hawaiian_phrase: I hoʻolulu, hoʻohulei ʻia e ka makani.
english_phrase: There was a lull, and then the wind began to blow about.
meaning_phrase: There was a promise of peace and quiet, and then the disturbance was renewed.

hawaiian_phrase: I ʻike ʻia nō ʻoe i ka lā o ko loaʻa; i ka lā o ka nele pau kou ʻike ʻia mai.
english_phrase: You are recognized when prosperous; but when poverty comes, you are no longer recognized.
meaning_phrase: Fair-weather friends gather when one is prosperous and scatter when prosperity is gone.

hawaiian_phrase: I ʻike ʻia nō ʻoe i ka loaʻa aku o kāu.
english_phrase: You are recognized as long as yours is received.
meaning_phrase: A warning about fair-weather friends who are friendly as long as they continue to benefit.

hawaiian_phrase: I ʻike ʻia nō ʻo Kohala i ka pae kō, a ʻo ka pae kō ia kole ai ka waha.
english_phrase: One can recognize Kohala by her rows of sugar cane which can make the mouth raw when chewed.
meaning_phrase: When one wanted to fight a Kohala warrior, he would have to be a very good warrior to succeed. Kohala men were vigorous, brave, and strong.

hawaiian_phrase: I ʻike ʻia nō ke aliʻi, i ka nui o nā makaʻāinana.
english_phrase: A chief is known by his many followers.
meaning_phrase: One who wishes to succeed should be alert to every opportunity, like one who catches birds by imitating their cries.

hawaiian_phrase: I ʻike ʻoe iā Kauaʻi a puni a ʻike ʻole iā Kauaʻi-iki, ʻaʻole nō ʻoe i ʻike iā Kauaʻi.
english_phrase: If you have seen all of the places on the island of Kauaʻi and have not seen Little Kauaʻi, you have not seen the whole of Kauaʻi.
meaning_phrase: Kauaʻi-iki (Little Kauaʻi) is a stone that stood in a taro patch at Wahiawa, Kauaʻi. When it was threatened with destruction by the building of a road, it was rescued by Walter McBryde and taken to Maiʻaloa and later to Kukuiolono Park, where it stands today.

hawaiian_phrase: I ka ʻai, i ka nānā; i ka ʻai, i ka hālō; i ka ʻai, i ke kiʻei.
english_phrase: Eat, look about; eat, peer; eat, peep.
meaning_phrase: Said of the eating of a thief — the eyes dart here and there to see if anyone is coming.

hawaiian_phrase: I ka hale nō pau ke aʻo ʻana.
english_phrase: Instructions are completed at home.
meaning_phrase: Do all of your teaching at home. First uttered by Pupuakea, half-brother of Lonoikamakahiki, when his instructor advised him as they were preparing for battle. The instructor’s teaching was all done at home; from then on the warrior chief was on his own. Also directed toward parents who noisily scold their children in public.

hawaiian_phrase: I kahi ʻē ka malia, hana i ka makau.
english_phrase: While fair weather is still far away, make your fishhooks.
meaning_phrase: Be prepared.

hawaiian_phrase: I kahi ʻē nō ke kumu mokihana, paoa ʻē nō ʻoneʻi i ke ʻala.
english_phrase: Although the mokihana tree is at a distance, its fragrance reaches here.
meaning_phrase: Although a person is far away, the tales of his good deeds come to us.

hawaiian_phrase: I Kahiki ka ua, ako ʻē ka hale.
english_phrase: While the rain is still far away, thatch the house.
meaning_phrase: Be prepared.

hawaiian_phrase: I Kahiki nō ka hao, ʻo ke kiʻo ʻana i Hawaiʻi nei.
english_phrase: In Kahiki was the iron; in Hawaiʻi, the rusting.
meaning_phrase: Perhaps the foreigner was a good person while he was at home, but here he grows careless with his behavior.

hawaiian_phrase: I ka holo nō i ke alahao a piʻi i ka lani.
english_phrase: While going along the railroad one suddenly goes up to the sky.
meaning_phrase: A drinker soon finds himself “up in the clouds.” An expression used by the sweet-potato beer drinkers of Lahaina, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: I ka hoʻolewa aku nei o Kuhelemai.
english_phrase: Attended the funeral of Kuhelemai.
meaning_phrase: A play on hoʻolewa (to lift) and kū hele mai (stand up and come), meaning that we stood up and lifted the beer down our throats. An expression used by the sweet-potato beer drinkers of Lahaina, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: I ka ʻike!
english_phrase: If there is knowledge!
meaning_phrase: Said in scorn or annoyance of one who pretends knowledge, meaning, “What does he know about it?” Sometimes shortened to I ka ʻī.

hawaiian_phrase: I kai nō ka iʻa, mali ʻē ka makau.
english_phrase: While the fish is still in the sea, make the hook fast to the line.
meaning_phrase: Be prepared.

hawaiian_phrase: I ka moana nō ka iʻa, liuliu ʻia nā pono lawaiʻa.
english_phrase: While the fish is still in the sea, get your gear ready.
meaning_phrase: Be prepared.

hawaiian_phrase: I kanaka nō ʻoe ke mālama i ke kanaka.
english_phrase: You will be well served when you care for the person who serves you.
meaning_phrase: A prosperous person has the voice of authority.

hawaiian_phrase: I ka nānā nō a ʻike.
english_phrase: By observing, one learns.
meaning_phrase: Family life requires an exchange of mutual help and recognition.

hawaiian_phrase: I kani koʻaka i ka leʻaleʻa; i puʻu ko nuku i ka huhū; i leʻa ka nohona i ka māʻona.
english_phrase: One laughs when joyous; sulks when angry; [is] at peace with all when the stomach is satisfed with food.
meaning_phrase: Said of an angry host. First uttered by Lohiʻau when he arrived at Kīlauea and encountered the wrath of Pele.

hawaiian_phrase: I kani nō ka ʻalae i ka wai.
english_phrase: A mudhen cries because it has water.
meaning_phrase: A prosperous person has the voice of authority.

hawaiian_phrase: I kani nō ka pahu i ka ʻolohaka o loko.
english_phrase: It is the space inside that gives the drum its sound.
meaning_phrase: It is the empty-headed one who does the most talking.

hawaiian_phrase: I ka noho pū ʻana a ʻike i ke aloha.
english_phrase: It is only when one has lived with another that one knows the meaning of love.
meaning_phrase: When mullet came into Keʻehi they came in such great schools that children could drive the fish up to the sand by striking the water with their hands or with the vines that grow on the beach.

hawaiian_phrase: I ka ʻōlelo nō ka ola, i ka ʻōlelo nō ka make.
english_phrase: Life is in speech; death is in speech.
meaning_phrase: Words can heal; words can destroy.

hawaiian_phrase: I ka pāhiʻuhiʻu.
english_phrase: To play the game of pāhiʻuhiʻu.
meaning_phrase: A saucy retort when asked, “Where are you going?” It is a play on hiʻu, which is a part of ʻohiʻu (to pry). Hence, a way of reminding the questioner that he is prying.

hawaiian_phrase: I ka pali nō ka hoa a hele, kalakala ke kua i ka ʻopeʻope.
english_phrase: The companion stays up on the hill and then goes, the back roughened by the load.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who keeps at a distance and departs. Also said of luck that stays away like a disinterested friend, carrying its load of fortune away with it. This was first uttered by Lohiʻau in a chant when he failed to make a score in kilu.

hawaiian_phrase: I ka piko nō ʻoe lihaliha.
english_phrase: Eat of the belly and you will he satiated.
meaning_phrase: The best part of the fish is the belly, especially when it’s fat. There is a play on piko (genitals) whereby this saying acquires sexual import.

hawaiian_phrase: I ka pono kau i nā waha, mai noho a pehi wale aku.
english_phrase: Those who put into the mouth need not throw stones.
meaning_phrase: The mouths that eat the food should never revile the producers.

hawaiian_phrase: I ka pule nō o Lohiʻau a make.
english_phrase: Lohiʻau was still praying when he died.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who waits until he is face to face with death before beginning to pray.

hawaiian_phrase: I Kaulua, Kaulua ka lā, Kaulua ka ua.
english_phrase: In Kaulua, sunshine and rain alternate.
meaning_phrase: Kaulua is a dual-natured month, sunny and rainy both.

hawaiian_phrase: I ka waha nō a ulu ka ʻai; i ka waha nō a maloʻo.
english_phrase: Food crops are made to grow by the mouth; while still in the mouth they wither.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who talks about farming and plans to plant but does nothing about it.

hawaiian_phrase: I ke aha hoʻi? I ka ʻahakea!
english_phrase: Why? The ʻahakea!
meaning_phrase: A saucy retort to the question “Why?” A play on aha (why) and ʻaha in the word ʻahakea. The ʻahakea is a native tree.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻIke aku, ʻike mai, kōkua aku kōkua mai; pēlā ihola ka nohona ʻohana.
english_phrase: Recognize and he recognized, help and he helped; such is family life.
meaning_phrase: Family life requires an exchange of mutual help and recognition.

hawaiian_phrase: I ke alo nō ka ʻulu a hala.
english_phrase: The breadfruit was just in front and it was missed.

hawaiian_phrase: I ke alo nō o ka lawaiʻa lā a pūkē hewa nā leho, haki wale nā kākala.
english_phrase: It was right in front of the fishermen that the cowry shells came together violently and the spikes broke off.
meaning_phrase: In spite of watchfulness, trouble occurs. The leho is a cowry-shell octopus lure fashioned with a spike on it.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻIkea maila ʻo Mānā, ua hāʻale i ka wai liʻulā.
english_phrase: Mānā notices the waters of the mirage.
meaning_phrase: The attempt to fool is very obvious.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻIke au i kona mau poʻopoʻo.
english_phrase: I know all of his nooks.
meaning_phrase: I know all about him, including his family connections, faults, and virtues.

hawaiian_phrase: I Kehena, i Kaiholena.
english_phrase: At Kehena, at Kaiholena.
meaning_phrase: Lazy. A play on hena and lena. “He has gone to Listless and Loafing.”

hawaiian_phrase: ʻIke ʻia aʻe nō ma ka huluhulu kau i ka puka ihu.
english_phrase: Attention is paid only to the hairs of the nostrils.
meaning_phrase: Attention is paid to the favored few whom one does not like to offend.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻIke ʻia e ka nui manu.
english_phrase: Known by the many birds.
meaning_phrase: Recognized by many people.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻIke ʻia nō ka loea i ke kuahu.
english_phrase: An expert is recognized by the altar he builds.
meaning_phrase: It is what one does and how well he does it that shows whether he is an expert.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻIke i ke au nui me ke au iki.
english_phrase: Knows the big currents and the little currents.
meaning_phrase: Is very well versed.

hawaiian_phrase: I ke kaua e ʻike ʻia ai nā hoaaloha a me nā kānaka koa.
english_phrase: It is in war that one learns who his friends are and who among them is brave.
meaning_phrase: One learns who one’s friends are when one faces trouble. Said by Kaʻeo to the chiefs of Oʻahu, who were fighting against Kalanikūpule.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻIke maka iā Kaneoneo.
english_phrase: He has seen Kaneoneo for himself.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who has been disappointed. A play on Ka-neoneo (The Nothing).

hawaiian_phrase: ʻIke nō i ka lā o ka ʻike; mana nō i ka lā o ka mana.
english_phrase: Know in the day of knowing; mana in the day of mana.
meaning_phrase: Knowledge and mana — each has its day. Another day may bring greater knowledge and greater mana than today.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻIke nō ke aliʻi i kona kanaka, a ua ʻike nō ke kanaka i kona aliʻi.
english_phrase: The chief knows his servant; the servant knows his chief.
meaning_phrase: Outsiders do not understand our relationships to our chiefs, and we do not care to discuss it with them.

hawaiian_phrase: Ikiiki i ka lā o Keawalua.
english_phrase: Depressed with the heat of Keawalua.
meaning_phrase: Sick and tired of living in an atmosphere of unkindness and hatred.

hawaiian_phrase: I Kōkī o Wailau, i ke alapiʻi a ka ʻōpae.
english_phrase: At Kōkī at Wailau is the stairway of the shrimp.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Wailau, Molokaʻi, where the fishing god ʻAiʻai hid all the shrimps at a ledge called Kōkl because he was annoyed at the people there for neglecting to preserve the fish spawn. He later revealed the hiding place to a youth he especially liked.

hawaiian_phrase: I komo ka ʻai i ka paʻakai.
english_phrase: It is the salt that makes the poi go in.
meaning_phrase: Poi tastes much better with salted meats. If there is no meat, one can make a meal of poi and salt.

hawaiian_phrase: I komo nō ka haʻi puaʻa i ka paʻa ʻole o ka pā.
english_phrase: Other people’s pigs come in when the fence is not kept in good repair.
meaning_phrase: When you behave well and tend to your own business, no sorcerer can send his evil gods to destroy you, for your own gods will give you their protection.

hawaiian_phrase: I kua naʻu.
english_phrase: A burden for me.
meaning_phrase: A request to a dying person for last instruction: “Let me carry out your last wishes.” This saying also implies simply, “Let me bear the responsibilities,” or “Let me help.”

hawaiian_phrase: I kū i ke ola, ola; i kū i ka make, make.
english_phrase: If it is on the side of life, there is life; if on the side of death, death.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who lies between life and death.

hawaiian_phrase: I kū ka makemake e hele mai, hele nō me ka maloʻeloʻe.
english_phrase: If the wish to come arises, walk frmly.
meaning_phrase: If you wish to come do not be hesitant, for you are welcome.

hawaiian_phrase: I kūpalu ʻia i ka mūheʻe.
english_phrase: Fattened with squid.
meaning_phrase: Squid is sometimes used as bait. After eating some, the fisherman throws a piece into the sea as lure.

hawaiian_phrase: I laila i luakaha ai me Hiku.
english_phrase: There [he] whiled the time with Hiku.
meaning_phrase: Had an enjoyable time. Hiku was a hero who lived in the mountains of Hawaiʻi and was thought of as a man who lived happily.

hawaiian_phrase: I laka nō ka uhu i ka pakali.
english_phrase: The uhu is attracted by the decoy.
meaning_phrase: If one wants to attract a person he must have something to interest him. Be patient and you will get what you want.

hawaiian_phrase: I lalo i Milu.
english_phrase: Down to Milu.
meaning_phrase: The fate after death of one who has not been obedient to his family gods, Milu is the ruler of the underworld.

hawaiian_phrase: I leʻa ka hula i ka hoʻopaʻa.
english_phrase: The hula is pleasing because of the drummer.
meaning_phrase: The lesser details that one pays little attention to are just as important as the major ones. Although the attention is given to the dancer, the drummer and chanter play an important role in the dance.

hawaiian_phrase: I lele no ka lupe i ke pola.
english_phrase: It is the tail that makes the kite fly.
meaning_phrase: It is the number of followers that raises the prestige of the chief.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻIliʻili o Hāloa.
english_phrase: Pebbles of Hāloa.
meaning_phrase: Descendants of chiefs of Hāloa, grandson of Wākea and Papa, or any chiefs descended from the gods.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻIliki ke kai i ka ʻopeʻope lā, lilo; i lilo no he hāwāwā.
english_phrase: The sea snatches the bundle and it is gone; it goes when one isn’t watchful.
meaning_phrase: A person who fails to watch out often loses.

hawaiian_phrase: I lohe i ka ʻōlelo a hoʻokō, e ola auaneʻi a laupaʻi.
english_phrase: One who hears good counsel and heeds [it] will live to see many descendants.
meaning_phrase: Said in derision of one who steals, then boasts of possessions that are not rightly his. Also said of one who claims illustrious relatives. The Kauaʻula wind is a wind of Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: I luna nā maka, i lalo nā kuli.
english_phrase: Eyes up, knees down.
meaning_phrase: Pray.

hawaiian_phrase: I lima nō ka ua, wehe ʻē ke pulu o lalo.
english_phrase: While the rain is still in the sky, clear the field below.
meaning_phrase: In dry places, farmers cleared the fields when they saw signs of rain so the water would soak the earth.

hawaiian_phrase: I maikaʻi ke kalo i ka ʻohā.
english_phrase: The goodness of the taro is judged by the young plant it produces.
meaning_phrase: Parents are often judged by the behavior of their children.

hawaiian_phrase: I make nō he hāwāwā; ʻauhea nō hoʻi nā lima a ʻau mai?
english_phrase: It is inexperience that causes death; where are your arms with which to swim?
meaning_phrase: When you have something to do, learn to do it and gain experience. Experience often saves life.

hawaiian_phrase: I mānai kau, i pua hoʻi kaʻu, kui ʻia ka makemake a lawa pono.
english_phrase: Yours the lei-making needle, mine the flowers; so let us do as we wish [— make a complete lei].
meaning_phrase: You, the man and I, the woman; let us satisfy the demands of love. Said by Hiʻiaka in a chant as she embraced Lohiʻau at the rim of Kīlauea to rouse the jealous wrath of her sister Pele.

hawaiian_phrase: I moe au i Kanikū, i waenakonu o ka ʻino.
english_phrase: I slept in [the lava bed] of Kanikū, amid the rough lava rocks.
meaning_phrase: I was in trouble. From a portion of a mele uttered by Pāmano when he was surrounded with trouble.

hawaiian_phrase: I mōhala nō ka lehua i ke keʻekeʻehi ʻia e ka ua.
english_phrase: Lehua blossoms unfold because the rains tread upon them.
meaning_phrase: It is the rain that brings forth the lehua blossoms. So do gentle words bring forth much that is desired.

hawaiian_phrase: I mua e nā pōkiʻi a inu i ka wai ʻawaʻawa.
english_phrase: Forward, my younger hrothers, until you drink the bitter water [of battle].
meaning_phrase: Uttered by Kamehameha as he rallied his forces in the battle of ʻĪao Valley.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻInā e lepo ke kumu wai, e hōʻea ana ka lepo i kai.
english_phrase: If the source of water is dirty, the muddy water will travel on.
meaning_phrase: Where there is evil at the source, the evil travels on.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻInā he moe maiʻa makehewa ka hele i ka lawaiʻa.
english_phrase: If one dreams of bananas it is useless to go fishing.
meaning_phrase: Said with laughter when a person forgets to come home on time. A straying pig can end up roasted in an imu. A common saying in Puna and eastem Kaʻū.

hawaiian_phrase: I nanea nō ka holo o ka waʻa i ke akamai o ke kū hoe.
english_phrase: One can enjoy a canoe ride when the paddler is skilled.
meaning_phrase: A sexual union is successful when the man knows how it is done.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻInā paha he puaʻa, pau i kālua.
english_phrase: If a pig, [you] would have heen roasted.
meaning_phrase: Said with laughter when a person forgets to come home on time. A straying pig can end up roasted in an imu. A common saying in Puna and eastem Kaʻū.

hawaiian_phrase: I noho ʻoukou a i pae mai he waʻa o Kahiki-makolena, hopu ʻoukou a paʻa; o ke kahuna ia ʻaʻohe e ʻeha ka ʻili ʻoiai no Kahiki aku ana ka ʻāina.
english_phrase: If sometime in the future a canoe from Kahiki-makolena arrives, grasp and hold fast to it. There is the kahuna for you, and your skins will never more he hurt [in war],for the land will someday he owned hy Kahiki.
meaning_phrase: A prophecy uttered by Kaleikuahulu to Kaʻahumanu and her sisters as he was dying. Foreign priests (missionaries) will come. Accept their teachings.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻIno ka moana ke ahu mōkākī nei ka puna i uka.
english_phrase: The sea is rough, for the corals are strewn on the beach.
meaning_phrase: Here are all the indications that there is trouble yonder.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻIno ka palu ʻaʻohe e mīkokoi ʻia e ka iʻa.
english_phrase: When the bait is not good, fish will not gather to eat it.
meaning_phrase: One knows that goodness and graciousness always attract. Palu is bait of dried, mashed octopus liver.

hawaiian_phrase: Inu wai kōliʻuliʻu o Hilo.
english_phrase: Drink the waters of the distant sky in Hilo.
meaning_phrase: The rain of Hilo is a chief source of drinking water.

hawaiian_phrase: I ola nō ke kino i ka māʻona o ka ʻōpū.
english_phrase: The body enjoys health when the stomach is well filled.
meaning_phrase: Shrimp. A man once rewarded some menehune friends with shrimp after they had made him a canoe.

hawaiian_phrase: I ʻolāʻolā nō ka huewai i ka piha ʻole.
english_phrase: The water gourd gurgles when not filled full.
meaning_phrase: A person not very well informed talks more than one who is.

hawaiian_phrase: I ʻo Nana hoʻokau ka mālie.
english_phrase: When Nana arrives, calm weather finds a place.
meaning_phrase: Good weather comes in the month of Nana.

hawaiian_phrase: I paʻa iā ia ʻaʻole ʻoe e puka.
english_phrase: If it had ended with him [or her] you would not be here.
meaning_phrase: Said to a younger sibling to encourage more respect for an elder.

hawaiian_phrase: I paʻa i ka hānau mua, ʻaʻole e puka nā pōkiʻi.
english_phrase: Had the mother died in bearing the oldest, all the others would not have been born.
meaning_phrase: Said in reminding brothers and sisters to respect the hiapo (eldest).

hawaiian_phrase: I paʻa i kona kupuna ʻaʻole kākou e puka.
english_phrase: Had our ancestress died in bearing our grandparent, we would not have come forth.
meaning_phrase: Said to remind a member of the family to respect the senior line, because they came first. Also expressed I paʻa i kona makua....

hawaiian_phrase: I paʻa ke kino o ke keiki i ka lāʻau.
english_phrase: That the body of the child be solidly built by the medicines.
meaning_phrase: A mother ate herbs during pregnancy and nursing for the sake of the baby’s health. The herbs were given to the child up to the age of twenty so that he would be healthy and strong through maturity and old age.

hawaiian_phrase: I pao i ka huewai nuku pueo a ke kanaka.
english_phrase: Pecked at the man’s short-necked gourd bottle.
meaning_phrase: Attempted an affair with another’s wife. This saying comes from the story of the ʻelepaio bird that pecked at a man’s water bottle while he slept.

hawaiian_phrase: I pīʻena ka lio i ka pūnuku; e komo kaula waha ʻia ka maikaʻi.
english_phrase: The horse shies at the halter; better use the bridle.
meaning_phrase: Advice not to suppress the activities of a wild-behaving person all at once, but to tame him gradually.

hawaiian_phrase: Ipu kai hīnālea.
english_phrase: A dish of hīnālea fish.
meaning_phrase: A rude remark about one with bad breath, or one whose nose has the foul odor of catarrh. The hīnālea was a favorite fish for a dish called iʻa hoʻomelu. Before preparation, the fish was left to decompose slightly, thus acquiring a strong odor. After seasoning with salt, kukui relish, and chili pepper, the fish lost its unpleasant smell.

hawaiian_phrase: Ipu lei Kohala na ka Moaʻe Kū.
english_phrase: Kohala is like a wreath container for the Moaʻe breeze.
meaning_phrase: Kohala is a windy place.

hawaiian_phrase: I puni iā ʻoe o Kaʻū a i ʻike ʻole ʻoe iā Kaʻūloa, ʻaʻohe nō ʻoe i ʻike iā Kaʻū.
english_phrase: If you have been around Kaʻū and have not seen Kaʻūloa, you have not seen the whole of the district. Kaʻūloa and Waiōhinu were two stones, wife and husband, that stood in a kukui grove on the upper side of the road between Na’alehu and Waiōhinu. With the passing of time, these stones gradually sank until they vanished completely into the earth. After Kaʻūloa was no longer seen, Palahemo was substituted as the chief point of interest.
meaning_phrase: Some of the natives of Kaʻū had a reputation for not being very hospitable. Hasty eating on the part of the host did not encourage guests to linger.

hawaiian_phrase: I puni iā ʻoe o Lānaʻi a i ʻike ʻole iā Lānaʻi-Kaʻula me Lānaʻi-Hale, ʻaʻohe nō ʻoe i ʻike iā Lānaʻi.
english_phrase: If you have gone around Lānaʻi, and have not seen Lānaʻi Kaʻula and Lānaʻi Hale, you have not seen all of Lānaʻi.
meaning_phrase: Said of people who stand about, look on, go to sleep and sit around, but who do not lend a hand with work.

hawaiian_phrase: Ipu paʻu lena i ka uahi.
english_phrase: Soot containers yellowed by smoke.
meaning_phrase: A term of contempt applied to the kauā of Kaupō, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: I ʻūlili ka ʻūlili he kanaka.
english_phrase: When the sandpiper cries, someone approaches.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who runs here and there for trivial things.

hawaiian_phrase: I ulu nō ka lālā i ke kumu.
english_phrase: The branches grow because of the trunk.
meaning_phrase: Without our ancestors we would not be here.

hawaiian_phrase: I Ulupaʻupaʻu, i ka hale o ka makapō.
english_phrase: In Ulupaʻupaʻu, house of the sightless.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is actually or figuratively “blind.” Hema, chief of Maui, went deep-sea fishing to satisfy the longing of his pregnant wife. He landed at Ulupaʻupaʻu where his eyes were pecked out by a large bird.

hawaiian_phrase: I Waialua ka poʻina a ke kai, ʻo ka leo ka ʻEwa e hoʻolono nei.
english_phrase: The dashing of the waves is at Waialua but the sound is being heard at ʻEwa.
meaning_phrase: Sounds of fighting in one locality are quickly heard in another.

hawaiian_phrase: I wai noʻu.
english_phrase: Give me water.
meaning_phrase: Said to challenge another to a game or contest.

hawaiian_phrase: I walea ka manu i ka ʻula o ka lehua.
english_phrase: The bird is attracted by the redness of the lehua.
meaning_phrase: The youth is attracted by the charm of another.

hawaiian_phrase: I wawā ʻia ka hale kanaka. Na wai e wawā ka hale kanaka ʻole?
english_phrase: Voices are heard around an inhabited house. Who hears voices about an uninhabited one ?
meaning_phrase: Where people are, life is. From a chant for Kaʻahumanu.

hawaiian_phrase: I wawā nō ka noio, he iʻa ko lalo.
english_phrase: When the noio make a din, there are fish below.
meaning_phrase: When people gossip, there is a cause.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻai a Kaiaʻupe.
english_phrase: The [lua] stroke of Kaiaupe.
meaning_phrase: Said when one is lured and suffers the consequences. Kaiaʻupe was a noted female robber who lived near the cliff trail of ʻAʻalaloa, Maui. She would entice a man to lie with her on the edge of the cliff, and then kick him off with her foot. This expression came to refer to any kind of treachery.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻai hūnā i ka poli.
english_phrase: The food hidden in the bosom.
meaning_phrase: Breast milk.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻai kīʻoʻe lāʻau.
english_phrase: The food reached for with a stick.
meaning_phrase: Said of the breadfruit, which grows high on the tree.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻai lewa i ka ʻāʻī.
english_phrase: The food that swings from the neck.
meaning_phrase: Refers to food containers that were carried suspended from poles.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻāina hiʻialo ʻo Honuakaha.
english_phrase: The land of Honuakaha [where chiefs] were embraced.
meaning_phrase: Honuakaha, back of the Kawaiahaʻo Cemetery, was once the home of Kalākaua. Here chiefs were entertained with parties.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻai nānā i luna.
english_phrase: The food that requires looking up to.
meaning_phrase: Said of breadfruit, which grows on the tree, in contrast with taro, sweet potato, and yam, which grow underground.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻai niho ʻole a ka makani i ka ʻai.
english_phrase: Even without teeth the wind consumes the food crops.
meaning_phrase: Said of a destructive windstorm.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻai waha ʻulaʻula o ka ʻāina.
english_phrase: The red-mouthed food of the land.
meaning_phrase: Watermelon. When the Hawaiians first saw Captain Cook’s men eating watermelon, they thought that they were eating human flesh and referred to them as akua waha ʻulaʻula (red-mouthed gods).

hawaiian_phrase: Kaʻa ka pōhaku.
english_phrase: The stones roll.
meaning_phrase: Thunder.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻalaʻihi kualoa e kukū ʻai i nā lima.
english_phrase: The long-backed ʻalaʻihi fish that pierces the hands.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is not to be trifled with.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻalā paʻa o Kaueleau.
english_phrase: The hard rock of Kaueleau.
meaning_phrase: A dollar, or a hard, unyielding person. There is a rock at Kaueleau, Puna, Hawaiʻi, called the ʻalāpaʻa.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaʻapā ka manu hulu ʻole.
english_phrase: A bird without feathers is helpless.
meaning_phrase: Said of a weakling.

hawaiian_phrase: Kāʻanapali wāwae ʻulaʻula.
english_phrase: Red-footed Kāʻanapali.
meaning_phrase: A term of derision for the people of Kāʻanapali. The soil there is red, and so the people are said to be recognizable by the red soles of their feet.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻawa lena o Kaliʻu.
english_phrase: The yellowed ʻawa of Kaliʻu.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Kaliʻu, Kilohana, Kauaʻi. People noticed drunken rats in the forest and discovered some very potent ʻawa there. There is a Kaliʻu in Puna, Hawaiʻi, where good ʻawa is also grown.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻehu kai o Puaʻena.
english_phrase: The sea sprays of Puaʻena.
meaning_phrase: Wind blows the sea sprays of Puaʻena, Waialua, Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻelele leo ʻole.
english_phrase: The silent messenger.
meaning_phrase: A letter. It brings messages but does not speak.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻelele leo ʻole o ke aloha.
english_phrase: The voiceless messenger of love.
meaning_phrase: A letter bearing words of love and cheer.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaha akula ka nalu o kuʻu ʻāina.
english_phrase: The surf of my land has swept everything away.
meaning_phrase: A retort to one who boasts about the value and beauty of his own land.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka hāʻawi a ka mea hale, koe koena ʻole ma kūʻono.
english_phrase: Giving as a house owner does, with nothing left hidden in the corners.
meaning_phrase: Said of a very generous person who gives freely of all he has.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaha Kaʻena me he manu lā i ka mālie.
english_phrase: Kaʻena Point poises as a bird in the calm.
meaning_phrase: This is a line in a chant by Hiʻiaka praising Kaʻena Point, Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaha ka ʻio i ka mālie.
english_phrase: The ʻio bird poises in the calm.
meaning_phrase: Said in admiration of a handsome person. An ʻio dips gracefully as it flies, with wings that flap slowly.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka haka o ka moa kāne, ua kau ʻia e ka moa wahine.
english_phrase: The perch of the cock is now occupied by a hen.
meaning_phrase: Said by Puna, whom Kalaniʻōpuʻu placed as governor in Hāna, Maui. Mahihelelima wanted Puna out of the way and lied that Kalaniʻōpuʻu had sent word for Puna to meet him in Hawaiʻi at once. When Puna arrived in Hawaiʻi, he discovered that he had been duped and that Kaʻuiki hill in Hāna had been taken by the Maui chiefs in the meantime. The saying was later used to mean that a superior worker had been replaced by another who was not as good.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka hala lau kalakala o Wakiu.
english_phrase: The thorny-leaved hala tree of Wakiu.
meaning_phrase: A boast about one who is not to be tampered with.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka hala māpu ʻaʻala o Upeloa.
english_phrase: The sweet-scented hala of Upeloa.
meaning_phrase: Upeloa, in Hilo, was noted for its sweet-smelling hala.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka hālau a ʻĪ.
english_phrase: The house of ʻĪ.
meaning_phrase: The descendants of ʻĪ, who extended through Hāmākua, Hilo, Puna and Kaʻū. One of these was ʻĪmakakoloa, who was condemned to death by Kamehameha. According to the historian Kamakau, ʻĪmakakoloa was put to death in Kamaʻoa. But according to the people of Kaʻū, a junior kinsman of similar appearance was substituted at the execution.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka hale koʻekoʻe o ka pō.
english_phrase: The cold house of darkness.
meaning_phrase: Death.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka hale weliweli o nā aliʻi.
english_phrase: The dreaded house of chiefs.
meaning_phrase: The chiefs had many taboos, rules, and regulations in their households and to break any of these meant severe punishment, even death.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka hana a ka mākua, ʻo ka hana nō ia a keiki.
english_phrase: What parents do, children will do.
meaning_phrase: Reply of Liholiho when someone praised his wisdom.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka hana a ke aloha, he kohu mūheʻe i ke alo pali.
english_phrase: The action of a lover is like that of a squid at the face of a precipice.
meaning_phrase: A squid is said to be a creature that goes every which way. A squid-like lover is not to be trusted.

hawaiian_phrase: Kāhana auhā.
english_phrase: Kāhana of the shed.
meaning_phrase: Said of the natives of Kāhana, who were said to be stingy. Their fish was hidden in the canoe shed rather than shared.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka hao a ka makani Kona, ʻaʻohe manu koe o ke kuahiwi.
english_phrase: When the Kona wind does its worst, no birds remain in the mountains.
meaning_phrase: When someone goes into a towering rage, everyone flees his presence.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka hao a ka wai nui, pihaʻā o kai.
english_phrase: When a great flood washes down, the shore is littered with stones and debris from the upland.
meaning_phrase: When one is careless in speech, trouble results.

hawaiian_phrase: Kahaualeʻa i ke kūkae kupu.
english_phrase: At Kahaualeʻa, where the dung sprouts.
meaning_phrase: The people of Kahaualeʻa, Puna, were said to eat noni fruit, seeds and all. The seeds would sprout wherever the people excreted.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka hau hoʻokuakea ʻili.
english_phrase: The snow that bleaches the skin.
meaning_phrase: Living in a land where it snows was believed to lighten the skin.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka hāuli o ka mea hewa ʻole, he nalowale koke.
english_phrase: A bruise inflicted on an innocent person vanishes quickly.
meaning_phrase: Mean words uttered against the innocent may hurt, but the hurt will not last.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka Hau o Maʻihi.
english_phrase: The Hau [breeze] of Maʻihi.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Maʻihi, Kona, Hawaiʻi. Because this locality was named for Maʻihi-ala-kapu-o-Lono, daughter of the god Lono-a-ipu, this wind was regarded as sacred and did not blow beyond Kainaliu and Keauhou.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka hauwalaʻau a ka nui manu.
english_phrase: The loud chattering of many birds.
meaning_phrase: Gossip that is spread abroad by a lot of busybodies.

hawaiian_phrase: Kahe ka hou, ʻoni ka puʻu.
english_phrase: Perspiration flows, the Adam’s apple moves.
meaning_phrase: Said in fun of a person who intensely desires the unobtainable, such as a young man longing for a maiden who will not reciprocate.

hawaiian_phrase: Kahe ka wai ʻula, kuakea ka moana.
english_phrase: When the brown waters run, the sea is white with foam.
meaning_phrase: Signs of a storm.

hawaiian_phrase: Kāhihi ka puka o ka hale i ka pūnāwelewele.
english_phrase: Cobwebs spread over the door of the house.
meaning_phrase: A person comes here, grows prosperous, and goes away without a thought to the source of his prosperity.

hawaiian_phrase: Kahi keiki maʻi lewalewa.
english_phrase: Small child with dangling penis.
meaning_phrase: A term of ridicule for a small boy who acts like a grownup. Until a boy was old enough to enter the mua (men’s eating house), he wore no malo.

hawaiian_phrase: Kāhiko i Nuʻuanu ka ua Waʻahila.
english_phrase: Adorned is Nuuanu by the Waʻahila rain.
meaning_phrase: The Wa’ahila rain makes Nuʻuanu grow green and beautiful.

hawaiian_phrase: Kāhiko o ke akua.
english_phrase: The adornment of the gods.
meaning_phrase: A shower of rain. The gods express their approval with rain.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka hiku o nā lani.
english_phrase: The seventh of the heavenly ones.
meaning_phrase: A term of affection for Kalākaua, who was the seventh ruler of united Hawai’i.

hawaiian_phrase: Kahilihili lau ʻilima.
english_phrase: A brushing off with ʻilima leaves.
meaning_phrase: After leaping into dirt at Kaumaea, Kaʻū, the players wiped off the dust that adhered to their skin with ʻilima branches before going to Paiahaʻa to surf. Later applied to one who takes a sketchy bath.

hawaiian_phrase: Kahilipulu Kohala na ka makani.
english_phrase: Kohala is swept, mulch and all, by the wind.
meaning_phrase: Kohala is a windy place.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka hilu pani wai o Hauʻula.
english_phrase: The water-damming hilu fish of Hauula.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Hauʻula, Oʻahu. In ancient days, two brothers came from Kahiki in the form of hilu fish. Near Oʻahu they separated, one going to the east side of the island and the other to the west. The younger brother was caught in a net at Hauʻula and divided among the families of the fishermen. When the older brother arrived he was grieved to find pieces of his brother’s body throughout the village. He went to the upland and dammed the water of the stream with his own body. After a while he rose, and the backed-up water rushed down, sweeping everyone into the sea. The pieces of his brother’s body were joined again into a hilu fish.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka home kaupoku ʻole.
english_phrase: The home without a ridgepole.
meaning_phrase: A prison, ship, or any place that is occupied but is not actually a home.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka honua nui a Kāne i hoʻīnana a ʻahu kīnohinohi.
english_phrase: The great earth animated and adorned by Kāne.
meaning_phrase: Kāne was the god of fresh water and life.

hawaiian_phrase: Kahoʻolawe ʻai kūpala.
english_phrase: Kahoʻolawe, eater of kūpala.
meaning_phrase: The kūpala is a wild plant whose tubers were eaten in time of famine. It grew on Kahoʻolawe.

hawaiian_phrase: Kahu i ka lae o ka manō, he ʻale ka wahie.
english_phrase: Kindle a fire on the forehead of a shark with waves for fuel.
meaning_phrase: Said when food in the imu is not cooked because of a lack of firewood. A criticism of the hosts’ half-cooked food.

hawaiian_phrase: Kahuku ʻāina lewa.
english_phrase: Kahuku, an unstable land.
meaning_phrase: Oʻahu, according to legend, was once two islands that grew together. Kahuku is the part that bridges the gap.

hawaiian_phrase: Kahuku kau ʻaoʻao.
english_phrase: One-sided Kahuku.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Kahuku, Kaʻū. At one time, Kamehameha I made a bargain with some farmers to exchange poi for fish. A konohiki of Kahuku named Kaholowaho took huge calabashes of poi to the chief, who gave him one small fish in return. Kaholowaho tied the fish to one end of a carrying stick to show his neighbors what the chief had done. After several such exchanges, Kaholowaho brought Kamehameha a small taro in a big container. When the chief saw the taro he laughed, and from then on he played fair. The fish tied to one side of the carrying stick produced the saying, “One-sided Kahuku.”

hawaiian_phrase: Kāhunahuna paʻakai o Kālia.
english_phrase: Fine-grained salt of Kālia.
meaning_phrase: A derogatory expression for the dried, viscid matter in the comers of the eyes of an unwashed face. Kālia was a place for gathering salt, although any place name might be used.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa ʻai pū me ka lepo.
english_phrase: The fish eaten with mud.
meaning_phrase: The clam. Even when washed before cooking it still retains a bit of the mud in which it lived.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa a ka wai nui i lawe mai ai.
english_phrase: The fish borne along by the flood.
meaning_phrase: The ʻoʻopu, which was often carried to the lowlands in freshets.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa a ke kualau i lawe mai ai.
english_phrase: The fish brought in by the rain at sea.
meaning_phrase: The spawn of the manini fish that came to the islands by the millions during the summer months. They were said to come after a shower at sea, in the early morning.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa ʻau mai me he manu.
english_phrase: The fish that swims with the movements of a bird.
meaning_phrase: A turtle.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa ʻawaʻawa a ka haole.
english_phrase: The foreigners’ sour fish.
meaning_phrase: Salted salmon, a fish commonly eaten by Hawaiians after its introduction here.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa ʻeli i ka lepo.
english_phrase: The fish that digs in the mud.
meaning_phrase: The clam

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa hāʻawe i ka paʻakai.
english_phrase: The fish that carries salt on its back.
meaning_phrase: The mountain shrimp (ʻōpae kolo), a creature that does not die readily after being removed from the water. Once a stranger arrived at the house of a man noted for his stinginess. While the host loudly deplored his lack of any kind of meat to eat with the poi, a shrimp with a lump of salt on its back crawled out of a container in the corner. The selfish man had placed it there earlier, with the salt for seasoning, intending to eat it himself.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa hāhā i kahawai.
english_phrase: The fish groped for in the streams.
meaning_phrase: The ʻoʻopu, often caught by groping under rocks and hollow places in a stream.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa hali a ka makani.
english_phrase: The fish fetched by the wind.
meaning_phrase: The ʻanaeholo, a fish that travels from Honouliuli, where it breeds, to Kaipāpaʻu on the windward side of Oʻahu. It then turns about and returns to its original home. It is driven closer to shore when the wind is strong.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa hāmau leo o ʻEwa.
english_phrase: The fish of ʻEwa that silences the voice.
meaning_phrase: The pearl oyster, which has to be gathered in silence.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa hanu ʻala o kahakai.
english_phrase: The fragrant-breathed fish of the beach.
meaning_phrase: The līpoa, a seaweed with an odor easily detected from a distance.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa hāwanawana i ka wāwae, a ʻōlelo i ka lau o ka lima.
english_phrase: The fish that whispers to the feet and speaks to the tips of the fingers.
meaning_phrase: The mahamoe, found in the sand. It is felt under the feet and picked up by the fingers.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa hei i ka uahi.
english_phrase: The fish caught by smoke.
meaning_phrase: Birds caught at night with a net after being attracted by a bonfire.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa hoʻāla i ka pō, wai lama i ke ahi.
english_phrase: The fish that wakes people up at night and causes a glowing of torches over the water.
meaning_phrase: The mālolo, or flying fish.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa hōʻeha lima.
english_phrase: The fish that can hurt the hands.
meaning_phrase: The wana (sea urchin).

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa holehole iwi o ka ʻāina.
english_phrase: The fish of the land that strips the flesh from the bones.
meaning_phrase: Goats. When one pursues them for meat, many a limb suffers skinning and bruises.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa hoʻohihia makau o ʻĀinahou.
english_phrase: The fish of ʻĀinahou that tangles the fish line.
meaning_phrase: The ʻalalauwā, which came in great schools to the waterfront of Honolulu. Fishermen of all ages came with their poles to fish, and the crowds were sometimes so great that the lines tangled.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa hoʻopā ʻili kanaka o Waimea.
english_phrase: The fish of Waimea that touch the skins of people.
meaning_phrase: When it was the season for hinana, the spawn of ʻoʻopu, at Waimea, Kauaʻi, they were so numerous that one couldn’t go into the water without rubbing against them.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa hoʻopumehana i ka weuweu.
english_phrase: The fish that warms the clumps of grass.
meaning_phrase: Mountain shrimp, which cling to weeds and grasses along the banks of streams when a cloudburst occurs in the upland. Unlike the ʻoʻopu, they are not washed down to the lowland.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa huli wale i ka pōhaku.
english_phrase: The fish that turns over the stones.
meaning_phrase: The wī, a shellfish found in mountain streams. They can be discovered only by turning over the stones to which they cling.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻia i ka pōhuehue.
english_phrase: Smitten with the pōhuehue.
meaning_phrase: Said of a victim of sorcery. One who bore ill against another would smite the sea with a pōhuehue vine while the intended victim was at sea.
