It was believed that with the proper incantations this would cause the surf to rise. The sea would become rough and dangerous and the intended victim would be killed.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa i māʻona ai ka menehune.
english_phrase: The fish that satisfied the menehune.
meaning_phrase: Shrimp. A man once rewarded some menehune friends with shrimp after they had made him a canoe.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa ʻimi i ka moana, na ka manu e haʻi mai.
english_phrase: The fish sought for in the ocean, whose presence is revealed by birds.
meaning_phrase: A school of aku, whose presence is signaled by the gathering of noio at sea.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa ʻiniki o ka mākeke.
english_phrase: The pinched fish of the market.
meaning_phrase: Fish at the market are pinched by customers to determine their freshness.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa i nui ai o Kamehameha.
english_phrase: The fish on which Kamehameha was raised.
meaning_phrase: Taro greens. The Kamehameha mentioned here is the son of Kekaulike, ruler of Maui, not Kamehameha I, the conqueror. Once, when it was necessary for his personal attendants to be gone for the day, the chief, who was then a small child, was left in the care of his attendants’ two young sons. Taro greens had been prepared and cooked for the royal child, because they were tender and easy to swallow. Kekaulike arrived unexpectedly and was displeased to see only taro greens instead of fish being given to his son. When the boys, who did not recognize him, explained that this was a very precious child and that the taro greens were fed him because they had no bones that would lodge in his throat, Kekaulike was pleased. Thus the little chief, who was reared at Pakaikai, Moloka’i, became known as Kamehameha-nui-ʻai-lūʻau (Great Kamehameha, Eater-of-taro-greens).

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa kaʻa poepoe o Kalapana, ʻīnaʻi ʻuala o Kaimū.
english_phrase: The round, rolling fish of Kalapana, to be eaten with the sweet potato of Kaimū.
meaning_phrase: The kukui nut, cooked and eaten as a relish. This is from a hoʻopāpā riddling chant in the story of Kaipalaoa, a boy of Puna, Hawaiʻi, who went to Kauaʻi to riddle with the experts there and won.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa kā kēhau o ka ʻāina.
english_phrase: The dew-dislodging fish of the land.
meaning_phrase: The ʻūhini, a locust (now extinct) that was caught in the morning while the dew was still on the shrubbery. They were strung on the stems of grass blossoms, broiled and eaten.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa kālai i ke koʻi.
english_phrase: The fish hewn with a hatchet.
meaning_phrase: Animals which produce beef, pork, mutton, venison, etc. Such meat has to be cut or chopped to a size that makes cooking easier.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa kāohi aho o nā kai uli.
english_phrase: The fish of the deep that pulls the line taut.
meaning_phrase: The ulua. Also, a fine lad.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa kaulana i ka waha o ka ʻale.
english_phrase: The fish that rests over the furrows of the billows.
meaning_phrase: The mālolo, or flying fish.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa kā wāwae o Hīlia.
english_phrase: The fish of Hīlia, kicked by the feet.
meaning_phrase: Mullet. Hīlia is a place on Molokaʻi where mullet often come in schools near the shore. The people, wading into the water, would kick the fish ashore where others would pick them up.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa kā welelau o ke ahi.
english_phrase: The fish that lies on the top edge of the fire.
meaning_phrase: The ʻoʻopu, wrapped in ti leaves and laid on the hot coals.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa kīnohinohi pōhaku.
english_phrase: The fish that adorn the rocks.
meaning_phrase: The periwinkles and nerites that cling to the rocks in shallow water.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa koʻekoʻe o ka ʻili i ka wai.
english_phrase: The fish that chills one’s skin in the water.
meaning_phrase: The ʻoʻopu, usually found in upland streams.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa kuehu ōkea.
english_phrase: The fish that scatters white sand.
meaning_phrase: The ʻōhiki (sand crab), which kicks out the sand as it makes its burrow.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa kuhi lima o ʻEwa.
english_phrase: The gesturing fish of ʻEwa.
meaning_phrase: The pipi, or pearl oyster. Fishermen did not speak when fishing for them but gestured to each other like deaf-mutes.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa lamalama i ka pali.
english_phrase: The fish caught by torching along the seacoast.
meaning_phrase: The ʻaʻama, a crab that is often caught at night by torching along the rocky shore.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa lamalama i ke one.
english_phrase: The fish caught in the sand by torching.
meaning_phrase: The ʻōhiki, or sand crab.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa lau nui o ka ʻāina.
english_phrase: Big-leaved fish of the land.
meaning_phrase: Lūʻau, or taro greens.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa lauoho loloa o ka ʻāina.
english_phrase: The long-haired fish of the land.
meaning_phrase: Any vegetable eaten with poi, such as taro greens, hoʻiʻo or kikawaiō ferns, or sweet potato greens. Poetically, leaves are the oho or lauoho, hair, of plants.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa lauoho loloa o ke kai.
english_phrase: The long-haired fish of the sea.
meaning_phrase: Limu, or seaweed.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa lawe mai a ka makani, he lāʻau ka ʻupena e hei ai.
english_phrase: The fish brought by the wind, a stick is the net to catch them with.
meaning_phrase: Said of turtles that come to certain localities in the islands. They were driven ashore with sticks.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa lele me he manu.
english_phrase: The fish that flies like a bird.
meaning_phrase: The mālolo, or flying fish.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa leo nui o ka pali.
english_phrase: Loud-voiced fish of the cliffs.
meaning_phrase: Goats, which were pursued by shouting hunters.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa leo nui o Keʻehi.
english_phrase: Loud-voicedfish of Keʻehi.
meaning_phrase: Mullet, which were often found in large schools at Keʻehi Lagoon. Fishermen talked and shouted as they drove the fish into their nets.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa loloa o ke kai.
english_phrase: The long fish of the sea.
meaning_phrase: The eel.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa māewa i ke kai.
english_phrase: The fish that sways in the sea.
meaning_phrase: The limu (seaweed), which sways with the movement of the sea.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa mana nui.
english_phrase: The fish of many divided parts.
meaning_phrase: The octopus, with its eight tentacles.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa maunu lima o Kuloloia.
english_phrase: The hand-baited fish of Kuloloia.
meaning_phrase: Small eels (pūhi ʻōilo) that were caught by placing bait on the open palm of one hand with the fingers held wide apart. When the eels came up to take the bait, the fingers were clenched into a tight fist, grabbing the eels tightly by the heads.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa maunu ʻole o ke kahawai.
english_phrase: The fish of the stream that requires no bait.
meaning_phrase: The wī, a freshwater shellfish.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa mili i ka poho o ka lima.
english_phrase: The fish fondled by the palm of the hand.
meaning_phrase: When it was the season for the hinana (ʻoʻopu spawn), they were so numerous that they could be scooped up in the palm of the hand.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa mili lima o ʻUlakoheo.
english_phrase: The fish of ʻ Ulakoheo, handled by many hands.
meaning_phrase: Fish sold in a market. There was a fishmarket at ʻUlakoheo in Honolulu.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa moe kahawai.
english_phrase: The fish that lies in the stream.
meaning_phrase: The ʻoʻopu.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa nānā i ka lani ke ola.
english_phrase: The fish that looks to the sky for life.
meaning_phrase: Any vegetable, a food depending on sunshine and rain for subsistence.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa pā i ka ihu o ka waʻa a lele.
english_phrase: The fish that touches the prow of the canoe and leaps.
meaning_phrase: The mālolo, or flying fish.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa pani i ka waha o ke kānaka.
english_phrase: The fish that closes the mouth of men.
meaning_phrase: The pearl oyster, which was gathered in silence.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa pīkoi kānaka o Kālia; he kānaka ka pīkoi, he kānaka ka pōhaku.
english_phrase: The fish caught by the men of Kālia; men are the floaters, men are the sinkers. [Kālia is a fishing net with human floats, human sinkers. (PE)]
meaning_phrase: In ancient days, when a school of mullet appeared at Kālia, Oʻahu, a bag net was set and the men swam out in a row and surrounded the fish. Then the men would slap the water together and kick their feet, driving the frightened fish into the opening of their bag net. Thus the fishermen of Kālia became known as human fishnets.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa pipili i ka lima.
english_phrase: The fish that sticks to the hand.
meaning_phrase: The octopus, whose tentacles have suction cups.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa uahi a holo i ka pali.
english_phrase: The fish pursued by running after them on the hills.
meaning_phrase: Goats.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa uahi nui o ka ʻāina; o ka iʻa ma luna, o ka ʻai ma lalo.
english_phrase: The many smoky fish of the land; with the fish ahove and the vegetable food beneath.
meaning_phrase: This refers not to any particular fish or meat but to anything that is cooked in an imu. When lighted, the imu is smoky until the stones redden and the wood is reduced to coals.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa ʻula weli i ke kai.
english_phrase: The red fish that causes a red color to show in the sea.
meaning_phrase: The ʻalalauwā, a small red fish whose appearance in great numbers was regarded as a sign that a member of the royal family would soon die.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa ʻumi i ka hanu.
english_phrase: The fish that holds the breath.
meaning_phrase: The wana, or sea urchin. The fisherman holds his breath as he dives for them.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa ʻuwā lua.
english_phrase: The fish of loud shouting.
meaning_phrase: The mālolo. The fishermen who went out for them did not hold their silence but shouted and called to one another.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa wale nui o ke Koʻolau.
english_phrase: The slimy fish of the windward side [of Oʻahu].
meaning_phrase: An octopus. Before it is ready to eat, it must be pounded and rubbed with salt to remove the slime and make it tender.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iʻa wāwae loloa.
english_phrase: The long-legged fish.
meaning_phrase: A human sacrifice.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaiehu ʻia a pulu ka puka uahi.
english_phrase: The sea tosses up the sprays, wetting the smokestack.
meaning_phrase: Said of a towering rage.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaihalulu i ke alo o Kaʻuiki.
english_phrase: Kaihalulu lies in the presence of Kaʻuiki.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who is always found in the company of another. Kai-halulu (Roaring-sea) is a place that lies before Kaʻuiki hill in Hāna, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iho ʻana iho o ko luna poʻe, hikikiʻi ka ua o ʻEna.
english_phrase: When those from above come down, the rain of ʻEna leans backward.
meaning_phrase: When drowsiness comes, one can lean back and relax contentedly. Also, when one feels mellow after imbibing, there is contentment and relaxation.

hawaiian_phrase: Kā i ka ʻai ka ʻaihue.
english_phrase: A thief is hurt in his thievery.
meaning_phrase: Theft is accompanied by fear.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaʻikaʻi i ka lima, hiʻi i ke alo.
english_phrase: Lead with one hand, carry with one arm.
meaning_phrase: Said of a mother with children born too close together.

hawaiian_phrase: Kā i ka ʻino.
english_phrase: To smite with evil.
meaning_phrase: Hikapoloa, a Kohala chief, treated his brothers-in-law with severe cruelty and later was destroyed by them.

hawaiian_phrase: Kā i kaʻino, no ka ʻino.
english_phrase: To return evil for evil.
meaning_phrase: Said by Kamehameha. All iron that was found belonged to him.

hawaiian_phrase: Kai-ka-ʻowā.
english_phrase: Sea divided.
meaning_phrase: A cry uttered by the chief Kekuaokalani, nephew of Kamehameha I, and his men while guarding the ruling chief night after night.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaʻi ka puaʻa i luna o Hāʻupu, e ua ana.
english_phrase: When the pigs move around the summit of Hāʻupu, it is going to rain.
meaning_phrase: When puffy “pig” clouds encircle the top of Hāʻupu, above Kīpū on Kauaʻi, it is a sign of rain.

hawaiian_phrase: Kā i ka waha.
english_phrase: Struck the mouth.
meaning_phrase: Having criticized or spoken unkindly of others, the things he said happened to him.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻike a ka makua he hei na ke keiki.
english_phrase: The knowledge of the parent is [unconsciously] absorbed by the child.
meaning_phrase: Why believe all that? It is only wind.

hawaiian_phrase: Kā i ke kino.
english_phrase: Smites the body.
meaning_phrase: Said of the evil done to others that rebounds and hurts the person who started it.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iki koaiʻe a Hanakāpīʻai.
english_phrase: The small koaiʻe tree of Hanakāpīʻai.
meaning_phrase: A boast of that locality on Kauaʻi. One may be small in stature but he is as tough and sturdy as the koaiʻe tree.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iki ʻulu kēia o Kanekina e kōkē ai nā pine.
english_phrase: This is the little bowling ball of Kanekina that knocks down the pins.
meaning_phrase: A boast: This fellow may be small but he is powerful.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaikoʻeke a ka hāuna ʻino.
english_phrase: Brothers-in-law who smite severely.
meaning_phrase: Hikapoloa, a Kohala chief, treated his brothers-in-law with severe cruelty and later was destroyed by them.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaikoʻo ke awa, popoʻi ka nalu, ʻaʻohe ʻike ʻia ka poʻe nāna i heʻe ka nalu.
english_phrase: The harbor is rough, the surf rolls, and the rider of the surf cannot be seen.
meaning_phrase: A stormy circumstance with uncertain results.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻili hau pā kai o ʻAlio.
english_phrase: The hau bark, wet by the sea sprays of ʻAlio.
meaning_phrase: This is a reference to a strong shore-dweller. Salt air and sea sprays made the bark of the hau trees on the shore stronger than those of the upland. ʻAlio is a place on Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaʻiliʻili hānau o Kōloa; ka nalu haʻi o Kāwā.
english_phrase: The reproducing pebbles of Kōloa; the breaking surf of Kāwā.
meaning_phrase: In Punaluʻu, Kaʻū, is a small beach called Kōloa. The pebbles found here were believed to reproduce — the smooth ones being males and the porous ones, females. These were considered the best on the island of Hawaiʻi for hula ʻiliʻili. Kāwā is just beyond Kōloa toward Honuʻapo.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻiliʻili o ʻĀʻalāmanu.
english_phrase: Pebbles of ʻĀʻalāmanu.
meaning_phrase: ʻAʻalāmanu is in Puna, Hawaiʻi. The best pebbles of this district were found here and were much liked by the chiefs for the game of kōnane.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻiliʻili o Kalaekimo.
english_phrase: The pebbles of Kalaekimo.
meaning_phrase: Kalaekimo is where the chiefs of Kaʻū played the game of kimo. The pebbles there were much liked for the purpose. The place is now called Kalaeokimo.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaino he koa no ka lā nui, he koa kā no ka lā iki.
english_phrase: [I thought] you were warriors worthy of a great day, but instead you are warriors of a short day.
meaning_phrase: Said of those who flee in cowardice.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaino paha he pali nui o Kīpū e ʻōlelo ia nei, eia kā he pali iki nō.
english_phrase: By the way it is talked about, one would think that Kīpū is a large cliff, but instead it is only a small one.
meaning_phrase: By the way people talked the task sounded difficult, but it was easy after all. Kīpū is on Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Kai nuʻu a Kāne.
english_phrase: Kāne’s rising sea.
meaning_phrase: The foamy sea that follows after a tumbling wave.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaiʻokia kānāwai.
english_phrase: An ocean-separating edict.
meaning_phrase: A law of Pele. When pronounced over a person it set him apart as Pele’s exclusively.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻiole ʻaihue moa o Keauhou.
english_phrase: The chicken-stealing rat of Keauhou.
meaning_phrase: One who steals another’s sweetheart or mate. Any place name may be used, depending on where the “rat” is from.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻio nui maka lana au moku.
english_phrase: The great ʻio with eyes that see everywhere on the land.
meaning_phrase: A ruling chief.

hawaiian_phrase: Kai pakī o Maunalua.
english_phrase: The spraying sea of Maunalua [Oʻahu].
meaning_phrase: Said of a courageous person who withstands the storm of life. Point Maunauna (Battered) is at Waimea, Oʻahu, where high seas are common.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ipukukui pio ʻole i ke Kauaʻula.
english_phrase: The light that will not go out in spite of the blowing of the Kauaʻula wind.
meaning_phrase: Said of the Lahainaluna School, where many leaders of old Hawaiʻi were educated.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka iwi ʻopihi o ka ʻāina ʻē.
english_phrase: ʻOpihi shells from foreign lands.
meaning_phrase: Money.

hawaiian_phrase: Kakaʻi ka puapuaʻa i ka mālie, he ʻino.
english_phrase: When the piglets follow one after the other in the calm, it is a sign of bad weather.
meaning_phrase: When the clouds called ao puapuaʻa or puaʻa, “pig” clouds, follow one after the other on the mountaintops in calm weather, bad weather is to be expected.

hawaiian_phrase: Kā! Ke lele mai nei ka pāoʻo.
english_phrase: Ha! The pāoʻo fish is leaping about.
meaning_phrase: A remark made about one who snuffles and does not blow his nose. The mucus of a runny nose darts in and out of the nostril like a pāoʻo fish in its sea pool.

hawaiian_phrase: Kākia kui nao a ke akamai.
english_phrase: The nailing down of a screw by an expert.
meaning_phrase: A boast of skill in securing something and holding on to it. This saying is taken from an old love song in which the singer claims that the love of her sweetheart is securcly nailed down.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka lāʻau kumu ʻole o Kahilikolo.
english_phrase: The trunkless tree of Kahilikolo.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who lacks a family background. Famed in many Kauaʻi chants and legends is the trunkless koa tree of Kahilikolo. The tree does not grow upright but spreads over the ground. To say that one has found the trunk of Kahilikolo is to say that he has found nothing.

hawaiian_phrase: Kālaʻe peʻe kākonakona.
english_phrase: Kālaʻe hides and avoids contacts.
meaning_phrase: Applied to the kauwā in Kālaʻe, Molokaʻi. The chiefs there were proud and arrogant and the kauwā were full of humility and fear for their lives.

hawaiian_phrase: Kalaʻihi ka lani, kūpilikiʻi ka honua.
english_phrase: When the day is stormy, the earth is distressed.
meaning_phrase: When the chief is angry, the people are unhappy.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka lā i ka Mauliola.
english_phrase: The sun at the source of life.
meaning_phrase: Mauli-ola (Breath-of-life) is the god of health.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka lā ikiiki o Honolulu.
english_phrase: The intensely warm days of Honolulu.
meaning_phrase: People from the country often claim that Honolulu is excessively warm.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka laʻi loa a Kamaluohua.
english_phrase: The long peace of Kamaluohua.
meaning_phrase: Said of the long period of peace enjoyed by this chief of Maui after his retum from Kauaʻi. He and others had accompanied the chief of Hawaiʻi there to make war. They were defeated, but their lives were spared by Kūkona, ruler of Kauaʻi, and they were kindly treated. After a while the defeated chiefs plotted to tum against Kūkona, but Kamaluohua refused to hurt their kind benefactor. As a reward for his loyalty, he and the others were permitted to go home to their respective islands. Kamaluohua spent the rest of his days in peace. The saying was later used to refer to permanent peace after a period of trouble.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka laʻi o Hauola.
english_phrase: The calm of Hauola.
meaning_phrase: Peace and comfort. There is a stone in the sea at Lahama, Maui, called Pōhaku-o-Hauola, where pregnant women went to sit to ensure an easy birth. The umbilical cords of babies were hidden in crevices in the stone.

hawaiian_phrase: Kālai o Lūaliʻi i ke kiʻi a ʻike i ka ʻino haʻalele.
english_phrase: Lūaliʻi carved an image and, finding it bad, deserted it.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who abandons a thing he used to indulge in. Lūaliʻi was a chief of Hawaiʻi who wanted to carve an image. He went to the mountains, found a log and bore it to the lowland to work on. It was almost finished when he discovered a rotted spot. He deserted it and went to find another log to carve. As he worked on the second log he heard the first one say, “Lūaliʻi carved an image and, finding it bad, deserted it.” He went back to it, cleaned out the rotted spot and finished it. He knew that a god possessed it. This god later helped him rid Oʻahu of evil beings.

hawaiian_phrase: Kala kahiko i au wale ai ka lā.
english_phrase: The sun has gone down long since.
meaning_phrase: A reply to one who asks about something that took place a long time ago.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka lā koi hana o Lahainaluna.
english_phrase: The sun of Lahainaluna urges one to work.
meaning_phrase: Daytime at the Lahainaluna School is occupied with studying and working.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka lālā kaukonakona haki ʻole i ka pā a ka makani Kona.
english_phrase: The tough branch that does not break in the Kona gales.
meaning_phrase: Said of a sturdy, strong person.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka lama kū o ka noʻeau.
english_phrase: The standing torch of wisdom.
meaning_phrase: Said in admiration of a wise person.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka lani kaʻapuni honua.
english_phrase: The chief who went around the world.
meaning_phrase: Kalākaua, who traveled to many lands.

hawaiian_phrase: Kalaoaʻai pōʻeleʻele.
english_phrase: Kalaoa eats in the dark.
meaning_phrase: The people of Kalaoa in east Hilo were noted for their lack of hospitality. To avoid having to ask visitors or passers-by to partake of food with them, they ate in the dark where they could not be seen.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka lauaʻe ʻala o Kalalau.
english_phrase: Fragrant lauaʻe ferns of Kalalau.
meaning_phrase: Makana and Kalalau, on Kauaʻi, were noted for the growth and fragrance of lauaʻe fems.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka lau ʻoliwa a ke aloha.
english_phrase: The olive leaf of love.
meaning_phrase: A gift, kindly given. From the story of Noah’s Ark.

hawaiian_phrase: Kalaupapa ʻai ʻinoʻino.
english_phrase: Kalaupapa of the bad food.
meaning_phrase: An epithet for Kalaupapa, Molokaʻi. In the early days of the leper settlement, the food situation was deplorable. Poi was floated in on the tide, and meat sometimes began to spoil before it was received.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka lawaiʻa nui i ʻeaʻea nā kuʻemaka, i ʻehuʻehu nā lihilihi.
english_phrase: The great fisherman whose brows are salt-encrusted and whose lashes are reddened [by the sun].
meaning_phrase: Said in admiration of an experienced fisherman who has spent many a day at his trade.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka lehua neneʻe o Kāʻana.
english_phrase: The low-growing lehua of Kāʻana.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Kāʻana, Molokaʻi. Often mentioned in chants of Molokaʻi, the lehua of Kāʻana were loved by the goddess Kapo. This lehua grove was destroyed by introduced animals. The first or one of the first hula schools in the islands is said to have been located at Kāʻana.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka lei hāʻule ʻole, he keiki.
english_phrase: A lei that is never cast aside is one’s child.
meaning_phrase: Such a scattering all over the place, like fallen leaves, with bits and pieces all strewn about. A play on haule-lau (fallen leaves), kalalau (wander around), lū-aliʻi (scatter in pieces), and kau-liʻiliʻi (a little here and a little there).

hawaiian_phrase: Kālele ka uahi o Puʻuloa.
english_phrase: The smoke of Puuloa leans over.
meaning_phrase: Said in amusement of one who leans over, intent on his work.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka leo o ke ola.
english_phrase: The voice of life.
meaning_phrase: Said of any helpful advice or suggestion, or of a kindly invitation to eat.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka lepo alualu me he kanaka lā.
english_phrase: The dust that runs after one like a person.
meaning_phrase: Said of the dust raised up by a whirlwind and carried, spinning round and round like a living object.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka limu kā kanaka o Manuʻakepa.
english_phrase: The man-throwing algae of Manuakepa.
meaning_phrase: Hanalei, Kauaʻi, was known for its pouring rain. A slippery algae grows among the grasses on the beach, and when carelessly stepped on, it can cause one to slip and fall. This algae is famed in songs and chants of that locality.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka limu lana o Kawahine.
english_phrase: The fioating seaweed of Kawahine.
meaning_phrase: A term applied to the kauwā who were drowned at Kualoa, Oʻahu, before serving as sacrifices.

hawaiian_phrase: Kālina ka pono, ʻaʻohe hua o ka puʻe, aia ka hua i ka lālā.
english_phrase: The potato hill is bare of tubers for the plant no longer bears; it is the vines that are now bearing.
meaning_phrase: The mother is no longer bearing, but her children are.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka liona o ka Pākīpika.
english_phrase: The lion of the Pacific.
meaning_phrase: Kamehameha I.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka līpoa ʻala o Kalauonaona.
english_phrase: The fragrant līpoa seaweed of Kalauonaona.
meaning_phrase: The most fragrant līpoa seaweed in Puna, Hawaiʻi, is found at Kalauonaona (also known as Kalauonaone) in Kaimū.

hawaiian_phrase: Kalo kanu o ka ʻāina.
english_phrase: Taro planted on the land.
meaning_phrase: Natives of the land from generations back.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka lonolau no i ka lonolau; ka puʻulīʻulī no i ka puʻulīʻulī.
english_phrase: The large gourds to the large gourds; the little gourds to the little gourds.
meaning_phrase: In battle, chiefs attack chiefs and commoners fight commoners. Also, chiefs seek the society of chiefs, commoners the society of commoners.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka lua kupapaʻu o na aliʻi.
english_phrase: The burial place of chiefs.
meaning_phrase: Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi, where the bones of many noted ones are hidden in secret caves.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka lulu o Moikeha i ka laulā o Kapaʻa.
english_phrase: The calm of Moikeha in the breadth of Kapaʻa.
meaning_phrase: Thc chief Moikeha enjoyed the peace of Kapaʻa, Kauaʻi, the place he chose as his permanent home.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka Maʻaʻa wehe lau niu o Lele.
english_phrase: The Maʻaʻa wind that lifts the coco leaves of Lele.
meaning_phrase: Lele is the old name for Lahaina, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Kama ʻia ke aloha a paʻa i loko.
english_phrase: Bind love that it may remain fast within.
meaning_phrase: Be a person who knows love.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka maile lau liʻi o Koʻiahi.
english_phrase: The fine-leaved maile of Koʻiahi.
meaning_phrase: Koʻiahi, Oʻahu, was famed in old chants for the finest and most fragrant small-leaved maile in the islands. It was destroyed by introduced animals.

hawaiian_phrase: Kamaʻilio ka waha, hana ka lima.
english_phrase: Let the mouth talk while the hands work.
meaning_phrase: While talking, keep the hands busy.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka makani ʻĀpaʻapaʻa o Kohala.
english_phrase: The ʻĀpaʻapaʻa wind of Kohala.
meaning_phrase: Kohala was famed in song and story for the ʻĀpaʻapaʻa wind of that district.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka makani ʻawa o Leleiwi.
english_phrase: The cold wind of Leleiwi.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Leleiwi Point in Hilo district.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka makani haʻihaʻi lau hau o Olowalu.
english_phrase: The hau-leaf tearing wind of Olowalu.
meaning_phrase: A gusty wind.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka makani hali ʻala o Puna.
english_phrase: The fragrance-bearing wind of Puna.
meaning_phrase: Puna, Hawaiʻi, was famed for the fragrance of maile, lehua, and hala. It was said that when the wind blew from the land, fishermen at sea could smell the fragrance of these leaves and flowers.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka makani hāpala lepo o Pāʻia.
english_phrase: Dust-smearing wind of Paia.
meaning_phrase: Pāʻia, Maui, is a dusty place.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka makani Hoʻeo o Moanalua.
english_phrase: The Hoʻeo, whistling wind of Moanalua.
meaning_phrase: Moanalua is on Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka makani hoʻolapa o Kaumaea.
english_phrase: The playful wind of Kaumaea.
meaning_phrase: Kaumaea is in Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka makani kā ʻAhaʻaha laʻi o Niua.
english_phrase: The peaceful ʻAhaʻaha breeze of Niua that drives in the ʻahaʻaha fish.
meaning_phrase: The ʻAhaʻaha breeze begins as the Kiliʻoʻopu in Waiheʻe, Maui, before reaching Niua Point in Waiehu. It is a gentle breeze and the sea is calm when it blows. Fishermen launch their canoes and go forth to fish, for that is the time when the ʻahaʻaha fish arrive in schools.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka makani kāʻili aloha o Kīpahulu.
english_phrase: The love-snatching wind of Kīpahulu.
meaning_phrase: A woman of Kipahulu, Maui, listened to the entreaties of a man from Oʻahu and left her husband and children to go with him to his home island. Her husband missed her very much and grieved. He mentioned his grief to a kahuna skilled in hana aloha sorcery, who told the man to find a container with a lid. The man was told to talk into it, telling of his love for his wife. Then the kahuna uttered an incantation into the container, closed it, and hurled it into the sea. The wife was fishing one morning at Kālia, Oʻahu, when she saw a container floating in on a wave. She picked it up and opened it, whereupon a great longing possessed her to go home. She walked until she found a canoe to take her to Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka makani kāʻili kapa o Nuʻuanu.
english_phrase: The garment-snatching wind of Nuuanu.
meaning_phrase: The gale that blows at Nuʻuanu Pali, Oʻahu, could whisk away the tapa garment of a traveler there.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka makani kokololio o Waikapiā.
english_phrase: The swift, gusty wind of Waikapū.
meaning_phrase: Waikapū is on Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka makani kuehu lepo o Naʻalehu.
english_phrase: The dust-scattering wind of Naʻalehu.
meaning_phrase: Said of good crops as a result of showers.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka makani kūkulu peʻa nui, he ʻEka.
english_phrase: The ʻEka, the wind that sets up the big sails.
meaning_phrase: When the ʻEka wind blew in Kona, Hawaiʻi, the fishermen sailed out to the fishing grounds.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka makani kulaʻi kanaka o Nuʻuanu.
english_phrase: The wind of Nuʻuanu that pushes people over.
meaning_phrase: The strong gales at Nuʻuanu were known to make travelers fall down.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka makani wehe lau niu o Laupāhoehoe.
english_phrase: The coconut-leaf-lifting wind of Laupāhoehoe.
meaning_phrase: Laupāhoehoe, Hawai’i.

hawaiian_phrase: Kamaliʻi hūpe kole.
english_phrase: Runny-nosed brats.
meaning_phrase: Advice to a bride. Be too friendly with another woman and she may hecome too friendly with your husband.

hawaiian_phrase: Kamaliʻi ʻike ʻole i ka helu pō: Muku nei, Muku ka malama; Hilo nei, kau ka Hoaka.
english_phrase: Children who do not know the moon phases: Muku is here, Muku the moon; Hilo comes next, then Hoaka.
meaning_phrase: The first part of a child’s chant for learning the names of the moon phases. Also said of one who does not know the answer to a question or is ignorant. He is compared to a small child who has not learned the moon phases.

hawaiian_phrase: Kamaliʻi ʻōkole heleleʻi.
english_phrase: Loose-seated child.
meaning_phrase: A small child excretes anywhere he pleases. Such a child isn’t old enough to know anything.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka malu ao o nā pali kapu o Kakaʻe.
english_phrase: The cloud shelter of the sacred cliffs of Kakaʻe.
meaning_phrase: Kakaʻe, an ancient ruler of Maui, was buried in ʻīao Valley, and the place was given his name. It was known as Na-pali-kapu-o-Kakaʻe (Kakaʻe’s Sacred Precipice) or Na-pela-kapu-o-Kakaʻe (Kakaʻe’s Sacred Flesh). Since that time, many high chiefs have shared his burial place.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka malu hālau loa o ke kukui.
english_phrase: The long shelter of the kukui trees.
meaning_phrase: A kukui grove shelters like a house.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka malu niu o Huʻehuʻewai.
english_phrase: The coconut grove of Huʻehuʻewai.
meaning_phrase: This grove was in Kaimū, Puna.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka malu niu o Pōkāʻī.
english_phrase: The coco-palm shade of Pōkaī.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Waiʻanae, on Oʻahu. At Pōkāʻī was the largest and best-known coconut grove on Oʻahu, famed in chants and songs.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka manu hoʻāla i ke ao.
english_phrase: The bird that wakes [everyone] at daybreak.
meaning_phrase: The rooster.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka manu kāhea i ka waʻa e holo.
english_phrase: The bird that calls to the canoe - to sail.
meaning_phrase: Said of the kioea (stilt), whose early morning call was often a signal to canoemen to be ready to fish or travel.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka manu kaʻupu hālō ʻale o ka moana.
english_phrase: The kaʻupu, the bird that observes the ocean.
meaning_phrase: Said of a careful observer.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka manu keʻu ahiahi.
english_phrase: The bird that croaks in the evening.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who talks of or brings bad luck. When the ʻalae (mudhen) croaks near a house at night, trouble is to be expected there.

hawaiian_phrase: Kamaʻomaʻo, ka ʻāina huli hana.
english_phrase: At Kamaʻomaʻo, land of activities.
meaning_phrase: Ghosts who do not go to the pō of their ancestors often wander about in certain areas. Kamaomao, Maui, is such a place. The activities of such ghosts usually annoy the living.

hawaiian_phrase: Kamilo pae aliʻi; Kamilo pae kanaka.
english_phrase: Kamilo where chiefs land; Kamilo where commoners land.
meaning_phrase: Refers to the beach in Kaʻū called Kamilo. It is partly rocky and partly sandy. When a person died at sea between Halaaniani, Puna, and Kamilo, the current would wash up the body at this beach. If the drowned person was a chief, his body would wash up on the rough side, but if he was a commoner he would float to the smooth side where anyone could come and remove him.

hawaiian_phrase: Kamipulu Kawaihae.
english_phrase: Damned fool Kawaihae.
meaning_phrase: Said of Kawaihae natives. Some natives of Kawaihae, Hawaiʻi, once sold sweet potatoes to the captain of a ship. He discovered some sticks placed at the bottom of the barrel for filler and called the men damned fools [kamipulu].

hawaiian_phrase: Ka moa i hānai ʻia i ka lā, ua ʻoi ia i ka moa i hānai ʻia i ka malu.
english_phrase: A cock fed in the sunlight is stronger than one fed in the shade.
meaning_phrase: If you want a strong son, raise him with plenty of sunlight.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka moe kau a Moi, ke kahuna mana o Hāʻupukele.
english_phrase: You sleep like Moi, the powerful kahuna of Haupukele.
meaning_phrase: Said to one who oversleeps. The kahuna Moi, of Hāʻupukele, Molokaʻi, had a long, prophetic dream of misfortune to befall his chief. The chief paid no attention and kidnapped a chiefess of Hilo. This led to a war with her sons, Niheu and Kana.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka moena pāwehe o Mokulēʻia.
english_phrase: The patterned mat of Mokulēʻia [Oʻahu].
meaning_phrase: It is as varied and pretty as a patterned mat.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka moe no kau a Mele Wile, ala aʻe ua moʻa i ke kuke.
english_phrase: You sleep the sleep of Mary [wife of] Willie; when you awake, the food is cooked.
meaning_phrase: A common saying on Hawaiʻi applied to any sleepy-head. Mary, wife of William Shipman, was annoyed with a servant who constantly overslept. One morning she looked into the servant’s room and loudly uttered this condemnation. The other servants laughed, and the sleeping servant was so ashamed that she rose bright and early thereafter.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka moku kāʻili lā o Manokalanipo.
english_phrase: The sun-snatching island of Manokalanipo.
meaning_phrase: Kauaʻi, the northwesternmost island of the group, beyond which the sun vanishes at dusk. Manokalanipo was an ancient ruler of Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka moku puni kuapuʻu.
english_phrase: The hunchbacked island.
meaning_phrase: Maui. Its shape on the map resembles the figure of a hunchbacked person.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka mū ʻai paka o Puʻunui.
english_phrase: The tobacco-eating bug of Puʻunui.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is a pest. Puʻunui is now a part of Honoluiu.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka nahele hihipeʻa o Paliuli.
english_phrase: The impenetrable forest of Paliuli.
meaning_phrase: Paliuli, in Hilo, was like a mirage — at times seen and at other times unseen.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka nalu haʻaheo i ka hokua o ke kanaka.
english_phrase: The surf that proudly sweeps over the nape of one’s neck.
meaning_phrase: Said of a wind which surges and blows from the back. A play on hokua (crest of high wave).

hawaiian_phrase: Ka nalu haʻi o Kalehuawehe.
english_phrase: The rolling surf of Kalehuawehe.
meaning_phrase: Ka-lehua-wehe (Take-off-the-kehua) was Waikīkī’s most famous surf. It was so named when a legendary hero took off his lei of lehua blossoms and gave it to the wife of the ruling chief, with whom he was surfing.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka nalu heʻe o Puʻuhele.
english_phrase: The surf of Puuhele that is ridden.
meaning_phrase: Puʻuhele is a place in Hāna, Maui, where there is good surfing.

hawaiian_phrase: Kani ka moa i ka ʻīpuka, he malihini kipa.
english_phrase: When a cock crows at the door, a guest is to he expected.
meaning_phrase: Mind your own business, or you’ll hear something that will hurt your feelings.

hawaiian_phrase: Kani ka pahu, holo ke kao.
english_phrase: The drum is sounded, the goat flees.
meaning_phrase: A humorous expression applied to a bald-headed man whose bare head is likened to a drum.

hawaiian_phrase: Kani ka pola o ka malo.
english_phrase: The flap of the loincloth makes a snapping sound.
meaning_phrase: The boast of an athlete so swift in movement that the flap of his loincloth snaps.

hawaiian_phrase: Kani ke ʻō, he ihona pali.
english_phrase: One may shout with joy, as this is a going downhill.
meaning_phrase: The hard work is over; from here on all is easy.

hawaiian_phrase: Kani kōlea, he kanaka; nū ka puaʻa, he lapu lā.
english_phrase: When a plover cries, there is a man nearby; when a pig grunts, a ghost is near.
meaning_phrase: Said while drawing down the lid of the eye in contempt. Also, a vulgar expression arising from the following story: On Hawaiʻi lived a man who was dim-sighted but not entirely blind, though he liked to pretend to be so. One day, two women saw him coming with a friend, and one said to the other, “One of those men can see, and the other is not as blind as he pretends to be.” Her companion disagreed. “I am sure he is blind,” she said. Then the first woman replied, “I will expose myself and we shall see.” When the men drew near, the woman sat down and facing the “blind” man, exposed herself. He looked and exclaimed, “A ‘ula! Kolekole!” Because of this, his friend and the two women knew that he was not totally blind.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka nīoi aku ia e welawela ai ko nuku.
english_phrase: That is the chili pepper that will burn your lips.
meaning_phrase: Said of one whose lovemaking is like the fiery taste of peppers. It’s long remembered.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka nīoi wela o Pakaʻalana.
english_phrase: The burning nīoi of Pakaʻalana.
meaning_phrase: Refers to the heiau of Pakaʻalana in Waipiʻo, Hawaiʻi. The timber used about the doorway was of nioi wood. According to ancient legend, the nīoi, ʻohe, and kauila trees on Molokaʻi are said to be possessed by poison gods and are regarded as having mana. To tamper with the trees or the wood, especially in places of worship, is to invite serious trouble.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka niu peʻahi kanaka o Kaipalaoa.
english_phrase: The man-beckoning coco pa1ms of Kaipalaoa.
meaning_phrase: The swaying palms that once grew at Kaipalaoa, Hilo, seemed to wave an invitation.

hawaiian_phrase: Kano ke kihi poʻohiwi o Honokōhau.
english_phrase: Hard are the shoulder muscles of Honokōhau.
meaning_phrase: The people of Honokōhau, Maui, were said to be hard workers.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka nui e ʻauamo ai i ke keiki i ke kua.
english_phrase: The size that enables one to carry a smaller child on the back.
meaning_phrase: Said of a child about ten years old who has grown big enough to carry a younger sibling on his back. In ancient days the age of a child was not reckoned by years but by physical ability to perform a certain task.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka nui e moʻa ai ka pūlehu.
english_phrase: The size when one is old enough to broil food.
meaning_phrase: Old enough to have a mate.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka nui e paʻa ai i ka hue wai.
english_phrase: The size that enables one to carry a water bottle.
meaning_phrase: Said of a child about two years old. In Kaʻū, where fresh water was scarce and had to be obtained from upland springs, every person who went helped to carry home water. When a child was about two, he was given a small gourd bottle for carrying water.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka nui e paʻa ai i nā niu ʻelua.
english_phrase: The size that enables one to carry two coconuts.
meaning_phrase: Said of a child of about five.

hawaiian_phrase: Kanukanu, hūnā i ka meheu, i ka maʻawe alanui o Kapuʻukolu.
english_phrase: Covering with earth, hiding the footprints on the narrow trail of Kapuukolu.
meaning_phrase: Said of a cautious person who guards his ways from those who pry. In ancient times a person who did not want to be traced by his footsteps carefully eradicated them as he went.

hawaiian_phrase: Kanu ke kalo i Welo, ʻaʻole e ulu nui ʻia e ka ʻohā.
english_phrase: Plant taro in Welo and the offshoots will not be many.
meaning_phrase: The corm of taro planted in the month of Welo grows very large but the offishoots are few.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka nuku o Māmala.
english_phrase: The mouth of Māmala.
meaning_phrase: The entrance to Honolulu Harbor, named for a shark goddess who once lived in the vicinity.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻōhiʻa hihipeʻa o Kealakomo.
english_phrase: The entwining ʻōhiʻa branches of Kealakomo.
meaning_phrase: Kealakomo, in Puna, Hawaiʻi, where ʻōhiʻa trees grow thickly together.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaʻohu kāku o Kīlauea.
english_phrase: The draping mists of Kīlauea.
meaning_phrase: The mists in the crater of Kilauea look like drapery along its cliffs.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaʻohu wānana ua o Hāʻupu.
english_phrase: The mist of Hāʻupu that foretells rain.
meaning_phrase: When clouds circle the peak of Hāʻupu, Kauaʻi, it is sure to rain.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻōlohe puka awakea o Kamaʻomaʻo.
english_phrase: The bare one of Kamaʻomaʻo that appears at noonday.
meaning_phrase: The plain of Kamaomao, Maui, is said to be the haunt of ghosts (ʻōlohe) who appear at night or at noon. Also a play on ʻōlohe (nude), applied to one who appears unclothed.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻōnohi Wai a Uli.
english_phrase: Water of Uli made visible to the eyes.
meaning_phrase: A mirage revealed by the goddess Uli.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ō ʻole i ka wehe a ka Hoʻolua.
english_phrase: No stopping when the Hoʻolua wind opens up.
meaning_phrase: Said of anything that can’t be stopped.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻoʻopu peke o Hanakāpīʻai.
english_phrase: The short ʻoʻopu of Hanakāpīʻai.
meaning_phrase: The ʻoʻopu at Hanakāpīʻai on Kauaʻi were said to be shorter and plumper than those anywhere else. Mentioned in chants.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻōpuʻu pua i mōhala.
english_phrase: A flower that began to unfold.
meaning_phrase: A baby.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻōwili makani ʻino o Kāwili.
english_phrase: The stormy wind of Kāwili.
meaning_phrase: Kāwili is the current that comes from Kona and goes out to sea at Kalae, Kaʻū.

hawaiian_phrase: Kāpae aʻe nō i kulakula.
english_phrase: Just set it aside on the embankment.
meaning_phrase: Let’s not bother with it anymore.

hawaiian_phrase: Kapa ʻehu kai o Kaʻena na ka makani.
english_phrase: Kaʻena is adorned with a garment of sea sprays by the blowing of the wind.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Kaʻena, Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: Kāpae ka ʻalaʻala he heʻe no kai uli.
english_phrase: [The weight causes] the head of the octopus to lean to one side; it is of the deep sea.
meaning_phrase: Said disparagingly of a prosperous or important person. Once Hiʻiaka purposely avoided a kahuna who was seeking her. When he found her he said, “Oh! The head of the octopus leans to one side! After all, you are an octopus of the deep sea, a goddess!”

hawaiian_phrase: Kāpae ke kaua e ka hoahānau.
english_phrase: Let kinsmen cease fghting each other.
meaning_phrase: Said by Kawelo to his opponent and kinsman, Kauahoa.

hawaiian_phrase: Kapakahi ka lā ma Waiʻanae.
english_phrase: Lopsided is the sun at Waiʻanae.
meaning_phrase: Used to refer to anything lopsided, crooked, or not right. First uttered by Hiʻiaka in a rebuke to Lohiʻau and Wahineʻōmaʻo for talking when she warned them not to.

hawaiian_phrase: Kapakahi Manuia; Keokoʻi ka moku!
english_phrase: Crooked is Manuia; Keokoʻi is the ship!
meaning_phrase: When Boki sailed to Noumea, Manuia and his wife Kaʻupena and two hundred others followed in the ship Keokoʻi. They were to join Boki’s party in the New Hebrides, but Boki’s ship was lost, and Boki was never seen again. Shortly before the return of the Keokoʻi, a lunatic went about the streets of Honolulu, crying these words. When the ship finally arrived, its flag was at half-mast, for most of the crew had died of disease and been buried at sea. Manuia’s body was brought home. This expression is said humorously of anything that is crooked or lopsided.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka pali hinahina o Kāʻanapali.
english_phrase: The gray hills of Kāʻanapali.
meaning_phrase: Said of a child born in the month of Hinaiaʻeleʻele.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka pali kahakō lele a koaʻe.
english_phrase: Sheer cliff reached only by the tropic bird.
meaning_phrase: A tall, inaccessible cliff.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka pali kāʻili wahine o Kēʻē.
english_phrase: The wife-snatching cliff of Kēʻē.
meaning_phrase: Once upon a time some men of Kēʻē, Kauaʻi, fell in love with the wives of some Nuʻalolo men. They climbed the ladder up to Nualolo, threatened the men there, and departed with their wives.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka pali kāohi kumu aliʻi o ʻĪao.
english_phrase: The cliff of ʻĪao that embraces the chiefly sources.
meaning_phrase: ʻĪao, Maui, was the burial place of many chiefs of high rank who are the ancestors of living chiefs.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka pali kapu o Kamohoaliʻi.
english_phrase: The sacred cliff of Kamohoaliʻi.
meaning_phrase: This cliff, at the crater of Kīlauea, is sacred to Kamohoaliʻi, brother of Pele. Smoke from the pit never swept over this cliff, even when the wind blew against it. Instead, the smoke rose directly upward due to the great respect Pele had for this beloved brother.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka pali nānā uhu kaʻi o Makapuʻu.
english_phrase: The uhu-observing cliff of Makapuʻu.
meaning_phrase: The sea surrounding Makapuʻu Point, Oʻahu, is the favorite haunt of the uhu (parrotfish).

hawaiian_phrase: Ka pali ʻō ahi o Makana.
english_phrase: The firebrand-hurling of the cliff of Makana.
meaning_phrase: Pāpala or hau wood was cut, thoroughly dried, and carried up the hillside to where an imu lay ready to be lighted. When dusk descended, the imu was lighted and the logs placed in it. When the blowing of the wind was just right, the lighted log was hurled into the wind and borne seaward, high over the heads of the spectators, before dropping into the sea.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka pali walowalo hea kanaka o Mōlīlele.
english_phrase: The eerie man-calling cliff of Mōlīlele.
meaning_phrase: Mōlī-lele (Mōlī’s Leap), in Kaʻū, is the place where an unhappy girl named Mōlī once leaped over the cliff in suicide. On each anniversary of her death the gale there blows a little harder than usual, and a person standing at the point from which she jumped can hear a rushing sound, as of a tapa-clad person running by.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka papa kāhulihuli o Wailuku.
english_phrase: The unstable plank of Wailuku.
meaning_phrase: Said of an unstable person or situation. First uttered by Hiʻiaka when she compared the physical condition of the chief ʻOlepau to the weak plank that spanned Wailuku Stream in Hilo.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka pau, o ka ʻōneanea.
english_phrase: The end, and barrenness.
meaning_phrase: All were destroyed and nothing but desolation is left.

hawaiian_phrase: Kāpeku ka leo o ke kai, o hoʻoilo ka malama.
english_phrase: When the voice of the sea is harsh, the winter months have come.
meaning_phrase: First uttered by Hiʻiaka.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka pela kapu o Kakaʻe.
english_phrase: The sacred flesh of Kakaʻe.
meaning_phrase: The burial place of chiefs in ʻĪao Valley.

hawaiian_phrase: Kāpī ʻia i ka paʻakai a miko.
english_phrase: Sprinkled with salt until well salted.
meaning_phrase: Made to pay a stiff fine.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka piʻi nō ia a kōkī o Wailau.
english_phrase: Ascends to the highest point in Wailau.
meaning_phrase: Praise for one who has made a worthy accomplishment. The inhabitants of Wailau, Molokaʻi, a place of tall precipices, were excellent climbers. [cf 2434]

hawaiian_phrase: Ka pōhaku kihi paʻa.
english_phrase: The solid cornerstone.
meaning_phrase: A reliable, dependable person.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka poi ʻuoʻuo o kāohi puʻu.
english_phrase: The tenacious poi that presses down in the throat.
meaning_phrase: A humorous reference to poi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka poli lauaʻe o Makana.
english_phrase: Makana, whose bosom is adorned with lauaʻe ferns.
meaning_phrase: Famed in songs and chants are the fragrant lauaʻe fems of Makana, Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka pō nui hoʻolakolako, ke ao nui hoʻohemahema.
english_phrase: The great night that provides, the great day that neglects.
meaning_phrase: The gods supply, but man does not always accept with appreciation. Guidance is given in dreams that man often misunderstands and neglects.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka pouhana.
english_phrase: The main post.
meaning_phrase: The person on whom others depend for leadership, guidance, and help — the mainstay of the family or group.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka puhi o ka ale, ahu ke ʻolo.
english_phrase: An eel of the sea caverns, the chin sags.
meaning_phrase: When an eel of the deep sea grows large, the upper part of its neck sags with fat. Said of one who is prosperous — his pockets sag with money. Also said of a person with a double chin. Also, the scrotum.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka puka kahiko.
english_phrase: The ancient hole.
meaning_phrase: The anus. According to ancient legend, man did not have an anus and was not physically strong and well until Māui, the demigod, made the opening for him.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka pūnua peʻe poli.
english_phrase: The fledgling that hides in the bosom.
meaning_phrase: A young sweetheart.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua Apuakea o Mololani.
english_phrase: The Apuakea rain of Mololani.
meaning_phrase: Apuakea was once a beautiful maiden who was changed by Hiʻiaka into the rain that bears her name. Mololani is in Nuʻuanu.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua ʻAwa o Kīlauea.
english_phrase: The ʻAwa rain of Kīlauea.
meaning_phrase: The ʻAwa is a bitterly cold rain of ʻŌlaʻa and Kilauea, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua Hāʻao o Waiōhinu.
english_phrase: The Hāʻao rain of Waiōhinu.
meaning_phrase: A poetical expression in reference to Waiōhinu in Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi. The Hāʻao rain comes down from the mountain in columns to Waiōhinu. It is mentioned in songs and chants of Kaʻū.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua heʻe nehu o Hilo.
english_phrase: The nehu-producing rain of Hilo.
meaning_phrase: The people knew the season when the schools of nehu fish followed the rain.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua hehi ʻulu o Piʻihonua.
english_phrase: The rain that treads on the breadfruit leaves of Piʻihonua.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Piʻihonua.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua hōʻeha-ʻili o Waiehu.
english_phrase: The skin-hurting rain of Waiehu.
meaning_phrase: A chilly, pelting rain.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua hoʻopala ʻōhiʻa.
english_phrase: The rain that ripens mountain apples.
meaning_phrase: The rain that comes just as the mountain apple is beginning to ripen.

hawaiian_phrase: Kauaʻi a ka ʻai paʻa.
english_phrase: Kauaʻi of the hard poi.
meaning_phrase: There was a man of Kauaʻi who was inclined to be stingy and whose favorite meat was dried octopus. He would cut it into small pieces, remove the skin, and mix it into the poi. Whenever hospitality compelled him to invite anyone to share his food, he would say, “I am sorry that I have no meat. All I have is very lumpy poi. Just poke your fingers straight in and pull them up again. Push the lumps aside.” Naturally, many declined the invitation. But one day several visitors from Hawai’i who were very hungry accepted. One noticed that the host was chewing, so he stuck a lump in his mouth and chewed, thus discovering that the lumps were pieces of dried octopus.

hawaiian_phrase: Kauaʻi a Manokalanipo.
english_phrase: Kauai of Manokalanipo.
meaning_phrase: Manokalanipo was a chief of Kauaʻi in ancient times.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaʻū ʻai kōʻalaʻala.
english_phrase: Kaʻū of the hasty repast.
meaning_phrase: Some of the natives of Kaʻū had a reputation for not being very hospitable. Hasty eating on the part of the host did not encourage guests to linger.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaʻūʻāina kipi.
english_phrase: Kaʻū, land of rebels.
meaning_phrase: The people of Kaʻū were known to rebel against oppression, even killing their own oppressive chiefs.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaʻū, ʻāina kua makani.
english_phrase: Kaʻū, a land over whose back the wind hlows.
meaning_phrase: Kaʻū is a windy land.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua kāhiko hala o Keaʻau.
english_phrase: The rain that adorns the pandanus trees of Keaʻau.
meaning_phrase: Refers to the pandanus grove of Keaʻau, Puna, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua kani koʻo o Heʻeia.
english_phrase: The rain of Heʻeia that sounds like the tapping of walking canes.
meaning_phrase: Also said of the rain of Hilo.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua Kanilehua o Hilo.
english_phrase: The Kanilehua rain of Hilo.
meaning_phrase: Hilo, where the rain moistens the lehua blossoms.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua kapa kea o Mololani.
english_phrase: The white-tapa rain of Mololani.
meaning_phrase: The rain and mist at Mololani, Nuʻuanu, resembles a white sheet.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua kapuaʻi kanaka o Pālawai.
english_phrase: The rain of Pālāwai [which sounds like] human footsteps.
meaning_phrase: What causes you to refuse to speak or listen to me?

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua kau lāʻau o Pāhala.
english_phrase: The tree-resting rain of Pāhala.
meaning_phrase: The rain of Pāhala in Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi, seems to rest on the tree tops.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua kea o Hāna.
english_phrase: The white rain of Hāna.
meaning_phrase: Refers to the misty rain of Hāna, Maui, that comes in from the sea.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua kiawe lehua o Hōpoe.
english_phrase: The rain that sets the lehua of Hōpoe to swaying.
meaning_phrase: When the rain patters down, the lehua of Hōpoe, Puna, gently sway to and fro.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua kīhene lehua o Hāmākua.
english_phrase: The rain that produces the lehua clusters of Hāmākua.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Hāmākua, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua kīkē hala o Punaluʻu.
english_phrase: The hala-pelting rain of Punaluu.
meaning_phrase: Refers to the rain at Punaluʻu, Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua kinai lehua o Panaʻewa.
english_phrase: The rain that bruises the lehua blossoms of Panaʻewa.
meaning_phrase: Both lehua and rain are commonly found in Panaʻewa.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua Kīpuʻupuʻu o Waimea.
english_phrase: The Kīpuʻupuʻu rain of Waimea.
meaning_phrase: An expression often used in songs of Waimea, Hawaiʻ1. When Kamehameha organized an army of spear fighters and runners from Waimea, they called themselves Kīpuʻupuʻu after the cold rain of their homeland.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua koʻi-lipilipi o Kalihi.
english_phrase: The adz rain of Kalihi.
meaning_phrase: A pouring rain that lasts for days. A story is told of a couple who slept while the rain poured. The rain lasted so long that when they awoke, the sides of their heads were flattened, as though cut away by an adz.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua Kolowao o Kaʻala.
english_phrase: The Mountain-creeper rain of Kaʻala.
meaning_phrase: This rain is accompanied by a mist that seems to creep among the trees.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua Kuahine o Mānoa.
english_phrase: The Kuahine rain of Mānoa.
meaning_phrase: This rain is famed in the songs of Mānoa. According to an old legend, Kuahine was a chiefess, the wife of Kahaukani. Their daughter Kahalaopuna was so beautiful that rainbows appeared wherever she was. Once, two gossiping men claimed they had made love to her. This so angered her betrothed husband that he beat her into unconsciousness. She was revived by an owl god, but after hearing more gossip, her betrothed killed her. In grief, her mother became the Kuahine rain. Her father adopted two forms — the wind Kahaukani and a hau tree. It was said that this tree moaned in grief whenever a member of royalty died.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua Kūkalahale o Honolulu.
english_phrase: The Kūkalahale rain of Honolulu.
meaning_phrase: The rain that announces itself to the homes by the pattering it makes on the roofs as it falls. Often mentioned in songs.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua kūnihi a Kaʻupena.
english_phrase: The rain of Kaʻupena that turns aside.
meaning_phrase: Kaʻupena was a seeress of Kamaʻoa Plain, in Kaʻū. Whenever rain approached, she called it to come to her home and to leave the homes of her neighbors alone so that their crops would not be ruined by a too-early rain. The rain obeyed.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua Kūpunikapa o Lanakila.
english_phrase: The Hold-fast-to-the-clothing rain of Lanakila.
meaning_phrase: The rain of Lanakila, Maui, is so cold that it makes one clutch and hold his clothing close to his body.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua Lanihaʻahaʻa o Hāna.
english_phrase: The Rain-of-the-low-sky of Hāna
meaning_phrase: Refers to Hāna, Maui. once, the young warrior chief Kaʻeokulani ran to a banana grove to escape a sudden squall. As he stood safe and dry in the shelter of the banana leaves he lifted his spear. It accidentally pierced through the leaves and a trickle of water came through. He remarked that the sky where he stood was so low he had pierced it.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua Lanipaʻina o ʻUlupalakua.
english_phrase: The Sky-crackling rain of ʻ Ulupalakua.
meaning_phrase: Refers to ʻUlupalakua, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua lei māʻohu o Waiānuenue.
english_phrase: The rain of Waiānuenue that is like a wreath of mist.
meaning_phrase: Wai-ānuenue (Rainbow-water) in Hilo, Hawaiʻi, is now known as Rainbow Falls. On sunny days a rainbow can be seen in the falls, and on rainy days the rising vapor is suggestive of a wreath of mist.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua leina hua o Kāʻanapali.
english_phrase: The rain of Kāʻanapali that leaps and produces fruit.
meaning_phrase: This is used at the end of a tale to indicate that it is finished.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua Līhau o Pāhoa.
english_phrase: The Līhau rain of Pāhoa.
meaning_phrase: The icy cold rain of Pāhoa, Puna, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua Lililehua o Kāʻanapali.
english_phrase: The Tiny-drops-on-the-lehua rain of Kāʻanapali.
meaning_phrase: This is used at the end of a tale to indicate that it is finished.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua loku o Hanalei.
english_phrase: The pouring rain of Hanalei.
meaning_phrase: An expression used in dirges and chants of woe to express the burden of sadness, the heaviness of grief, and tears pouring freely like rain. Rains and fogs of other localities may also be used.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua lū lehua o Panaʻewa.
english_phrase: The lehua-shedding rain of Panaʻewa.
meaning_phrase: The heavy rain of the lehua forests of Panaʻewa in Hilo, Hawaiʻi. Famed in chants of old.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua Makakoʻi o Haleleʻa.
english_phrase: The Adz-edged rain of Haleleʻa.
meaning_phrase: A rain so cold that it feels like the sharp edge of an adz on the skin. Refers to Haleleʻa, Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua moaniani lehua o Puna.
english_phrase: The rain that brings the fragrance of the lehua of Puna.
meaning_phrase: Puna is known as the land of fragrance.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua nāulu o Kawaihae.
english_phrase: The cloudless rain of Kawaihae.
meaning_phrase: The rain of Kawaihae often surprises visitors because it seems to come out of a cloudless sky. A native knows by observing the winds and other signs of nature just what to expect.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua nihi pali o Moelana.
english_phrase: The rain that sneaks along the cliffs at Moelana.
meaning_phrase: The rain at Moelana, below the Nuʻuanu Pali.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua Noelehua o Waiʻaleʻale.
english_phrase: The Misty-lehua rain of Waiʻaleʻale.
meaning_phrase: The rain of Waiʻaleʻale that moistens the lehua blossoms there.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua nounou ʻili o Waimea.
english_phrase: The skin-pelting rain of Waimea.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Waimea, Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua ʻōʻiliʻili maka akua.
english_phrase: The rain that appears here and there to denote the presence of a god.
meaning_phrase: Said of the rain that falls with a drop here and a drop there instead of falling in a shower.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua Paliloa o Waimea.
english_phrase: The Tall-cliffs rain of Waimea.
meaning_phrase: The rain of Waimea, Hawaiʻi, that sweeps down the cliffs.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua Paʻūpili o Lele.
english_phrase: The Pili-soaking rain of Lele.
meaning_phrase: The plains of Lahaina, Maui, were covered with pili grass in ancient days. When the rain poured the grass was well soaked.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua peʻe pōhaku o Kaupō.
english_phrase: The rain of Kaupō that makes one hide behind a rock.
meaning_phrase: It falls so suddenly that one flees behind rocks for shelter.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua peʻe pū hala o Huelo.
english_phrase: The rain of Huelo that makes one hide in a hala grove.
meaning_phrase: Water is life and Kāne is the keeper of water. To dream of a well-filled water gourd that breaks and spills its contents is a warning of death for someone in the family.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua pehi hala o Hāmākua.
english_phrase: The rain of Hāmākua that pelts the pandanus fruit clusters.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Hāmākua, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua Pōʻaihale o Kahaluʻu.
english_phrase: The rain that moves around the homes of Kahaluu.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Kahaluʻu of windward Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua pōʻai puni o Kumaka.
english_phrase: The rain of Kumaka that completely surrounds.
meaning_phrase: The rain and mists of Kumaka, Kauaʻi, completely screen homes, trees, and so forth from view.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua poʻo nui o ke kuahiwi.
english_phrase: The big-headed rain of the mountain.
meaning_phrase: The ʻAwa rain, which falls in fine, icy cold drops that make one’s head appear white.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua Pōpōkapa o Nuʻuanu.
english_phrase: The Tapa-bundling rain of Nuuanu.
meaning_phrase: The Pōpōkapa rain is so called because anyone who came up Nuʻuanu Pali from the windward side had to bundle his garments and hold his arms against his chest to keep from getting wet.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua ʻŪkiu o Makawao.
english_phrase: The ʻŪkiu rain of Makawao.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Makawao, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua ʻulalena o Piʻiholo.
english_phrase: The reddish-yellow rain of Piʻiholo.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Piʻihonua.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ua Waʻawaʻahia o Waipiʻo.
english_phrase: The Furrow-cutting rain of Waipio.
meaning_phrase: The rain of Waipiʻo, Hawaiʻi, sweeps along the gullies and gulches as it pours

hawaiian_phrase: Kaʻū, hiehie i ka makani.
english_phrase: Kaʻū, regal in the gales.
meaning_phrase: An expression of admiration for the district of Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi, or for a stately or outstanding person of that district.

hawaiian_phrase: Kauhū ka ʻena o ka ukiuki na ka inaina.
english_phrase: Annoyance gives heat to anger.
meaning_phrase: Annoyance easily leads to wrath.

hawaiian_phrase: Kau i ka lani ka holowaʻa ua o Hilo.
english_phrase: Placed high in heaven is the rain trough of Hilo.
meaning_phrase: An expression of admiration for a person of regal bearing.

hawaiian_phrase: Kau i Kāpua ka poʻe polohuku ʻole.
english_phrase: Those without resources will land at Kāpua.
meaning_phrase: Without resources one gets nowhere.

hawaiian_phrase: Kau ʻino na waʻa o Kaʻaluʻalu.
english_phrase: The canoes hasten ashore at Kaʻalualu.
meaning_phrase: Said of those who hurry away from the scene of trouble. Kaʻaluʻalu is a beach in Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi, where fishermen hastened away from Halaʻea after unloading their fish onto his canoe.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaʻū, i Palahemo.
english_phrase: In Kaʻū, at Palahemo.
meaning_phrase: Palahemo is a pool near Kalae in Kaʻū. Salt water is found under the fresh water, and any disturbance, like the dropping of a heavy stone, reverses the water, so that the salt water rises to the top. This place is famed in songs and chants.

hawaiian_phrase: Kau ka lā i ka lolo, hoʻi ke aka i ke kino.
english_phrase: The sun stands over the brain, the shadow retreats into the body.
meaning_phrase: Said of high noon, when the sun is directly overhead and no shadows are seen — an important time for some ancient rites and ceremonies.

hawaiian_phrase: Kau ka mahina.
english_phrase: The moon is shining.
meaning_phrase: A remark made in fun when a bald head is seen.

hawaiian_phrase: Kau ka maka.
english_phrase: The eyes rest upon [him or her].
meaning_phrase: A longing to see a certain person or to possess a certain thing.

hawaiian_phrase: Kau ka ʻōnohi aliʻi i luna.
english_phrase: The royal eyes rest above.
meaning_phrase: A rainbow — a sign that the gods are watching the chiefs — is now visible.

hawaiian_phrase: Kau ka peʻa, holo ka waʻa!
english_phrase: Up go the sails; away goes the canoe!
meaning_phrase: Said humorously of one who dresses up and goes out for a gay time.

hawaiian_phrase: Kau ke keha i ka uluna.
english_phrase: The head rests upon the pillow.
meaning_phrase: All work is done and there is nothing more to worry about.

hawaiian_phrase: Kau ke poʻo i ka uluna ʻo Welehu ka malama.
english_phrase: Rest the head on the pillow; Welehu is the month.
meaning_phrase: Said of one whose work is done and who is able to rest. Welehu is a stormy month when little can be done except remain at home and sleep.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaulaʻi nā iwi i ka lā.
english_phrase: To bleach the bones in the sun.
meaning_phrase: To talk too freely and unkindly of one’s family to outsiders.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaulana ka pali o Pōhina.
english_phrase: Famous is the pali of Pohina.
meaning_phrase: From a chant for the chiefess Maukaʻa of Kaʻū.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaʻū lepo ʻulaʻula.
english_phrase: Kaʻū of the red earth.
meaning_phrase: Said of the natives of old Kaʻū, who were one vast family. Because of pride in their own people and homeland, Kaʻū people intermarried until they were of one blood and as one with their homeland. The kauwā were the only exceptions to this rule — they were despised and considered a people apart.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaulīlua i ke anu, Waiʻaleʻale.
english_phrase: Extremely cold is Waiʻaleʻale.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is high above others, as is Waiʻaleʻale, a mountain on Kauaʻi. A chant beginning with this line was composed for a chiefess of Waialua, Oʻahu, named Kaumealani. The last person to inherit it was Kalākaua, who was also known by the name Kaulīlua.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ulua kāpapa o ke kai loa.
english_phrase: The powerful ulua of the deep sea.
meaning_phrase: A strong warrior. The ulua fish is a strong fighter.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ulu koa i kai o Oneawa.
english_phrase: The koa grove down at Oneawa.
meaning_phrase: From the legend of Hiʻiaka. Canoes are sometimes referred to as the koa grove at sea, for canoes in ancient times were made of koa.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ulu kukui o Lanikāula.
english_phrase: The kukui grove of Lanikāula.
meaning_phrase: Lanikāula was the kāula (prophet) of Molokaʻi. His fame was so great that it incurred the jealousy of Kawelo, prophet of Lānaʻi, who sought every means of destroying Lanikāula. His efforts were rewarded when he discovered where Lanikāula went to relieve himself. Kawelo made a hole in a sweet potato and filled it with his rival’s excrement. This he took back to Lānaʻi and with it prayed his victim to death. When Lanikāula saw that his end was near, he asked his sons to suggest a burial place. He found each suggestion unsatisfactory except that of his youngest son. So Lanikāula was buried in a kukui grove near his home. In the grave were placed his personal belongings, which, by the power invested in them by a kahuna, would bring harm to anyone who disturbed the remains. So Lanikāula rests in his kukui grove, famed in songs of Molokaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ulu lāʻau ma kai.
english_phrase: The forest on the seaward side.
meaning_phrase: Refers to the masts of the ships that came the harbors of Lahaina or Honolulu.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaululāʻau piapia.
english_phrase: Kaululāʻau of the sticky eyes.
meaning_phrase: An expression of derision for one who has the “sand” of sleep in his eyes. Kaululāʻau, son of Kakaʻe of Maui, was banished to Lānaʻi by his father and killed the evil beings that overran the island. The largest group was destroyed very early in the moming. Kaululāʻau applied a gum to their eyes while they slept, thus rendering them blind and helpless.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka ʻulu loaʻa ʻole i ka lou ʻia.
english_phrase: The breadfruit that even a pole cannot reach.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person of very high rank.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaʻū, mai ʻOkiʻokiaho a Mawae.
english_phrase: Kaʻū, from ʻOkiʻokiaho to Mawae.
meaning_phrase: The district of Kaʻū, from ʻOkiʻokiaho at the boundary of Puna, to Mawae at the boundary of Kona.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaʻū mākaha.
english_phrase: Kaʻū of the fierce fghters.
meaning_phrase: The district of Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi, was known for its fierce and independent warriors. Kohāikalani, Koihala, and Halaʻea, selfish and oppressive chiefs, were each destroyed by rebellious subjects.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaʻū malo ʻeka, kua wehi.
english_phrase: Kaʻū of the dirty loincloth and black back.
meaning_phrase: The farmers there squatted on their haunches and worked the soil with short digging sticks. The sun darkened the backs of the workers.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaunaʻoa pālaha kukui o Kamehaʻikana.
english_phrase: The kaunaʻoa that spreads and fattens the kukui foliage of Kamehaʻikana.
meaning_phrase: Said of kaunaoa niālolo, which grows so thickly in some places that it covers the leaves of kukui and other trees.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaʻū nui kua makani.
english_phrase: Great Kaʻū of the windblown back.
meaning_phrase: The wind always blows in Kaʻū.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaʻū nui maka lepo.
english_phrase: Great Kaʻū of dirty faces.
meaning_phrase: An expression of ridicule. Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi, is a dry, wind-swept district where clouds of dust rise into the air.

hawaiian_phrase: Kauō ulupau ka holo-kahiki.
english_phrase: A sailor drags his anchor in many harbors.
meaning_phrase: A sailor has a sweetheart in every port.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaupō ʻai loli.
english_phrase: Kaupō, land of the loli eaters.
meaning_phrase: Kauakahiakua, a chief of Kaupō, Maui, is said to have been fond of loli and to have once built a large imu for roasting them. Since that time the people of Kaupō have had a reputation for being especially fond of this sea creature.

hawaiian_phrase: Kau pō Kāneiahuea.
english_phrase: All night long rode Kāneiahuea.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who wastes time in useless effort. From the story of a man who started out from the inlet of Kāneiahuea, Kona, one night. Because he was unfamiliar with the place, he went back and forth all night without finding an outlet to the open sea. Similar to the saying Naʻaupō wale ʻo Kāneiahuea.

hawaiian_phrase: Kaʻupu hehi ʻale o ka moana.
english_phrase: The kaʻupu bird that steps on the ocean billows.
meaning_phrase: A ship.

hawaiian_phrase: Kauā ke aloha i nā lehua o Kāʻana.
english_phrase: Love is a slave to the lehua blossoms of Kāʻana.
meaning_phrase: Kāʻana is a place between Keaʻau and ʻŌlaʻa where travelers used to rest and make lei of lehua. It took many blossoms and much patience to complete a lei. The lei was later given to a loved one.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wahine ʻai honua.
english_phrase: The earth-eating woman.
meaning_phrase: Pele.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wahine ʻai lāʻau o Puna.
english_phrase: The tree-eating woman of Puna.
meaning_phrase: Pele.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wahine ʻai pōhaku.
english_phrase: The stone-eating woman.
meaning_phrase: Pele.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wahine alualu pū hala o Kamilo.
english_phrase: The hala-pursuing woman of Kamilo.
meaning_phrase: A current comes to Kamilo in Kaʻū from Halaaniani in Puna; whatever is tossed in the sea at Halaaniani floats into Kamilo. Kapua once left her husband in Puna and went to Kaʻū. He missed her so badly that he decided to send her a pretty loincloth she had made him. This might make her think of him and come back. He wrapped the malo around the stem of a hala cluster, tied it securely in place with a cord, and tossed it into the sea. A few days later some women went fishing at Kamilo and noticed a hala cluster bobbing in the water. Kapua was among them. Eagerly they tried to seize it until one of the women succeeded. Kapua watched as the string was untied and the malo unfolded. She knew that it was her husband’s plea to come home, so she returned to Puna.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wahine hele lā o Kaiona, alualu wai liʻulā o ke kaha pua ʻōhai.
english_phrase: The woman, Kaiona, who travels in the sunshine pursuing the mirage of the place where the ʻōhai blossoms grow.
meaning_phrase: Kaiona was a goddess of Kaʻala and the Waiʻanae Mountains. She was a kind person who helped anyone who lost his way in the mountains by sending a bird, an ʻiwa, to guide the lost one out of the forest. In modern times Princess Bernice Pauahi Bishop was compared to Kaiona in songs.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wahine o ka liʻulā.
english_phrase: The woman of the twilight.
meaning_phrase: Lāʻiekawai, a legendary chiefess who became a goddess after her marriage to Ka-ʻōnohi-o-ka-lā (Eyeball-of-the-sun), a supernatural chief.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wahine pōʻai moku.
english_phrase: The woman who made a circuit of the islands.
meaning_phrase: Hiʻiaka, who traveled to all of the islands of the Hawaiian group.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wai ʻeleʻele a ka poʻe ʻike.
english_phrase: The black fluid of the learned.
meaning_phrase: Ink.

hawaiian_phrase: Kawaihae i ke kai hāwanawana.
english_phrase: Kawaihae of the whispering sea.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Kawaihae, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wai hālau o Wailua.
english_phrase: The expansive waters of Wailua.
meaning_phrase: Wailua, Kauaʻi, is the land of large streams.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wai hoʻihoʻi lāʻī o ʻEleile.
english_phrase: The water of ʻEleile that carries back the ti-leaf stalk.
meaning_phrase: The pool of ʻEleile on Maui is famed in songs and chants. Visitors throw ti stalks into the pool and watch the water carry them all around before washing them downstream.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka waihona o ka naʻauao.
english_phrase: The repository of learning.
meaning_phrase: Said in admiration of a learned person.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wai hoʻomalule kino.
english_phrase: The liquid that causes limpness to the body.
meaning_phrase: Intoxicating drinks.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wai huahuaʻi o Kewalo.
english_phrase: The bubbling water of Kewalo.
meaning_phrase: Kewalo once had a large spring where many went for cool, refreshing water.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wai hūnā a ka pāoʻo.
english_phrase: The hidden water of the pāoʻo fish.
meaning_phrase: A little pool of water on Lehua often mentioned in chants of Niʻihau. It is said to be guarded by a supernatural pāoʻo fish. When this fish rises to the surface, its back resembles the surrounding rocks, which makes the pool difficult to see. When the pāoʻo sinks to the bottom, the water can again be seen. Also, a pool not far from the crater of Kīlauea. The priests of Pele who knew of its location obtained water from it to mix with the ʻawa drinks they offered to her. Like the pool on Lehua, a supernatural pāoʻo fish guarded it. This pool was destroyed during the making of a road.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wai kāʻili ao.
english_phrase: The liquid that snatches away the light [of intelligence].
meaning_phrase: Kawaihāpai, Oʻahu. A drought once came there in ancient times and drove out everyone except two aged priests. Instead of going with the others, they remained to plead with their gods for relief. One day they saw a cloud approaching from the ocean. It passed over their house to the cliff behind. They heard a splash and when they ran to look, they found water. Because it was brought there by a cloud in answer to their prayers, the place was renamed Ka-wai-hāpai (The-carried-water) and the water supply was named Ka-wai-kumu-ʻole (Water-without-a-source).

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wai kumu ʻole.
english_phrase: The water without source.
meaning_phrase: Kawaihāpai, Oʻahu. A drought once came there in ancient times and drove out everyone except two aged priests. Instead of going with the others, they remained to plead with their gods for relief. One day they saw a cloud approaching from the ocean. It passed over their house to the cliff behind. They heard a splash and when they ran to look, they found water. Because it was brought there by a cloud in answer to their prayers, the place was renamed Ka-wai-hāpai (The-carried-water) and the water supply was named Ka-wai-kumu-ʻole (Water-without-a-source).

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wai lewa i ka makani.
english_phrase: The water that sways in the breeze.
meaning_phrase: The coconut, which contains water and is found in clusters high up in the tree.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wai liʻulā o Mānā.
english_phrase: Mirage of Mānā.
meaning_phrase: Mirages were seen at Mānā on the nights of Kū and Kāne.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wai lumalumaʻi kanaka o Wailuku.
english_phrase: The water of Wailukn where men were drowned.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Wailuku, Hilo, where victims were drowned to be offered in sacrifice at a nearby heiau.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wai nāʻuke poʻo o Kahā.
english_phrase: The water of Kahā that removed head lice.
meaning_phrase: The water of Kahā is in Waiōhinu, Kaʻū. The chief Keouakuahuʻula once discovered that he had lice on his head. Not wanting others to know, he went to Kahā where he washed his head and had the pests removed.

hawaiian_phrase: Kawaipapa mūkī.
english_phrase: Kawaipapa of sibilant sounds.
meaning_phrase: When fishing, the natives of Kawaipapa, Hāna, Maui, made smacking sounds with the lips rather than call out or speak to one another.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wai puka iki o Helani.
english_phrase: The water of Helani that comes from a small opening.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Helani, Kona, Hawaiʻi. Here a coconut grove thrived, and from a small opening in the shell of the nut one could get water to drink.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wai ʻula ʻiliahi o Waimea.
english_phrase: The red sandalwood water of Waimea.
meaning_phrase: This expression is sometimes used in old chants of Waimea, Kauaʻi. After a storm Waimea Stream is said to run red. Where it meets Makaweli Stream to form Waimea River, the water is sometimes red on one side and clear on the other. The red side is called wai ʻula ʻiliahi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wana momona o Mokoliʻi.
english_phrase: The fat sea urchins of Mokoliʻi.
meaning_phrase: Mokoliʻi, a small island off windward Oʻahu, is known for its fine sea urchins.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wela o ka ua.
english_phrase: Heated rain.
meaning_phrase: Warrior chiefs in feather capes and helmets. They look like little rainbows — rain “heated” by the sun.

hawaiian_phrase: Kāwelu holu o Lanihuli.
english_phrase: The swaying grass of Lanihuli.
meaning_phrase: Visitors to Nuʻuanu Pali know the kāwelu grass on the slope of the hill, dipping, rippling, and swaying in the breeze. It is mentioned in many chants and poems.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wiliwili o Kaupeʻa.
english_phrase: The wiliwili grove of Kaupeʻa.
meaning_phrase: In ʻEwa, Oʻahu. Said to be where homeless ghosts wander among the trees.

hawaiian_phrase: Ka wohi kū kahi.
english_phrase: A chief of the wohi rank, most outstanding.
