meaning_phrase: Often used in referring to Kalākaua.

hawaiian_phrase: Keaʻau, i ke kai nehe i ka ʻiliʻili.
english_phrase: Keaʻau, where the sea murmurs over the pebbles.
meaning_phrase: Keaʻau, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke ahi lele o Kāmaile.
english_phrase: The soaring fire of Kāmaile.
meaning_phrase: This refers to the firebrands hurled off the cliffs at Nāpali, Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke ahu a Kaunuohua i kaulu pali.
english_phrase: The heap of Kaunuohua on the slope of the cliff.
meaning_phrase: A humorous reference to the scrotum.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke akua liʻiliʻi hana ʻole i ka lani me ke honua.
english_phrase: Little god who did not create heaven and earth.
meaning_phrase: A saying used by Christian Hawaiians to express scorn for any god of old Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke alahaka o Nuʻalolo.
english_phrase: The ladder of Nuʻalolo.
meaning_phrase: The ascent of Nuʻalolo, Kauaʻi, is steep and difficult. In the olden days the people built a ladder in order to go up and down more easily. This ladder is famed in ancient poetry of Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke ala iki a kāhuna.
english_phrase: The narrow trail on which priests walk.
meaning_phrase: There are many restrictions to be heeded by kāhuna.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke ala kīkeʻekeʻe a Māui.
english_phrase: The winding trails of Māui.
meaning_phrase: Trails made by Māui when he was pursued by those who wished to destroy him. One trail was at Waiahole, Oʻahu, one at Kekaʻa between Lahaina and Kāʻanapali, and the third at Kealakahakaha, Kahakuloa, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke alanui pali o ʻAʻalaloa.
english_phrase: The cliff trail of ʻAʻalaloa.
meaning_phrase: A well-known trail from Wailuku to Lahaina.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke ala pūpū i Molokaʻi.
english_phrase: The path of seashells of Molokaʻi.
meaning_phrase: Among the noted things made by Kihaapiʻilani, ruler of Maui, was a paved road lined with seashells at Kaluakoʻi, Molokaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke aliʻi nāna e kālua i ke poʻo i ka imu a poʻalo aʻe i nā maka.
english_phrase: The chief who can roast the head in the imu and scoop out the eyes.
meaning_phrase: Said of a chief who had the power and authority to have the head of one who offended him cut off and roasted in an imu, or to order his eyes dug out. The heads were roasted and then discarded, a warning to lesser chiefs and commoners to respect their superiors.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke ʻā makauli o Kamilo.
english_phrase: The dark-faced lava rocks of Kamilo.
meaning_phrase: The dark stones of Kamilo Beach in Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke amo ʻia aʻela ʻo Kaʻaoʻao; ke kahe maila ka hinu.
english_phrase: Kaʻaoʻao is being carried by; the grease is flowing from his body.
meaning_phrase: What has happened to him is very obvious. Kaʻaoʻao, angry with his brother Kekaulike, ruthlessly destroyed the crops in his absence. The latter followed him up to Haleakalā and there slew him. His decomposed body was found later by his followers.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke ʻanapa nei ka wai liʻulā o Mānā.
english_phrase: The water in the mirage of Mānā sparkles.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is overdressed.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke ā nui, ke ā iki.
english_phrase: Big jaw, little jaw.
meaning_phrase: Much bragging and wheedling, as of a man seeking the favor of a woman.

hawaiian_phrase: Keauhou i ka ʻihi kapu.
english_phrase: Keauhou, where strict kapu were observed.
meaning_phrase: Keauhou, Kona. This was the place where many of the highest chiefs resided and where Kamehameha III was born.

hawaiian_phrase: Keauhou, kai nehe i ka ʻiliʻili.
english_phrase: Keauhou, where the sea murmurs to the pebbles.
meaning_phrase: Keauhou, Puna, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke awa haulani o Māhukona.
english_phrase: The restless harbor of Māhukona.
meaning_phrase: Poets refer also to the surging (hanupanupā) waves of Māhukona.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke awa laʻi lulu o Kou.
english_phrase: The peaceful harbor of Kou.
meaning_phrase: Honolulu Harbor.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke awa lau o Puʻuloa.
english_phrase: The many-harbored sea of Puuloa.
meaning_phrase: Puʻuloa is an early name for Pearl Harbor.

hawaiian_phrase: Keawe ʻenaʻena.
english_phrase: Red-hot Keawe.
meaning_phrase: Said of Keawe, son of ʻUmi, whose kapu was so great it was compared to a red-hot imu.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke ʻehuehu nei nā ʻale.
english_phrase: The billows show signs of a rough sea.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person whose temper is rising.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke ʻehu kai o Puaʻena.
english_phrase: The sea sprays of Puaʻena.
meaning_phrase: Puaʻena, Waialua, Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke ʻEka, makani hoʻolale waʻa o nā Kona.
english_phrase: The ʻEka breeze of Kona that calls to the canoemen to sally forth to fish.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Kona, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke ēwe hānau o ka ʻāina.
english_phrase: The lineage born of the land.
meaning_phrase: A native Hawaiian who is island-born and whose ancestors were also of the land.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke haʻi ʻia ala ke keʻe o Moʻolau.
english_phrase: The defects of Moʻolau are being told.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who reveals the faults of others. Moʻolau was a lizard of Kohala who battled with Hiʻiaka.

hawaiian_phrase: Keha kaʻakepa ka ʻōlelo i Hīhīmanu.
english_phrase: High and round about goes the talk at Hīhīmanu.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who boasts repeatedly.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke hea mai nei ʻo Kawelohea.
english_phrase: Kawelohea calls.
meaning_phrase: An expression much used in poems of Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi. Kawelo was a woman murdered by her husband. Her spirit entered a blowhole at Honuʻapo, where her remains had been tossed. Out of this hole she warned of impending trouble, and the people grew fond of this voice from the depths.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke hele maila ko Kaʻū; he iho maila ko Palahemo; he hōkake aʻela i Manukā; haele loa akula i Kaleinapueo.
english_phrase: There come those of Kaʻū; those of Palahemo descend; those of Manukā push this way and that; and away they all go to Kaleinapueo.
meaning_phrase: Said when one tries to find out something about another and meets with failure at every turn. A play on place names: ʻū (a grunt of contempt) in Kaʻū; hemo (to get away) in Palahemo; kā (to run along like a vine) in Manukā; and leinapueo (owl’s leaping place) in Kaleinapueo.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke hiʻi lā ʻoe i ka paukū waena, he neo ke poʻo me ka hiʻu.
english_phrase: You hold the center piece without its head and tail.
meaning_phrase: You know only the middle part of the genealogy or legend. What about the origin and the latter part?

hawaiian_phrase: Ke hina ke uahi ma kahi ʻaoʻao he mea mākole ko ia ʻaoʻao.
english_phrase: When the smoke falls on one side, someone on that side will feel a smarting of the eyes.
meaning_phrase: Where strong words fall, feelings are hurt.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke hoʻi aʻela ka ʻōpua i Awalau.
english_phrase: The rain clouds are returning to Awalau.
meaning_phrase: Said of a return to the source.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke hoʻokumu nei Kumukahi i ka ʻino.
english_phrase: Kumukahi is brewing a storm.
meaning_phrase: Said of one whose anger increases. Kumukahi is a point at Puna, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke hōʻole mai nei o Hāloa.
english_phrase: Hāloa denies that.
meaning_phrase: Hāloa is the god of taro. It was said that whatever business was discussed before an open poi bowl was denied by Hāloa. If a medical kahuna was called while eating, he took it as a sign that he was not the right person to treat the sick one. However, if he was told while eating that someone was dying, he was able to treat the illness, for Hāloa would deny the death.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke iho mai nei ko luna.
english_phrase: Those above are descending.
meaning_phrase: A fog is beginning to settle. Said by one who is beginning to feel the effects of the ʻawa he has drunk.

hawaiian_phrase: Keikei kūlana hale wili, ʻaʻohe mea hana o loko.
english_phrase: A fine-looking mill, but no machinery inside.
meaning_phrase: Good-looking but unintelligent. Taken from a hula song.

hawaiian_phrase: Keikei Lahaina i ka ua Paʻūpili.
english_phrase: Majestic Lahaina in the Paʻūpili rain.
meaning_phrase: When he is old enough to toddle or creep by himself into the sunlight.

hawaiian_phrase: Keiki haehae poko o Naʻalehu.
english_phrase: The lad of Naʻalehu who tears into bits.
meaning_phrase: Said in admiration of a strong warrior of Naʻalehu who fearlessly attacks his foes. Later said of a Naʻalehu-born person who shows no fear in any situation.

hawaiian_phrase: Keiki holoholo kuāua o Makawao.
english_phrase: The lad of Makawao who goes about in the rain.
meaning_phrase: Said of a native of that place who is not afraid of being wet.

hawaiian_phrase: Keiki kāohi lā o Kumukahi.
english_phrase: The lad that holds back the sun at Kumukahi.
meaning_phrase: Praise of an outstanding youth of Puna. Kumukahi is the eastern point of Hawaiʻi, the place where the sun comes up.

hawaiian_phrase: Keiki kia manu o Laʻa.
english_phrase: Bird-catching lad of Laʻa.
meaning_phrase: A person whose charm attracts the opposite sex. ʻŌlaʻa, Hawaiʻi, was once known as Laʻa. Birdcatchers often went into the forest there for feathers. This expression is also used in a chant composed for Kalākaua.

hawaiian_phrase: Keiki ʻopeʻope nui o Kaluakoʻi.
english_phrase: The lad of Kaluakoʻi with the big hundle.
meaning_phrase: A person heavily laden with bundles. Kuapakaʻa, a boy of Kaluakoʻi, made ready to go with Keawe-nui-a-ʻUmi, chief of Hawaiʻi, to Kaʻula in search of Pakaʻa. The lad knew all the time that Pakaʻa was on Molokaʻi, for Pakaʻa was his father. Before going he asked permission to bring his bundles on board. To everyone’s surprise they consisted of a large log filled with necessities, and a large rock which was later used as an anchor.

hawaiian_phrase: Keiki uhaʻi koaiʻe o ʻOhaikea.
english_phrase: Lad of ʻOhaikea who breaks koaiʻe logs.
meaning_phrase: An expression of admiration for any youth of ʻOhaikea in Kaʻū. A handsome young man of that locality was said to have been so strong that he could break a log in two with his bare hands.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke ʻīnana lā me he ʻōpae ʻoehaʻa.
english_phrase: Active like freshwater shrimp.
meaning_phrase: Said of scattered warriors who climb rocks and hillsides to escape death.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke inu akula paha aʻu ʻĀlapa i ka wai o Wailuku.
english_phrase: My ʻĀlapa warriors must now be drinking the water of Wailuku.
meaning_phrase: Said when an expected success has turned into a failure. This was a remark made by Kalaniʻōpuʻu to his wife Kalola and son Kiwalaʻō, in the belief that his selected warriors, the ʻAlapa, were winning in their battle against Kahekili. Instead they were utterly destroyed.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kaena a ka noho hale.
english_phrase: The boast of the stay-at-home.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who boasts of his own chiefs, homeland, or affairs.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kaha ʻai ʻole a ʻīloli.
english_phrase: The foodless place, ʻĪloli.
meaning_phrase: ʻĪloli, Molokaʻi, was said to be a place where no food could be grown because of its lack of moisture.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kaha ʻōhai o Kaiona.
english_phrase: Kaiona s place where the ʻōhai grows.
meaning_phrase: Kaiona is a benevolent goddess whose home is Mt. Kaʻala and vicinity. The ʻōhai grew in profusion there. Because of her graciousness, Princess Bernice Pauahi Bishop was compared to this goddess in songs.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kaha pili a ka iʻa kea.
english_phrase: The beach where the white fish are always around.
meaning_phrase: A woman around whom white men gather like fish.

hawaiian_phrase: Kekaha wai ʻole o nā Kona.
english_phrase: Waterless Kekaha of the Kona district.
meaning_phrase: Kekaha in Kona, Hawaiʻi, is known for its scarcity of water but is dearly loved by its inhabitants.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kāhuli leo leʻa o ka nahele.
english_phrase: The sweet-voiced kāhuli landshell of the forest.
meaning_phrase: A compliment to a sweet-voiced person.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kai ʻau umauma o Māmala.
english_phrase: The sea of Māmala, where one swims at the surface.
meaning_phrase: Māmala is the entrance to Honolulu Harbor.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kai hāwanawana o Kawaihae.
english_phrase: The whispering sea of Kawaihae.
meaning_phrase: Said of Kawaihae, Kohala.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kai heʻe nalu o Puakea.
english_phrase: The sea of Puakea, where surfing is done.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Puakea, Kohala.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kai heʻe nehu o ʻEwa.
english_phrase: The sea where the nehu come in schools to ʻEwa.
meaning_phrase: Nehu (anchovy) come by the millions into Pearl Harbor. They are used as bait for fishing, or eaten dried or fresh.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kai holu o Kahului.
english_phrase: The swaying sea of Kahului.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Kahului, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kai kā ʻanae o Keʻehi.
english_phrase: The mullet-driving sea of Keʻehi.
meaning_phrase: When mullet came into Keʻehi they came in such great schools that children could drive the fish up to the sand by striking the water with their hands or with the vines that grow on the beach.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kai kaha nalu o Makaiwa.
english_phrase: The surfing of Makaiwa.
meaning_phrase: Famous is the surf of Makaiwa at Wailua, Kauaʻi, enjoyed by the native chiefs and royal guests from the other islands.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kai kuaʻau lehua o Panaʻewa.
english_phrase: The sea where lehua fringes float about in the shallows.
meaning_phrase: Long ago, when lehua trees grew down to the shore at Puna and Hilo, the fringes of the flowers often fell into the sea, reddening the surface.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kai kulaʻi kānaka o Poʻo.
english_phrase: The sea of Poʻo that knocks down men.
meaning_phrase: The sea of Poʻo, Kauaʻi, was said to be very rough.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kai leo nui o Mokoliʻi.
english_phrase: The loud-voiced sea of Mokoliʻi.
meaning_phrase: The sea of Mokoliʻi (now known as Chinaman’s Hat) is said to roar. This small island is said to have once been a reptile that Hiʻiaka stuck into the sea, head down and tail up.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kai leo nui o Paikaka.
english_phrase: The loud-voiced sea of Paikaka.
meaning_phrase: Paikaka is in Hilo.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kai lipolipo polihua a Kāne.
english_phrase: The dark-hlue ocean of Kāne.
meaning_phrase: The deep sea out of sight of land.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kai maka koholua o Keahole.
english_phrase: The sea of Keahole that pierces like the point of a koholua stick.
meaning_phrase: Keahole in Kona, Hawaiʻi, is a cold place to swim.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kai malino o Kona.
english_phrase: The calm sea of Kona.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Kona, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kai nehe o Puʻuhale.
english_phrase: The murmuring sea of Puuhale.
meaning_phrase: The sea at Puʻuhale in Kalihi, Oʻahu, was said to murmur softly as it washed ashore. There were once many fishponds there.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kai piʻi kākala niho puaʻa.
english_phrase: The sea rises like a pointed hogs tusk.
meaning_phrase: A weakling.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kai wawalo leo leʻa o Kālia.
english_phrase: The pleasing, echoing sea of Kālia.
meaning_phrase: Refers to the sea of Kālia, Honolulu, now known as Ala Moana.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kalo paʻa o Waiahole.
english_phrase: The hard taro of Waiahole.
meaning_phrase: A reminder not to treat others badly. One day, a man went to Waiahole, Oʻahu, to visit his sister, whom he had not seen for many years. She was absent, and her husband neither asked the stranger in nor offered him any food. When hunger possessed the visitor he asked if he might have some taro to eat. His brother-in-law directed him to his taro patches and told him to get some from there. The man went to the patches and then continued on his way. When the woman returned she was told of the visitor, and by her husband’s description she knew that it was her brother. She rebuked him for his lack of hospitality. When they went to their taro patches they found all the taro pulled up and hacked to pieces.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kalukalu moe ipo o Kapaʻa.
english_phrase: The kalukalu of Kapaʻa that sleeps with the lover.
meaning_phrase: Lovers were said to like whiling the time in the soft kalukalu plants.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kamalei a Kuluipō, ka hiʻialo a Pōnahe.
english_phrase: Beloved child of Kuluipō, one embraced in the arms of Pōnahe.
meaning_phrase: A benighted person. A play on pō (darkness).

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kani nei ka ʻālana.
english_phrase: The gift is sounded.
meaning_phrase: Said of an offering to the gods with a loudly spoken prayer.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kaulana paʻa ʻāina o nā aliʻi.
english_phrase: The famed landholders of the chiefs.
meaning_phrase: The best warriors were awarded the best lands by the chiefs.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kau mai nei ka mākole.
english_phrase: The red-eyed one rests ahove.
meaning_phrase: Said of the rainbow with red predominating. A sign to some people that their ʻaumakua is watching them.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kau mai nei ʻo ʻOlepau.
english_phrase: The moon is in the phase of ʻOlepau.
meaning_phrase: There is nothing more to consider. A play on ʻole (no) and pau (finished).

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kawa lele ʻopu o Kaumaea.
english_phrase: The diving place of Kaumaea [where skill is shown].
meaning_phrase: Kaumaea, Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi, is famed in old chants because it was there that a unique game was played. Instead of leaping off into water, the players leaped off into a heap of dirt in a pit. Then they tried to slide down the mound with the least raising of dust. This game was usually followed by riding the surf of Kuaʻana at Paiahaʻa, thus washing off the dirt that clung to the perspiring skins of the players.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kawa wai ʻole o Kaumaea.
english_phrase: The waterless leaping place of Kaumaea.
meaning_phrase: An expression used in dirges and chants of woe to express the burden of sadness, the heaviness of grief, and tears pouring freely like rain. Rains and fogs of other localities may also be used.

hawaiian_phrase: Kekeʻe hau o Maʻalo.
english_phrase: Crooked are the hau trees of Maʻalo.
meaning_phrase: A humorous saying. The hau grove of Maʻalo, Maui, was known as a place for illicit love affairs.

hawaiian_phrase: Kekeʻe ka waha, ua nahu i ka makani.
english_phrase: His mouth is wry after biting the wind.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who has found that what he said of others is true of himself.

hawaiian_phrase: Kekē ka niho o ka pāpaʻi.
english_phrase: The crab exposes its teeth.
meaning_phrase: Sometimes when a crab sees a person it opens its claws as if to bite and then, at the first opportunity, seeks escape. Said of a threat that is uttered but will never be carried out.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kini mahiʻai o Kaʻū.
english_phrase: The farming multitude of Kaū.
meaning_phrase: A derogatory remark by Keāulumoku, author of the chant “Haui ka lani,” that the people of Kaʻ ū, who were mostly farmers, were insignificant people.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke Kīpuʻupuʻu hoʻānu ʻili o Waimea.
english_phrase: The Kīpuʻupuʻu rain of Waimea that chills the skin of the people.
meaning_phrase: Said of an unlucky person who, in spite of every effort, gets nothing.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke koaʻe iho ia, he manu lele no ka pali kahakō.
english_phrase: That is the tropic hird, one that flies at the sheer cliffs.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who is hard to catch.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke koaʻe lele kaha i ka pali o Līloa.
english_phrase: The tropic bird that soars to the cliff of Līloa.
meaning_phrase: Said of a chief of high rank.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke koa ia e laumeki ai kahawai o Hilo.
english_phrase: That is the warrior who will dry the streams of Hilo.
meaning_phrase: A powerful warrior.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kō ʻeli lima o Halāliʻi.
english_phrase: The sugar cane of Halāliʻi, dug out by hand.
meaning_phrase: Winds blowing over this place on Niʻihau buried the sugar cane. Here and there the leaves would be seen and the people would dig them out by hand.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kokoke maila ka Hoʻoilo.
english_phrase: The rainy season is drawing near.
meaning_phrase: Beware lest you shed tears.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kololio ka hau o uka, kō mai ka nae ʻaʻala o ke kiele.
english_phrase: When the dew-laden breeze of the upland creeps swiftly down it brings with it the fragrance of the gardenias.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who comes with happy tidings.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kope hoʻohiaʻā maka o Kona.
english_phrase: The coffee of Kona that keeps the eyes from sleeping.
meaning_phrase: This saying applies not only to coffee, but also to love. To be in love with a person of Kona is to lose much sleep.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kōpiko i ka piko o Waiʻaleʻale.
english_phrase: A kōpiko tree on the summit of Waiʻaleʻale.
meaning_phrase: A boast about an outstanding person.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kua a kānāwai.
english_phrase: The back [guarded by] law.
meaning_phrase: Said of Pele’s back, which was so kapu that to stand behind or approach it was punishable by death. Her back was said to be so hot that a bundle of taro leaves placed on it would cook at once. Her priests, chiefs, and certain of her devotees had a similar kapu — no one was permitted to walk or pass behind them nor wear anything that had been worn upon such a kapu back.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kū i Kahiki.
english_phrase: If one lands at Kahiki.
meaning_phrase: If it is possible to do so. A play on hiki (possible).

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kui lā i nā ʻāpiki lei o Makaiwa.
english_phrase: Stringing the ʻilima flowers into lei at Makaiwa.
meaning_phrase: ʻĀpiki was another name for ʻilima.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kuko waiwai ʻole a Keʻinohoʻomanawanui.
english_phrase: The worthless wish of Keʻinohoʻomanawanni.
meaning_phrase: A worthless desire that shows no ambition. Keʻinohoʻomanawanui and his friend, Kalelealuakā discussed one night the things they would like to receive from the ruler, Kakuhihewa, if possible. Keʻinohoʻomanawanui thought of food, much food. His companion spoke of being the ruler’s son-in-law and achieving honors. Unknown to them, their discussion was overheard and reported to the ruler. Kakuhihewa was angered but was appeased by his kahuna, who told him that the wish for food was indeed worthless but the wish to be his son-in-law showed ambition and a desire to accomplish.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kula o Kamaʻomaʻo ka ʻāina huli hana.
english_phrase: The plain of Kamaʻomaʻo — that is the place where plenty of work is to he found.
meaning_phrase: A taunt to one who talks of looking for work but does not do it. The plain of Kamaʻomaʻo, Maui, was said to be the haunt of ghosts whose activities were often terrifying.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kula wai ʻole o Kamaʻoa.
english_phrase: The waterless plain of Kamaʻoa.
meaning_phrase: The plain of Kamaʻoa, in Kaʻū, was well populated, but its people had to go upland for their water supply.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kū nō a Maui; ke kiʻei nō a Lānaʻi; ka moe nō a Molokaʻi; ka noho nō a Oʻahu.
english_phrase: Maui stands; Lānaʻi peers in; Molokaʻi sleeps; Oʻahu sits.
meaning_phrase: Said of people who stand about, look on, go to sleep and sit around, but who do not lend a hand with work.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke kupa ʻai au.
english_phrase: The native [son] forever.
meaning_phrase: May the chief live without end.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke lepo ke kumu wai, e huaʻi ana ka lepo i kai.
english_phrase: When the source of the water is dirty, muddy water will he seen in the lowland.
meaning_phrase: When the thoughts are dirty, dirty words are heard.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke lino aʻe nei ke kāhau o Waiʻopua.
english_phrase: The dew of Waiʻopua glistens.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who is prosperous.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke mokomoko lā me ka makani.
english_phrase: He is boxing the wind.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is being disagreeable.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke momole nei no ka mole ʻo ʻĪ.
english_phrase: The ʻĪ chiefs still adhere to their taproots.
meaning_phrase: The descendants of ʻĪ hold fast.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke nae iki nei nō.
english_phrase: Still breathing lightly.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is dying.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke nānā lā i Nānāwale.
english_phrase: Just looks at Nānāwale.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who has nothing or no one to look to for help. A play on nānā-wale (merely look), a Puna place name.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke ola nō ia o kiaʻi loko.
english_phrase: That is the livelihood of the keeper of the pond.
meaning_phrase: This is one’s livelihood. Certain fish in a pond were reserved for the owner, but shrimps, crabs, and such could be taken by the caretaker.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke one ʻai aliʻi o Kakuhihewa.
english_phrase: The chief-destroying sands of Kakuhihewa.
meaning_phrase: The island of Oʻahu. When the priest Kaʻopulupulu was put to death by the chief Kahāhana for warning him against cruelty to his subjects, he uttered a prophecy. He predicted that where his own corpse would lie in a heiau at Waikīkī, there would lie the chief’s corpse as well. Furthermore, he said, the land would someday go to the sea — that is, to a people from across the sea. This was felt to be a curse. When Kamehameha III was persuaded by a missionary friend to move the capital from Lahaina to Oʻahu, a kahuna, remembering the curse, warned him not to, lest the monarchy perish. The warning was ignored, and before the century had passed, the Kingdom of Hawaiʻi was no more.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke one ʻanapa o Waiolama.
english_phrase: The sparkling sand of Waiolama.
meaning_phrase: This is an expression much used in chants of Hilo, Hawaiʻi. Waiolama is a place between Waiakea and the town of Hilo. It was said to have sand that sparkled in the sunlight.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke one kani o Nohili.
english_phrase: The sounding sands of Nohili.
meaning_phrase: Nohili is the old name, famed in song and chant, for Barking Sands, Mānā, Kauaʻi. When one slides down the sand hill, it makes a grunting sound.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke one kapu o Kahamaluʻihi.
english_phrase: The sacred sand of Kahamalu ihi.
meaning_phrase: A city of refuge for those of Waimea, Mānā, and the Kona side of Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke one kuilima laula o ʻEwa.
english_phrase: The sand on which there was a linking of arms on the hreadth ofʻEwa.
meaning_phrase: ʻEwa, Oʻahu. The chiefs of Waikīkl and Waikele were brothers. The former wished to destroy the latter and laid his plot. He went fishing and caught a large niuhi, whose skin he stretched over a framework. Then he sent a messenger to ask his brother if he would keep a fish for him. Having gained his consent, the chief left Waikīkī, hidden with his best warriors in the “fish.” Other warriors joined them along the way until there was a large army. They surrounded the residence of the chief of Waikele and linked arms to form a wall, while the Waikīkī warriors poured out of the “fish” and destroyed those of Waikele.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke one lauʻena a Kāne.
english_phrase: The rich, fertile land of Kāne.
meaning_phrase: Puna, Hawaiʻi, was said to have been a beautiful, fertile land loved by the god Kāne. Pele came from Kahiki and changed it into a land of lava beds, cinder, and rock.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke one lei pūpū o Waimea.
english_phrase: The sand of Waimea, where shells for lei are found.
meaning_phrase: Waimea, Oʻahu, and Lumahaʻi, Kauaʻi, were the two places where the shells that were made into hat bands were found. Those on Oʻahu were predominantly white and those on Kauaʻi, brown. Not now seen.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke one lele o Moʻohelaia.
english_phrase: The flying sands of Moʻohelaia.
meaning_phrase: When the sands of Moʻohelaia, Molokaʻi, were blown about by the wind, it was believed that ghosts were present.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke one wali o ʻOhele.
english_phrase: The fine sands of ʻOhele.
meaning_phrase: ʻOhele is a place in Hilo on the town side of Waiakea, often mentioned in chants of that locality.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke pani wai o ʻĪao.
english_phrase: The dam of ʻĪao.
meaning_phrase: In a battle between Kamehameha and Kalanikūpule at ʻĪao, Maui, the latter escaped and fled to Oʻahu. The stream of ʻĪao was dammed by the bodies of the dead. This battle was called Kaʻuwaʻupali (Precipice-clawing) because the defeated warriors clawed the hillside in an attempt to escape.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke pau ka moa, kākā i ka nuku; ke pau ka ʻiole, ahu kūkae; ke pau ka manō, lanaō i ke kai.
english_phrase: When a chicken finishes [eating] he cleans his beak; when a rat finishes, he leaves a heap of excreta; when a shark finishes, he rises to the surface of the sea.
meaning_phrase: A description of the table manners of people. Some are clean like the chicken; others are unclean and careless, like the rat; and still others, like the shark, loll around without offering to help.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke ʻula maila ka pili.
english_phrase: The pili grass turns red.
meaning_phrase: The natural color of the grass is covered by an army of warriors ready for war.

hawaiian_phrase: Ke uē nei ka ʻōhiʻa o Kealakona.
english_phrase: The ʻōhiʻa wood of Kealakona weeps [for you].
meaning_phrase: Uttered as a taunt by Mahihelelima, powerful warrior of Maui, when he sent his slingshots toward the warriors of Hawaiʻi under Piʻimaiwaʻa. ʻŌhiʻa logs from Kealakona were used for the fortress on Kaʻuiki, where the Maui warriors fought the invaders. Later used to mean, “We are prepared to defend ourselves and we are sorry for you if you try to fight us.”

hawaiian_phrase: Ke wela nei nō ka ʻili i ka maka ihe.
english_phrase: The skin still feels the heated sting of the spear point.
meaning_phrase: Said when one is still at war. First uttered by Keaweamaʻuhili to Kahāhana.

hawaiian_phrase: Kiʻekiʻe ka lele a ke ao i ka lani, i hāpai ʻia e ka makani i luna.
english_phrase: High flies the cloud in the sky, lifted by the wind.
meaning_phrase: Said of one whose position is elevated by a chief.

hawaiian_phrase: Kiʻekiʻe Kaupoku-o-Hanalei.
english_phrase: High up is Kaupoku-o-Hanalei.
meaning_phrase: Said of the haughty, conceited, or wilful. Kaupoku-o-Hanalei is a ridge behind Hanalei Valley, Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Kihe, a mauli ola.
english_phrase: Sneeze, and may you have long life.
meaning_phrase: Said when someone sneezes. [exclamation to one who has sneezed, to ward off ill effects (PE)]

hawaiian_phrase: Kihe ka ihu i ka ʻale.
english_phrase: One who sneezes when the spray from the surf rises at the bow of the canoe.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who braves danger with indifference.

hawaiian_phrase: Kiʻi ʻia aku ko ʻai i kiʻona.
english_phrase: Go and recover your food from the dung heap.
meaning_phrase: Said in disgust and anger to one who complains of the amount of food another has eaten, or of the number of times another has eaten one’s food.

hawaiian_phrase: Kiʻi kū wale i ke alo o nā aliʻi.
english_phrase: Images that stand about in the presence of chiefs.
meaning_phrase: Idle people who stand about like images.

hawaiian_phrase: Kīʻililī ka pua hau o Kalena.
english_phrase: The hau blossoms of Kalena squat.
meaning_phrase: Said of pretty young women who squat and do nothing — they are good lookers but not good workers. A play on lena (lazy) in Kalena.

hawaiian_phrase: Kiʻi maka liʻiliʻi.
english_phrase: Small-eyed images.
meaning_phrase: Ordinary people.

hawaiian_phrase: Kiʻi maka nunui.
english_phrase: Big-eyed images.
meaning_phrase: Important people.

hawaiian_phrase: Kīkaha ka ʻiwa he lā makani.
english_phrase: When the ʻiwa bird soars on high it is going to be windy.
meaning_phrase: Said of a nice-looking, well-dressed person.

hawaiian_phrase: Kīkaha ka ʻiwa i nā pali.
english_phrase: The ʻiwa hird soars over the cliff.
meaning_phrase: Said of a well-dressed person.

hawaiian_phrase: Kīkē ka ʻalā, uē ka māmane.
english_phrase: When the boulders clash, the māmane tree weeps.
meaning_phrase: This was first uttered by Hiʻiaka as she watched the fires of Pele destroy Lohiʻau. She described the terrifying outpouring of lava as it overwhelmed him. Later used to mean that when two people clash, those who belong to them often weep.

hawaiian_phrase: Kīkī kōʻele huli a mahi.
english_phrase: An uncultivated patch awaiting all workers.
meaning_phrase: A big project.

hawaiian_phrase: Kilioe wahine i uka.
english_phrase: Kilioe, woman of the upland.
meaning_phrase: Kilioe was a wahine moʻo (lizard woman) famed in chants and songs of the aliʻi. She belonged to Kauaʻi and it was she who tried to prevent Hiʻiaka from taking the body of Lohiʻau from a cave at Hāʻena.

hawaiian_phrase: Kīlua ka poʻe waʻa.
english_phrase: The canoe paddlers all paddle shoreward.
meaning_phrase: Said of no luck in fishing.

hawaiian_phrase: Kini Kailua, mano Kāneʻohe.
english_phrase: Forty thousand in Kailua, four thousand in Kāneʻohe.
meaning_phrase: A great number. Said by a woman named Kawaihoʻolana whose grandson was ruthlessly murdered by someone from either Kailua or Kāneʻohe. She declared that this many would perish by sorcery to avenge him. Another version credits Keohokauouli, a kahuna in the time of Kamehameha, for this saying. He suggested sorcery as a means of destroying the conqueror’s Oʻahu enemies.

hawaiian_phrase: Kinikini kauhale liʻiliʻi o lalo lilo e. “He Ahu au no Kaʻū”; “He ʻIo au no Hilo.”
english_phrase: A multitude are the small houses way down helow. [The inhabitants claim,] “I am an Ahu of Kaʻu’ and “I am an ʻIo of Hilo.”
meaning_phrase: This saying is used in anger or to make fun of those who are low in rank yet claim relationship with the high chiefs. A play on ahu (a heap of nothing), ʻū (a grunt of contempt) in Kaʻū, and ʻio, the mighty hawk that sits on any branch it chooses.

hawaiian_phrase: Kino lau.
english_phrase: Many bodied.
meaning_phrase: Said of a god who was able to assume other forms, such as plant, animal, fish, or human, at will. Pele is referred to as akua kino lau because of her ability to change into a child, a beautiful maiden, a plain matron, or a very old woman.

hawaiian_phrase: Kino pāpālua.
english_phrase: Dual bodied.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who had the nature of a god and that of a human being, and who mingled with humans as a human and with gods as a god. Later applied humorously to one who is drunk, meaning that when drunk he is possessed by the “god” of rum but when sober he is an ordinary mortal.

hawaiian_phrase: Kioea ʻai pua ʻiʻi o Hīlia.
english_phrase: The kioea bird that eats the fish spawn of Hīlia.
meaning_phrase: Said of the kioea (curlew), an eater of little fish, or of a big fellow who gobbles up little ones.

hawaiian_phrase: Kioea hoʻolale waʻa.
english_phrase: The kioea, who calls the canoes to sally forth [to fish].
meaning_phrase: A Molokaʻi saying.

hawaiian_phrase: Kīpū loa o Keoni Pulu i ka hoe.
english_phrase: John Bull still holds fast to the oar.
meaning_phrase: He is still full and wants nothing more to eat. A play on Pulu, Hawaiianized from the English “full” and “Bull.”

hawaiian_phrase: Kīwini!
english_phrase: [How] pointed!
meaning_phrase: What nerve! Kiwini (brazen) derives from wini (pointed).

hawaiian_phrase: Koaʻe ka manu pili pōhaku.
english_phrase: The koaʻe, a bird that clings to rocks.
meaning_phrase: A rude expression referring to a landless person who, like the koaʻe among the rocks on the cliff, just hangs on to his small footing.

hawaiian_phrase: Koʻekoʻe ka pō hoa ʻole.
english_phrase: Cold are the nights without a mate.
meaning_phrase: Some do good work, others do not; but the hustle and bustle are the same.

hawaiian_phrase: Koʻele nā iwi o Hua i ka lā.
english_phrase: The bones of Hua rattled in the sun.
meaning_phrase: A warning not to talk too much of one’s kin. Also, a reminder that trouble is sure to befall those who destroy the innocent. Hua was a chief of Maui who heeded the lies of jealous men and ordered the death of his faithful priest, Luahoʻomoe. Before he died, he sent his sons to the mountains for safety, because it was foretold by gods what was to come over the land. After his death, drought and famine came. Many died, including the chief Hua. There was no one to hide his remains, so his bones were left exposed to sun and wind. Also expressed Nakeke nā iwi....

hawaiian_phrase: Kohā ka leo o ka ʻaukuʻu.
english_phrase: The voice of the ʻaukuʻu is heard to croak.
meaning_phrase: Said of a snooping gossip. The ʻaukuʻu bird lives in the upland and goes to the lowland for fish, often snatching them from people’s ponds.

hawaiian_phrase: Kohala ʻāina haʻaheo.
english_phrase: Kohala, land of the proud.
meaning_phrase: The youths, lei-bedecked, were proud of their handsome appearance and of their home district.

hawaiian_phrase: Kohala ihu hakahaka.
english_phrase: Kohala of the gaping nose.
meaning_phrase: Kohala is full of hills, and the people there are said to breathe hard from so much climbing.

hawaiian_phrase: Kohala i ka unu paʻa.
english_phrase: Kohala of the solid stone.
meaning_phrase: The people of Kohala were known for their firm attitudes.

hawaiian_phrase: Kohala, mai Honokeʻā a Keahualono.
english_phrase: Kohala, from Honokeʻā to Keahuaiono.
meaning_phrase: The extent of Kohala.

hawaiian_phrase: Kohu ʻole kahi wai o Kanaio.
english_phrase: Unattractive is the water of Kanaio.
meaning_phrase: A contemptuous expression meaning that something another person has said or done is worthless. A play on naio (pinworm), found in the anus.

hawaiian_phrase: Ko ke akua haʻi āmio.
english_phrase: The gods reveal through narrow channels.
meaning_phrase: The gods reveal to the priests, and the priests declare to the people.

hawaiian_phrase: Kō ke au iā Halaʻea.
english_phrase: The current carried Halaʻea away.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who goes out and forgets to return. Halaʻea was a chief of Kaʻū who was so selfish that he demanded every fish caught by the fishermen. After years of going without fish, the fishermen rebelled. One day, the whole fleet went to the fishing grounds outside of Kalae and did not return. The chief wanted the catch and ordered a servant to go and ask for it. The servant refused, and in anger the chief went himself. When he asked for the fish the whole fleet turned the prows of their canoes shoreward. One by one the fishermen unloaded their fish onto the chief’s canoe. The canoe began to sink under the weight of the fish, and the chief cried out to the men to stop. They refused. The chief, his canoe, and his fish were swept out on the current and never seen again. This current, which comes from the east and flows out to sea at Kalae, is known as Ke au o Halaʻea.

hawaiian_phrase: Ko ke kahuna haʻi kupua.
english_phrase: To the kahuna belongs the duty of declaring the revelations of the supernatural beings.
meaning_phrase: Said of a handsome person.

hawaiian_phrase: Ko koā uka, ko koā kai.
english_phrase: Those of the upland, those of the shore.
meaning_phrase: In olden days relatives and friends exchanged products. The upland dwellers brought poi, taro, and other foods to the shore to give to kinsmen there. The shore dweller gave fish and other seafoods. Visits were never made empty-handed but always with something from one’s home to give.

hawaiian_phrase: Kōkō ʻiole ka ua i ke kula.
english_phrase: Like the rat [-gnawed] net is the rain over the plains.
meaning_phrase: A Kaʻū saying. Makaliʻi, an ancient chief, once gathered all the food plants in a huge net and hung it up in the sky. The result was famine. A rat volunteered to go up to see what he could do about it. He ascended a rainbow and found the net, which he chewed. Down fell the contents, everywhere. So when the rain pours over the land and plants sprout everywhere, it is compared to the gnawed net that scattered food from the hills to the sea, bringing life to all.

hawaiian_phrase: Kokoke e ʻā ke ahi o ka ʻaulima.
english_phrase: Almost ready to make fire with a fire stick held in the hand.
meaning_phrase: Said of a boy who is almost old enough to mate.

hawaiian_phrase: Kokolo ka uahi o Kula, he Kēhau.
english_phrase: The smoke of Kula creeps along when the Kēhau breeze blows.
meaning_phrase: Where there is smoke there is fire.

hawaiian_phrase: Kokolo no o pipipi, o kalamoe me ālealea a ke alo o Kuhaimoana.
english_phrase: Pipipi, kalamoe and ālealea crept to the presence of Kuhaimoana.
meaning_phrase: Kuhaimoana is an important shark god, and pipipi, kalamoe and ālealea are shellfish. Said of hangers-on who gather around an important person for favors.

hawaiian_phrase: Kōlea aku i ka ʻohana.
english_phrase: Cry “Plover!” in seeking one’s kinfolk.
meaning_phrase: Names are family possessions. In seeking one’s unknown kin, repeat the family names until they are found.

hawaiian_phrase: Kōlea hewa i ka inoa.
english_phrase: He cried “Plover!” over the wrong name.
meaning_phrase: He told untruths about someone.

hawaiian_phrase: Kōlea kai piha.
english_phrase: Plover, bird of high tides.
meaning_phrase: The plover feeds along the edge of the sea.

hawaiian_phrase: Kōlea kau āhua, a uliuli ka umauma hoʻi i Kahiki.
english_phrase: Plover that perches on the mound, waits till its breast darkens, then departs for Kahiki.
meaning_phrase: The darkening of the breast is a sign that a plover is fat. It flies to these islands from Alaska in the fall and departs in the spring, arriving thin and hungry and departing fat. Applied to a person who comes here, acquires weahh, and departs.

hawaiian_phrase: Kōlea nō ke kōlea i kona inoa iho.
english_phrase: The plover can only cry its own name.
meaning_phrase: Said of an egotistical person.

hawaiian_phrase: Kole ka waha i ka hānai wahine maikaʻi.
english_phrase: One’s mouth can grow weary and sore when one rears a beautiful daughter.
meaning_phrase: Said when a hard-headed daughter finds suitors who are not to one’s liking.

hawaiian_phrase: Kolekole ka noʻa.
english_phrase: Red is the noʻa.
meaning_phrase: The secret is out. The noʻa is the stone used in the game pūhenehene, and red is a conspicuous color.

hawaiian_phrase: Ko luna pōhaku no ke kaʻa i lalo, ʻaʻole hiki i ko lalo pōhaku ke kaʻa.
english_phrase: A stone that is high up can roll down, but a stone that is down cannot roll up.
meaning_phrase: When a chief is overthrown his followers move on, but the people who have lived on the land from the days of their ancestors continue to live on it.

hawaiian_phrase: Komo akula i ke anapuni a Limaloa.
english_phrase: Entered the circle of Limaloa.
meaning_phrase: A play on Lima-loa (Long-hand). He has entered the domain of one who has the upper hand.

hawaiian_phrase: Komo akula ʻoe i ka ʻai a ka lua i Kealapiʻiakaʻōpae.
english_phrase: You are caught by the hold in lua fghting called Kealapiʻiakaʻōpae.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who procrastinates. A play on alia (to wait).

hawaiian_phrase: Komo mai kau māpuna hoe.
english_phrase: Put in your dip of the paddle.
meaning_phrase: Pitch in.

hawaiian_phrase: Komo pohō i ka naele o Alakaʻi.
english_phrase: Sunk in the bog of Alakaʻi.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is overwhelmed with trouble.

hawaiian_phrase: Komo wai ʻē ʻia.
english_phrase: A different liquid had entered.
meaning_phrase: Said of one whose paternity is suspect.

hawaiian_phrase: Kona ʻākau, mai Keahualono a Puʻuohau.
english_phrase: North Kona,from Keahualono to Puʻuohau.
meaning_phrase: The boundary of North Kona, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Kona hema, mai Puʻuohau a Kaheawai.
english_phrase: South Kona from Puʻuohau to Kaheawai.
meaning_phrase: The boundaries of South Kona.

hawaiian_phrase: Kona Honua-ʻino.
english_phrase: Kona, [the] Bad Land.
meaning_phrase: Said in humor of Kona, Hawaiʻi, for within its boundaries is a place called Honuaʻino.

hawaiian_phrase: Kona i ke kai māʻokiʻoki.
english_phrase: Kona of the sea that is cut up.
meaning_phrase: From a distance one can see the smooth surface of the sea at Kona, Hawaiʻi, cut by innumerable streaks of color.

hawaiian_phrase: Kona, kai malino a Ehu.
english_phrase: Kona, land of the calm sea of Ehu.
meaning_phrase: Ehunuikaimalino was a chief of Kona, Hawaiʻi, under the ruler Liloa.

hawaiian_phrase: Kona, kai ʻōpua i ka laʻi.
english_phrase: Kona, where the horizon clouds rest in the calm.
meaning_phrase: When rain falls at the time of a person’s death or during his funeral, it is said, the gods mingle their tears with those of the mourners.

hawaiian_phrase: Kona, mai ka puʻu o Kapūkakī a ka puʻu o Kawaihoa.
english_phrase: Kona, from Kapūkakī to Kawaihoa.
meaning_phrase: The extent of the Kona district on Oʻahu is from Kapūkakī (now Red Hill) to Kawaihoa (now Koko Head).

hawaiian_phrase: Kona, mauna uliuli; Kona mauna ulupō.
english_phrase: Kona of the green mountains; Kona of the dense forest.
meaning_phrase: North and South Kona, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Kona poʻo kuʻi.
english_phrase: Kona of the added head.
meaning_phrase: Said of farmers of Kona, Hawaiʻi, retuming from the fields with a load on the shoulders and a child sitting atop the load.

hawaiian_phrase: Konohiki lua ka lā i Olowalu.
english_phrase: The heat of the sun rules in Olowalu.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who permits the heat of anger to possess him. Olowalu, Maui, is known for its warm climate.

hawaiian_phrase: Kō nō i Manila.
english_phrase: Really gone to Manila.
meaning_phrase: A saying that began in the 1890s. Said of one who goes and forgets to return, as though he had departed for Manila.

hawaiian_phrase: Koʻolau hauwalaʻau.
english_phrase: Koʻolau of the loud voices.
meaning_phrase: The inhabitants of Koʻolau, Maui, were said to be loud of voice.

hawaiian_phrase: Koʻolau kai maloʻo.
english_phrase: Koʻolau of the very low tide.
meaning_phrase: An expression of contempt for the people of Koʻolau, Maui, who were said to lack generosity and hospitality.

hawaiian_phrase: Kōpī wale nō i ka iʻa a ʻeu nō ka ilo.
english_phrase: Though the fish is well salted, the maggots crawl.
meaning_phrase: Similar to the saying, “There’s a skeleton in every closet.”

hawaiian_phrase: Koʻūkoʻū i ka wai a ka nāulu.
english_phrase: Tasty to the palate is the water of the showers.
meaning_phrase: Said of drinks.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū aʻaha lua.
english_phrase: A standing together in twos.
meaning_phrase: A time of comradeship, not contention.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū aʻe ʻEwa; Noho iho ʻEwa.
english_phrase: Stand-up ʻEwa; Sit-down ʻEwa.
meaning_phrase: The names of two stones, now destroyed, that once marked the boundary between the chiefs’ land (Kūaʻe ʻEwa) and that of the commoners (Noho iho ʻEwa) in ʻEwa, Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: Kuailo!
english_phrase: “I give up!”
meaning_phrase: An expression used by one who cannot guess the answer to a riddle, meaning,“I give up!” If the riddler doesn’t want to tell the answer, he may reply tartly: ʻEu nō ka ilo, make! (Maggots move, death!) [kūāilo = be devoured by worms (PE)]

hawaiian_phrase: Kū a keʻokeʻo; ʻaʻohe i hōʻea mai.
english_phrase: Have stood until bleached white; no one came.
meaning_phrase: Said of a long, hopeless wait.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū akula i ka pana a Pikoi-a-ka-ʻalalā, keiki pana ʻiole o ke kula o Keahumoa.
english_phrase: Shot by the arrow of Pikoi-[son] of-the-crow, the expert rat-shooter of the plain of Keahumoa.
meaning_phrase: Got his just deserts.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū akula i ka pua; ke wī lā ka niho.
english_phrase: Hit by an arrow; now he is gnashing his teeth.
meaning_phrase: Now he is getting his just deserts.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū akula kaʻu lāʻau i ka ʻaʻama kua lenalena.
english_phrase: My spear pierced the yellow-shelled crab.
meaning_phrase: This was the boast of the warrior who speared Keʻeaumoku at the battle of Mokuʻohai. Keʻeaumoku revived and shortly after killed Kiwalaʻō. This battle was between the two cousins Kamehameha and Kiwalaʻō.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū a māloʻeloʻe, lālau nā lima i ka hoe nui me ka hoe iki.
english_phrase: Stand up straight; reach for the big and little paddle.
meaning_phrase: Said to young people — be prepared to weather whatever comes your way.

hawaiian_phrase: Kuāua nui hoʻi kēlā e hele mai nei.
english_phrase: That is a big shower coming this way.
meaning_phrase: A company of people is seen approaching.

hawaiian_phrase: Kuehu ka ʻai hoʻopau a ka ua.
english_phrase: Shaken up are the products over which the rain did its best to produce.
meaning_phrase: Said of good crops as a result of showers.

hawaiian_phrase: Kuha! Nāu nō ʻoe e hele aʻe.
english_phrase: Spit! You come to seek me of your own accord.
meaning_phrase: It was called Kuhakalani (Heaven’s expectoration). After the kahuna had prayed that the victim fall in love with the person who consulted him, the consultant was sent to stand with his back against the wind, holding a flower and facing a spot where the victim was likely to appear. Here he spat upon the flower with the words, “Kuha! Nāu nō ʻoe e hele aʻe,” and dropped the blossom. When the victim of the sorcery came near the flower, an intense love would possess him and he would go in search of the person who dropped it there.

hawaiian_phrase: Kūhela kāhela i ka laʻi o Lele.
english_phrase: Stretched out full-length in the calm of Lele.
meaning_phrase: Said of a sleeper stretched out in a careless manner.

hawaiian_phrase: Kuhikuhi kahi lima i luna, hāpapa kahi lima i lalo.
english_phrase: One hand points upward, the other gropes downward.
meaning_phrase: Said of a religious leader who teaches others to seek heavenly wealth while he himself seeks worldly possessions.

hawaiian_phrase: Kuhi nō ka lima, ʻāwihi nō ka maka, ʻo ka loaʻa nō ia a ka maka onaona.
english_phrase: With a hand gesture and a wink, an attractive person can get whatever he desires.
meaning_phrase: Sleep.

hawaiian_phrase: Kuhi nō ka lima, hele nō ka maka.
english_phrase: Where the hands move, there let the eyes follow.
meaning_phrase: A rule in hula.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū hoʻolehelehekiʻi i ka mahina ʻai a Nūkeʻe.
english_phrase: Standing like a protruding-lip image at the food patch of Nūkeʻe.
meaning_phrase: Standing around doing nothing, gaining nothing; hence, worth nothing. The reference to Nūkeʻe (Twist-mouth) adds a touch of contempt.

hawaiian_phrase: Kuʻia ka hele a ka naʻau haʻahaʻa.
english_phrase: Hesitant walks the humble hearted.
meaning_phrase: A humble person walks carefully so he will not hurt those about him.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū ʻia ka malama ʻeʻelekoa.
english_phrase: Weathered the storms of the stormy month.
meaning_phrase: Endured with courage the discomforts and privations of war.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū ihola i Mamalakā, i ka hale o Kāneheoheo.
english_phrase: There one stands at Mamalakā, the house of Kāneheoheo.
meaning_phrase: Luck has departed, and one is left disappointed. A play on heo (to be gone or to depart) in Kāneheoheo.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū i ka hāiki, ʻaʻole ma mua, ʻaʻole ma hope.
english_phrase: Stands in a narrnow space until nothing before and nothing behind.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who has nothing to fall back on and no one to help.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū i ka īpuka o ka hoka.
english_phrase: Stands at the doorway of disappointment.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is disillusioned after giving many gifts. Wakaʻina was a ghost of North Kohala who deceived people. He often flew to where people gathered and chanted. When he had their attention he would say, “I could chant better if I had a tapa cloth.” In this way he would name one thing after another, and when all had been given him he would fly away chanting these words.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū i ka māna.
english_phrase: Like the one from whom he received what he learned.
meaning_phrase: Said of a child who behaves like those who reared him. Mana is food masticated by an elder and conveyed to the mouth of a small child. The haumāna (pupil) receives knowledge from the mouth of his teacher.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū i ka moku.
english_phrase: Stands on the island.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who has become a ruler — he stands on his district or island.

hawaiian_phrase: Kuʻi ka pōhaku, ʻanapa ke ahi o ka lewa.
english_phrase: The stones pound; the fire flashes in the sky.
meaning_phrase: Thunder and lightning.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū i ka poholima ua mea he wahine maikaʻi.
english_phrase: A beautiful woman stands on the palm of the hand.
meaning_phrase: A beautiful woman makes one desire to caress and serve her.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū i ka welo.
english_phrase: Fits into the family behavior pattern.
meaning_phrase: Whether good or bad, one’s behavior is judged by the family he belongs to.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū i ke ʻaki.
english_phrase: Has reached the very highest spot.
meaning_phrase: Do not procrastinate; make preparations for the future now.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū i ke aʻuaʻu.
english_phrase: Jabbed by a small swordfish.
meaning_phrase: Felt the blows of a smaller person in a fight or a contest of strength.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū i ke Kīpuʻupuʻu.
english_phrase: Buffeted by the Kīpuʻupuʻu.
meaning_phrase: Said of hurt feelings. Kīpuʻupuʻu is a chilly wind and rain at Waimea, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Kuʻikuʻi, hana pele; holo i uka, holo i kai, holo i kahi e peʻe ai a nalo.
english_phrase: Pound, pound, pulverize; run mountainward, run seaward, run till you find a hiding place and hide.
meaning_phrase: The chant used in hide-and-go-seek. One child gently pounds the back of the “master” and repeats this chant while the other children run and hide.

hawaiian_phrase: Kuʻi pē ʻia e ka ʻĀpaʻapaʻa.
english_phrase: Pounded flat by the ʻĀpaʻapaʻa wind.
meaning_phrase: Said of a sudden and terrible disaster, or of one who has taken a beating. The ʻĀpaʻapaʻa is a wind of Kohala.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū kaʻapā ia Hawaiʻi, he moku nui.
english_phrase: [It is well for] Hawaiʻi to show activity; it is the largest of the islands.
meaning_phrase: Hawaiʻi should lead forth for she is the largest.

hawaiian_phrase: Kūkae uli.
english_phrase: Octopus ink.
meaning_phrase: A term applied to prostitutes in the whaling days because of their cleverness in escaping from precarious situations, like an octopus that squirts ink to cover its escape.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū ka hale i Punaluʻu, i Ka-wai-hū-o-Kauila.
english_phrase: The house stands at Punaluʻu, at the gushing water of Kauila.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who has found peace and comfort at last. Ka-wai-hū-o-Kauila is a spring, the gift of a turtle goddess to the people of Punaluʻu, Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi. The people of that locality feared the cannibal woman Kaikapū, who lived near their best springs. In order to avoid her and obtain water, they dived to the sea floor where fresh water bubbled up — hence the name Puna-luʻu (Water-dived-for). Seeing their difficulty, a turtle goddess created this spring.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū ka hālelo, ke ʻā o kahawai.
english_phrase: A lot of trash accumulated with the rocks in the streams.
meaning_phrase: The sign of a storm. Also said of the many useless, hurtful words uttered in anger.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū ka lau lama.
english_phrase: Many torches stand.
meaning_phrase: There are many lighted bonfires, a signal of joy and victory.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū ka liki mai nei hoʻi ʻo ia ala.
english_phrase: What a proud stance he has over there.
meaning_phrase: Said of a show-off.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū ka liki o Nuʻuanu i ka makani.
english_phrase: Nuʻuanu draws her shoulders up in the wind.
meaning_phrase: Said of a show-off.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū ka paila, hana ka hāʻawe.
english_phrase: A pile has accumulated; now to carry the load.
meaning_phrase: Said of a big accumulation of work that requires effort to clear up. Paila is Hawaiianized from the English “pile.”

hawaiian_phrase: Kū ka pao a Keawe.
english_phrase: Keawe’s burial place stands.
meaning_phrase: Said of Hale-o-Keawe in Hōnaunau, Kona, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū ka pūʻali.
english_phrase: His forces are ready.
meaning_phrase: He is ready to get to work.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū ka ule, heʻe ka laho.
english_phrase: The penis stands, the scrotum sags.
meaning_phrase: This expression is not meant to be vulgar. When the ule or pōule (breadfruit blossom) appears, it is the sign of the fruiting season. The young breadfruit first appears upright, and as the fruit grows larger its stem bends so that it hangs downward.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū ka uahi o Papio.
english_phrase: Up rose the smoke of Papio.
meaning_phrase: Off she went! The Papio was a boat; rising smoke indicated that she was departing.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū ke ʻā i ka hale o Kaupō.
english_phrase: The lava is heaped at the house of Kaupō.
meaning_phrase: A saying from the legend of Pāmano. Pāmano shouted this as his uncle Waipū was trying to make him drunk with ʻawa before killing him. The saying denotes great distress.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū ke ʻā i kai o ʻĀpua.
english_phrase: Lava rocks were heaped down at ʻĀpua.
meaning_phrase: Said of a confusing untidiness, like the strewing of lava rocks, or of utter destruction. ʻApua, in Puna, Hawaiʻi, is a land of rocks.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū ke ʻehu o ka huhū o ka mea hale, nakeke ka ʻauwae i ka inaina.
english_phrase: The anger of the house owner rises like the [sea] spray, and the chin rattles with wrath.
meaning_phrase: Said of an angry host. First uttered by Lohiʻau when he arrived at Kīlauea and encountered the wrath of Pele.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū ke ʻehu o nā wahi ʻauwaʻa liʻiliʻi.
english_phrase: How the spray dashes up before the fleet of little canoes.
meaning_phrase: An expression originating in the game kōnane. Trifling things are as dust to experts. Used in a chant of ʻAukele-nui-a-Iku.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū ke paʻi, hana ka hāʻawe.
english_phrase: A big heap that requires carrying on the back.
meaning_phrase: A heap of work.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū kiʻi i kai o Kahuwā.
english_phrase: The image stands at the shore of Kahuwā.
meaning_phrase: An idle and ignorant person who stands around like an image.

hawaiian_phrase: Kukū a kākalaioa.
english_phrase: Thorny like the kākalaioa plant.
meaning_phrase: Said of any unpleasant condition.

hawaiian_phrase: Kukui ʻā mau i ka awakea.
english_phrase: Torch that continues to burn in daylight.
meaning_phrase: A symbol of the family of Iwikauikaua. After his daughter was put to death by one of his wives, this chief made a tour of the island of Hawaiʻi with torches burning day and night. This became a symbol of his descendants, who included Kalākaua and Liliʻuokalani.

hawaiian_phrase: Kukui-lau-nui-o-Kona.
english_phrase: Thickly leafed kukui of Kona.
meaning_phrase: A thick cloud that shuts out the light of the sun, like a heavily leafed kukui tree. This expression was used in the Kona district of Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Kukū ka pihapiha a piʻi ka lena.
english_phrase: The gills stand out and the yellow color arises.
meaning_phrase: Filled with anger.

hawaiian_phrase: Kūkulu ka ʻike i ka ʻōpua.
english_phrase: Knowledge is set up in the clouds.
meaning_phrase: Clouds are observed for signs and omens.

hawaiian_phrase: Kūkulu kalaʻihi ka lā i Mānā.
english_phrase: The sun sets up mirages at Mānā.
meaning_phrase: Said of a boastful person who exaggerates.

hawaiian_phrase: Kūkulu kauhale a Limaloa.
english_phrase: Limaloa builds his house.
meaning_phrase: Limaloa was the god of mirages who at certain times of the year would build a village in the moonlight at Mānā, Kauaʻi. The village would vanish as quickly as it had appeared.

hawaiian_phrase: Kūkuni i kāʻili o ka ipo ahi.
english_phrase: Burning the skin of the lovers.
meaning_phrase: When sparks from hurled firebrands fell near the spectators, lovers would pick them up quickly and drop them on the skin. The resulting scar was a remembrance of the event.

hawaiian_phrase: Kula unahi pikapika heʻe.
english_phrase: Kula people, scalers of the suckers on the tentacles of the octopus.
meaning_phrase: Said in fun of the people of Kula, Maui. A Kula chiefess who lived inland did not know what the suckers on an octopus were and tried to scale them as one scales fish.

hawaiian_phrase: Kūlele ke ʻehu kai i ka makani.
english_phrase: The sprays are a-flying in the wind.
meaning_phrase: What wrath!

hawaiian_phrase: Kūlia i ka nuʻu.
english_phrase: Strive to reach the highest.
meaning_phrase: Motto of Queen Kapiʻolani.

hawaiian_phrase: Kūlia i ka nuʻu, i ka paepae kapu o Līloa.
english_phrase: Strive to reach the summit, to the sacred platform of Līloa.
meaning_phrase: Strive to do your best.

hawaiian_phrase: Kuli uōuō.
english_phrase: Bellowing deaf person.
meaning_phrase: Said of a deaf person who speaks louder than necessary because of his own inability to hear.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū loa akula i kulakula.
english_phrase: Stopped way up on dry land.
meaning_phrase: Stranded.

hawaiian_phrase: Kulu ka waimaka, uē ka ʻōpua.
english_phrase: The tears fall; the clouds weep.
meaning_phrase: When rain falls at the time of a person’s death or during his funeral, it is said, the gods mingle their tears with those of the mourners.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū mai nō, he pali.
english_phrase: There it stands, a cliff.
meaning_phrase: Said in admiration of a handsome person who, like a cliff, attracts the attention.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū ma ka pā o Homa.
english_phrase: Stood by the fence of Homa.
meaning_phrase: Standing in the way of disappointment. A Mr. Oliver Holmes (“Homa” to the Hawaiians) lived at Polelewa in Honolulu. A play on homa (disappointment).

hawaiian_phrase: Kumuhea kupu ʻino.
english_phrase: Kumuhea, an evil demigod.
meaning_phrase: Said of anything destructive to the health. Kumuhea was a caterpillar god who ruined the health of his human wife and almost caused her death by keeping her on a diet of sweet-potato leaves. Her father called to his father, the god Kū, who deprived Kumuhea of his human form, thus making it impossible for him to live with her any more. Kumuhea lived on Puʻuʻenuhe in Kaʻū.

hawaiian_phrase: Kūneki nā kūʻauhau liʻiliʻi, noho mai i lalo; hoʻokahi nō, ʻo ko ke aliʻi ke piʻi i ka ʻiʻo.
english_phrase: Set aside the lesser genealogies and remain humble; let only one be elevated, that of the chief.
meaning_phrase: Boast not of your own lineage but elevate that of your chief. Said to members of the junior line of chiefs.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū nō i ke keʻa.
english_phrase: Like his sire.
meaning_phrase: Like sire, like child.

hawaiian_phrase: Kūʻonoʻono ka lua o Kuhaimoana.
english_phrase: Deep indeed is the cave of Kuhaimoana.
meaning_phrase: Said of a prosperous person. Kuonoʻono (deep) also means “to be well supplied.” The cave of Kuhaimoana, a shark god, is at the islet of Kaʻula.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū pākū ka pali o Nihoa i ka makani.
english_phrase: The clff of Nihoa stands as a resistance against the wind.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who stands bravely in the face of misfortune.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū palaka ka wai o Welokā.
english_phrase: The water of Welokā is blocked.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who has lost interest or becomes inactive, or of a situation that is at a standstill.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū pāpiā Hilo i ka ua.
english_phrase: Hilo stands directly in the path of the rain.
meaning_phrase: Off she went! The Papio was a boat; rising smoke indicated that she was departing.

hawaiian_phrase: Kūpihipihi loa kahi koena ʻopihi.
english_phrase: The remaining limpets have dwindled in size.
meaning_phrase: A modern saying — the finances have dwindled considerably.

hawaiian_phrase: Kū piki mola maoli nō.
english_phrase: “Too bit small” indeed.
meaning_phrase: It is such a tiny little bit. Kū piki mola is Hawaiianized from the English.

hawaiian_phrase: Kūpinaʻi i ke alo o Haoaloa.
english_phrase: Keeps repeating in the presence of Haoaloa.
meaning_phrase: The din of shouting is heard again and again. Also, the noise keeps flowing like rushing water.

hawaiian_phrase: Kūpopou ana i ka pali o Kēʻē.
english_phrase: Going downhill at the cliff of Kēʻē.
meaning_phrase: A play on kē (to object) and ʻe (elsewhere). Said of one who is not cooperative.

hawaiian_phrase: Kupouli Kānehoa i ka hele a Kaukaʻōpua.
english_phrase: Kānehoa is darkened by the departure of Kaukaʻōpua.
meaning_phrase: Said of dark grief at the departure of a loved one.

hawaiian_phrase: Kuʻu ēwe, kuʻu piko, kuʻu iwi, kuʻu koko.
english_phrase: My umbilical cord, my navel, my bones, my blood.
meaning_phrase: Said of a very close relative.

hawaiian_phrase: Kuʻu ʻia ka palu i piʻi ka moano.
english_phrase: To let down the mashed fish lure so that the moano fish rises to the surface.
meaning_phrase: To tell tall tales that attract gullible people. Palu (fish lure) here refers to lies. The fish come with the idea of feasting and are caught.

hawaiian_phrase: Kuʻu ka luhi, ua maha.
english_phrase: He has let down his weariness and is at rest.
meaning_phrase: He is dead. He has left all his labors, all that wearied his mind and body, and now he is at peace.

hawaiian_phrase: Kuʻu manu lawelawe ō o Hoʻolehua.
english_phrase: My bird of Hoʻolehua that cries out about food.
meaning_phrase: Said of the kioea, whose cry sounds like “Lawelawe ke ō! Lawelawe ke ō!" (“Take the food! Take the food!”). The kioea is the bird that calls to the fishermen to set out to sea.

hawaiian_phrase: Lahaina, i ka malu ʻulu o Lele.
english_phrase: Lahaina, in the shade of the breadfruit trees of Lele.
meaning_phrase: The old name for Lahaina was Lele.

hawaiian_phrase: Lāhui pua o lalo.
english_phrase: The many flowers below.
meaning_phrase: The commoners.

hawaiian_phrase: Lāʻie i ka ʻēheu o nā manu.
english_phrase: Lāʻie, borne on the wings of birds.
meaning_phrase: Lāʻie is a gathering place for people. Twin girls were born at a place now bearing the name of Lāʻie, Oʻahu. The older twin, Lāʻiekawai, was reared by her grandmother, Waka, and was said to rest on the wings of birds. The younger, Lāʻielohelohe, was taken by a kahuna to rear.

hawaiian_phrase: Laʻi Hauola i ke kai māʻokiʻoki.
english_phrase: Peaceful Hauola by the choppy sea.
meaning_phrase: Peace and tranquility in the face of disturbance.

hawaiian_phrase: Laʻi ke keha o ka nohona.
english_phrase: One can boast of a peaceful life.
meaning_phrase: Love removes hurt.

hawaiian_phrase: Laʻi lua ke kai.
english_phrase: The sea is very calm.
meaning_phrase: All is peaceful.

hawaiian_phrase: Lālau aku ʻoe i ka ʻulu i ka wēkiu, i ke alo nō ka ʻulu, a hala.
english_phrase: You reach for the breadfruit away at the top and miss the one in front of you.
meaning_phrase: Sometimes one who reaches afar misses an opportunity that is right before him. Once Kalākaua promised to give a better position to Kamaʻiopili of Maui, but then forgot his promise. One day, while playing billiards with the king, Kamaʻiopili purposely played very badly and exclaimed, “I ke alo nō ka ʻulu, a hala,” whenever he missed the cue ball (ʻulu). This puzzled the king, and when the game was over, he asked a man who knew all the old sayings what Kamaʻiopili had meant. The king was told that Kamaʻiopili was reminding him that others had been rewarded with good positions, but that the man right in front of him, Kamaʻiopili, had been forgotten.

hawaiian_phrase: Lānaʻi a Kaululāʻau.
english_phrase: Lānai of Kaululāʻau.
meaning_phrase: Said in admiration of Lānaʻi. Kaululāʻau was a Maui chief banished to Lānaʻi by his father for destroying his breadfruit grove. By trickery Kaululāʻau destroyed the island’s evil spirits and became its ruler.

hawaiian_phrase: Lānaʻi a ke aea.
english_phrase: Lānai raises its face.
meaning_phrase: A rude expression for the people of Lānaʻi. Once, a Lānaʻi chief was conquered in battle, and the conqueror offered him either humiliation or death. He was to choose between kissing his conqueror’s penis or receiving a death clout on the head with a club. He chose humiliation, and as he bent to kiss the penis, he lifted his face quickly in distaste. Hence this saying. His relatives were ashamed, for they felt he should have chosen death and retained his dignity as a chief.

hawaiian_phrase: Lānaʻi i ke ʻehu o ke kai.
english_phrase: Lānaʻi stands among the sea sprays.
meaning_phrase: Said of the kauā of Lānaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Lānaʻi poʻo kūkae moa.
english_phrase: Lānaʻi, with head smeared with chicken dung.
meaning_phrase: Said of the kauā of Lānaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Lana ka ʻauwae i kahi hāiki.
english_phrase: The chin floated in a narrow place.
meaning_phrase: He barely escaped.

hawaiian_phrase: Lanalana, pā i ke Kona, huli pū.
english_phrase: Insecurely rooted, when the Kona winds blow it topples over.
meaning_phrase: When one is insecurely rooted in his knowledge or character, any adversity causes him to fall.

hawaiian_phrase: Lauaʻe o Makana.
english_phrase: The lauaʻe fern of Makana.
meaning_phrase: Famed in songs and chants is the lauaʻe that grows everywhere at Makana on Kauaʻi. When crushed it has a scent similar to that of the maile and is often used with the pandanus fruit in making lei.

hawaiian_phrase: Lauahi Pele i kai o Puna, one ʻā kai o Malama.
english_phrase: Pele spreads her fire down in Puna and leaves cinder down in Malama.
meaning_phrase: There are two places in Puna called Malama, one inland and one on the shore where black sand (one ʻā) is found.

hawaiian_phrase: Lau ʻauʻa.
english_phrase: Much held back.
meaning_phrase: She ignored the bait. She had a chance to get him for a husband, but she let her opportunity slip by.

hawaiian_phrase: Lauʻī pekepeke.
english_phrase: Short-leaved ti plant.
meaning_phrase: An insult applied to the kauā. Like small-leaved ti, they weren’t of much use. Longer leaves were better liked because they were useful as food wrappers.

hawaiian_phrase: Lau-kapalili. Lau-kapalala.
english_phrase: Tremble-leaf. Broad-leaf.
meaning_phrase: These were the names applied to the leaves of the very first taro plant, whieh according to legend was named Hāloa. Taro leaves are sometimes referred to poetically by these terms.

hawaiian_phrase: Lau koaiʻe.
english_phrase: Koaiʻe leaves.
meaning_phrase: Said of anything found only in the upland, like the leaves of the koaiʻe tree.

hawaiian_phrase: Laulaha ka ʻai a ke ʻahi.
english_phrase: The ʻahi fish takes the hook in swarms.
meaning_phrase: Said when the sea is full of canoes fishing for ʻahi. Also said of a successful business — customers come in swarms.

hawaiian_phrase: Lawea ke kihe i Mauliola.
english_phrase: Take the sneeze to Mauliola.
meaning_phrase: Said to one who sneezes. A similar saying is Kihe, a Mauliola.

hawaiian_phrase: Lawe i ka maʻalea a kūʻonoʻono.
english_phrase: Take wisdom and make it deep.
meaning_phrase: As long as there are potatoes, even small or broken ones, a farmer gets along.

hawaiian_phrase: Lawe ka hanu i ʻOlepau.
english_phrase: The breath was taken to ʻOlepau.
meaning_phrase: A play on ʻole (no) and pau (finished) Said of one who dies by accident, in a war, etc., and not from natural causes. ʻOlepau is a moon phase in the lunar month.

hawaiian_phrase: Lawelawe mālie ka Waiʻopua.
english_phrase: The Waiōpua breeze handles gently.
meaning_phrase: Said of one whose ways are gentle and easygoing or of one who is very careful in handling anything.

hawaiian_phrase: Lawe liʻiliʻi ka make a ka Hawaiʻi, lawe nui ka make a ka haole.
english_phrase: Death by Hawaiians takes a few at a time; death by foreigners takes many.
meaning_phrase: The diseases that were known in the islands before the advent of foreigners caused fewer deaths than those that were introduced.

hawaiian_phrase: Lawe ʻo Lehua i ka lā; lilo!
english_phrase: Lehua takes away the sun; [it is] gone!
meaning_phrase: The sun is said to vanish beyond Lehua at sunset. In love chants, this saying means that one’s sweetheart has been taken away.

hawaiian_phrase: Lawe ʻo Maleka i ka hoa lā; lilo!
english_phrase: America takes the mate; [she is] gone!
meaning_phrase: This expression was used in a chant of the whaling days, when some Hawaiians lost their wives and sweethearts to the white sailors.

hawaiian_phrase: Leʻa ka ʻai a ka ʻiole, ua nui ka ʻili.
english_phrase: The rats joyously eat their fill, there are many skins [remaining].
meaning_phrase: There were two Hilo brothers who lived at Kukuau and Puʻueo. The latter was very prosperous but neglectful of his needy brother. One day the Kukuau man decided to visit his wealthy brother and found many friends eating. After watching them for a while he made this remark. It was overheard by someone who reported it to their host. When he came to see who it was he found that it was his own brother. Sadly he realized then how he had neglected his own kin while outsiders enjoyed his weakh. This saying is sometimes used for one who does for outsiders but neglects his own.

hawaiian_phrase: Leʻa kaena a ka lawaiʻa, ua mālie.
english_phrase: The fisherman enjoys bragging when the weather is calm.
meaning_phrase: A person who enjoys peace and comfort can very well boast of his luck.

hawaiian_phrase: Leʻa ke kau ʻai.
english_phrase: The time for food is pleasing.
meaning_phrase: One can eat with pleasure — there are no wars, just peace.

hawaiian_phrase: Leʻa kūlou a ka lawaiʻa, ua mālie.
english_phrase: The fisherman enjoys bending over in his work when all is calm.
meaning_phrase: When the sea is calm and no gales blow, the fisherman can enjoy fishing.

hawaiian_phrase: Leʻaleʻa ka ʻōlelo i ka pohu aku o loko.
english_phrase: Conversation is pleasant when the inside is calm.
meaning_phrase: Talk is pleasant when hunger is satisfied.

hawaiian_phrase: Lehu ke poʻo i ka uahi o ka hoʻoilo.
english_phrase: The head turns ash gray in the smoke of winter.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who remains indoors constantly during the windy, rainy month of Welehu, huddled by a fireplace for warmth. Later applied to one who prefers being indoors.

hawaiian_phrase: Lei Hanakahi i ke ʻala me ke onaona o Panaʻewa.
english_phrase: Hanakahi is adorned with the fragrance and perfume of Panaʻewa.
meaning_phrase: The forest of Panaʻewa was famous for its maile vines and hala and lehua blossoms, well liked for making lei, so Hilo (Hanakahi) was said to be wreathed with fragrance.

hawaiian_phrase: Lei i ke ʻolo.
english_phrase: Wearers of gourds around the neck.
meaning_phrase: The kauā, who were a despised people. One who was marked for sacrifice was made to wear a small gourd suspended from the neck by a cord.

hawaiian_phrase: Leikō ka ʻanakā.
english_phrase: Let go the anchor.
meaning_phrase: Hawaiianized from the English, this phrase appears in chants of the whaling days.

hawaiian_phrase: Lei Mahiki i ka ua kōkō ʻula.
english_phrase: Mahiki wears a wreath of rainbow-hued rain.
meaning_phrase: A total loss.

hawaiian_phrase: Lēʻī ʻo Kohala i ka nuku nā kānaka. [Lēʻī Kohala, eia i ka nuku nā kānaka. (PE)]
english_phrase: Covered is Kohala with men to the very point of land.
meaning_phrase: A great populahon has Kohala. Kauhiakama onee traveled to Kohala to spy for his father, the ruling chief of Maui. While there, he did not see many people for they were all tending their farms in the upland. He returned home to report that there were hardly any men in Kohala. But when the invaders from Maui came they found a great number of men, all ready to defend their homeland.

hawaiian_phrase: Lele ʻaʻau na manu o Kīwaʻa.
english_phrase: The birds of Kīwaʻa took flight in confusion.
meaning_phrase: Said of people fleeing in panic.

hawaiian_phrase: Lele au lā, hokahoka wale iho.
english_phrase: I fly away, leaving disappointment behind.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is disillusioned after giving many gifts. Wakaʻina was a ghost of North Kohala who deceived people. He often flew to where people gathered and chanted. When he had their attention he would say, “I could chant better if I had a tapa cloth.” In this way he would name one thing after another, and when all had been given him he would fly away chanting these words.

hawaiian_phrase: Lele i Kona; lele i Koʻolau.
english_phrase: Flies to the leeward side of the island and flies to the windward.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is hard to locate.

hawaiian_phrase: Lele kāhili, holo ka uhaʻi, uhi kapa.
english_phrase: Kāhili sway, the door covering is closed, the tapa is drawn up.
meaning_phrase: The chief sleeps.

hawaiian_phrase: Lele ka hoaka.
english_phrase: The spirit has flown away.
meaning_phrase: The glory of the land has departed. Also, the person is dead.

hawaiian_phrase: Lele ka ʻiwa mālie kai koʻo.
english_phrase: When the ʻiwa bird flies [out to sea] the rough sea will be calm.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who is still a child, either physically or mentally.

hawaiian_phrase: Lele ka makani o Makahūʻena, kuakea ka moana.
english_phrase: When the wind of Makahuena flies, the ocean is white with foam.
meaning_phrase: A play on maka (eyes), hū (overflow), and ʻena (red hot or wrath) in the name Makahūʻena (Eyes-spilling-wrath). Applied to one whose eyes and manner denote fury. First uttered by Pele in a chant about the winds of Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Lele ka manu i Kahiki.
english_phrase: The bird has flown to Kahiki.
meaning_phrase: He has taken flight like the plover to a foreign country and is not to be found.

hawaiian_phrase: Lele kapu i kai.
english_phrase: The kapu has flown to the sea.
meaning_phrase: The kapu has been abolished.

hawaiian_phrase: Lele koaʻe.
english_phrase: Tropic bird flying.
meaning_phrase: A term of reproach applied to the kauā — flyers into space without a foothold.

hawaiian_phrase: Lele kōheoheo i ka pali o Kapaheo.
english_phrase: Plummeting from the cliff of Kapaheo.
meaning_phrase: A Kaʻū saying and a play on heo (quickly gone).

hawaiian_phrase: Lele Laukī i ka pali.
english_phrase: Laukī leaped off the cliff.
meaning_phrase: Said when one in desperation does harm to himself. Laukl was a native of Puna who was ashamed after being derided about his small penis, so he committed suicide by leaping off a cliff. Sometimes applied humorously to one who has lost his sexual potency.

hawaiian_phrase: Lele liʻiliʻi ka lehu o kapuahi.
english_phrase: The ashes of the fireplace are scattered.
meaning_phrase: Said of one whose wrath sends everybody going in all directions to get out of his way, or of a scattering of things helter-skelter. This saying came from the scattering of ashes at sea by the kahuna ʻanāʻanā on the night of Kāne or Lono, after he had prayed over and burnt the “bait” taken from the victim.

hawaiian_phrase: Lele nō ka ʻohe i kona lua.
english_phrase: The ʻohe taro leaps into its own hole.
meaning_phrase: Each person to his own place. From the legend of Kamiki, in whieh the hero called to the various taros by name, and each leaped into its own hole and stood there.

hawaiian_phrase: Lele o Kohala me he lupe lā.
english_phrase: Kohala soars as a kite.
meaning_phrase: An expression of admiration for Kohala, a district that has often been a leader in doing good works.

hawaiian_phrase: Lewa i ke alahaka o Nuʻalolo.
english_phrase: Swaying on the ladder of Nualolo.
meaning_phrase: Lacking security, especially of one who has no home.

hawaiian_phrase: Lewa ka waha o ka puhi o Laumeki.
english_phrase: The mouth of the eel of Laumeki gapes.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who talks so much that his mouth is hardly ever closed. Laumeki was an eel-man who lived at Wailau, Molokaʻi. When he saw that Kuʻula’s fishpond at Hāna, Maui, was always full of fish, he decided to assume his eel form and go there to steal some. On one of his thieving expeditions, he was caught by a magic hook and drawn ashore, where his jaw was smashed and left gaping.

hawaiian_phrase: Līhuʻe hōʻā wahie lālā koa.
english_phrase: Līhue lights fires with koa branches.
meaning_phrase: Līhuʻe, Oʻahu, once had a grove of koa trees whose branches were used for firewood.

hawaiian_phrase: Liʻiliʻi hāuliuli, monimoni ka hāʻae.
english_phrase: Little hāuliuli fish, makes the mouth water.
meaning_phrase: Said in reference to a young person who is already wise in the ways of sex and has a strong attraction for the opposite sex.

hawaiian_phrase: Liʻiliʻi kamaliʻi ʻawahia ke au.
english_phrase: Though the child is small, the gall is bitter.
meaning_phrase: Said of a rude, impudent child.
