hawaiian_phrase: Liʻiliʻi kamaliʻi, nunui ka ʻomoʻomo palaoa; liʻiliʻi pua mauʻu kihe ka puka ihu.
english_phrase: Small child, but a big loaf of bread; small blade of grass, but it tickles the nostril enough to cause sneezing.
meaning_phrase: Once said by a chiefess in praise of a teenage boy with whom she had an affair, this became a humorous saying throughout the islands.

hawaiian_phrase: Liʻiliʻi manu ʻai laiki, akamai i ka hana pūnana.
english_phrase: Small is the rice bird but an expert in nest building.
meaning_phrase: He may be insignificant but he’s a good worker.

hawaiian_phrase: Liʻiliʻi nīoi hiohio ka waha.
english_phrase: Small pepper makes the mouth blow.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is small but potent.

hawaiian_phrase: Liʻiliʻi ʻōhiki loloa ka lua.
english_phrase: Little sand crabs dig deep holes.
meaning_phrase: Said in disgust of little girls too wise in the ways of sex.

hawaiian_phrase: Lī ka ʻili i ke anu o Hauaʻiliki.
english_phrase: The skin is chilled in the cold of Hauaʻiliki.
meaning_phrase: It is extremely cold. A play on the name Hau-a-iliki (Ice-strikes).

hawaiian_phrase: Like nō i ka laʻi o Hanakahi.
english_phrase: All the same in the calm of Hanakahi.
meaning_phrase: There is unity; all are as one. A play on kahi (one) in the place name Hanakahi.

hawaiian_phrase: Like nō Kaʻena me Waialua.
english_phrase: Kaʻena and Waialua are one.
meaning_phrase: Kaʻena Point is in Waialua. Similar to the saying, “Six of one and half a dozen of the other.”

hawaiian_phrase: Like no lāua me Limunui.
english_phrase: He is like Limunui.
meaning_phrase: Women fall in love with him as easily as gathering limu (seaweed). This was said of Kahalaiʻa, a chief who was very handsome and kind.

hawaiian_phrase: Like ʻole ka pilina o ka nihoniho.
english_phrase: The scallops were not all of the same size.
meaning_phrase: This saying compares people to the scallops on lace. When all are in harmony, they are attractive and interesting. But when they are not, they are like lace with scallops of all sizes and shapes.

hawaiian_phrase: Līlā ka maiʻa o ka ʻeʻa, wili ka ʻōkaʻi.
english_phrase: Though the banana of the mountain patch is spindly, thc blossom container twists.
meaning_phrase: Even a spindly plant or person can bear fruit.

hawaiian_phrase: Lilo akula ka nui a koe ka unahi.
english_phrase: Most [of the fish] are taken and only the scales are left.
meaning_phrase: Said after someone has taken the lion’s share for himself.

hawaiian_phrase: Lilo i ke kake o Lehua.
english_phrase: Absorbed in the kake chant of Lehua.
meaning_phrase: The kake is a chant composed with words so broken up that it requires considerable attention to understand. Said of one who is so absorbed that he is hardly conscious of anything else.

hawaiian_phrase: Lilo i Puna i ke au a ka hewahewa, hoʻi mai ua piha ka hale i ke akua.
english_phrase: Gone to Puna on a vagrant current and returning, fnds the house full of imps.
meaning_phrase: From a chant by Hiʻiaka when she faced the lizard god Panaʻewa and his forest full of imps in a battle. It was later used to refer to one who goes on his way and comes home to find things not to his liking.

hawaiian_phrase: Lilo ka maka i ke kua.
english_phrase: The eyes are turned to the back.
meaning_phrase: There is an angry look in the eyes.

hawaiian_phrase: Lilo loa me Lāʻielohelohe.
english_phrase: Gone entirely with Lāʻielohelohe.
meaning_phrase: A play on lohelohe (droopy). Said of one who droops with intoxication.

hawaiian_phrase: Lima kaʻa lolena.
english_phrase: Hands occupied with uselessness.
meaning_phrase: I am a small person who can accomplish much. When Lonoikamakahiki visited Kamalalawalu, ruling chief of Maui, he took along his half-brother Pupukea to serve him. Makakuikalani, half-brother and personal attendant of Kamalalawalu, made fun of the small stature of Pupukea. This saying was Pupukea’s retort.

hawaiian_phrase: Limua ka moku.
english_phrase: The land is moss-covered.
meaning_phrase: There is peace in the land, and no wars to disturb it.

hawaiian_phrase: Limu pahapaha nolu i ke kai.
english_phrase: Sea lettuce, easily swayed by the action of the tide.
meaning_phrase: A derogatory expression for a person weak of character or physical ability.

hawaiian_phrase: Liʻuliʻu wale ka nohona i ka lā o Hauola, a holoholo i ke one o ʻAlio.
english_phrase: Long has one tarried in the sunlight of Hauola and walked on the sand of ʻAlio.
meaning_phrase: Said in praise of an aged person. There is a play on ola (life) in the name Hauola.

hawaiian_phrase: Liʻu nā maka o ke akua i ka paʻakai.
english_phrase: The eyes of the supernatural beings are made to smart with salt.
meaning_phrase: Said of people who have been duped.

hawaiian_phrase: Loaʻa i ka lāʻau a Kekuaokalani, ʻo Lehelehekiʻi.
english_phrase: You will get Kekuaokalani s club called Lehelehekiʻi.
meaning_phrase: You will find nothing but disappointment. Kekuaokalani was a nephew of Kamehameha I, to whom the latter entrusted the care of his war god after his death. Kekuaokalani had a club called Lehelehe-kiʻi (Lips-of-an-image). One meaning of Lehelehekiʻi is “to get around doing nothing but ʻlip’,” that is, talking.

hawaiian_phrase: Loaʻa i ka piwa lenalena.
english_phrase: He has caught the yellow fever.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is extremely lazy. A play on lena (lazy).

hawaiian_phrase: Loaʻa kāu o ka niu-niu.
english_phrase: You will have yours, the coconut-coconut.
meaning_phrase: You’ll have nothing for all your trouble! A rude remark warning one that double disappointment (niu-niu) is to be expected. A dream of coconuts is a sign that any project planned for the following day will meet with failure.

hawaiian_phrase: Loaʻa ke ola i Hālau-a-ola.
english_phrase: Life is obtained in the House-of-life.
meaning_phrase: One is happy, safe, well again. A play on ola (life, health, healing, contentment, and peace after a struggle).

hawaiian_phrase: Loaʻa pono ka ʻiole i ka pūnana.
english_phrase: The rat was caught right in the nest
meaning_phrase: The fellow was caught red-handed.

hawaiian_phrase: Lohiʻau Puna i ke akua wahine.
english_phrase: Puna is retarded by the goddess.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Pele, ruler of volcanoes. The lava flows she pours into the district retard the work and progress of the people.

hawaiian_phrase: Lomia a wali i ka wali lima ʻole a ke aloha.
english_phrase: Squeezed and crushed by love, who does it without hands.
meaning_phrase: Said of heartrending grief.

hawaiian_phrase: Lona kau lani.
english_phrase: A block on which the royal [canoe] rested.
meaning_phrase: A chief whose sire was higher than that of his mother.

hawaiian_phrase: Lonalona ka moana i ka ʻauwaʻa lawaiʻa.
english_phrase: The ocean is thickly dotted with fishing canoes.
meaning_phrase: Said when a large number of people are spread over a wide area for work or fun, like a very large picnic group.

hawaiian_phrase: Luahine, ke kāʻawe o Kaʻahumanu.
english_phrase: Luahine, shoulder covering of Kaʻ ahumanu.
meaning_phrase: Kaʻahumanu was hurt when Kamehameha took her sister Kaheiheimalie as one of his wives. She swam out to sea with the intention of going until her strength gave out. While in the water she saw a boy following her. She cried out to him to go back, but he kept following. Noticing that he was getting tired, she allowed him to lean on her shoulder to rest. Pity for the boy, Luahine, made her swim back to shore. So it was said that the boy was Kaʻahumanu’s shoulder cover.

hawaiian_phrase: Luahine moe nono.
english_phrase: Old woman who sleeps and snores.
meaning_phrase: Pele, who is said to sleep in lava beds.

hawaiian_phrase: Luhe i ka wai o Pāʻieʻie.
english_phrase: Drooped over the pool of Pāʻieʻie.
meaning_phrase: Drunk.

hawaiian_phrase: Luhi ʻuʻa i ka ʻai a ka lio.
english_phrase: Wasted time and labor getting food for the horse.
meaning_phrase: Applied to one who worked hard, like a Hawaiian sailor on a whaling ship. Retuming home with a well-filled pocket, he would find many friends and girlfriends to help him spend his earnings. In a very short time his cash would be gone and his friends would find another prosperous person. Sadly he would retum to work.

hawaiian_phrase: Luhi wahine ʻia.
english_phrase: Labored over by a woman.
meaning_phrase: Spoken in respect and admiration of a family reared by a woman who alone fed and clothed them.

hawaiian_phrase: Lū i ka ʻōlelo ʻawaʻawa.
english_phrase: Scatters bitter words.
meaning_phrase: Curses another and says unkind words.

hawaiian_phrase: Lū ka makani, mōkākī ka lau lāʻau.
english_phrase: When the wind shakes the trees, the leaves are scattered.
meaning_phrase: Said of a wrathful person who causes everyone to flee from him.

hawaiian_phrase: Luluāʻina ʻole.
english_phrase: Without freckles or spots.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who was well cared for in every way, such as a young chief or a favorite child.

hawaiian_phrase: Lūlū ka heʻe.
english_phrase: Now shake for the octopus.
meaning_phrase: Two men went fishing for octopus. One was half-witted and often the object of the other’s pranks. They came to a spot where the crabs had made holes in the sand, and the wise one said to the fool, “Lūlū ka heʻe!" The fool dropped his cowry lure and gave his line the customary jerk, while his companion continued on to a place where octopus were to be found. In later years this saying was applied in derision to one who rode jerkily on horseback with his legs swaying in time to the animal’s movements.

hawaiian_phrase: Lulu kohekohe.
english_phrase: The kohekohe grass is stilled.
meaning_phrase: Trouble is over. The kohekohe grass, whieh grows in wet patches, is taken up, washed, and allowed to wilt. Then it is spread on the ground with a mat over it. The owner of the mat then sits down in comfort.

hawaiian_phrase: Luʻuluʻu Hanakahi i ka ua nui.
english_phrase: Weighted down is Hanakahi hy the heavy rain.
meaning_phrase: Hanakahi, Hilo, was named for a chief of ancient times. This expression was much used in dirges to express heaviness of the heart, as tears pour like rain.

hawaiian_phrase: Luʻuluʻu Hanalei i ka ua nui; kaumaha i ka noe o Alakaʻi.
english_phrase: Heavily weighted is Hanalei in the pouring rain; laden down by the mist of Alakaʻi.
meaning_phrase: An expression used in dirges and chants of woe to express the burden of sadness, the heaviness of grief, and tears pouring freely like rain. Rains and fogs of other localities may also be used.

hawaiian_phrase: Maʻemaʻe i ke kai ka pua o ka hala, ua māewa wale i ka poli o Kahiwa.
english_phrase: Cleaned by the sea are the blossoms of the hala whose leaves sway at the bosom of Kahiwa.
meaning_phrase: These two lines from a chant of praise for a chief are used as an expression of admiration.

hawaiian_phrase: Maʻemaʻe Puna i ka hala me ka lehua.
english_phrase: Lovely is Puna with the hala and lehua.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Puna, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Maʻewaʻewa i ka hale kuleana ʻole.
english_phrase: One receives abuse in a house without a relative.
meaning_phrase: Pitiful is the lot of one who dwells with those who do not care.

hawaiian_phrase: Mahae ka ua i Alakaʻi.
english_phrase: The rain at Alakaʻi is divided.
meaning_phrase: The people are divided in their opinion of their leader (alakaʻi).

hawaiian_phrase: Māhanalua nā kukui.
english_phrase: The lights are doubled.
meaning_phrase: Said of a drunk person who sees double.

hawaiian_phrase: Māhukona kālua paʻa.
english_phrase: Māhukona, roasted whole.
meaning_phrase: An epithet applied to Māhukona, Hawaiʻi. During Kamehameha’s rule, Kānemakini, a native of Māhukona, was roasted whole there for thievery.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai ʻalaʻala paha i ka ua o ka Waʻahila.
english_phrase: Almost received a scar on the neek, perhaps, from the Waʻahila rain.
meaning_phrase: He just escaped trouble.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai ʻena i ke kanaka i laka aku.
english_phrase: Do not shy away from a person who is attracted to you.
meaning_phrase: Treat him who comes in kindness with kindness.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai hāʻawi wale i ka lei o ka ʻāʻī o ʻalaʻala.
english_phrase: Do not give a lei too freely lest a scrofulous sore appear on the neek.
meaning_phrase: In olden times one never gave the lei he wore except to a person closely related. Should such a lei fall into the hands of a sorcerer who disliked him, a scrofulous sore would appear on his neck. If you wish to make a present of a lei, make a fresh one.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai hahaki ʻoe i ka ʻōhelo o punia i ka ua noe.
english_phrase: Do not pluck the ʻōhelo berries lest we be surrounded by rain and fog.
meaning_phrase: A warning not to do anything that would result in trouble. It is kapu to pluck ʻōhelo berries on the way to the crater of Kīlauea. To do so would cause the rain and fog to come and one would lose his way. It is permissible to pick them at the crater if the first ʻōhelo is tossed into the fire of Pele. Then, on the homeward way, one may pick as he pleases.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai hana wale aku, he niho.
english_phrase: Do not annoy [him, for] he has teeth.
meaning_phrase: Do not tamper with him, for he knows the art of sorcery.

hawaiian_phrase: "Mai hea mai ʻoe?" “Mai Kona mai.” “Pehea ka ua o Kona?” “Palahī puaʻa ka ua o Kona.” “A pehea ke aku?” “Hī ka pā, hī ka malau.”
english_phrase: “Where are you from?” “From Kona.” “How is the rain of Kona?” “The rain of Kona pours like the watery excreta of a hog.” “How are the aku fish?” “They run loose from the hook and the bait carrier.”
meaning_phrase: Said in fun of one suffering from loose bowels. Once, a chief was out relieving himself when his bowels were very loose. A runner came by the little-traveled path through the underbrush and seeing the chief there extended his greetings. The chief began to ask questions, which the runner answered. When the chief went home he told those of his household of the abundance of rain and the run of fish in Kona. His servant, whose curiosity was roused, asked, “What were you doing at the time?” “I was excreting, and my bowels were loose,” answered the chief. “He wasn’t talking about the rain and fish,” said the servant, “he was talking about you.” The chief was angry when he heard this, but it was too late to do anything about it.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai hele kīkaha aku.
english_phrase: Don’t go a-strutting there.
meaning_phrase: Don’t give yourself to ways that are offensive to others.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai Hikapoloa mai.
english_phrase: From Hikapoloa.
meaning_phrase: A play on the name Hikapoloa (Stagger-in-the-dark). Said of a stupid person, or of a drunk.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai hōʻaʻano aku o loaʻa i ka niho.
english_phrase: Don’t go daring others lest [you] be caught between the teeth.
meaning_phrase: Said by Kawelo to his opponent and kinsman, Kauahoa.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai hōʻaleʻale i ka wai i lana mālie.
english_phrase: Do not stir up water that is still.
meaning_phrase: Do not stir up contention when all is peaceful.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai hoʻomakamaka wahine, he hūpē ka loaʻa.
english_phrase: Do not make friends of a woman lest you blow your nose with weeping.
meaning_phrase: Advice to a bride. Be too friendly with another woman and she may hecome too friendly with your husband.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai hoʻomāuna i ka ʻai o huli mai auaneʻi o Hāloa e nānā.
english_phrase: Do not be wasteful of food lest Hāloa turn around and stare [at you].
meaning_phrase: Do not be wasteful, especially of poi, because it would anger Hāloa, the taro god, who would someday let the waster go hungry.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai hoʻoni i ka wai lana mālie.
english_phrase: Do not disturb the water that is tranquil.
meaning_phrase: Let the peaceful enjoy their peace.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai hopu mai ʻoe, he manu kapu; ua kapu na ka nahele o ʻOʻokuauli.
english_phrase: Do not catch it, for it is a bird reserved; reserved for the forest of ʻOʻokuauli.
meaning_phrase: Do not try to win one who is reserved for another.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai ʻike ʻole ʻia nō!
english_phrase: It almost missed being noticed!
meaning_phrase: A sarcastic reply to one who boasts of his accomplishments.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai ka ā a ka w.
english_phrase: From A to W.
meaning_phrase: The alphabet of Hawaiian.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai kaena, o kō ʻole auaneʻi.
english_phrase: Do not boast lest you fail to accomplish what you had boasted you could do.
meaning_phrase: This is a line in a chant by Hiʻiaka praising Kaʻena Point, Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai ka hikina a ka lā i Kumukahi a ka welona a ka lā i Lehua.
english_phrase: From the sunrise at Kumukahi to the fading sunlight at Lehua.
meaning_phrase: From sunrise to sunset. Kumukahi, in Puna, Hawaiʻi, was called the land of the sunrise and Lehua, the land of the sunset. This saying also refers to a life span — from birth to death.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai ka hoʻokuʻi a ka hālāwai.
english_phrase: From zenith to horizon.
meaning_phrase: An expression mueh used in prayers. In calling upon the gods in prayers, one mentions those from the east, west, north, south, and those from zenith to horizon.

hawaiian_phrase: Maikaʻi Kauaʻi, hemolele i ka mālie.
english_phrase: Beautiful Kauaʻi, peaceful in the calm.
meaning_phrase: Line from a chant.

hawaiian_phrase: Maikaʻi nō ka hoʻoipoipo i ka wā e lana ana ke koko; a pau ka lana ana, pau nō ka hie o ia mea.
english_phrase: Lovemaking is good when the blood is circulating freely [in youth]; but when the blood ceases to circulate freely [as in old age] the pleasure one derives from it ceases.
meaning_phrase: An expression of admiration for the district of Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi, or for a stately or outstanding person of that district.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai ka lā hiki a ka lā kau.
english_phrase: From the sun’s arrival to the sun’s rest.
meaning_phrase: Said of a day, from sunrise to sunset. This phrase is much used in prayers. Any mention of the setting of the sun was avoided in prayers for the sick; instead one referred to the sun’s rest, thus suggesting rest and renewal rather than permanent departure.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai ka lā ʻōʻili i Haʻehaʻe a hāliʻi i ka mole o Lehua.
english_phrase: From the appearance of the sun at Haʻehaʻe till it spreads its light to the foundation of Lehua.
meaning_phrase: Haʻehaʻe is a place at Kumukahi, Puna, Hawaiʻi, often referred to in poetry as the gateway of the sun.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai ka ʻōʻili ʻana a ka lā i Kumukahi a ka lā iho aku i ka mole ʻolu o Lehua.
english_phrase: From the appearance of the sun at Kumukahi till its descent beyond the pleasant base of Lehua.
meaning_phrase: From the sunrise at Kumukahi, in Puna, Hawaiʻi, to the sunset beyond the islet of Lehua.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai kāpae i ke aʻo a ka makua, aia he ola ma laila.
english_phrase: Do not set aside the teachings of one’s parents for there is life there.
meaning_phrase: Advice to one who has erred and wishes to rectify his mistake. Young taro leaves often were substituted for pigs when making an offering to the gods. To remove sickness of mind or body, one made five separate offerings of young taro leaves.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai ka piko o ke poʻo a ka poli o ka wāwae, a laʻa ma nā kihi ʻehā o ke kino.
english_phrase: From the crown of the head to the soles of the feet, and the four corners of the body.
meaning_phrase: An expression used in prayers of healing. The four corners are the shoulders and hips; between them are the vital organs of the body.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai ka pō mai ka ʻoiaʻiʻo.
english_phrase: Truth comes from the night.
meaning_phrase: Truth is revealed by the gods.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai ka uka a ke kai, mai kahi pae a kahi pae o Kaʻū, he hoʻokahi nō ʻohana.
english_phrase: From the upland to the sea, from end to end of Kaʻū, there is only one family.
meaning_phrase: The inhabitants of old Kaʻū were of one family.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai kaulaʻi wale i ka iwi o nā kūpuna.
english_phrase: Do not dry out the bones of the ancestors.
meaning_phrase: Do not discuss your ancestors too freely with strangers, for it is like exposing their bones for all to see.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai ke kai kuwā e nū ana i ka ulu hala o Keaʻau a ka ʻāina kāʻili lā o lalo o ka Waikūʻauhoe.
english_phrase: From the noisy sea that moans to the hala groves of Keaʻau, to the land that snatches away the sun, below Waikuauhoe.
meaning_phrase: From Puna, Hawaiʻi, where the sun was said to rise, to Lehua, beyond Waikūʻauhoe, where it vanishes out of sight.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai ke kumu a ka welau.
english_phrase: From trunk to leaf buds.
meaning_phrase: The whole thing.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai kīʻai a hālo wale i ko haʻi ʻīpuka o pā auaneʻi i ka leo.
english_phrase: Do not peer or peep in the doorway of other people’s houses or you’ll be struck by the voice.
meaning_phrase: Mind your own business, or you’ll hear something that will hurt your feelings.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai Kinohi a Hōʻike ʻAna.
english_phrase: From Genesis to Revelation.
meaning_phrase: From the beginning to the end. A favorite expression after Christianity was introduced.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai kolohe i ka moʻo o lele i ka pali.
english_phrase: Do not bother lizards or youll fall off a cliff.
meaning_phrase: A warning not to bother lizards lest someday the moʻo cause a madness that makes one leap off a cliff and die.

hawaiian_phrase: Maile lau liʻi o Koʻiahi.
english_phrase: Fine-leaved maile of Koʻiahi.
meaning_phrase: Often used in chants. The fine-leaved maile of Koʻiahi, in Waiʻanae, was considered the best on Oʻahu for beauty and fragrance. After the introduction of goats this beautiful and much-liked vine vanished.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai lele mua o pā auaneʻi.
english_phrase: Do not leap first lest you be hurt.
meaning_phrase: Don’t be the first to start a fight.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai lilo ʻoe i puni wale, o lilo ʻoe i kamaliʻi.
english_phrase: Do not believe all that is told you lest you be [led as] a little child.
meaning_phrase: Do not be gullible; scan, weigh, and think for yourself.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai lou i ka ʻulu i luna lilo, o lou hewa i ka ʻaʻai ʻole; eia nō ka ʻulu i ke alo.
english_phrase: Do not hook the breadfruit away up above lest you hook an imperfect one; take the one in front of you.
meaning_phrase: Why reach afar for a mate? Choose one from among your own acquaintances

hawaiian_phrase: Mai nānā i ka lāʻau maloʻo, ʻaʻohe mea loaʻa o laila.
english_phrase: Do not pay attention to a dry tree for there is nothing to be gained from it.
meaning_phrase: Nothing is learned from an ignoramus.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai nānā i ka ʻulu o waho, ʻaʻohe ia nāu; e nānā nō i ka ʻulu i ke alo, nāu ia.
english_phrase: Never mind looking for the breadfruit away out, that is not for you; look at the breadfruit in front of you, that is yours.
meaning_phrase: Be satisfied with what you have.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai ʻōlelo i ke kuapuʻu e kū pololei, o hina auaneʻi.
english_phrase: Dont tell the hunchback to stand up straight lest he fall down.
meaning_phrase: Don’t go around correcting others.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai paʻa i ka leo, he ʻole ka hea mai.
english_phrase: Do not withhold the voice and not call out [a welcome].
meaning_phrase: From a password chant used in hula schools. It was often used by one who would like a friendly invitation to come into another’s home.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai pale i ke aʻo a ka makua.
english_phrase: Do not set aside the teachings of a parent.
meaning_phrase: A low commoner.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai piʻi aʻe ʻoe i ka lālā kau halalī o ʻike ʻia kou wahi hilahila e ou mau hoa.
english_phrase: Do not climb to the topmost branches lest your private parts be seen by your companions.
meaning_phrase: Do not put on an air of superiority lest people remember only your faults.

hawaiian_phrase: Mai puni aku o hei i ka ʻupena a ka Lawakua.
english_phrase: Do not helieve it or youll he caught in the net of the Lawakua wind.
meaning_phrase: Why believe all that? It is only wind.

hawaiian_phrase: Makaʻā hōlapu kāheka.
english_phrase: Makaʻā fish that makes a disturbance in the sea pool.
meaning_phrase: An over-active child who disturbs those around him. The makaʻā is an active little fish.

hawaiian_phrase: Makaʻala ke kanaka kāhea manu.
english_phrase: A man who calls birds should always be alert.
meaning_phrase: One who wishes to succeed should be alert to every opportunity, like one who catches birds by imitating their cries.

hawaiian_phrase: Ma ka hana ka ʻike.
english_phrase: In working one learns.
meaning_phrase: Dried fish were rolled in ti leaves and hung up. When the leaves dried, they matched the color of the thatch of the house and often were not noticed at a glance.

hawaiian_phrase: Ma kahi maea ma laila ka nalo e wā ai.
english_phrase: Where the odor is bad, there the flies hum.
meaning_phrase: Scandal-mongers delight in “dirt.”

hawaiian_phrase: Ma kahi o ka hana he ola ma laila.
english_phrase: Where work is, there is life.
meaning_phrase: Wrongdoing in the upland of Puna brings the wrath of Pele.

hawaiian_phrase: Ma kahi o ka makani e pā ai, ma laila ka uahi e hina ai.
english_phrase: Where the wind blows, there the smoke falls.
meaning_phrase: Where the chief commands, the subjects go.

hawaiian_phrase: Mākālei, lāʻau piʻi ona ʻia e ka iʻa.
english_phrase: Mākālei, the stick that attracts and draws thefish.
meaning_phrase: Said of a handsome person who attracts the interest of others. Mākālei was a supernatural tree who attracted fish.

hawaiian_phrase: Makaliʻi ka malama, makaliʻi nā maka, makaliʻi nā nahele.
english_phrase: Makalii is the month in which people squint and plants grow stunted.
meaning_phrase: A play on different meanings of makaliʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Makaliʻi puaināwele ke kai o Keoneʻoʻio.
english_phrase: The sea of Keoneʻoʻio is dim and distant.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who feels himself too good for his associates.

hawaiian_phrase: Makani ʻEka aheahe o Makalawena.
english_phrase: The gentle ʻEka breeze of Makalawena.
meaning_phrase: He who goes where he tempts trouble is bound to suffer.

hawaiian_phrase: Makani holoʻūhā.
english_phrase: The wind that brushes the thighs.
meaning_phrase: A cold wind that chills the legs of the fisherman.

hawaiian_phrase: Makani luna ke lele ʻino maila ke ao.
english_phrase: There is wind from the upland, for the clouds are set a-flying.
meaning_phrase: Signs of trouble are seen. This saying originated shortly after the completion of the Puʻukoholā heiau by Kamehameha I. He sent Keaweaheulu to Kaʻū to invite Keouakuahuʻula to Kawaihae for a peace conference between them. Against the advice of his own high priest, Keouakuahuʻula went, taking his best warriors along with him. When outside of Māhukona, he saw canoes come out of Kawaihae and realized that treachery awaited him. It was then that he uttered the words of this saying. His navigator pleaded with him to go back, but he refused. Arriving in Kawaihae, Keouakuahuʻula stepped off the canoe while uttering a chant in honor of Kamehameha. One of the latter’s war leaders stepped up from behind and killed him. All of his followers were slaughtered except for Kuakahela, who hid and later found his way home, where he wailed the sad story.

hawaiian_phrase: Makapaʻa ʻike ʻole i ka ʻope iʻa.
english_phrase: One-eyed person who does not see the bundle of fish.
meaning_phrase: Dried fish were rolled in ti leaves and hung up. When the leaves dried, they matched the color of the thatch of the house and often were not noticed at a glance.

hawaiian_phrase: Maka piapia.
english_phrase: Dirty, sticky eyes.
meaning_phrase: A rude expression applied to one who looks at a thing but doesn’t seem to see it. Also said of the sticky eyes of one who has just gotten up from sleep.

hawaiian_phrase: Makaʻu ka hana hewa i ka uka o Puna.
english_phrase: Wrongdoing is feared in the upland of Puna.
meaning_phrase: Wrongdoing in the upland of Puna brings the wrath of Pele.

hawaiian_phrase: Makaʻu ke kanaka i ka lehua.
english_phrase: Man is afraid of the lehua.
meaning_phrase: When going to the mountains one is warned not to pluck lehua blossoms lest it rain. Only when one is going out of the upland region is it permissible to pluck flowers. So the mountaingoer is said to fear the lehua.

hawaiian_phrase: Makaʻu wāwae.
english_phrase: Feared by the feet.
meaning_phrase: Said of excreta — unpleasant to step on.

hawaiian_phrase: Make auaneʻi i ka moana a pae kupapaʻu i Lānaʻi.
english_phrase: May probahly die at sea and his corpse wash ashore on Lānaʻi.
meaning_phrase: Refers to a person on a very hazardous venture.

hawaiian_phrase: Make iā Pipili.
english_phrase: Killed by Pipili.
meaning_phrase: Killed by Stick-around. So boasted Kamehameha I when he slew Kapakahili, a Maui chief, in the battle of Kawaʻanui. He stuck around and succeeded in eliminating a foe.

hawaiian_phrase: Makemake akula i ka uhu kāʻalo i ka maka.
english_phrase: There is a desire for the parrot-fish that passes the eyes.
meaning_phrase: Said when one desires a lass or lad who is passing by.

hawaiian_phrase: Make nō ke kalo a ola i ka naio.
english_phrase: The taro dies but lives again in the pinworm.
meaning_phrase: The matter may be thought dead, but it is likely to come alive again. Naio (pinworms) were sometimes found in poi and caused itching in the anal passage.

hawaiian_phrase: Make nō ke kalo a ola i ka palili.
english_phrase: The taro may die but lives on in the young plants that it produces.
meaning_phrase: One lives on in his children.

hawaiian_phrase: Make nō ʻo Pāmano i ka ʻiʻo ponoʻī.
english_phrase: It was a near relative who destroyed Pāmano.
meaning_phrase: Troubles often come from one’s nearest relatives. From the legend of Pāmano, a hero who met his death through his uncle, Waipū.

hawaiian_phrase: Make o Keawe a kū i ke kāʻai.
english_phrase: Keawe died and stood in the kāʻai.
meaning_phrase: The kāʻai is a plaited container for the bones of a deceased chief. The head was placed in an upper compartment and the bones of the body in the lower one, which was shaped like an armless, legless torso.

hawaiian_phrase: Make ʻo Keawe me kona kālele.
english_phrase: Keawe and the person he leaned upon are both dead.
meaning_phrase: Said to one who has a habit of depending on others. Keawe-i-kekahi-aliʻi-o-ka-moku was a noted chief of Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Make ʻo Mikololou a ola i ke alelo.
english_phrase: Mikololou died and lived again through his tongue.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who talks himself out of a predicament. Mikololou was a shark god of Maui destroyed by the shark goddess Kaʻahupāhau of Pearl Harbor for expressing a desire to eat a human being. He was drawn up to land where his flesh fell off and dried in the heat of the sun. One day some children found his tongue in the sand and played with it, tossing it back and forth. When it fell into the sea, the spirit of Mikololou possessed it and it became a living shark again.

hawaiian_phrase: Mākole iho hewa i Mākua.
english_phrase: Red-eyed one goes to Mākua by mistake.
meaning_phrase: Applied to one who has gone off his course. Once, a red-eyed person left Mokulēʻia, Oʻahu, intending to go to Mākaha, but went by way of Kawaihāpai and arrived at Mākua instead.

hawaiian_phrase: Mākole lā i Waolani.
english_phrase: The red-eyed ones at Waolani.
meaning_phrase: Waolani, Nuʻuanu, was said to have been the home of many defective people — the hunchbacked, the club-footed, the red-eyed, and so forth. To see such a person anywhere outside of Waolani was regarded as a sign of bad luck.

hawaiian_phrase: Ma Koʻolau e ʻōlelo ai, he lohe ma Kona.
english_phrase: Words spoken on the windward side are heard on the leeward side.
meaning_phrase: Said of anything spoken that travels very quickly through the land.

hawaiian_phrase: Makua keiki i ka poli.
english_phrase: The child in the heart has grown up to be a man.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who loved as a child and finds his love reawakened in manhood. First uttered by Lohiʻau, whose love reawakened upon meeting his old sweetheart, Peleʻula.

hawaiian_phrase: Ma lalo aku au o ko leo.
english_phrase: I will be under your voice.
meaning_phrase: I will obey you in all you command.

hawaiian_phrase: Mālama i ke kala ka iʻa hiʻu ʻoi.
english_phrase: Watch out for the kala, the fish with a sharp tail.
meaning_phrase: A warning to beware of a person who is well equipped to defend himself. The kala, a surgeonfish, has a spike near the caudal fin which it uses in defense.

hawaiian_phrase: Mālama o ʻike i ke kaula ʻili hau o Kailua.
english_phrase: Take care lest you feel the hau-bark rope of Kailua.
meaning_phrase: Take care lest you get hurt. When braided into a rounded rope, hau bark is strong, and when used as a switch it can be painful.

hawaiian_phrase: Mālama o kole ka lae.
english_phrase: Watch out lest the forehead be skinned.
meaning_phrase: Pay heed what you do lest you get hurt.

hawaiian_phrase: Malama o kū i ke aʻu, ka iʻa nuku loa o ke kai.
english_phrase: Take heed that you are not jabbed by the swordfish, the long-nosed fish of the sea.
meaning_phrase: Do not annoy that fellow, or you will suffer the consequences.

hawaiian_phrase: Mālama o pakū ke au.
english_phrase: Take care not to break the gall bladder.
meaning_phrase: Watch that you do not do anything to cause bitterness.

hawaiian_phrase: Mālama o pā ʻoe.
english_phrase: Be careful lest the result be disastrous to you.
meaning_phrase: Watch your step lest evil attach itself to you. A warning not to break a kapu.

hawaiian_phrase: Māla ʻuala.
english_phrase: Potato patch.
meaning_phrase: Said in annoyance by an oldster when another Hawaiian asks in English, “What’s the matter?” “Matter” sounds like “māla,” and the retort “Māla ʻuala" squelches any more questioning.

hawaiian_phrase: Mālia Hāna ke ahuwale nei Kaihuokala.
english_phrase: Hāna is calm, for Kaihuokala is clearly seen.
meaning_phrase: Kaihuokala is a hill on the Hāna side of Haleakalā. When no cloud rests upon it, it is a sign of clear weather. Also expressed Mālie Maui, ke waiho maila Kaihuokala.

hawaiian_phrase: Malia paha he iki unu, paʻa ka pōhaku nui ʻaʻole e kaʻa.
english_phrase: Perhaps it is the small stone that can keep the big rock from rolling down.
meaning_phrase: I am a small person who can accomplish much. When Lonoikamakahiki visited Kamalalawalu, ruling chief of Maui, he took along his half-brother Pupukea to serve him. Makakuikalani, half-brother and personal attendant of Kamalalawalu, made fun of the small stature of Pupukea. This saying was Pupukea’s retort.

hawaiian_phrase: Malō ka wai i ka lā.
english_phrase: The water dries up in the sun.
meaning_phrase: Joy withers in the presence of wrath.

hawaiian_phrase: Ma loko o ka hale, hoʻopuka ʻia ka pili, a ma waho o ka hale, he haku ia.
english_phrase: Inside of the house you may mention your relationship, but outside of the house your chief is your lord.
meaning_phrase: Those who served the chief in his home were usually loyal blood relatives. From childhood they were taught not to discuss the relationship with anyone outside of the household, and always to refer to their chief as Kuu haku (My lord), never by any relationship term. Only the chief could mention a relationship if he chose.

hawaiian_phrase: Malolo kai ē! Malolo kai!
english_phrase: Tide is not high! Tide is not high!
meaning_phrase: Said of threatening disaster. Robbers once lived at a place in Wai’anae now known as Malolo-kai. Their spies watched for travelers to kill and rob. When there were only a few that could be easily overcome, the spies cried, “Low tide!” which meant disaster for the travelers. But if there were too many to attack, the cry was “High tide!”

hawaiian_phrase: Maloʻo ka lani, wela ka honua.
english_phrase: When the sky is dry, the earth is parched.
meaning_phrase: I walked. The “double canoes” are one’s two feet and the “ten prows” are his toes.

hawaiian_phrase: Malu ke kula, ʻaʻohe keʻu pueo.
english_phrase: The plain is quiet; not even the hoot of an owl is heard.
meaning_phrase: All is at peace.

hawaiian_phrase: Ma luna mai nei au o ka waʻa kaulua, he ʻumi ihu.
english_phrase: I came on a double canoe with ten prows.
meaning_phrase: I walked. The “double canoes” are one’s two feet and the “ten prows” are his toes.

hawaiian_phrase: “Māmā Hilo?” “ʻAe, māmā Hilo i ka wai ʻole.”
english_phrase: “Is Hilo light?” “ Yes, Hilo is light for lack of water.”
meaning_phrase: A question asked of a runner, and his reply. It means that the way is clear, with no robbers or unpleasant experiences, and no rains to swell the streams and make traveling difficult.

hawaiian_phrase: "Māmaki" aku au, “hamaki” mai ʻoe. Pehea ka like?
english_phrase: I say “māmaki” and you say “hamaki.” How are they alike?
meaning_phrase: Once a Hawaiian had some tapa made of māmaki bark which he wished to trade with some white sailors. He did not speak English and they did not speak Hawaiian. He said, “He kapa māmaki kēia.” (“This is kapa made of māmaki.”) Although they did not know exactly what he said, they understood that his goods were for sale. They asked, “How much?” He thought they were asking what kind of tapa he had, so he answered, “Māmaki.” Again the sailors asked, “How much?” which sounded like “hamaki” to the Hawaiian. In exasperation he cried, “I say ʻmāmaki’ and you say ʻhamaki.’How are they alike?” This utterance came to apply to two people who absolutely cannot agree.

hawaiian_phrase: Māmā Kona i ka wai kau mai i ka maka o ka ʻōpua.
english_phrase: Kona is lightened in having water in the face of the clouds.
meaning_phrase: Kona is relieved, knowing that there will be no drought, when the clouds promise rain.

hawaiian_phrase: Mānā, i ka puʻe kalo hoʻoneʻeneʻe a ka wai.
english_phrase: Mānā, where the mounded taro moves in the water.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Mānā, Kauaʻi. In ancient days there were five patches at Kolo, Mānā, in which deep water mound-planting was done for taro. As the plants grew, the rootlets were allowed to spread undisturbed because they helped to hold the soil together. When the rainy season came, the whole area was flooded as far as Kalamaihiki, and it took weeks for the water to subside. The farmers built rafts of sticks and rushes, then dived into the water. They worked the bases of the taro mounds free and lifted them carefully, so as not to disturb the soil, to the rafts where they were secured. The weight of the mounds submerged the rafts but permitted the taro stalks to grow above water just as they did before the flood came. The rafts were tied together to form a large, floating field of taro.

hawaiian_phrase: Mānā kaha kua welawela.
english_phrase: Mānā where the back feels the heat [of the sun].
meaning_phrase: Refers to Mānā, Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Manaʻo pahaʻoe i kaʻeleʻele o kuʻu kuʻemaka he kauā au nāu?
english_phrase: Do you think that because my eyebrows are black I am your servant?
meaning_phrase: Said in annoyance by one who is asked to do distasteful work. Kauā were sometimes identifiable by the black tattoos on their foreheads.

hawaiian_phrase: Manene ka pepeiao.
english_phrase: The ears have an unpleasant sensation.
meaning_phrase: Said when someone uses vulgar and obscene language — the ears are offended.

hawaiian_phrase: Mānoa aliʻi, Mānoa kānaka.
english_phrase: Mānoa of the chiefs, Mānoa of the commoners.
meaning_phrase: In ancient days an invisible line was drawn from the center of the low, green hill, Puʻu Luahine, at the head of Mānoa Valley, to the center of Rocky Hill back of Punahou School. Looking up into the valley, Mānoa of the commoners was on the right side. Here lived the commoners and here too, the excreta of the chiefs was secretly buried by the kahu moka (protector and keeper of the excreta). This was an important position, for if any of the excreta fell into the hands of an enemy, the chief might die through sorcery. On the left side of the valley lived the chiefs and their retainers.

hawaiian_phrase: Mānuʻunuʻu wale kini o Honokōhau.
english_phrase: Multitudinous are the inhabitants of Honokōhau.
meaning_phrase: Said of the people of Honokōhau, Maui, who were known for having big families.

hawaiian_phrase: Ma ʻō, ma ʻō ka uahi; mākole, mākole ma ʻaneʻi.
english_phrase: Yonder, yonder the smoke; here, over here, the infamed eyes.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who takes a part against another and after winning, comes around to express friendship and sympathy.

hawaiian_phrase: Mao ʻole ke kai o Mokupaoa.
english_phrase: Endlessly rough is the sea of Mokupaoa.
meaning_phrase: Endless bad luck. Mokupaoa means “Island of Misfortune.”

hawaiian_phrase: Maui a Kama.
english_phrase: Maui, island of Kama.
meaning_phrase: Kamalalawalu was a ruling chief of Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Maui nō ka ʻoi.
english_phrase: Maui excels.
meaning_phrase: From the song of this title by the Reverend Samuel Kapū.

hawaiian_phrase: Maui poʻo hakahaka.
english_phrase: Maui the empty headed.
meaning_phrase: The people of Maui were said to lack intelligence. This saying originally referred to the empty skulls of defeated Maui warriors.

hawaiian_phrase: Mauliʻawa ke aho.
english_phrase: The breath hiccoughed.
meaning_phrase: He gasped his last.

hawaiian_phrase: Mauna Kea, kuahiwi kū haʻo i ka mālie.
english_phrase: Mauna Kea, standing alone in the calm.
meaning_phrase: The din of shouting is heard again and again. Also, the noise keeps flowing like rushing water.

hawaiian_phrase: Mauna Loa kīkala nui.
english_phrase: Big-sterned Mauna Loa.
meaning_phrase: The Mauna Loa was a ship that plied between the islands. This expression is applied in derision to a woman who is large in the rear. Also expressed, Mauna Loa kīkala ʻūpehupehu: Swollen-sterned Mauna Loa.

hawaiian_phrase: Maunu ʻekaʻeka.
english_phrase: Dirty bait.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person whose personality does not attract, as inferior bait fails to attract fish.

hawaiian_phrase: Maunu paiʻea.
english_phrase: Bait of paiʻea crab.
meaning_phrase: Angry words coming out of the mouth. When a fisherman went out to sea he sometimes chewed crabs and spewed them into the water to attract fish.

hawaiian_phrase: Meʻe uʻi o Hanalei.
english_phrase: The handsome hero of Hanalei.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is attractive.

hawaiian_phrase: Mehameha wale nō ʻo Puʻuloa, i ka hele a Kaʻahupāhau.
english_phrase: Puuloa hecame lonely when Kaʻahupāhau went away.
meaning_phrase: The home is lonely when a loved one has gone. Kaʻahupāhau, guardian shark of Puʻuloa (Pearl Harbor), was dearly loved by the people.

hawaiian_phrase: Me he lau nō ke Koʻolau ke aloha.
english_phrase: Love is like the ends [fingertips] of the Koʻolau breeze.
meaning_phrase: Love is like a zephyr — gentle and invisible but present nevertheless.

hawaiian_phrase: Me he makamaka lā ka ua no Kona, ke hele lā a kipa i Hanakahi.
english_phrase: The rain is like a friend from Kona — it goes and calls on Hanakahi.
meaning_phrase: These are two lines from an old chant used to express a friendly visit with one who dwells in a distant place.

hawaiian_phrase: Me he makani hulilua lā, huli ka manaʻo, hele ka noʻonoʻo.
english_phrase: Like the wind that blows one way and then blows another, so does the mind turn and the thoughts depart.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who makes a promise and then forgets all about it.

hawaiian_phrase: Miki ka ʻīlio kahu ʻole no ka hemahema.
english_phrase: Stray dogs will take what one neglects to care for.
meaning_phrase: When one is careless with his possessions, they may be stolen.

hawaiian_phrase: Mimiki ke kai, ahuwale ka papa leho.
english_phrase: When the sea draws out in the tidal wave, the rocks where the cowries hide are exposed.
meaning_phrase: Secrets will out on the day of wrath.

hawaiian_phrase: Minamina ka leo o ke aliʻi i ka hāʻule i ka pūweuweu.
english_phrase: A pity to allow the words of the chief to fall among the clumps of grass.
meaning_phrase: A reminder to heed the commands and wishes of one’s chief.

hawaiian_phrase: Moʻa aʻela nō kā ka ʻalae huapī.
english_phrase: The red-headed mudhen has finished cooking her own.
meaning_phrase: Said of a selfish person who does only for himself with no regard for others. A play on pī (stingy) in huapī. From the legend of Māui.

hawaiian_phrase: Moʻa i kapuahi a Uli.
english_phrase: Cooked in Uli’s fireplace.
meaning_phrase: Destroyed by sorcery.

hawaiian_phrase: Moa kākala ʻole.
english_phrase: A spurless cock.
meaning_phrase: A weakling.

hawaiian_phrase: Moa kani ao.
english_phrase: A chicken that cackles in the daytime.
meaning_phrase: A woman who talks all day.

hawaiian_phrase: Moa kani hewa.
english_phrase: A cock that crows too soon.
meaning_phrase: One who speaks out of turn.

hawaiian_phrase: Moʻa nopu ka lā i ke kula o Hoʻolehua.
english_phrase: The sun scorches the plain of Hoʻolehua.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Hoʻolehua, Molokaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Moʻa nopu o ke kau.
english_phrase: Summer’s first parched product.
meaning_phrase: The first sweet potato of the summer or the first from one’s field.

hawaiian_phrase: Moe i ka lau o ka lihilihi.
english_phrase: The sleep on the tip of the eyelashes.
meaning_phrase: A very light sleep.

hawaiian_phrase: Moe i ka moe kapu o Niolopua.
english_phrase: Asleep in the sacred sleep of Niolopua.
meaning_phrase: Dead. Niolopua is the god of sleep.

hawaiian_phrase: Moe i ka moe kau a hoʻoilo.
english_phrase: Asleep with the sleep that lasts through summers and winters.
meaning_phrase: Dead.

hawaiian_phrase: Moe i kauwawe.
english_phrase: The sleep under the leaf covering of an imu.
meaning_phrase: Death, compared to an imu that was covered and never opened again.

hawaiian_phrase: Moe kokolo ka uahi o Kula, he Hau.
english_phrase: The smoke of Kula traveled low and swift, borne by the Hau wind.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is swift in movement. Also, in love and war much depends on swiftness and subtlety.

hawaiian_phrase: Moe kūpuna i ka mamo, a puka hou mai nō nā mamo.
english_phrase: Ancestors slept with descendants, and more descendants were born.
meaning_phrase: Said when a girl mates with a supernatural lover in a dream and later bears him a child. The lover might be a family ʻaumakua, hence the reference to an ancestor.

hawaiian_phrase: Moe lāpuʻu i ke anu o Puʻupā.
english_phrase: Sleep curled up in the cold of Puʻupā.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who sleeps with legs drawn up, as with cold. Also said in derision about one who likes to sleep.

hawaiian_phrase: Moe loa ka wahine, nānā wale ke kāne.
english_phrase: When a wife oversleeps, the husband just looks about.
meaning_phrase: A lazy wife is no help to her husband.

hawaiian_phrase: Moe loa ke kāne, nānā wale ka wahine.
english_phrase: When the husband sleeps too much, the wife just looks about.
meaning_phrase: A lazy husband does not help his wife.

hawaiian_phrase: Moena hāunu ʻole o ka nahele.
english_phrase: Mat of the forest to which no strips are added in making.
meaning_phrase: Said of a bed made of fern, banana, or other leaves of the forest — one needs no strips of lauhala or other material to make a mat.

hawaiian_phrase: Moena pāwehe o Niʻihau.
english_phrase: Patterned mat of Niʻihau.
meaning_phrase: Poetic expression often used in reference to Niʻihau. Fine makaloa mats of Niʻihau, beautifully patterned, were famed throughout the islands.

hawaiian_phrase: Moe poʻo a hiʻu i Kalaeʻoiʻo.
english_phrase: Lies head and tail at Kalaeʻoiʻo.
meaning_phrase: Is up to the neck in trouble. Processions of ghosts were sometimes encountered here. If one had a relative among them, he escaped death; if not, he perished.

hawaiian_phrase: Mōhala i ka wai ka maka o ka pua.
english_phrase: Unfolded by the water are the faces of the flowers.
meaning_phrase: Flowers thrive where there is water, as thriving people are found where living conditions are good.

hawaiian_phrase: Mōhala ka pua, ua wehe kaiao.
english_phrase: The blossoms are opening, for dawn is breaking.
meaning_phrase: One looks forward with joy to a happy event.

hawaiian_phrase: Mōhala maikaʻi ke oho o ke kupukupu.
english_phrase: Unfolded well are the fronds of the ferns.
meaning_phrase: Said of a handsome person.

hawaiian_phrase: Mohio lū ʻopeʻope.
english_phrase: Gale that scatters bundles.
meaning_phrase: Said of an untidy person who scatters his possessions around.

hawaiian_phrase: Mō ka piko.
english_phrase: Cut is the umbilical cord.
meaning_phrase: A friendly relation between closely related persons has been severed. To dream of an injury to one’s piko is an omen of the death of a close relative.

hawaiian_phrase: Mō ke kī lā — make!
english_phrase: Cut is the kī — it is death!
meaning_phrase: Used in riddling contests of old, when persons who failed to guess correctly were often tortured or put to death. A wicked Puna chief once invented a riddle that no one could solve: He kī e, he kī e, mō ke kī — make! (It is the kī, it is the kī, [when it is] cut [there is] death!) The answer? The parts of the body whose names include the word kī, such as kīkala (hip) and kihi poʻohiwi (shoulder). Many people tried and failed to guess the answer and so were put to death. Finally, an old woman took pity on a youthful contestant and secretly told him the solution. In addition she told the youth about an additional kī that the chief himself had forgotten. On the day of his contest, the youth answered the chief’s riddle. Then he challenged the chief with the same riddle. A dispute arose when the chief denied that there were any other body parts with kī. The youth pointed to the chief’s fingernails (mikiʻao) and was declared the winner. The wicked chief was put to death as he had put others to death.

hawaiian_phrase: Mokihana onaona o Maunahina, lei hoʻohihi a ka malihini.
english_phrase: The fragrant mokihana berries of Maunahina, lei in which visitors delight.
meaning_phrase: Maunahina is a mountain on Kauaʻi, where the mokihana berries grow best.

hawaiian_phrase: Moku holo honua.
english_phrase: A land-sailing ship.
meaning_phrase: Any animal used for transportation.

hawaiian_phrase: Moku i ka ʻohe a Kahaʻi.
english_phrase: Cut off by the bamboo knife of Kahaʻi.
meaning_phrase: Said of any complete severing. Kahaʻi was a chief who traveled afar. He is credited with introducing the first breadfruit plant to the islands.

hawaiian_phrase: Moku ka huelo o Kalahumoku lā!
english_phrase: Bitten off was the tail of Kalahumoku!
meaning_phrase: Said when one starts a fight and then gets beaten. Kalahumoku was a supernatural dog from Kahiki who became the friend of ʻAiwohikupua, chief of Kauaʻi. He was taken by the latter to Hawaiʻi to fight the lizard guardian of Paliuli and to destroy ʻAiwohikupua’s sisters, who resided there. The girls had been deserted by the chief when they did not win for him the woman he wanted to wed. The lizard won the battle and the dog returned to his friend with his ears chewed up and part of his tail bitten off.

hawaiian_phrase: Moku ka ihu iā Hio lā!
english_phrase: Bitten off is the nose by Hio!
meaning_phrase: Used by adults to frighten children into staying at home. Hio was an akua (ghost) who wandered about peering into the doors of homes and biting off the noses of those who annoyed him. He escaped when his companions were caught in a fishnet set by the super-natural hero Kamiki at Kuʻunaakeakua (Net-let-down-for-akua), Makalawena, Kona.

hawaiian_phrase: Moku ka pepeiao, na ke aliʻi ia puaʻa.
english_phrase: When the ear is cut, it is a sign that the pig belongs to the chief.
meaning_phrase: The ears of certain pigs were cut to show that they were the property of the chief.

hawaiian_phrase: Molale loa nō kumu pali o Kalalau.
english_phrase: Clearly seen is the base of Kalalau cliff.
meaning_phrase: It is obvious that one is way off the subject. A play on lalau (to wander, err).

hawaiian_phrase: Molokaʻi ʻāina o ka ʻehaʻeha.
english_phrase: Molokaʻi, island of distress.
meaning_phrase: This expression came about after the establishment of the leper colony there. It refers to the separation of loved ones, the ravages of the disease, and the sad life in the early days at Kalawao, when so much was lacking for the comfort of the patients.

hawaiian_phrase: Molokaʻi koʻo lāʻau.
english_phrase: Molokaʻi of the canoe-poler.
meaning_phrase: The reef at the southern shore of Molokaʻi extends out as far as one-half mile in some places. At low tide the water is no more than eight feet deep. Because it is so shallow, the people could propel their canoes with poles.

hawaiian_phrase: Molokaʻi kuʻi lāʻau.
english_phrase: Molokai, pounder of medicine.
meaning_phrase: The kāhuna of Molokaʻi were said to be experts in compounding medicines and poisonous potions. Also, a stick dance bore this name.

hawaiian_phrase: Molokaʻi nui a Hina.
english_phrase: Great Molokaʻi, land of Hina.
meaning_phrase: The goddess Hina is said to be the mother of Molokaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Molokaʻi pule oʻo.
english_phrase: Molokaʻi of the potent prayers.
meaning_phrase: Molokaʻi is noted for its sorcery, which can heal or destroy.

hawaiian_phrase: Mū ka waha heahea ʻole.
english_phrase: Silent is the mouth of the inhospitable.
meaning_phrase: It is considered rude not to call a welcome (heahea) to anyone approaching one’s home.

hawaiian_phrase: Muʻu mōkākī ka lau lāʻau, he makani kā.
english_phrase: The leaves lie strewn about in a pelting gale.
meaning_phrase: The remnants of a violent burst of temper.

hawaiian_phrase: Muʻumuʻu hōkake ipu kai.
english_phrase: One-armed fellow who messes up his meat dish.
meaning_phrase: An expression of ridicule for a person who has lost a hand or is without hands or fingers. He messes up his dish in his attempt to pick up the food. Also said in humor of anyone who is clumsy with his hands.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā ʻale āpiʻipiʻi o nā kai ʻewalu.
english_phrase: The rising billows of the eight seas.
meaning_phrase: The “eight seas” are the channels between the islands.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā ʻale hānupanupa o Pailolo.
english_phrase: The choppy billows of Pailolo.
meaning_phrase: Pailolo is the channel between Oʻahu and Molokaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā ʻale kua loloa o Kaʻieʻie.
english_phrase: The long-backed billows of Kaʻieʻie.
meaning_phrase: Kaʻieʻie is the channel between Kauaʻi and Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā ʻale kuehu o Māmala.
english_phrase: The billows of Māmala with wind-blown sprays.
meaning_phrase: Māmala is the entrance to Honolulu Harbor.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā aliʻi mai ka pō mai.
english_phrase: Chiefs from the night.
meaning_phrase: Chiefs whose ancestors were chiefs in remote antiquity and were recognized by the gods.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā aliʻi o ke kuamoʻo o Hāloa.
english_phrase: Chiefs of the lineage of Hāloa.
meaning_phrase: Said of high chiefs whose lineage goes back to ancient times — to Hāloa, son of Wākea. Wākea mated with Hoʻohokukalani and had two sons, both named Hāloa. The older Hāloa was born a taro, the younger one a man. It was this younger brother that the high chiefs name with pride as their ancestor.

hawaiian_phrase: Naʻaupō wale o Kāneiahuea.
english_phrase: Ignorant indeed is Kāneiahuea.
meaning_phrase: A Nāpoʻopoʻo, Hawaiʻi, saying for one who blunders on without using his head.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā ʻeʻepa o Waolani.
english_phrase: The ʻeʻepa of Waolani.
meaning_phrase: Waolani, Nuʻuanu, was the home of legendary beings like the Nāmū (Silent ones), the Nāwā (Loud ones), menehune, and akua. This saying applies to anyone whose ways are incomprehensible.

hawaiian_phrase: Nae iki ʻĪao i ka uhiwai.
english_phrase: Īao is barely breathing in the heavy mist.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is in dire distress, with trouble pressing on all sides.

hawaiian_phrase: Nahā ka huewai a ua kahe ka wai.
english_phrase: The gourd water-bottle is broken and the water has run out.
meaning_phrase: The body is dead; life has fled.

hawaiian_phrase: Nahā ka mākāhā, lele ka ʻupena.
english_phrase: When the sluice gate breaks, the fishnets are lowered.
meaning_phrase: One’s loss may be another’s gain.

hawaiian_phrase: Nahā ke kanaka, ka hale o ke aloha.
english_phrase: Broken is man, the house of love.
meaning_phrase: One is grieved by the death of a beloved.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā hala o Kekele.
english_phrase: The hala grove of Kekele.
meaning_phrase: This grove, famous for the variety and fragrance of its hala, was found at the foot of Nuʻuanu Pali. Some people declare that although the hala trees have been cut down for many years, they can still smell the fragrance in the breeze as they pass at night.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā hala o Naue ʻau i ke kai.
english_phrase: The hala of Naue swim out to sea.
meaning_phrase: The hala trees of Naue, Kauaʻi, seem to reach out to sea. This expression is used in songs and chants.

hawaiian_phrase: Nahā nā ʻōmaka wai a ka lihilihi.
english_phrase: Broken are the water-holders of the eyelashes.
meaning_phrase: Tears spill.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā hana pōʻalo maka.
english_phrase: Eye-scooping deeds.
meaning_phrase: Acts of treachery toward those who have shown kindness.

hawaiian_phrase: Nāhiku hauwalaʻau.
english_phrase: Much loud-talk Nāhiku.
meaning_phrase: Said of loud-voiced people. Refers to Nāhiku, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Nāhiku kōʻalaʻala ʻole.
english_phrase: [A man of] Nāhiku quickly departed, taking nothing with him.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who has left too abruptly.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā hoa ʻaka o ke one hāuli o ka malama.
english_phrase: Laughing friends — when the sands look dark in the moonlight.
meaning_phrase: Said of friends who will laugh and play in the moonlight but who will not lend a hand when daylight and labor come.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā hono a Piʻilani.
english_phrase: The bays of Piʻilani.
meaning_phrase: The realm of Piʻilani, a powerful ruling chief of Maui, included the islands of Molokaʻi and Lānaʻi, as well as all the bays of Maui whose names begin with hono.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā honu neʻe o Polihua.
english_phrase: The moving turtles of Polihua.
meaning_phrase: Polihua is a place on Lānaʻi where turtles come to lay their eggs.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā ʻilina wai ʻole o Kohala.
english_phrase: The waterless plains of Kohala, where water will not remain long.
meaning_phrase: After a downpour, the people look even in the hollows of rocks for the precious water.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā ʻili puakea o Maleka.
english_phrase: The white-blossom skin of Maleka.
meaning_phrase: Said of fair-skinned Americans.

hawaiian_phrase: Naio ʻai kae.
english_phrase: Dung-eating pinworm.
meaning_phrase: An expression of contempt for one who slanders, especially his own kin.

hawaiian_phrase: Na kahi ka malo, na kahi e hume.
english_phrase: The loincloth of one, the other can wear.
meaning_phrase: A close relationship. As a general rule, Hawaiians would not wear the clothing of people other than blood relatives. In explaining genealogy to a young relative, this conveyed the idea that a relationship was near enough to warrant the wearing of each other’s clothing.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā kai ʻewalu.
english_phrase: The eight seas.
meaning_phrase: The “seas” that divide the eight inhabited islands.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā kai haele lua o Kalae, o Kāwili lāua o Halaʻea.
english_phrase: The two sea currents of Kalae — Kāwili and Halaʻea.
meaning_phrase: The Halaʻea current, named for an evil chief who was swept away, comes from the east to Kalae and sweeps out to sea. The Kāwili (Hit-and-twist) comes from the west and flows out alongside the Halaʻea. Woe betide anyone caught between.

hawaiian_phrase: Na ka ʻīlio ka nānā pono.
english_phrase: Only dogs stare.
meaning_phrase: Said to a person who stares.

hawaiian_phrase: Nakaka ka puaʻa, nahā ka waʻa; aukahi ka puaʻa mānalo ka waʻa.
english_phrase: The pig cracks, the canoe breaks; perfect the pig, safe the canoe.
meaning_phrase: Whenever a new canoe was launched, a pig was baked as an offering to the gods. If the skin of the roasted pig cracked, misfortune would come to the canoe; but if it cooked to perfection the canoe would last a long time.

hawaiian_phrase: Na ka makua e komo i ka ʻāwelu o keiki, ʻaʻole na ke keiki e komo i ka ʻāwelu o ka makua.
english_phrase: Let the parent wear out his children s old clothes, but do not let the children wear their parent’s old clothes.
meaning_phrase: Some Hawaiians would wear the partly worn clothing of their children. However, wearing the old clothing of one’s parents was kapu.

hawaiian_phrase: Na kamaliʻi ka ʻū lua.
english_phrase: It is a child that grunts twice.
meaning_phrase: Said of a child too young to understand. When asked if he has eaten, he grunts “yes,” and when asked if he is hungry he again grunts “yes.”

hawaiian_phrase: Na ka mikimiki mua nō ka loaʻa.
english_phrase: The first on the spot is the one who receives.
meaning_phrase: The Hawaiian equivalent of “First come, first served.” Also expressed as Na ka ʻoiʻoi mua ka loaʻa.

hawaiian_phrase: Na ka mua, na ka muli.
english_phrase: Belonging to the older, belonging to the younger.
meaning_phrase: An explanation of the parentage of cousins.

hawaiian_phrase: Na ka puaʻa e ʻai; a na ka puaʻa ana paha e ʻai.
english_phrase: [It is] for the pigs to eat; and perhaps the pigs will taste [you].
meaning_phrase: A reminder to be hospitable to strangers. From the following story: A missionary and two Hawaiian companions arrived hungry and tired in Keonepoko, Puna, after walking a long distance. Seeing some natives removing cooked breadfruit from an imu, they asked if they could have some. “No,” said the natives, “it is for the pigs to eat.” So the visitors moved on. Not long after, leprosy broke out among the people of Puna. The first to contract it were taken to Oʻahu and later sent on to Kalaupapa. Others died at home and were buried. When the last ones fmally died, there was no one to bury them, and the pigs feasted on their bodies. Thus, justice was served.

hawaiian_phrase: Na ka pupuka ka lili.
english_phrase: Jealousy belongs to the ugly.
meaning_phrase: This kukui grove, in Makawao, Maui, was much visited by travelers, for it was a favorite spot of the chiefs. The nuts gathered from the trees produced a fragrant, tasty relish.

hawaiian_phrase: Na ke akua ʻoe e ʻike.
english_phrase: May the god see you.
meaning_phrase: An ʻānai (to rub hard) curse that someone meet with dire trouble sent him by the gods. To alleviate this, one replies quickly, if he remembers to, “Me ʻoe nō kāuʻ (“Let your words remain with you”) or “Hoʻi nō kāu ʻōlelo maluna ou” (“May your words go back on you”). This turning back of a curse is called hoʻihoʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā keiki a Kālaihaohia.
english_phrase: The children of Kālaihaohia.
meaning_phrase: Greedy people. A play on kālai (hew) and haohia (grab-all-one-can).

hawaiian_phrase: Nā keiki huelo loloa o ka ʻĀina Pua.
english_phrase: The long-tailed sons of the Flowery Kingdom.
meaning_phrase: The Chinese, who once wore queues.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā keiki o Waipouli me Honomaʻele.
english_phrase: Children of Waipouii and Honomaʻele.
meaning_phrase: A humorous reference to very dark people. A play on pouli (dark) in Waipouli and ʻele (black) in Honomaʻele.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā keiki uneune māmane o Kula.
english_phrase: The lads of Kula, who tug and pull the māmane up by the roots.
meaning_phrase: An expression of admiration for the people of Kula, Maui, who accomplish whatever they set out to do.

hawaiian_phrase: Na ke kanaka mahiʻai ka imu ō nui.
english_phrase: The well-filled imu belongs to the man who tills the soil.
meaning_phrase: As long as there are potatoes, even small or broken ones, a farmer gets along.

hawaiian_phrase: Nakeke ka ua i ka lau o ka niu.
english_phrase: Rain patters on the coconut leaves.
meaning_phrase: Said of idle talk.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā kōhi kelekele a Kapuʻukolu.
english_phrase: The rich foods of the Triple Hills.
meaning_phrase: Kapuʻukolu is on Kauaʻi, an island known for its abundance. This saying describes any abundance of delicious food.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā kuʻi a Meheʻula.
english_phrase: The blows of Meheʻula.
meaning_phrase: Meheʻula was a war leader of Kalaniōpuʻu who, when defeated, would run away and return later. This saying is applied to one who runs away and returns later to resume the fight.

hawaiian_phrase: Naku liʻi.
english_phrase: Little wallower.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who grovels and kowtows.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā kūmau palapaʻa o Naʻalehu, ʻo ia mau nō ka pāpaʻa.
english_phrase: The thick-walled calabashes of Naʻalehu are always crusted [with dried poi].
meaning_phrase: A Kaʻū saying — the thick-headed natives of Naʻalehu are strict adherents to principles.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā kupa heʻe ʻĀhiu i ka laʻi o Kahana.
english_phrase: The native sons who surf in the ʻĀhiu wind in the peaceful land of Kahana.
meaning_phrase: Said in admiration of a native of Kahana, Oʻahu. In the days when Hiʻiaka traveled to Kahana as a woman, surfing was done there only by the chiefs. The ʻĀhiu is a well known wind of Kahana.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā lā ʻae ʻo ia.
english_phrase: The days that were days indeed.
meaning_phrase: The days of youth, prosperity, and strength.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā lā e lana ana ke koko.
english_phrase: The days when the blood circulates freely.
meaning_phrase: Youth.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā laʻi a Ehu.
english_phrase: The calm regions of Ehu.
meaning_phrase: The districts of Kona, Hawaiʻi, where Ehunuikaumanamana once ruled. Also, an epithet for Kalākaua, taken from a name chant.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā lālā kapu a Lono.
english_phrase: The sacred branches of Lono.
meaning_phrase: Refers to the various branches of the chiefly families directly descended from the god Lonoikamakahiki.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā lehua o Līhau i pehia e ka noe.
english_phrase: The lehua blossoms oj Līhau, weighted by the mist.
meaning_phrase: Līhau, a mountain of Maui, was noted for its beautiful lehua blossoms.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā lehua o Luluʻupali.
english_phrase: The lehua blossoms of Luluʻupali.
meaning_phrase: Famed in songs of Kauaʻi were the lehua blossoms of Luluʻupali.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā lehua o Mokaulele.
english_phrase: The lehua blossoms of Mokaulele.
meaning_phrase: The lehua blossoms of Mokaulele, Hilo, are famed in legends and chants.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā lehua puakea o Ninauapo.
english_phrase: The white lehua blossoms of Ninauapo.
meaning_phrase: White lehua blossoms flourished at Ninauapo in Mānoa, Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā lihilihi o Āwihikalani.
english_phrase: The eyelashes of Blinking-lord.
meaning_phrase: Sleep.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā līpoa ʻala o Kawehewehe.
english_phrase: The fragrant līpoa of Kawehewehe.
meaning_phrase: The līpoa seaweed of Waikikī, especially at Kawehewehe, was so fragrant that one could smell it while standing on the shore. Often mentioned in songs about Waikīkī.

hawaiian_phrase: Nalowale i ke ʻehu o ke kai.
english_phrase: Lost in the sea sprays.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who disappears from sight to avoid coming in contact with others, like a canoe that speeds away and raises sprays so that it can’t be seen.

hawaiian_phrase: Nalowale nā maka, hūnā i ke ao uli.
english_phrase: The face is out of sight, hidden in the sky.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is dead.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā makani paio lua o Kawaihae.
english_phrase: The two conflicting winds of Kawaihae.
meaning_phrase: Refers to the Mumuku wind from the uplands and the Naulu wind, which brings the rains to Kawaihae.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā maka o ka makani.
english_phrase: Eyes of the wind.
meaning_phrase: Clouds, which show the direction of the wind.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā mamo a ke kipi.
english_phrase: Descendants of rebels.
meaning_phrase: Said of the people of Kaʻū, who rebelled against oppression.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā mamo i ka halo o Kūa.
english_phrase: The descendants of the gill fins of Kūa.
meaning_phrase: The people of Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi, are related to Kūa, the great shark god and protector of that district, by descent from his human sister.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā mamo pihaʻā i kai o Kaʻaluʻalu.
english_phrase: The driftwood descendants at the sea of Kaʻaluʻalu.
meaning_phrase: Said of the innumerable children of large families, who are like the driftwood that litters the beach of Kaʻaluʻalu, Kaʻū.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā mamo ʻuī waiū o Waikakalaua.
english_phrase: Children of the cow-milkers of Waikakalaua.
meaning_phrase: The Portuguese. At one time there were many Portuguese working in a dairy at Waikakalaua, Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā manu leo nui o Panaʻewa.
english_phrase: Loud-voiced birds of Panaʻewa.
meaning_phrase: Loud talkers. Panaʻewa, Hilo, was famous for its lehua forests that sheltered the honey-sucking birds. Here people went to gather lehua and maile.

hawaiian_phrase: Nāna i waele mua i ke ala, ma hope aku mākou, nā pōkiʻi.
english_phrase: He [or she] first cleared the path and then we younger ones followed.
meaning_phrase: Said with affection and respect for the oldest sibling (hiapo).

hawaiian_phrase: Nanā ka leo o ke kai o Hoʻohila.
english_phrase: Surly is the voice of the sea of Hoʻ ohila.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who speaks harshly.

hawaiian_phrase: Nānā ka maka; hana ka lima.
english_phrase: Observe with the eyes; work with the hands.
meaning_phrase: Just watching isn’t enough. Pitch in and help!

hawaiian_phrase: Nānā ka maka; hoʻolohe ka pepeiao; paʻa ka waha.
english_phrase: Observe with the eyes; listen with the ears; shut the mouth.
meaning_phrase: Thus one learns.

hawaiian_phrase: Nānā keʻe ka iʻa i ka maunu ʻekaʻeka.
english_phrase: The fish look askance at dirty bait.
meaning_phrase: A person that is not to be trifled with. The ʻalaihi have spiny fins that can pierce the hands.

hawaiian_phrase: Nānā nō a ka lāʻau kū hoʻokahi.
english_phrase: Look for the plant that stands alone.
meaning_phrase: Often said by those seeking strong medicinal herbs. A plant that stood by itself was considered better for medicine than one that grew close to others of its kind.

hawaiian_phrase: Nānā nō a ka ʻulu i pakī kēpau.
english_phrase: Look for the gummy breadfruit.
meaning_phrase: Advice to a young girl — Look for a man who has substance, like gummy breadfruit, which is a sign of maturity.

hawaiian_phrase: Nani i ka hala ka ʻōiwi o Kahuku.
english_phrase: The body of Kahuku is beautifed by hala trees.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Kahuku, Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: Nani Kaʻala, he kiʻowai na ke kēhau.
english_phrase: Beautiful Kaʻala, a pool that holds the dew.
meaning_phrase: Praise of Mt. Kaʻala, on Oʻahu, a depository for the dew.

hawaiian_phrase: Nani ka ʻike a ka heʻe i nā wahi leho liʻiliʻi.
english_phrase: It is wonderful how the octopus notices the little cowries.
meaning_phrase: Said sarcastically of a man who looks at young girls with lust.

hawaiian_phrase: Nani ka ʻōiwi o ka lāʻau i ka luaiele ʻia e ka makani.
english_phrase: Beautiful is the body of the tree, even when swayed this way and that by the wind.
meaning_phrase: Even through adversities and dissipation some people remain handsome.

hawaiian_phrase: Nani ka waiho a Kohala i ka laʻi.
english_phrase: Beautiful lies Kohala in the calm.
meaning_phrase: An expression of admiration for Kohala, Hawaiʻi, or for a person with poise and charm — especially a native of that district.

hawaiian_phrase: Nani Lēʻahi, he maka no Kahiki.
english_phrase: Beautiful Lēʻahi, object of the eyes from Kahiki.
meaning_phrase: Diamond Head, always observed with interest by visitors from foreign lands.

hawaiian_phrase: Nani Puna pō i ke ʻala.
english_phrase: Beautiful Puna, heavy with fragrance.
meaning_phrase: Praise for Puna, Hawaiʻi, where the breath of maile, lehua, and hala blossoms are ever present.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā niu kulakulaʻi a nā aliʻi ʻai moku.
english_phrase: The coconut trees pushed over by the ruling chiefs.
meaning_phrase: Said by Pupukea, a chief of Kaʻū, of Makakuikalani, chief of Maui, in an exchange of insults. Later commonly used to refer to weaklings.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā niu moe o Kalapana.
english_phrase: The reclining coconut trees of Kalapana.
meaning_phrase: In ancient times it was a custom in Kalapana, Puna, to force a young coconut tree to grow in a reclining position in commemoration of a chiefly visit. The last two such trees were made to bow to Chiefess Ululani and Queen Emma. On one of Queen Emma’s visits to Puna, she was asked to participate in a commemoration. While mounted on a horse, she held a single coconut leaf growing from a tree, while the people pulled and strained until the tree was bent. Then the tree was fastened down so that it would grow in a reclining position. These trees are mentioned in chants and songs of Puna.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā niu ulu aoʻa o Mokuola.
english_phrase: The tall, slim coconut trees of Mokuola.
meaning_phrase: Mokuola (now called Coconut Island) in Hilo, is a place where pandanus and coconut trees were numerous.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā ʻOle ka pō, ʻo nā ʻOle ke ao, he ʻole ka loaʻa.
english_phrase: The nights are ʻOle, the days are ʻOle — nothing to be gotten.
meaning_phrase: The tide is high in the ʻOle period and no fish are caught.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā pahu kapu a Laʻamaikahiki, ʻŌpuku lāua ʻo Hāwea.
english_phrase: The sacred drums of Laʻamaikahiki — ʻŌpuku and Hāwea.
meaning_phrase: These were the drums brought by Laʻamaikahiki from the South Sea.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā pali alo lua o Waipiʻo.
english_phrase: Cliffs of Waipiʻo that face each other.
meaning_phrase: Said of Waipiʻo, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā pali hāuliuli o ke Koʻolau.
english_phrase: The dark hills of Koʻolau.
meaning_phrase: The hills and cliffs of the windward side of O’ahu are always dark and beautiful with trees and shrubs.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā pali kinikini o Kahakuloa.
english_phrase: The multitudinous cliffs of Kahakuloa.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Kahakuloa, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Nāpelepele nā pali o Kalalau i ka wili a ka makani.
english_phrase: Weakened are the cliffs of Kalalau in being buffeted by the wind.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is worn out.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā poʻe o ka pō.
english_phrase: People of the night.
meaning_phrase: An epithet applied to unseen gods who help their devotees.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā pōhaku kālai a ʻUmi.
english_phrase: The hewn stones of ʻUmi.
meaning_phrase: The girls in the household of ʻUmi, chief of Hawaiʻi, were well cared for; but, like stones, they did not go freely from place to place.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā puʻe ʻuala hoʻouai.
english_phrase: Movable mounds of sweet potato.
meaning_phrase: It was the custom of Pūlaʻa, Puna, Hawaiʻi, to remove the best mounds of sweet potato, earth and all, to wide strips of thick, coarse lauhala mats stretched out on racks. When a chief came on a visit, these mats were placed on the right-hand side of the road and made kapu. Should he return, the mat-grown potato field was carried to the opposite side of the road so that it would still be on the right of the traveling chief.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā puʻe ʻuala ʻīnaʻi o ke ala loa.
english_phrase: The sweet-potato mounds that provide for a long journey.
meaning_phrase: Said of a patch of sweet potatoes whose crops are reserved for a voyage or journey.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā puʻu haelelua, o Pili me Kalāhikiola.
english_phrase: The hills that go together — Pili and Kalāhikiola.
meaning_phrase: These two hills that stand together are often mentioned in chants and legends of Kohala.

hawaiian_phrase: Naueue ka hiʻu o ka iʻa lewa i ke kai.
english_phrase: The tails of thefish that move in the sea tremble.
meaning_phrase: Said of fish, such as the hīnālea, in the cold month Welehu. The tails of the hīnālea bend as they seek hollows in the corals for hiding.

hawaiian_phrase: Nāu ke keiki, kūkae a naʻau.
english_phrase: Yours is the child, excreta, intestines and all.
meaning_phrase: In giving a child to adoptive parents, the true parents warned that under no condition would they take the child back. To do so would be disastrous for the child. Recognition, love, and help might continue; but removal while the adoptive parents live — never.

hawaiian_phrase: Nau ke kuʻi, lohi ka lima.
english_phrase: When one grinds the teeth, the hand slows.
meaning_phrase: Anger makes one slow in working.

hawaiian_phrase: Naʻu ke poʻo o ka iʻa.
english_phrase: Keep the head of the fish for me.
meaning_phrase: Used to annoy a man on his way to fishing. It was believed that such a request would give him no catch at all.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā ʻulu hua i ka hapapa.
english_phrase: The breadfruit that bears on the ground.
meaning_phrase: Breadfruit trees of Niʻihau were grown in sinkholes. The trunks were not visible, and the branches seemed to spread along the ground. These trees are famed in chants of Niʻihau.

hawaiian_phrase: Nau nā kuʻi o ka niho o ka lā.
english_phrase: The teeth of the sun gnash.
meaning_phrase: Said of a very warm day in which the heat is almost unbearable.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā wāhine kiaʻi alanui o Nuʻuanu.
english_phrase: The women who guard the Nuʻuanu trail.
meaning_phrase: Hapuʻu and Kalaʻihauola were supernatural women whose stone forms guarded the Nuʻuanu trail near the gap. It was around Kalaʻihauola that the umbilical cords of babies were hidden to ensure their good health. When the new road over the Nuʻuanu Pali was made, these stones were destroyed.

hawaiian_phrase: Nā wai ʻehā.
english_phrase: The four wai.
meaning_phrase: A poetic term for these places on Maui: Wailuku, Waiehu, Waiheʻe, Waikapū, each of which has a flowing water (wai).

hawaiian_phrase: Na wai hoʻi ka ʻole o ke akamai, he alanui i maʻa i ka hele ʻia e oʻu mau mākua?
english_phrase: Why shouldnʻt I know, when it is a road often traveled by my parents ?
meaning_phrase: Reply of Liholiho when someone praised his wisdom.

hawaiian_phrase: Na wai ke kupu ʻo ʻoe?
english_phrase: Whose sprout are you ?
meaning_phrase: Whose child are you? Also expressed Na wai ke kama ʻo ʻoe?

hawaiian_phrase: Nā waimaka o ka lani.
english_phrase: The tears of heaven.
meaning_phrase: Rain at someone’s death or during his funeral is declared to be the affectionate tears of the gods, who weep in sympathy with the mourners.

hawaiian_phrase: Nāwele ka maka o Hinauluʻōhiʻa.
english_phrase: Pale is the face of Hinauluʻōhiʻa.
meaning_phrase: Said of the pink rim around the blossom end of the white mountain apple. Refers to the goddess Hina.

hawaiian_phrase: Neʻe aku, neʻe mai ke one o Punahoa.
english_phrase: That way and this way shifts the sand of Punahoa.
meaning_phrase: Said of a group that divides, or of an undecided person who shifts one way and then another.

hawaiian_phrase: Neʻe papa ka helu a ka lā i Punahoa.
english_phrase: The sun continued to scorch at Punahoa.
meaning_phrase: The fight didn’t end quickly.

hawaiian_phrase: Nei ka honua, he ōlaʻi ia.
english_phrase: When the earth trembles, it is an earthquake.
meaning_phrase: We know what it is by what it does.

hawaiian_phrase: Nele i ka mea poepoe, nele ka pilina mai.
english_phrase: Lacking the round object, no one stays around.
meaning_phrase: When one lacks round dollars to spend, companions disappear.

hawaiian_phrase: Nēnē ʻau kai.
english_phrase: A seagull.
meaning_phrase: A ship, which is compared to a white bird over the sea.

hawaiian_phrase: Niau kololani ka helena, hūnā nā maka i ke aouli.
english_phrase: Silently, quickly he departed, to hide his eyes in the sky.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who has died suddenly.

hawaiian_phrase: Nihoa i ka moku manu.
english_phrase: Nihoa, island of birds.
meaning_phrase: This saying compares people to the scallops on lace. When all are in harmony, they are attractive and interesting. But when they are not, they are like lace with scallops of all sizes and shapes.

hawaiian_phrase: Niʻihau a Kahelelani.
english_phrase: Niʻihau, land of Kahelelani.
