meaning_phrase: Kahelelani was the name of an ancient ruler of the island of Niʻihau. The tiny seashell that is made into the finest lei on the island now bears the name of Kahelelani.

hawaiian_phrase: Niʻihau i ka uhi paheʻe.
english_phrase: Niʻihau of the slippery yam.
meaning_phrase: The island of Niʻihau was noted for its fine yams. When grated raw for medicine, yams are very slippery and tenacious.

hawaiian_phrase: Niʻihau i ke kīkū.
english_phrase: Niʻihau leans back firmly.
meaning_phrase: Niʻihau people are independent.

hawaiian_phrase: Niniu Molokaʻi, poahi Lānaʻi.
english_phrase: Molokaʻi revolves, Lānaʻi sways.
meaning_phrase: A description of the revolving of the hips and the swaying movements in hula.

hawaiian_phrase: Niniu Puna, pō i ke ʻala.
english_phrase: Puna is dizzy with fragrance.
meaning_phrase: Puna is a land heavily scented with the blossoms of hala and lehua.

hawaiian_phrase: Niu maka o nōlaʻelaʻe.
english_phrase: Green coconuts for a clear vision.
meaning_phrase: In ancient days the water of young coconuts (niu hiwa a Kāne) was used by priests in divination.

hawaiian_phrase: Noʻeau ka hana a ka ua; akamai ka ʻimina o ka noʻonoʻo.
english_phrase: Clever are the deeds of the rain; wise in seeking knowledge.
meaning_phrase: Said in admiration of a clever person.

hawaiian_phrase: Noenoe ke aloha o Kānehoa.
english_phrase: Misty is the love of Kānehoa.
meaning_phrase: Said of a friend who departs peevishly. A play on hoa (friend) in the name Kānehoa.

hawaiian_phrase: No Hanamāʻulu ka ipu puehu.
english_phrase: The quickly emptied container belongs to Hanamāʻulu.
meaning_phrase: Said of the stingy people of Hanamāʻulu, Kauaʻi — no hospitality there. At one time, food containers would be hidden away and the people of Hanamāʻulu would apologize for having so little to offer their guests.

hawaiian_phrase: No Hilina paha, ke huikau ala ka ʻōlelo.
english_phrase: Perhaps he was born in Hilina — his speech is confused.
meaning_phrase: A play on hili (confusion). Hilina is the month of winds.

hawaiian_phrase: Noho i ka hohonu me he iʻa lā.
english_phrase: Remains in deep water, like a fish.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who won’t associate with others.

hawaiian_phrase: Noho i ke puhi.
english_phrase: Sits in the blowhole.
meaning_phrase: Jailed. One who falls into a blowhole rarely escapes.

hawaiian_phrase: Noho kāpae.
english_phrase: Riding sidesaddle.
meaning_phrase: Living together out of wedlock.

hawaiian_phrase: Noho ke koaʻe i ka lua.
english_phrase: The tropic bird remains in the hole.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who does not express his opinion.

hawaiian_phrase: Noho maialile ka ua o Hilo, ʻelua wale no māua.
english_phrase: Keep your silence, O rain of Hilo, there are only two of us.
meaning_phrase: Uttered by Kanuha in retort when rebuked by the Reverend Titus Coan for Sabbath-breaking: “Hold your silence, for there are only two of us in authority” — meaning Kanuha and Governor Kuakini. Rev. Coan was not to give orders when either was present. Now it is used to mean, “Keep quiet. You’re not the boss around here.”

hawaiian_phrase: Noho nā makani a Kāne, lawe i ke ō.
english_phrase: When the winds of Kāne blow, carry your food along.
meaning_phrase: When one doesn’t know what to expect, it is better to be prepared. On windy days, fruits fall and vegetable crops are lashed and beaten.

hawaiian_phrase: Noho nō ke kanaka a ka lā mālie, kau ka ipu hōkeo a ka lawaiʻa, nānā ana i ka ʻōpua.
english_phrase: A person waits for a clear day, sets up the gourd that holds the fishermans paraphernalia, and observes the clouds.
meaning_phrase: To a fisherman, a clear day, his tools, and the signs and omens seen in the clouds are important.

hawaiian_phrase: Noho pū i ka uahi pōhina.
english_phrase: Sat together in the gray smoke.
meaning_phrase: Said of a teacher and pupils who sat about a smoky fire at night.

hawaiian_phrase: No Kaʻaluʻalu nō lā hoʻi kūpuna.
english_phrase: Naturally, when the ancestors hailed from Kaʻalualu.
meaning_phrase: A play on ʻalualu (baggy or loose-fitting). Said of any person whose clothes do not fit properly or whose bundles are not secure. Kaʻaluʻalu is a place in Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: No Kaʻaona, ke ona ia ala.
english_phrase: [He was born] in Kaʻaona, for he attracts.
meaning_phrase: A play on ona (to attract). Children born in the month of Kaʻaona are said to be attractive to others, even when their features are very plain.

hawaiian_phrase: No kahi ka pilikia, pau a pau.
english_phrase: When one is in trouble, all [give aid].
meaning_phrase: Serious trouble indeed.

hawaiian_phrase: No kai heʻe ʻoe.
english_phrase: You belong to the sea where octopus is found.
meaning_phrase: You are a liar! A play on heʻe (octopus) which is part of wahaheʻe (falsehood).

hawaiian_phrase: No Kaipāpaʻu, paha?
english_phrase: From Kaipāpaʻu, perhaps?
meaning_phrase: A play on the name Kaipāpaʻu (Shallow-sea). He must be from Kaipāpaʻu, for he appears to be shallow-minded.

hawaiian_phrase: No Kalae nō lā hoʻi ke keiki.
english_phrase: The lad is from Kalae after all.
meaning_phrase: A boast: “He is a smart lad.” A play on lae (forehead). Refers to Kalae, Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: No ka noho ʻāina ka ʻāina.
english_phrase: The land belongs to the one dwelling on it.
meaning_phrase: Land was given to people by the chiefs. Should members of the family go elsewhere, the one who dwelled on the land was considered the owner. A returning family member was always welcome, but the one who tilled the soil was recognized as holding the ownership.

hawaiian_phrase: No ke ʻehu kakahiaka.
english_phrase: BeIongs to the early morning hours.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is not well versed.

hawaiian_phrase: No Kūkiʻi ke kanaka.
english_phrase: The person hails from Kūkiʻi.
meaning_phrase: A play on kū (stand) and kiʻi (image). Said of a lazy person who is as inactive as a wooden image.

hawaiian_phrase: No Kula ia poʻe ke hoe hewa nei.
english_phrase: To Kula belong the people who are such poor paddlers.
meaning_phrase: Kula, Maui, people are ignorant. Also, never mind the talk of fools.

hawaiian_phrase: No Miloliʻi akula paha, ke lōliʻi ala.
english_phrase: Perhaps [he] is from Miloliʻi, to be so relaxed.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who takes it easy. A play on lōliʻi (carefree) in Milo-liʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Nona ka malo, naʻu e hume; noʻu ka malo, nāna e hume.
english_phrase: His loincloth I could wear; my loincloth he could wear.
meaning_phrase: Said of very close kin.

hawaiian_phrase: Nona ka ʻūmiʻi lauwili i ka pākaʻawili.
english_phrase: His is the tie that is twisted and entangled into one that holds fast.
meaning_phrase: His ancestors have intermarried and re-intermarried to preserve the bloodline of his family. He is therefore of a very high and kapu rank.

hawaiian_phrase: No nehinei aʻe nei nō; he aha ka ʻike?
english_phrase: [He] just arrived yesterday; what does he hnow?
meaning_phrase: Gone to get nehu for bait. Gone to get her man; that is, gone to get the bait that will get him.

hawaiian_phrase: No Pelekunu mai paha?
english_phrase: From Pelekunu, perhaps?
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is not clean. A play on pelekunu (musty odor). Refers to Pelekunu, Molokaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Noʻu o luna, noʻu o lalo, noʻu o uka, noʻu o kai, noʻu nā wahi a pau.
english_phrase: Above, below, the upland, the lowland are mine; everywhere is mine.
meaning_phrase: Said by Kamehameha III to encourage his lover Kalama to come to him. She need not fear the wrath of Kaʻahumanu for he, Kamehameha, was the master everywhere.

hawaiian_phrase: Nui ka ʻai ma ke kuahiwi, puʻu nō ka ʻai, ʻiʻo no ka iʻa.
english_phrase: There is much food in the mountain; puʻu is food and ʻiʻo is meat.
meaning_phrase: This was said by the Reverend David Lyman, a missionary, in 1857 when his pupils went with him to the mountain and complained of having no food for the journey — there was an abundance of hāpuʻu and hōʻiʻo ferns in the mountains.

hawaiian_phrase: Nui ka hanu o Limahuli i nā lehua o Luluʻupali.
english_phrase: Heavily-sighed Limahuli falls over the lehua blossoms of Luluupali.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person in love who sighs over a sweetheart.

hawaiian_phrase: Nui kalakalai, manumanu ka loaʻa.
english_phrase: Too much whittling leaves only a little wood.
meaning_phrase: Said of nasty words that start dissension and argument. A play on kalakala (rough) and kala loa (very rough). First uttered by the lizard-goddess Kilioe, who was trying to stir Pele to wrath by her insults.

hawaiian_phrase: Nui pū maiʻa ʻolohaka o loko.
english_phrase: Large banana stalk, all pith inside.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person with a large physique but with no strength to match it.

hawaiian_phrase: Nuku ʻouʻou.
english_phrase: Jutting beak.
meaning_phrase: Applied to one who spreads malicious gossip.

hawaiian_phrase: Nūnū lawe leka o Kahului.
english_phrase: Letter-carrying pigeon of Kahului.
meaning_phrase: In 1893 carrier pigeons arrived at Kahului, Maui. One was brought to Honolulu and released with a letter tied to its neck. It flew back to Kahului. This was of such great interest to the people that a song was written and a quilt design made to commemorate the event.

hawaiian_phrase: Oʻahu a Lua.
english_phrase: Oʻahu, island of Lua.
meaning_phrase: According to an old legend, Lua is the father of Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: Oʻahu, ka ʻōnohi o nā kai.
english_phrase: Oʻahu, gem of the seas.
meaning_phrase: Oʻahu is the principal island of the group.

hawaiian_phrase: Oʻahu maka ʻewaʻewa.
english_phrase: Oʻahu of the averted eyes.
meaning_phrase: This saying began with Hiʻiaka, who asked two of her kinsmen on Oʻahu for a canoe to take her to Kauaʻi. They gave her a broken one, which she and her companion mended with no help from the men. In disgust, she called them Oʻahu maka ʻewaʻewa. After that, Oʻahu was said to have the least friendly people of all the islands.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ʻAlelele ke kawa kaulana o Makawao.
english_phrase: ʻAlelele, the famous diving pool of Makawao.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Makawao, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ʻAwili ka nalu, he nalu kapu kai na ke akua.
english_phrase: ʻAwili is the surf, a surf reserved for the ceremonial bath of the goddess.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Pele. There were three noted surfs at Kalapana, Puna: Kalehua, for children and those just learning to surf; Hoʻeu, for experienced surfers; and ʻAwili, which none dared to ride. When the surf of ʻAwili was rolling dangerously high, all surfing and canoeing ceased, for that was a sign that the gods were riding.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ʻEwa, ʻāina kai ʻula i ka lepo.
english_phrase: ʻEwa, land of the sea reddened by earth.
meaning_phrase: ʻEwa was once noted for being dusty, and its sea was reddened by mud in time of rain.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOhai o Papiohuli.
english_phrase: The ʻōhai of Papiohuli.
meaning_phrase: At Papiohuli, Mānā, Kauaʻi, grew the ʻōhai trees that bore red or whitish blossoms. These trees grew in profusion in olden days but are now rare. The blossoms made beautiful lei.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Hāna ia, he ʻāina au pehu.
english_phrase: That is Hāna, land where lack was known.
meaning_phrase: All husbands have some good qualities.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌhao ʻīlio.
english_phrase: Dog tied by the neck.
meaning_phrase: An expression of contempt for the kauā. While waiting to be taken to the heiau to be sacrificed, a kauā was compelled to wear a small gourd suspended from the neck with a cord.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOhi aku ka pō a koe kēia.
english_phrase: The night has taken all but this one.
meaning_phrase: All are dead; this is the only survivor.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌhiʻa noho malu.
english_phrase: Mountain apple in the shade.
meaning_phrase: Said of a beautiful or handsome person, who is compared to a mountain apple that ripens to perfection in the shade.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOhi hāpuku ka iʻa o Kapaʻau.
english_phrase: Any kind of fish was gathered at Kapaʻau.
meaning_phrase: At time of famine no one was particular about the kind of fish he received.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOhi hāpuku ka makapehu o Kaunu.
english_phrase: The hungry of Kaunu greedily gather.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who greedily takes anything, good or inferior. Also said of one who talks carelessly without regard for the feelings of others.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOhi hāpuku ka wahie o Kapaʻau.
english_phrase: Anything was gathered up as fuel at Kapaʻau.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who takes anything and everything. At one time Kohala suffered a drought and food became scarce. The women did their best to raise food at ʻAinakea while the men traveled far in search of some means of relieving the famine. In order to cook their meager, inferior crops, the women used whatever they found for fuel — dried sugar-cane leaves, grasses, potatoes, and so forth.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOhi ka manu o ke ao.
english_phrase: The bird of the day reaps its reward.
meaning_phrase: Said in praise of one’s industry whereby he has gained prosperity. “The bird of the day” refers to the industrious ʻuwaʻu that flies daily to the sea for its food.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Hikapoloa ka makuakāne, o Lanihūpō ka makuahine.
english_phrase: Hikapoloa was the father and Lanihūpō the mother.
meaning_phrase: Said of an utterly stupid person. A play on the names of the father (Stagger-in-the-dark) and the mother (Stupid chief).

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Hikapoloa ka pō, he pō kiʻikiʻi, he pō naʻanaʻa.
english_phrase: Hikapoloa is the night — a leaning night, a stretching night.
meaning_phrase: A play on ka pō loa (the long night). Said when one waits wearily for the night to pass, when there is nothing to do to shorten the hours.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Hinaiaʻeleʻele ka malama, ʻāluka ka pala a ka ʻōhiʻa.
english_phrase: Hinaiaʻeleʻele is the month when the mountain apples open everywhere.
meaning_phrase: Applied to a person with a sour disposition. The ʻamakihi is a Hawaiian honeycreeper.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Hinaiaʻeleʻele ka malama, ʻeleʻele ka umauma o ke kōlea.
english_phrase: Hinaiaʻeleʻele is the month in which the breast feathers of the plovers darken.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who talks too much — all noise and no sense. The ʻelepī is a small black crab that makes a loud noise resembling a smacking sound made by the mouth.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Hinaiaʻeleʻele ke kāne, ʻo Pōʻeleʻi ka wahine, hānau ke keiki, he keiki ʻakena a haʻanui.
english_phrase: Hinaiaʻeleʻele is the husband, Pōʻeleʻi (Supreme-dark-one) the wife; a child born to them is a boaster and an exaggerator.
meaning_phrase: Said of a child born in the month of Hinaiaʻeleʻele.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOhi wale ka iʻa a Palapala.
english_phrase: Palapala merely takes the fish.
meaning_phrase: Said when a person who does nothing profits from the labor of others. Palapala was a lazy fellow who did no fishing himself but knew the ancient rule about fish caught in a net: when a net full of fish was drawn ashore, no one — child or adult — was rebuked when he picked out a fish for himself. Nobody minded that Palapala often took fish, but his boast ʻOhi wale ka iʻa a Palapala annoyed them.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOho kū kai.
english_phrase: Hair immersed in sea water.
meaning_phrase: Said of fishermen who spend much time plying their trade — their hair is often wet from sea sprays.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Honoliʻi, huewai ʻolāʻolā i ka nuku.
english_phrase: Honoliʻi, where the water bottle gurgles at the mouth.
meaning_phrase: Said of those of Honoliʻi, Hilo, by Hiʻiaka. In ancient days, expert sorcerers there who prayed others to death muttered prayers that sounded like the gurgling of a water bottle.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Honuʻapo aku nō ia ʻo kahi o ka ʻahuʻawa.
english_phrase: That is Honuapo where the ʻahuʻawa grows.
meaning_phrase: A Kaʻū saying about disappointment. The ʻahuawa was much used as fiber for straining ʻawa. A play on hoka (to strain, to be disappointed).

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO huaʻole ka lā, ʻo nakaka ka lā, ʻo ʻōmilu ka lā, ʻo pōnalo ka lā.
english_phrase: Fruitless is the day, cracked is the day, puny is the day, blighted is the day.
meaning_phrase: Said of a day that brings no luck to the worker.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌhua palemo.
english_phrase: Slippery ʻōhua.
meaning_phrase: A term for uhu spawn. When applied to a person it means a slick, clever fellow who gets away with mischief.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌhule ke poʻo i niania.
english_phrase: Bald of head and smooth.
meaning_phrase: Said of a bald-headed man.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOhuʻohu Halemano i ka lau lehua.
english_phrase: Bedecked is Halemano with lehua leaves.
meaning_phrase: An expression of admiration for a good-looking person.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOhuʻohu Punaluʻu i Ka-wai-hū-o-Kauila.
english_phrase: Punaluʻu is adorned by the rushing water of Kauila.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Punaluʻu, Kaʻū.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOiai e nānā mai ana nō nā maka.
english_phrase: While the eyes still look around.
meaning_phrase: While a person is living, treat him kindly and learn what you can from him.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ia kona maʻi he ake pau.
english_phrase: His disease is tuberculosis.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who is too eager to finish his work. A play on ake pau (eager to finish), the Hawaiian term for tuberculosis (literally “consumed lung”).

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ia lā he koa no ke ʻano ahiahi; ʻo ia nei no ke ʻano kakahiaka.
english_phrase: He is a warrior of the evening hours; but this person here is of the morning hours.
meaning_phrase: That person has had his day and is no longer as active as before; but this person is strong, brave, and ready to show his prowess.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ia mau nō i ke alo pali.
english_phrase: Ever the same before the face of the cliff.
meaning_phrase: Just the same as ever.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ia mau nō nā ēwe a Kamaunuaniho.
english_phrase: The descendants of Kamaunuaniho are ever the same.
meaning_phrase: A play on niho (teeth) in the name Kamaunuaniho. Said of a nasty person.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOi hoʻi he hana hāʻawe o kaumaha.
english_phrase: It isn’t work to carry this heavy burden on the back. It’s no trouble at all.
meaning_phrase: A warning not to wear out one’s welcome.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOi ka niho o ka lā i Kūmanomano.
english_phrase: Sharp are the teeth of the sun at Kūmanomano.
meaning_phrase: A very hot place is Kūmanomano. A play on manomano (much).

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOi kau ka lā, e hana i ola honua.
english_phrase: While the sun yet shines do all you can.
meaning_phrase: While there is earthly life (ola honua), do all you can.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Ikiiki ke kāne, ʻo Hoʻopaupaualio ka wahine, hānau ke keiki, he keiki huhū koke.
english_phrase: Ikiiki is the husband, Hoʻopaupauaho (Cause-shortness-of-breath) is the wife; a child born to them is short of temper.
meaning_phrase: Said of a child born in the month of Ikiiki.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ʻIkuwā i pohā kōʻeleʻele, ʻikuwā ke kai, ʻikuwā ka hekili, ʻikuwā ka manu.
english_phrase: ʻIkuwā is the month when the dark storms arise, the sea roars, the thunder roars, the birds make a din.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Helani, Kona, Hawaiʻi. Here a coconut grove thrived, and from a small opening in the shell of the nut one could get water to drink.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ʻIkuwā ke kāne, ʻo Paʻiakuli ka wahine, hānau ke keiki, he leo nui.
english_phrase: ʻIkuwā is the husband, Paʻia-kuli (Deafening-noise) is the wife; a child born to them is loud of voice.
meaning_phrase: Said of a child born in the month of ʻIkuwā.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌʻili pulelo ke ahi o Kāmaile.
english_phrase: The fire of Kāmaile rises in triumph.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is victorious over obstacles, this is the first line of a chant composed for Kamehameha II. In olden days, firebrands hurled from the cliffʻs at Hāʻena, Kauaʻi, made a spectacular sight.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOiʻoi ʻo Maui Hikina.
english_phrase: East Maui forges ahead.
meaning_phrase: Those of East Maui are said to be very active and able to withstand anything.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka ʻaʻama holo pali pōhaku, e paʻa ana ia i ka ʻahele pulu niu.
english_phrase: The crab that runs about on a rocky cliff will surely be caught with a snare of coconut fibers.
meaning_phrase: He who goes where he tempts trouble is bound to suffer.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka ʻai no ka ʻai, ʻo ka ʻiʻo kanaka ka iʻa.
english_phrase: Food is here to be eaten, with only human flesh for meat.
meaning_phrase: Said when there is nothing to eat with poi. There were once two boys of Kaʻū who won a riddling contest against a Kona man, the champion of the island of Hawaiʻi. In one riddle the boys claimed to be eating human flesh. The audience pondered this, since no meat was visible, and began to dispute the claim. Suddenly the boys popped wads of poi into their mouths and proceeded to lick their fingers — the “human flesh.”

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Kaʻaona ka pua i ka uahi o ka hoʻoilo, a ulu māhiehie.
english_phrase: In Kaʻaona [is used] the dart that has rested in the smoke during the rainy months until it acquires beauty.
meaning_phrase: Said of the month Kaʻaona, when the young people bring out their darts for games. These darts had reddened in the smoke of the fireplaces during the wet months. With rubbing and polishing they acquired a beautiful sheen.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Kaʻaōna ke kāne, ʻo Laʻioeoe ka wahine, hānau ke keiki, he keiki leʻa i ke oli.
english_phrase: Kaʻaōna is the husband, Laʻi-oeoe (Calm-prolonged-sound) the wife; a child born to them is a pleasing chanter.
meaning_phrase: A child born in the month of Kaʻaōna is blessed with a pleasant voice for speaking and chanting.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka ʻaui aku nō koe o ka lā.
english_phrase: The sun will soon go down.
meaning_phrase: Said of an aged person.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Kāʻelo ka malama, kāpule ke kōlea.
english_phrase: Kāʻelo is the month when the breasts of the plovers darken.
meaning_phrase: This is the month when the plovers are fat and ready to fly on their migration to the north.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Kāʻelo ka malama, pulu ke aho a ka lawaiʻa.
english_phrase: Kāʻelo is the month when the fisherman’s lines are wet.
meaning_phrase: Kāʻelo was a good time to do deep-sea fishing.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Kāʻelo ke kāne, Pulukāʻelo ka wahine, hānau mai keiki kāpulu.
english_phrase: Kāʻelo is the husband, Pulu-kāʻelo (Well-drenched) the wife; children born to them are filthy.
meaning_phrase: Said of a filthy person. A play on ʻelo (soak). The month of Kāʻelo is rainy and muddy.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka hale e kū, ʻo ke kanaka e noho.
english_phrase: Where a house stands, there man dwells.
meaning_phrase: Said of a lucky person. It was believed that certain people’s bones brought them luck in fishing. When they died their bones were sought for the making of fishhooks.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka hana ia a ka lawaiʻa iwi paoa, iho nō ka makau, piʻi nō ka iʻa.
english_phrase: That is the way of a fisherman with lucky bones — down goes his hook, up comes a fish.
meaning_phrase: Said of a lucky person. It was believed that certain people’s bones brought them luck in fishing. When they died their bones were sought for the making of fishhooks.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka hāʻule nehe o ka lau lāʻau, he hāwanawana ia i ka poʻe ola.
english_phrase: The rustling of falling leaves is like a whisper to the living.
meaning_phrase: It is the living who appreciate such things.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka hua o ke kōlea aia i Kahiki.
english_phrase: The egg of the plover is laid in a foreign land.
meaning_phrase: The plover’s egg was never seen in Hawaiʻi. Said of a subject that no one knows anything about, or of something far away and impossible to reach.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka huhiā ʻino ka mea e ola ʻole ai.
english_phrase: Rage is a thing that does not produce life.
meaning_phrase: Said of lightning and thunder.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka iʻa i kū kona waha i ka makau ʻaʻole ia e ʻapo hou ia mea.
english_phrase: The fish whose mouth has heen pierced by a hook will never again take another.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who avoids trouble after once being hurt.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌkaʻi ka ʻeʻa, ʻōkaʻi huakaʻi ʻula.
english_phrase: A moving cloud of dust; a reddish procession.
meaning_phrase: A great cloud of dust moving along warns of the advance of warriors.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka iki hāwaʻe ihola nō ia o Miloliʻi.
english_phrase: Here is the little sea urchin of Miloliʻi.
meaning_phrase: A boast. I am small but potent.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka ʻīlio i paoa ka waha i ka hua moa ʻaʻole e pau ia hana iā ia.
english_phrase: A dog whose mouth likes the taste of eggs will not stop taking them.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who cannot be cured of a bad habit.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka ʻīlio kahu nō ka ʻīlio hae.
english_phrase: The dog who has a master is the dog who barks the most.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who resents any disparaging remarks about his chief.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka lāʻau i hina, ʻaʻole ia e kū hou.
english_phrase: A fallen tree does not rise again.
meaning_phrase: Said of an old man who has lost his sexual potency.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka lāʻau o ke kula e noho ana i ka ʻāina, ʻo ka lāʻau o ka ʻāina e nalowale aku ana.
english_phrase: The trees of the plains will dwell on the land; the trees of the native land will vanish.
meaning_phrase: A prophecy uttered by Kalaunuiohua. Trees from the plains of other lands will grow here and our native trees will become extinct.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌkala ka hulu o Hilo i ka wai.
english_phrase: The fur of Hilo bristles in the water.
meaning_phrase: Sexual passion is rising.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌkalakala heu pānini, ke piʻi nei koʻu maneʻo.
english_phrase: It is unpleasant here with fine cactus spines; I am beginning to itch.
meaning_phrase: A taunt when someone loses his temper.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌkalakala nā hulu ʻauwae.
english_phrase: The hairs on his chin bristle.
meaning_phrase: Said of an angry person who raves and rants.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka lā ko luna, o ka pāhoehoe ko lalo.
english_phrase: The sun above, the smooth lava below.
meaning_phrase: Said of a journey in which the traveler suffers the heat of the sun above and the reflected heat from the lava bed helow.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Kalani ka ʻio o Lelepā, ka ʻālapa piʻi moʻo o Kū.
english_phrase: The heavenly one is the hawk of Lelepā, the warrior descendant of Kū.
meaning_phrase: Retort of a kahu when he overheard someone criticize his chief, Kamehameha, who was then only a young warrior. He used the name Lele-pā to imply that his chief could fly over any barrier.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka lani kēlā, ʻo ka lani kēia.
english_phrase: That one a chief this one a chief.
meaning_phrase: Said of two persons well matched for a contest.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka liʻiliʻi pāʻā kōkea ia Kohala, e kole ai ko nuku.
english_phrase: It is the little white sugar stalk of Kohala that makes your mouth raw.
meaning_phrase: Said by Pupukea when Makakuikalani made fun of his small size. The fine, hair-like growth on stalks of sugar cane can cause irritation.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka līlā maiʻa ia o ka ʻeʻa, ʻaʻole e pala i ke anahulu.
english_phrase: A tall banana in a mountain patch whose fruit does not open in ten days.
meaning_phrase: A boast of his own height by Makakuikalani, chief of Maui, when Pupukea of Hawaiʻi made fun of his being so tall and thin.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka makani ke ala o ka ʻino.
english_phrase: Wind is the source of storms.
meaning_phrase: The wind drives the rain clouds that bring torrents and floods.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka makapō wale nō ka mea hāpapa i ka pōuli.
english_phrase: ʻOnly the blind grope in darkness.
meaning_phrase: Said to one who gropes around instead of going directly to the object he is seeking.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka makua ke koʻo o ka hale e paʻa ai.
english_phrase: The parent is the support that holds the household together.
meaning_phrase: A weak leader.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka manu ma luna, ʻo ia ma lalo.
english_phrase: The birds above, he below.
meaning_phrase: Said in admiration of one who travels with great speed — he equals the birds that fly in the sky.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka maoli maiʻa ʻono ia o ka ʻeʻa.
english_phrase: The tastiest banana of the patch.
meaning_phrase: The finest, most attractive lad of the community.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka mea makaʻala ʻaʻohe lilo kona waiwai i ka ʻīlio.
english_phrase: He who watches does not lose his property to dogs.
meaning_phrase: ʻOne who watches his possessions will not lose them to thieves.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka mea ua hala, ua hala ia.
english_phrase: What is gone is gone.
meaning_phrase: There is no use in recalling hurts of the past.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka mea ukuhi kai ʻike i ka lepo o ka wai; o ka mea inu ʻaʻole ʻo ia i ʻike.
english_phrase: He who dips knows how dirty the water is, but he who drinks does not.
meaning_phrase: He who does the work knows what trouble it takes; he who receives does not.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka mūheʻe ka iʻa holo lua.
english_phrase: The cuttlefish is the sea creature that travels two ways.
meaning_phrase: Said of a two-faced person.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka ʻOle ia, mai ʻOlekukāhi a ʻOlekupau.
english_phrase: It is the ʻOle nights from ʻOlekukāhi to ʻOlekupau.
meaning_phrase: No. Absolutely not. A play on ʻole (nothing). ʻOlekukāhi, ʻOlekulua, ʻOlekukolu and ʻOlekupau are moon phases in the lunar month.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka pā ʻai a ka iʻa, kuhi ka lima, leʻa ka hāʻawi.
english_phrase: With a pearl fishhook that the fish grasps, one can point with the hand and give with pleasure.
meaning_phrase: A good fishhook brings in enough food for the family and to give to relatives and friends.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka papa heʻe nalu kēia, paheʻe i ka nalu haʻi o Makaiwa.
english_phrase: This is the surfboard that will glide on the rolling surf of Makaiwa.
meaning_phrase: A woman’s boast. Her beautiful body is like the surf board on which her mate “glides over the rolling surf.”

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka piʻi nō ia a Kōkī-o-Wailau.
english_phrase: Ascended to the topmost part of Wailau.
meaning_phrase: An expression of admiration for one who reaches the top in spite of difficulties. Kōkī-o-Wailau is a peak on Molokaʻi whose sides are steep and difficult to ascend.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka poʻe e ʻai ana i ka loaʻa o ka ʻāina he lohe ʻōlelo wale aʻe nō i ka ua o Hawaiʻi.
english_phrase: Those who eat of the product of the land merely hear of the rains in Hawaiʻi.
meaning_phrase: Said of absentee royal landlords who reap the gain but know nothing of the difficulties in the land where the toilers work.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka poʻe hulilau ʻole o hope.
english_phrase: Those with no large gourd calabashes in the back.
meaning_phrase: Those with no wives at home.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka pono ke hana ʻia a iho mai nā lani.
english_phrase: Continue to do good until the heavens come down to you.
meaning_phrase: Blessings come to those who persist in doing good.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka pono o kahi aliʻi o ka mikimiki me ka ʻeleu.
english_phrase: The thing to do at the court of the chief is to do work and do it effciently.
meaning_phrase: Those who serve their chiefs must do their work quickly and well.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO kapuahi aku ia a Uli.
english_phrase: That is Uli’s fireplace.
meaning_phrase: That is a place where a sorcerer may burn a personal possession of his chosen victim. Uli was a god to whom a sorcerer might appeal. This is a warning to watch out lest one run into sorcery.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Kauaʻi nui moku lehua, ʻāina nui makekau.
english_phrase: Great Kauaʻi, isle of warriors and land of men ever on the defense.
meaning_phrase: Oʻahu was once inhabited by supernatural beings who ate people. They would extend their hospitality by day, but at night they would eat their sleeping guests. A canoe came from Kauaʻi one day, and among the passengers was a man who was distrustful of the Oahuans. When the other men went to sleep, he dug a hole under the wall, crept into it, pulled a mat over himself, and waited. Late at night he listened as the hosts came and ate his companions. After the evil beings were gone, he hurried to the canoe and sailed home. He told his friends, and together they made wooden images, hid them in the canoe, and sailed for Oʻahu, where they were welcomed. That night the images were put inside the house, while the men hid outside. When the hosts came around to eat the visitors, they bit into the hard wooden images. The Kauaʻi men burned the house, thus ending the evil on Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO kau aku, ʻo kā ia lā mai, pēlā ka nohona o ka ʻohana.
english_phrase: From you and from him — so lived the family.
meaning_phrase: The farmer gave to the fisherman, the fisherman to the farmer.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka uhiwai nō kai ʻike i ka ʻino o ka wai.
english_phrase: ʻOnly the mists know the storm that caused the streams to swell.
meaning_phrase: How I would like that handsome fellow for a sweetheart. The uhu is a bright-colored fish, beautiful to look at, and tasty.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Kaulua ka malama, ʻolo ka ʻōpū mālolo a ka lawaiʻa.
english_phrase: Kaulua is the month when the bag nets of the fishermen sag with flying fish.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person born in the month of Kaulua. He was likely to be a hard worker who carried large bundles on his back.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Kaulua ke kāne, ʻo Lanihua ka wahine, hānau ke keiki he kua leho.
english_phrase: Kaulua is the husband, Lani-hua (Productive-heaven) the wife; born to them is a child with calloused shoulders.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person born in the month of Kaulua. He was likely to be a hard worker who carried large bundles on his back.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka ʻulu iki mai kēia nāna e kaʻa i kahua loa.
english_phrase: This is the small maika stone that rolls over a long field.
meaning_phrase: I am a small person who can accomplish much. When Lonoikamakahiki visited Kamalalawalu, ruling chief of Maui, he took along his half-brother Pupukea to serve him. Makakuikalani, half-brother and personal attendant of Kamalalawalu, made fun of the small stature of Pupukea. This saying was Pupukea’s retort.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka ʻulu o lalo he loaʻa i ka pinana, ʻo ka ʻulu o luna loa he loaʻa i ka lou.
english_phrase: A breadfruit that is low can he reached by climbing, but a breadfruit high above requires a stick to reach it.
meaning_phrase: A mate of low station is easy to fmd, but one of higher rank is less easily acquired.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ka wai kau nō ia o Keʻanae; ʻo ka ʻūlei hoʻowali ʻuala ia o Kula.
english_phrase: It is the pool on the height of Keanae; it is the ʻūlei digging stick for the potato [patch] of Kula.
meaning_phrase: A handsome young man of Kula and a beautiful young woman of Keʻanae, on Maui, were attracted to each other. She boasted of her own womanly perfection by referring to her body as the pool on the heights of Keʻanae. Not to be outdone, he looked down at himself and boasted of his manhood as the digging stick of Kula.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ke aka kā ʻoukou ʻo ka ʻiʻo kā mākou.
english_phrase: Yours the shadow; ours the flesh.
meaning_phrase: A phrase used in prayers dedicating a feast to the gods. The essence of the food was the gods’, and the meat was eaten by those present.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ke alelo ka hoe uli o ka ʻōlelo a ka waha.
english_phrase: The tongue is the steering paddle of the words uttered by the mouth.
meaning_phrase: Advice to heed the tongue lest it speak words that offend.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ke aliʻi ka mea ikaika, ʻaʻole ʻo ke kanaka.
english_phrase: It is the chief who is strong, not the commoner.
meaning_phrase: A commoner’s own work of planting and fishing is limited by his physical ability. A chief can command a multitude to carry out his projects.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ke aliʻi lilo i ka leʻaleʻa a mālama ʻole i ke kanaka me ke kapu akua, ʻaʻole ia he aliʻi e kū ai i ka moku.
english_phrase: The chief who is taken with pleasure-seeking and cares not for the welfare of the people or the observation of the kapu of the gods, is not the chief who will become a ruler.
meaning_phrase: Said by Kekūhaupiʻo to Kamehameha. Advice to young people that success comes not by seeking idle pleasure but by living up to one’s beliefs and caring for the welfare of others.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ke aliʻi wale nō kaʻu makemake.
english_phrase: My desire is only for the chief.
meaning_phrase: An expression of loyalty and affection for one’s chief, used in chants of praise.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ke aloha ke kuleana o kahi malihini.
english_phrase: Love is the host in strange lands.
meaning_phrase: In old Hawaiʻi, every passerby was greeted and offered food whether he was an acquaintance or a total stranger.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ke aloha o ke ipo, he wela ia nō ke kino.
english_phrase: The love of a sweetheart is like a hot fire within the body.
meaning_phrase: No child can get along without adult supervision.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ke ao aku nō hoʻi koe, ʻaina ʻē ka hāuliuli.
english_phrase: It was almost day when the hāuliuli fish began to take the bait.
meaning_phrase: One was just about giving up hope when the person he was angling for showed some response.

hawaiian_phrase: Ōkea pili mai.
english_phrase: Clinging sand. [drift gravel]
meaning_phrase: Said of a shiftless hanger-on. [said disparagingly of persons who attach themselves to others for support; parasite. Lit., gravel clinging (PE)]

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ke ʻehu kakahiaka nō ka wā loaʻa.
english_phrase: The time to catch anything is in the early morning.
meaning_phrase: When you want to do something, don’t wait. Get at it as early as possible.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO kēia ʻuʻuku e nui ana.
english_phrase: This smallness will be big later.
meaning_phrase: Said of a small child who will grow into adulthood, a small place that may develop into a large one, and so forth.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ke kahua ma mua, ma hope ke kūkulu.
english_phrase: The site first, and then the building.
meaning_phrase: Learn all you can, then practice.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ke kāne kēlā uē waimaka.
english_phrase: If that is the husband [of your choice], there will he much crying [with unhappiness].
meaning_phrase: Said sarcastically to a person who boasts of his greatness.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ke keiki he loaʻa i ka moe, ʻo ka pōkiʻi ʻaʻole.
english_phrase: One can produce a child by sleeping with a mate, but he cannot produce a younger brother or sister.
meaning_phrase: Great affection between brothers and sisters, and especially for younger siblings, was not rare in olden days. This saying is a reminder to treat younger ones with love and respect.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ke kū hale wale iho nō i Makanoni.
english_phrase: Only the house stands there at Makanoni.
meaning_phrase: Said of a house from which the inhabitants are gone.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ke kū hoe akamai nō ia, he piʻipiʻi kai ʻole ma ka ʻaoʻao.
english_phrase: That is the way of a skilled paddler — the sea does not wash in on the sides.
meaning_phrase: Said of a deft lover.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ke kumu, o ka māna, hoʻopuka ʻia.
english_phrase: The teacher, the pupil — let it come forth.
meaning_phrase: A challenge from a pupil to the teacher who trained him in warfare or sports — “Now let the teacher and pupil vie against each other.”

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOki kilohana ka pali o Waialoha.
english_phrase: Straight and tall is the cliff of Waialoha.
meaning_phrase: Said in admiration of a tall, well-formed person.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOki loa ka ihu kau ʻia e ka nalo.
english_phrase: It is worse to have a fly sit on the nose
meaning_phrase: A young woman from Kaʻū was teased about being carried ashore by a sailor who found it hard to resist kissing her. This was her laughing reply — there are worse things than being kissed.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Kilohana ia, he ʻaweʻawe moku.
english_phrase: That is the Kilohana of the broken bundle cords.
meaning_phrase: Said of Kilohana above Līhuʻe on Kauaʻi. An old trail went by here, leading from Kona to Koʻolau. Robbers hid there and waylaid lone travelers or those in small companies and robbed them of their bundles.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOki pau ka hana i ke one kani o Nohili.
english_phrase: Strange indeed are the activities at the sounding sands of Nohili.
meaning_phrase: Barking Sands beach of Nohili, Kauaʻi, was believed to be the haunt of ghosts. Said of a person whose behavior is peculiar.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ko Kona mau nō ia ʻo ka laʻi.
english_phrase: Calm is typical of Kona.
meaning_phrase: Said of a Kona person who is always poised and calm.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOkole kāmano.
english_phrase: Salmon backside.
meaning_phrase: A vulgar expression for a white person whose backside is pink. Also expressed Kāmano ʻula (Red salmon).

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Kona i ka paka ʻona — ke haʻu iho ʻoe kūnewanewa.
english_phrase: Kona of the potent tohacco — a draw would make one stagger.
meaning_phrase: Kona is said to be a land of potent lovemaking.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Kuaʻana ka nalu; ʻo Paiahaʻa ka ʻāina.
english_phrase: Kuaʻana is the surf; Paiahaʻa the land.
meaning_phrase: Proud were the people of Kaʻū of the surf of Kuaʻana, where chiefs used to ride the waves to the shore of Paiaha’a.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Kula i ka hoe hewa.
english_phrase: Kula of the ignorant canoe-paddlers.
meaning_phrase: Said of Kula, Maui, whose people did not know how to paddle canoes because they were uplanders.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Kulu ka pō, o Welehu ka malama, he lā iʻa ʻole.
english_phrase: Kulu is the night and Welehu the month; no fish is to be found that day.
meaning_phrase: A play on kulu (drop). Welehu was said to be the month on which to lay the head on the pillow, for the sea was too rough for fishing. Hence an unlucky, unprofitable day.

hawaiian_phrase: "O kū, o kā," ʻo Wahineʻomaʻo.
english_phrase: “Kū and kā,” says Wahineʻomaʻo.
meaning_phrase: While walking toward Hilo one day, Hiʻiaka met Wahineʻomaʻo shivering by the roadside with a pig in her arms — a gift for Pele. Hiʻiaka suggested that she start walking to Kīlauea chanting, “O kū! O kā!” Before long Wahineʻomaʻo had reached the volcano, given her offering, and returned to meet Hiʻiaka, whom she followed on the long journey to Kauaʻi. “O kū! ʻO kā!” cannot be translated. However, any work done hurriedly might be referred to this way, meaning “with a lick and a promise.”

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO kuʻu wahi ōpū weuweu lā, nou ia.
english_phrase: Let my little clump of grass be yours.
meaning_phrase: A humble way of offering the use of one’s grass house to a friend.

hawaiian_phrase: Ola a kau kō kea.
english_phrase: Lives till the sugar cane tassels.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who lives until his hair whitens with age.

hawaiian_phrase: Ola akula ka ʻāina kaha, ua pua ka lehua i kai.
english_phrase: Life has come to the kaha lands for the lehua blooms are seen at sea.
meaning_phrase: “Kaha lands” refers to Kekaha, Kona, Hawaiʻi. When the season for deep-sea fishing arrived, the canoes of the expert fishermen were seen going and coming.

hawaiian_phrase: Ola ia kini ke ʻā maila ke ahi.
english_phrase: The multitude finds life at last; the fire is lighted.
meaning_phrase: It was later used as an expression of gladness that the fire is lighted and the food on the way.

hawaiian_phrase: Ola i ka ʻai uahi ʻole o ke kini o Mānā.
english_phrase: The inhahitants of Mānā live on food cooked without smoking.
meaning_phrase: Said of the people of Mānā, Kauaʻi, who in ancient days did very little poi-making, except in a place like Kolo, where taro was grown. The majority of the inhabitants were fishermen and gourd cultivators whose products were traded with other inhabitants of the island, even as far as Kalalau. Because all the taro cooking and poi-making was done elsewhere, the people of Mānā were said to live on “smokeless food.”

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOla i ka ʻōhulu.
english_phrase: There is subsistence in the sprouting tubers.
meaning_phrase: Said when there is a poor growth of sweet potatoes during an excessively warm summer. The broken pieces of potato sprouting among the weeds produces the few potatoes that feed the farmer and his family until a new crop is started.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOla i ka wai a ka ʻōpua.
english_phrase: There is life in the water from the clouds.
meaning_phrase: Rain gives life.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOla i ke ahe lau makani.
english_phrase: There is life in a gentle breath of wind.
meaning_phrase: Said when a warm day is relieved by a breeze.

hawaiian_phrase: Ola ka inoa.
english_phrase: The name lives.
meaning_phrase: Said when the name of a beloved, deceased relative is given to a child.

hawaiian_phrase: Ola ka makapehu.
english_phrase: The swollen-eyed ones are healed.
meaning_phrase: Said of those who are lacking food and then receive an abundance of it.

hawaiian_phrase: Ola ke awa o Kou i ka ua Waʻahila.
english_phrase: Life comes to the harbor of Kou because of the Waʻahila rain.
meaning_phrase: It is the rain of Nuʻuanu that gives water to Kou (now central Honolulu).

hawaiian_phrase: Ola nā ʻilima wai ʻole i ke ao ʻōpua.
english_phrase: Healed are the ʻilima of waterless places by the rain cloud.
meaning_phrase: The ʻilima blossom is one of the first medicines given to babies. It is a mild laxative. Hiʻiaka, goddess of medicine in Pele’s family, used ʻilima in some of her healings.

hawaiian_phrase: Ola nā iwi.
english_phrase: The bones live.
meaning_phrase: Said of a respected oldster who is well cared for by his family.

hawaiian_phrase: Ola nō i ka pua o ka ʻilima.
english_phrase: There is healing in the ʻilima blossoms.
meaning_phrase: The ʻilima blossom is one of the first medicines given to babies. It is a mild laxative. Hiʻiaka, goddess of medicine in Pele’s family, used ʻilima in some of her healings.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOla nō ka lawaiʻa i kahi poʻo maunu.
english_phrase: A fisherman can subsist on his left-over bait.
meaning_phrase: Bait made from octopus heart was carefully prepared and kept in a clean container. When a fisherman had no luck in fishing, the bait was eaten with poi.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOla nō ka mahiʻai i kahi kūʻōʻō.
english_phrase: A farmer can subsist on small, broken potatoes.
meaning_phrase: As long as there are potatoes, even small or broken ones, a farmer gets along.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOla nō ka mea akua, make nō ka mea akua ʻole.
english_phrase: He who has a god lives; he who has none, dies.
meaning_phrase: A god was regarded as a helper and protector of his devotee.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌlapa ka hoe a ka lawaiʻa, he ʻino.
english_phrase: Diffcult to handle is the paddle of the fisherman in a storm.
meaning_phrase: Said of one struggling against a difficult situation. First uttered by Pele in a chant about the winds of Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌlapa ke ahi o ka lewa.
english_phrase: The fire of the sky flashes.
meaning_phrase: Lightning.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOla Waiʻanae i ka makani Kaiaulu.
english_phrase: Waiʻanae is made comfortahle by the Kaiaulu breeze.
meaning_phrase: Chanted by Hiʻiaka at Kaʻena, Oʻahu, after her return from Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌlelo i ke aka ka hele hoʻokahi.
english_phrase: One who travels alone has but his shadow to talk to.
meaning_phrase: Said by Hiʻiaka as she was leaving Kīlauea on her quest for Lohiʻau.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌlelo ka waha, holehole ka lima.
english_phrase: The mouth talks, the hand strips.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who says friendly words yet does unfriendly deeds.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌlelo ke kupa o ka ʻāina ua mālie; ua au koaʻe.
english_phrase: The natives of the land declare that the weather is calm when the tropic bird travels afar.
meaning_phrase: The kūpala is a wild plant whose tubers were eaten in time of famine. It grew on Kahoʻolawe.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌlemu kaʻa.
english_phrase: Rolling buttocks.
meaning_phrase: A term of contempt for a vagabond.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOlo hewa ka pihe.
english_phrase: Shouted at the wrong time.
meaning_phrase: Bragged too soon.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOloʻolo aku nō i hope, kū i ke aʻu.
english_phrase: Linger behind and he jabbed by the swordfish.
meaning_phrase: Better to advance with one’s companions than to stay behind and get into trouble.

hawaiian_phrase: Olowalu ihu pāpaʻa.
english_phrase: Crusty-nosed Olowalu.
meaning_phrase: Disparaging expression for the people of Olowalu, Maui, where the wind is said to blow into the nostrils, drying the mucus into crust.

hawaiian_phrase: Olowalu ka moa.
english_phrase: Roosters all crowing.
meaning_phrase: Much talk.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO luna, ʻo lalo; ʻo kai,ʻo uka — ʻo ka hao pae ko ke aliʻi ia.
english_phrase: Above, below; seaward, inland — the iron that washes ashore belongs to the chief.
meaning_phrase: Said by Kamehameha. All iron that was found belonged to him.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO luna, ʻo lalo; ʻo uka, ʻo kai; ʻo ka palaoa pae, no ke aliʻi ia.
english_phrase: Above, helow; the upland, the lowland; the whale that washes ashore — all belong to the chief.
meaning_phrase: The chief owned everything in the land he ruled. Ivory obtained from the teeth of whales that washed ashore was very valuable.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Mahoehope ke kāne, ʻo Lanihua ka wahine, hānau ke keiki he kōkua nui a waiū nunui.
english_phrase: Mahoehope is the husband, Lanihua (Productive-heavenly-one) is the wife; a child born to them is either thick-shouldered or large-busted.
meaning_phrase: Said of a child born in the month of Mahoehope. If a boy, he would be strong-shouldered and able to do much work; if a girl, she would be large of breast.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Mahoemua ke kāne, Leleipele ka wahine, hānau ke keiki, he ʻōpulepule.
english_phrase: Mahoemua is the husband, Lele-i-pele (Leap-into-voIcano) the wife; a child born to them is reckless and irresponsible.
meaning_phrase: Said of a child born in the month of Mahoemua.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌmaka ka iʻa, hōʻā aku ka lamalama i ka moana.
english_phrase: If the fish is the ʻōmaka, light the torches at sea.
meaning_phrase: The ʻōmaka is not a fighting fish and is easy to catch. Therefore one need not be prepared too soon and can afford to take time.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Makaliʻi ke kāne, ʻo Hiʻipoi ka wahine, hānau ke keiki he maikaʻi.
english_phrase: Makaliʻi is the husband, Hiʻipoi (Cherished-one) the wife; a child born to them is well behaved.
meaning_phrase: Said of a child born in the month of Makaliʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Māuli kēia o ka lā pau.
english_phrase: This is Māuli, the last day [of the lunar month].
meaning_phrase: Said when a task is near completion.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Muku ka lā, mumuku nā hana.
english_phrase: Muku is the day; incomplete are the tasks.
meaning_phrase: A warning not to begin a project on the day of Muku lest it be unsuccessful.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO nā hihia wale ʻana i Moeawakea.
english_phrase: All the entangling shrubbery at Moeawakea.
meaning_phrase: Said of entangling affairs. There is a play on Moe-awakea (Sleep-till-the-sun-is-high).

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO nā hōkū nō nā kiu o ka lani.
english_phrase: The stars are the spies of heaven.
meaning_phrase: The stars look down on everyone and everything.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO nā hōkū o ka lani kai ʻike iā Pae. Aia a loaʻa ka pūnana o ke kōlea, loaʻa ʻo ia iā ʻoe.
english_phrase: Only the stars of heaven know where Pae is. When you find a plover’s nest, then you will find him.
meaning_phrase: Said of something so well hidden that it will not be found. Pae was a priest in the reign of ʻUmi. He was so lucky in fishing that the chief desired his bones for fishhooks after his death. When Pae died, his sons hid his bones so well that none of the chiefs and priests could find them. The sons would say, “When you find the nest of the plover, then will you find him.” But ʻUmi enlisted the help of a noted priest of Kauaʻi, who saw the ghost of Pae drinking from a spring in Waimanu Valley. Thus were the bones of Pae found and made into fishhooks for the chief. The sons of Pae were reminded that the chief was using their father’s bones for hooks by his constant cry, “O Pae, hold fast to our fish!”

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO nā hōkū o ka lani luna, ʻo Paʻaiea ko lalo.
english_phrase: The stars are above, Paʻaiea helow.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Kamehameha’s great fish-pond, Paʻaiea, in Kona, Hawaiʻi. Its great size led to this saying — the small islets that dotted its interior were compared to the stars that dot the sky. The pond was destroyed during a volcanic eruption.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Nana ka malama; momona ka pāpaʻi.
english_phrase: Nana is the month; the crabs are fat.
meaning_phrase: The sea urchin, a favorite food of the parrotfish, is fat during the season when the pandanus fruit is ripe. Feeding on fat sea urchin, the fish, too, hecome fat.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Nana ke kāne, ʻo Nanailewa ka wahine, hānau ke keiki, he keiki ʻaeʻa.
english_phrase: Nana is the hushand, Nana-i-lewa (Active-in-movement) the wife; a child born to them has wanderlust.
meaning_phrase: Said of a child born in the month of Nana.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO nā ʻunihipili o Keaweʻolouha ua haʻalele i ka haka.
english_phrase: The deified relatives of Keaweʻolouha have deserted the person they possessed.
meaning_phrase: A play on Keawe-ʻolo-uha (Keawe-with-the-sagging-colon), a term applied to one who is too lazy to work. Those who depended on him soon deserted.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOnea Kaupō, ua kā ka ʻai i ka lua.
english_phrase: Barren is Kaupō; the eating in the cavern has begun.
meaning_phrase: Fatal shark attacks were common at Kaupō at one time. As a result, the people moved elsewhere, after which a man-eating shark peered at Kaupō and said these words. The spot from which he watched was named Kiʻei (Peer). Later used to mean destitution.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOni kalalea ke kū a ka lāʻau loa.
english_phrase: A tall tree stands above the others.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person of outstanding achievements.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOnipaʻa.
english_phrase: Stand firm.
meaning_phrase: Motto of Liliʻuokalani.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌnohi ʻula i ka lani.
english_phrase: A red eyeball in the sky.
meaning_phrase: A fragment of rainbow.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOno kahi ʻao luʻau me ke aloha pū.
english_phrase: A little taro green is delicious when love is present.
meaning_phrase: Even the plainest fare is delicious when there is love.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ʻoe, a ʻo wau, nalo ia mea.
english_phrase: You and me; it is hidden.
meaning_phrase: Let the secret be with us alone.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ʻoe hoʻi kahi i Hāʻupu kēlā, ua kupu a kiʻekiʻe i luna.
english_phrase: You, too, were on the tall hill of Haʻupu going all the way up to the very top.
meaning_phrase: Said sarcastically to a person who boasts of his greatness.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ʻoe kaʻu!
english_phrase: Youre mine!
meaning_phrase: Said in anger to mean, “You’re going to get it!”

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ʻOlepau ka mahina; ʻo palaweka ka mahina; ʻo hina wale ka mahina; ʻo hāhā pōʻele ka mahina.
english_phrase: ʻOlepau is the moon phase; hazy is the light of the moon; quickly goes the light of the moon; one gropes in the dark.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is vague or hazy in explaining his thoughts, or of one whose knowledge is vague.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO ʻole wale mā.
english_phrase: Just nothing and his company.
meaning_phrase: A comment about another’s idea — it is nothing and still more nothing.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOʻopu peke o Hanakāpīʻai.
english_phrase: The stunted ʻoʻopu fish of Hanakāpīʻai.
meaning_phrase: Famed in the legends of Kauaʻi are the ʻoʻopu of Hanakāpīʻai, which are said to be plump and shorter in length than those elsewhere. Sometimes applied humorously to a short, plump person.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Paiahaʻa ka ʻāina, ʻo Kuaʻana ka nalu.
english_phrase: Paiahaʻa was the land, Kuaʻana the surf.
meaning_phrase: Paiahaʻa was a beach near Kaumaea, Kaʻū, Hawai’i. Here the dust that clung to the skin at Kaumaea was washed off by the surf of Kuaʻana. The inner surf, Kaina (Little Brother), was the place for children to surf, and the outer surf, Kuaʻana (Big Brother), was for grown-ups.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOpa nā kuku o Waimea.
english_phrase: Weary are the sticks that hold the nets at Waimea.
meaning_phrase: Weary are the legs after walking far. A line from an old chant.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌpelu haʻalili i ke kai.
english_phrase: ʻOpelu that make the sea ripple.
meaning_phrase: Said of active, quick-moving people.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOpeʻope Kohala i ka makani.
english_phrase: Kohala is buffeted by the wind.
meaning_phrase: Pele was said to be fond of swimming and surfing. While doing so she would pause to eat seafood.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOpihi kauwawe lehua o Hōpoe.
english_phrase: ʻOpihi covered by the lehua blossoms of Hōpoe.
meaning_phrase: The fringes of lehua at Hōpoe fall into the sea, and are washed up over the rocks, hiding the ʻopihi.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Poʻo ke koʻa, ka ipu kai aloha a nā aliʻi.
english_phrase: Poo is the fishing ground, beloved meat dish of chiefis.
meaning_phrase: Said of Poʻo, a favorite fishing place of the chiefs of Oʻahu, located near Mokumanu. Nuʻuanu Pali is the landmark by which it was located.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌpule moe one.
english_phrase: ʻŌpule fish that lies on the sand.
meaning_phrase: A shy person who prefers to make himself unobtrusive.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌpū palaʻai.
english_phrase: Pumpkin stomach.
meaning_phrase: Said in ridicule of one with a large, protruding abdomen.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌpū palula.
english_phrase: Stomach full of sweet-potato greens.
meaning_phrase: Said of an ignorant person who can only grow sweet potatoes.

hawaiian_phrase: Ōpū ʻukuʻuku.
english_phrase: Small clump.
meaning_phrase: A group of insignificant persons.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO uakeʻe nei i loko o Haʻaloʻu, ʻo ka pō nahunahu ihu.
english_phrase: The little bend in Haʻaloʻu (Bend-over), on the night that the nose is bitten.
meaning_phrase: This was said of Kahalaiʻa when he became angry with Kaʻahumanu. He was only a “little bend” whose wrath was no more important then a nip on the nose.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Ulumaheihei wale nō, iā ia ʻo loko, iā ia ʻo waho.
english_phrase: Ulumaheihei knows everything inside and out.
meaning_phrase: ʻOne who knows everything. Ulumaheihei was a very close friend of Kamehameha, who renamed him Hoapili. He was the king’s most trusted friend and knew every affair of the kingdom. It was to him that Kamehameha entrusted his bones after death.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŌʻu ō loa nā manu o Kaupeʻa.
english_phrase: The birds of Kaupeʻa trill and warble.
meaning_phrase: Said of the chatter of happy people.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOā!
english_phrase: A signal word used by Kukuaokalalau, a celebrated warrior of Kauaʻi who fought under Kalanialiloa, a chief of Kauaʻi. It means, “Here they come!”
meaning_phrase: You shall find out how wrong you are. A play on kuhihewa (erroneous).

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO wahie ka ʻai, ʻo loli ka iʻa, ʻo muku ka imu.
english_phrase: Wood is the vegetable food, sea cucumber is the meat, and a small imu is the only imu.
meaning_phrase: Said of scarcity from oppression.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO wai ka ʻoukou aliʻi i hānai ai?
english_phrase: What chief did you rear?
meaning_phrase: Those who had a part in the rearing of a young chief were proud of their position. Only kinsmen were given such places, but convention forbade discussing the relationship. When this is said in scorn it is the equivalent of “Who are you?”

hawaiian_phrase: O Waiōhinu aku ia kahi o ka maiʻa pala.
english_phrase: That is Waiōhinu, where ripe bananas are.
meaning_phrase: A Kaʻū saying meaning that one is in for bad luck. To see bananas while on a fishing or business trip was an omen of failure. From the story of twin brothers who were climbing a hill. The stronger brother climbed on while the weaker one sat and cried. The older looked down and said “Cry, baby, cry! Go to Waiōhinu to eat ripe bananas.”

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Waipiʻo me Waimanu, no ʻoawa mahoe i ke alo o ka makani.
english_phrase: Waipiʻo and Waimanu, the twin valleys that face the wind.
meaning_phrase: These two are neighboring valleys on Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Wananalua ia ʻāina; ʻo Punahoa ka wai; ʻo Kaʻuiki ka puʻu.
english_phrase: Wananalua is the land; Punahoa is the pool; Kaʻuiki is the hill.
meaning_phrase: Noted places in Hāna.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Welehu ka malama, lehu nui ke poʻo i ka uahi o ka hoʻoilo.
english_phrase: Welehu is the month; sooty is the head in the smoke of winter.
meaning_phrase: Said of Welehu, the most rainy of all the wet months, when the fireplace is kept going to give warmth to the house.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Welehu ke kāne, ʻo Huhune ka wahine, hānau ke keiki, he luluāʻina.
english_phrase: Welehu is the husband, Huhune (Tiny-specks) the wife; a child born to them is freckled.
meaning_phrase: Said of a child born in the month of Welehu.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻO Welo ke kāne, ʻo Mikikole ka wahine, hānau ke keiki, he keiki mākilo.
english_phrase: Welo is the hushand, Mikikole (Reach-before-the-meat-is-done) the wife; a child bom to them is a beggar.
meaning_phrase: Said of a child born in the month of Welo. Such a beggar does not ask for things, but the longing look in his eyes is a reason for invitation.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻOē sananā.
english_phrase: Make merry.
meaning_phrase: An old sailors’ drinking expression.

hawaiian_phrase: Paʻa aku i ka lani o kā ke akua ia, a hāʻule mai i lalo o kā Laiana ia.
english_phrase: What is held up in heaven is Godʻs, and what falls below is Lyonsʻs.
meaning_phrase: A reply made by the Reverend Lorenzo Lyons (Makua Laiana) when he was charged with being careless in accepting people as members of his church. He loved and accepted them and did not adhere rigidly to certain rules before allowing them to become members.

hawaiian_phrase: Paʻa ʻia iho i ka hoe uli i ʻole e īkā i ke koʻa.
english_phrase: Hold the steering paddle steady to keep from striking the rock.
meaning_phrase: Hold on; donʻt let yourself get into trouble.

hawaiian_phrase: Paʻa i ke aupuni a Limaloa.
english_phrase: Held fast by the kingdom of Limaloa.
meaning_phrase: A play on Lima-loa (Long-hand). The Big-grabber has it all now.

hawaiian_phrase: Paʻa i ke kānāwai kāmakaʻaha.
english_phrase: Held by the law of the sennit girdle.
meaning_phrase: Taken an oath to remain chaste. Luʻukia, wife of the high chief Olopana, designed and made a girdle of sennit to prevent her lover and brother-in-law from approaching her.

hawaiian_phrase: Paʻa kahi hope i ka malo.
english_phrase: The rear is covered with a malo.
meaning_phrase: Said of a boy about five or six years old. Prior to this age, a boy ate with the women in their eating house and wore no clothing, but when he was old enough to join the men in theirs, he wore a malo, just as they did.

hawaiian_phrase: Paʻa ka moku i ka helēuma.
english_phrase: The ship is held fast by the anchor.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is married.

hawaiian_phrase: Paʻa ka waha, hana ka lima.
english_phrase: Shut the mouth; keep the hands busy.
meaning_phrase: Never mind the talking; start working.

hawaiian_phrase: Paʻakikī kanaka o Kauaʻi.
english_phrase: Tough are the men of Kauaʻi.
meaning_phrase: Oʻahu was once inhabited by supernatural beings who ate people. They would extend their hospitality by day, but at night they would eat their sleeping guests. A canoe came from Kauaʻi one day, and among the passengers was a man who was distrustful of the Oahuans. When the other men went to sleep, he dug a hole under the wall, crept into it, pulled a mat over himself, and waited. Late at night he listened as the hosts came and ate his companions. After the evil beings were gone, he hurried to the canoe and sailed home. He told his friends, and together they made wooden images, hid them in the canoe, and sailed for Oʻahu, where they were welcomed. That night the images were put inside the house, while the men hid outside. When the hosts came around to eat the visitors, they bit into the hard wooden images. The Kauaʻi men burned the house, thus ending the evil on Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: Paʻa nō ka ʻaihue i ka ʻole.
english_phrase: A thief persists in denying his guilt.
meaning_phrase: A thief is also a liar.

hawaiian_phrase: Paʻapaʻaʻina ka malo i loko o ʻIkuwā.
english_phrase: The [flap of the] loincloth [flutters and] snaps in the month of ʻIkuwā.
meaning_phrase: ʻIkuwā is a month of rains, winds, and thunderstorms.

hawaiian_phrase: Paʻapaʻakai ʻo Malama.
english_phrase: Crusted with salt is Malama.
meaning_phrase: Said of a sour situation. Refers to Malama, Puna, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Pae ka waʻa i Kaʻena.
english_phrase: The canoe lands at Kaʻena.
meaning_phrase: Wrath. A play on ʻena (red-hot) in Kaʻena.

hawaiian_phrase: Pāʻele kū lani.
english_phrase: The chiefy blackening.
meaning_phrase: This expression, used in chants and songs, refers to the tattooing of Kahekili, ruler of Maui. Because he was named for the god of thunder, who was believed to be black on one side of his body, Kahekili had himself tattooed on one side from head to foot.

hawaiian_phrase: Pae maila ka waʻa i ka ʻāina.
english_phrase: The canoe has come ashore.
meaning_phrase: Hunger is satisfied; or, one has arrived hither.

hawaiian_phrase: Pāhala, ka ʻāina lepo haʻaheo i ka maka.
english_phrase: Pāhala, land [of those who are] proud of the dust in the faces.
meaning_phrase: The people of Pāhala, Kaʻū, like others of that district, are proud of their home, even though the wind-blown dust keeps their faces dirty.

hawaiian_phrase: Pahapaha lei o Polihale.
english_phrase: The pahapaha lei of Polihale.
meaning_phrase: At Polihale, Kauaʻi, grew pahapaha (sea lettuce). Visitors gathered and wore this pahapaha in lei because its green color could be revived by immersion in sea water after it had partially dried. Although pahapaha is common everywhere, only that which grows at Polihale revives once it is dry. It is famed in songs and chants of Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Paheʻe loa akula i ka welowelo.
english_phrase: Slipped away — off to flutter in the breeze.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who missed by a wide margin, whose aim was very poor.

hawaiian_phrase: Pahu kani.
english_phrase: Sounding drum.
meaning_phrase: A humorous epithet for a bald head. The skin-covered dome looks like a drum on which the skin is pulled taut and no hair grows. Also called pahu hinuhinu (shiny drum).

hawaiian_phrase: Paʻi ana nā pahu a hula leʻa; ʻo kaʻu hula nō kēia.
english_phrase: Let the better-enjoyed hula chanters beat their own drums; this is the hula chant that I know.
meaning_phrase: A retort: Let those who claim to know a lot produce their knowledge; this is what I know.

hawaiian_phrase: Paʻi a paʻi; like a like.
english_phrase: A slap and a slap; equal to equal.
meaning_phrase: A tie. Also, when agreement is reached as to the terms of a game, a contestant holds out his hand to be gently slapped by his opponent, then the opponent holds out his hand to be slapped. This clinches the terms, and the game begins.

hawaiian_phrase: Paiʻea noho i ka māwae.
english_phrase: Paiʻea crab that hides in a fissure.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who is too bashful to meet strangers.

hawaiian_phrase: Paʻihi ʻoe lā, lilo i ka wai, ʻaʻohe ʻike iho i ka hoa mua.
english_phrase: Well adorned are you, borne along by the water, no longer recognizing former friends.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who grows proud with prosperity and looks down on his friends of less prosperous days. There is a play on wai (water). When doubled — waiwai — it refers to prosperity.

hawaiian_phrase: Pā i ka leo.
english_phrase: Struck by the voice.
meaning_phrase: Told something that hurt the feelings.

hawaiian_phrase: Pā i ke kumu.
english_phrase: Struck the base.
meaning_phrase: There is something that prevents progress. A kumu is a large stone set in the way to stop the rolling of a maika stone.

hawaiian_phrase: Paʻipaʻi ka lima, ʻae ka waha.
english_phrase: The hand applauds, the mouth assents.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who offers verbal approval yet does nothing to help.

hawaiian_phrase: Pākahi ka nehu a Kapiʻioho.
english_phrase: The nehu of Kapiioho are divided, one to a person.
meaning_phrase: Kapiʻioho, ruler of Molokaʻi, had two ponds, Mauʻoni and Kanahā, built on his land at Kahului, Maui. The men who were brought from Molokaʻi and Oʻahu to build the ponds were fed on food brought over from Molokaʻi. The drain on that island was often so great that the men were reduced to eating nehu fish, freshwater ʻōpae and poi. The saying is used when poi is plentiful but fish is scarce and has to be carefully rationed.

hawaiian_phrase: Pā ka laki.
english_phrase: Bad luck.
meaning_phrase: A common expression Hawaiianized from the English.

hawaiian_phrase: Pā ka makani o ka Moaʻe, hele ka lepo o Kahoʻolawe i Māʻalaea.
english_phrase: When the Moaʻe wind blows, the dust of Kahoʻolawe goes toward Maalaea.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Māʻalaea, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Pākē kini kākai.
english_phrase: Chinese with a handled pail.
meaning_phrase: Said in fun of the Chinese, for many of them were salesmen, going about from place to place with pails of goods.

hawaiian_phrase: Pākiʻi moe one.
english_phrase: Flounder that sleeps in the sand.
meaning_phrase: A term applied jokingly to a flat-nosed person. The pākiʻi is a flat fish whose coloring is like the sand in which it hides.

hawaiian_phrase: Pakī ke kuha!
english_phrase: Saliva spatters!
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who scolds.

hawaiian_phrase: Pakī kēpau, oʻo ka ʻulu.
english_phrase: When the gum appears on the skin, the breadfruit is matured.
meaning_phrase: An observation. Also said when a young person begins to think seriously of gaining a livelihood — he is maturing.

hawaiian_phrase: Pala ʻaluʻalu ka ʻai a kamaliʻi.
english_phrase: Mostly peel when matured are the crops of children.
meaning_phrase: Children, lacking the strength of adults, are not successful farmers.

hawaiian_phrase: Palahuli i lalo ka waha ʻai ai.
english_phrase: Turned down is the mouth he eats food with.
meaning_phrase: He has more problems than he knows what to do with.

hawaiian_phrase: Pala ka hala, momona ka hāʻukeʻuke.
english_phrase: When the pandanus fruit ripens, the hāʻukeʻuke sea urchin is fat.
meaning_phrase: Anger is growing, and those near the angry one are moving out of the way. The hauke’uke is a sea urchin.

hawaiian_phrase: Pala ka hala, momona ka uhu.
english_phrase: When the pandanus fruit is ripe, the parrotfish is fat.
meaning_phrase: The sea urchin, a favorite food of the parrotfish, is fat during the season when the pandanus fruit is ripe. Feeding on fat sea urchin, the fish, too, hecome fat.

hawaiian_phrase: Pala ka hala, ʻula ka ʻāʻī.
english_phrase: When the hala ripens, the neck is brightened by them.
meaning_phrase: People are very fond of hala lei. From a name chant of Kualiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Palakahē ka ʻai o Makaʻukiu.
english_phrase: Spoiled rotten are the food crops of Makaʻukiu.
meaning_phrase: Said of anything that is rotting, or of destruction, or of death in battle.

hawaiian_phrase: Pala ka maiʻa.
english_phrase: The banana is ripe.
meaning_phrase: Nothing is gained. To dream of bananas is a sign that the following day will bring no luck. To talk of bananas while on a fishing trip is also bad luck.

hawaiian_phrase: Palakī a Moemoe.
english_phrase: Ti daubs of Moemoe.
meaning_phrase: Excrement. Ti eaten in great quantity loosens the bowels. Moemoe was a prophet whose excrement, when questioned, was said to reply of his whereabouts.

hawaiian_phrase: Pala uluhe.
english_phrase: Ripened in uluhe fern leaves.
meaning_phrase: A term of derision applied by the shore-dwellers of Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi, to the uplanders, who were poor farmers. They ripened their bananas in pits lined and covered with uluhe fern leaves, instead of allowing the bananas to ripen in the field.

hawaiian_phrase: Pale hāliʻi moena.
english_phrase: A mat cover.
meaning_phrase: A low commoner.

hawaiian_phrase: Pali ke kua, mahina ke alo.
english_phrase: Back [as straight] as a cliff, face as bright as the moon.
meaning_phrase: Said of a good-looking person.

hawaiian_phrase: Pā mai, pā mai ka makani o Hilo; waiho aku i ka ipu iki, hō mai i ka ipu nui.
english_phrase: Blow, blow, O winds of Hilo, put away the small containers and give us the large one.
meaning_phrase: Laʻamaomao, the god of wind, was said to have a wind container called Ipu-a-Laʻamaomao. When one desires more wind to make the surf roll high, or a kite sail aloft, he makes this appeal.

hawaiian_phrase: Pā nō, lilo!
english_phrase: Touched, gone!
meaning_phrase: Said of one with deft fingers: A touch and the thing is gone!

hawaiian_phrase: Paoa ka lawaiʻa i ka ʻōlelo ʻia o ka ʻawa.
english_phrase: Unlucky is fishing when ʻawa is discussed.
meaning_phrase: ʻAwa (kava) also means “bitterness.”

hawaiian_phrase: Pao ka lima, ʻae ka waha.
english_phrase: The hand reaches under, the mouth agrees.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who makes promises while accepting bribes.

hawaiian_phrase: Papahi i ka hae o ka lanakila.
english_phrase: Honor the flag of the victor.
meaning_phrase: Said in praise of a victorious person.

hawaiian_phrase: Pāpale ʻai ʻāina, kuʻu aloha.
english_phrase: The head-covering over the land, my beloved.
meaning_phrase: Said of Kamehameha by his wife, Kaʻahumanu.

hawaiian_phrase: Papani ka uka o Kapela; puaʻi hānono wai ʻole o Kukaniloko; pakī hunahuna ʻole o Holoholokū; ʻaʻohe mea nāna e ʻaʻe paepae kapu o Līloa.
english_phrase: Close the upland of Kapela; no red water gushes from Kukaniloko; not a particle issues from Holoholokū; there is none to step over the sacred platform of Līloa.
meaning_phrase: The old chiefs and their sacredness are gone; the descendants are no longer laid to rest at Ka-pela-kapu-o-Kakaʻe at ʻīao; the descendants no longer point to Kukaniloko on Oʻahu and Holoholokū on Kauaʻi as the sacred birthplaces; there is no one to tread on the sacred places in Waipiʻo, Hawaiʻi, where Līloa once dwelt.

hawaiian_phrase: Papapau kākou, he ʻaʻā ko ka hale.
english_phrase: We are all destroyed; only lava rocks will be found in the house.
meaning_phrase: Utter destruction, as by a lava flow.

hawaiian_phrase: Pāʻū halakā.
english_phrase: A skirt that can be instantly removed.
meaning_phrase: Referring to the hand, when it is used as a shield while bathing in the ocean or a stream.

hawaiian_phrase: Pau ka ʻike, pau ka lohe.
english_phrase: See no more, hear no more.
meaning_phrase: To be in a coma or in a state of unconsciousness.

hawaiian_phrase: Pau kā ʻoe hana, pio kā ʻoe ahi, pala kā ʻoe ʻāhui.
english_phrase: Your work is done, your fire is extinguished, your [banana] bunch has ripened.
meaning_phrase: Said by Kahekili, chief of Maui, after he defeated Peleioholani of Oʻahu. Used with relief and gladness that a person has died. Common in old newspapers.

hawaiian_phrase: Pau ka pali, hala ka luʻuluʻu kaumaha.
english_phrase: The cliff is now passed and with it the burden of difficulty.
meaning_phrase: Let’s get going and eat before company comes. The people of Honokaneiki, in Kohala, were not noted for their hospitality. Travelers to Honokaneiki were called “doubly-weighted” because they had to swim to get there from the cliff of Kakaʻauki. With bundles, and being soaked by the sea, the weight of a person was doubled. In order to finish their morning meal before others arrived, the people of Honokaneiki awoke early, ate, and went about their work.

hawaiian_phrase: Pau ka wai o ia pūnāwai, ke piʻi maila ka huʻahuʻa lepo.
english_phrase: The water is gone from that spring, for only muddy foam arises.
meaning_phrase: Said of a mudslinger. First uttered by the Reverend George B. Rowell on Kauaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Pau ke aho i ke kahawai lau o Hilo.
english_phrase: Oneʻs strength is exhausted in crossing the many streams of Hilo.
meaning_phrase: Said of or by one who is weary with effort. First uttered by Hiʻiaka in a chant when she found herself weary after a battle with the lizard god Panaʻewa.

hawaiian_phrase: Pau kōkō a Makaliʻi i ka ʻai ʻia e ka ʻiole.
english_phrase: The net of Makaliʻi was all chewed up by the rat.
meaning_phrase: A total loss.

hawaiian_phrase: Pau kuhihewa i ka nani o ʻAipō.
english_phrase: Gone are all the illusions of the beauty of ʻAipō.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who finds out for himself what a person, thing, or place is really like.

hawaiian_phrase: Pāuli hiwa ka lani o Hilo.
english_phrase: Black with rain clouds is the sky of Hilo.
meaning_phrase: Sometimes said in humor when a dark-skinned person is seen.

hawaiian_phrase: Pau ʻole ka ʻepa iā Hawaiʻi.
english_phrase: Endless is the strange behavior of those of Hawaii.
meaning_phrase: An expression of humor or annoyance used in old newspapers whenever Hawaiians criticized one another.

hawaiian_phrase: Pau ʻōlelo me ka luina, he kāpena ka hoa ʻōlelo.
english_phrase: No more talking to sailors, only conversing with the captain.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who has become prosperous and no longer associates with former friends.

hawaiian_phrase: Pau ʻole nō ka ʻumeke i kekahi, pau ʻole nō ka lemu i ka hāleu.
english_phrase: When one does not clean the sides of the poi bowl properly he is not likely to wipe his backside clean after excreting.
meaning_phrase: The ʻanaeholo, a fish that travels from Honouliuli, where it breeds, to Kaipāpaʻu on the windward side of Oʻahu. It then turns about and returns to its original home. It is driven closer to shore when the wind is strong.

hawaiian_phrase: Pau o Peʻapeʻa i ke ahi.
english_phrase: Peʻapeʻa is destroyed by fire.
meaning_phrase: Said of anything that is consumed by fire or is utterly destroyed. Peʻapeʻa was a chief and a relative of Kamehameha. He was killed by the explosion of a keg of gun powder on Kaʻuiki, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Pau Pele, pau manō.
english_phrase: [May I be] devoured by Pele, [May I be] devoured by a shark.
meaning_phrase: An oath, meaning “If I fail.. ..” It was believed that if such an oath were not kept, the one who uttered it would indeed die by fire or be eaten by a shark.

hawaiian_phrase: Pau pulu, ʻaʻohe lau kanu.
english_phrase: Gone, mulch and all; with not even a sweet-potato slip to plant.
meaning_phrase: Utter destruction, with nothing left for a new start.

hawaiian_phrase: Pau Puna ua koʻele ka papa.
english_phrase: Puna is ravaged; the foundation crackles.
meaning_phrase: Said of anything that is entirely consumed. From a chant by Lohiʻau when Pele sent her sisters to overwhelm him with lava.

hawaiian_phrase: Peʻa nā lima i ke kaha o Kaupeʻa.
english_phrase: Crossed his hands bchind him on the land of Kaupeʻa.
meaning_phrase: Met with disappointment. To see someone with his hands crossed behind his back [opea kua) was a sign of bad luck.

hawaiian_phrase: Peʻapeʻa maka walu.
english_phrase: Eight-eyed Peʻapeʻa.
meaning_phrase: Peʻapeʻa was the son of Kamehameha-nui of Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Peʻe kua o Kaʻulahaimalama; o Kekūhaupiʻo ka makua; hilinaʻi aʻe i ka pale kai, kālele moku aʻe ma hope.
english_phrase: Kaʻulahaimalama is secretive; Kekūhaupiʻo (Stands-leaning) is her father; she leans against the canoe side and rests against the back of the canoe.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who tries to conceal the true offender by pretending to know nothing.

hawaiian_phrase: Peʻepeʻe pū hala.
english_phrase: Hiders among the hala trees.
meaning_phrase: An epithet for the kauā of Hāmākualoa, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Pēlā iho a hala aʻe ka ua ka mea makaʻu.
english_phrase: Wait until the thing that is feared, the rain, has gone its way.
meaning_phrase: Wait until this person whom we are afraid of or do not want with us has gone.

hawaiian_phrase: Pepeʻe a palaholo.
english_phrase: A rolled-up frond — paste for tapa cloth.
