meaning_phrase: Said of the ʻamaʻu fern, which furnishes sap used in tapa-making. Implies the same thought as the saying, “Great oaks from little acorns grow.”

hawaiian_phrase: Pēpē i ka ua hoʻopoponi ʻili.
english_phrase: Bruised by the rain that bruises the skin.
meaning_phrase: Said of one whose feelings are hurt.

hawaiian_phrase: Pēpē i ka wai o Niuliʻi.
english_phrase: Crushed by the water of Niuliʻi.
meaning_phrase: Rendered helpless or made humble and obedient.

hawaiian_phrase: Pēpē ka nahele o Upeloa, nāwali i ka ua kakahiaka.
english_phrase: Crushed is the shruhhery of Upeloa, weakened by the morning rain.
meaning_phrase: An expression used in chants. Said of a person who is crushed by humiliation or woe, or of a craven person.

hawaiian_phrase: Pēpē ʻōmaka ʻoe, pā i ka paʻakai, uāniʻi.
english_phrase: You are a weak ʻōmaka — when touched with salt you stiffen.
meaning_phrase: The ʻōmaka is a small, soft fish. Said to a weakling who, with outside help, gains a little courage.

hawaiian_phrase: Pihaʻā moe wai uka.
english_phrase: Stones that lie in the water in the upland.
meaning_phrase: Experts in strenuous sports. They are compared to the stones that not even a freshet can wash down to the lowland.

hawaiian_phrase: Piha ʻōpala ke one o Haʻakua.
english_phrase: The sand of Haʻakua is flled with rubbish.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is untidy, or who talks nonsense. Haʻakua is under the Puʻueo end of the railroad bridge that spans the Wailuku River in Hilo, Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Pī ʻia ko wahi pilau iki, ʻaʻole ʻoe i ʻike i ko pilau nui.
english_phrase: Refuse to give your little stink a place and youʻll never know when a greater stink will come to you.
meaning_phrase: A curse uttered by a sorcerer to a woman who refuses his advances. In refusing a sexual union with him she may meet a greater “stink”- — death and decomposition.

hawaiian_phrase: Piʻi aku a kau i ka nuʻu.
english_phrase: Ascend and stand on the nuʻu.
meaning_phrase: Ascend to a place of honor. The nuʻu is a very kapu place reserved for certain chiefs.

hawaiian_phrase: Piʻi ka ʻena.
english_phrase: The heat rises.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is burning with wrath.

hawaiian_phrase: Piʻi ka ihu o ka naiʻa i ka makani.
english_phrase: The nose of the dolphin rises toward the wind.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is haughty.

hawaiian_phrase: Piʻi ka lepo i ka makani puahiohio.
english_phrase: The dust rises on the whirlwind.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who elevates himself with his bragging.

hawaiian_phrase: Piʻi ka ʻula a hanini i kumu pepeiao.
english_phrase: The red rises till it spills over the base of the ears.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who blushes violently or of one who is flushed with anger.

hawaiian_phrase: Piʻi ke kai.
english_phrase: The sea has risen.
meaning_phrase: The temper has risen.

hawaiian_phrase: Piʻi mai nei i ka pali me he ʻaʻama lā.
english_phrase: Climbs the cliff like a black crab.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who goes beyond his limit.

hawaiian_phrase: Piʻi nō ka poho, kani kohā!
english_phrase: Up comes the palm — and bang!
meaning_phrase: A good smack. The pounder is moistened by a dampened hand before it is brought down on a mass of hard poi.

hawaiian_phrase: Piʻipiʻi hahai moa.
english_phrase: Curly head followed by chickens.
meaning_phrase: Kahahana was a handsome, curly-haired man who was compared to a fine cock who attracts the attention of the hens. Said of any curly-haired man who has a way with women.

hawaiian_phrase: Pī ka ʻamo.
english_phrase: The anus breaks wind with small sounds.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who lives the life of a drudge. Such a person is said to be too busy to eat a proper meal and as a result has a gassy stomach.

hawaiian_phrase: Pī ka ihu, haʻu i ka makani.
english_phrase: The nose snorts as he puffs at the wind.
meaning_phrase: He is incoherent with anger.

hawaiian_phrase: Pili aʻe ana i ka lāʻau pili wale.
english_phrase: Leans against a leaning tree.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who depends too much on another for support, either materially or morally.

hawaiian_phrase: Pili aloha ʻo Kona, hoʻoipo i ka mālie.
english_phrase: Love remains close to Kona, who woos the calm.
meaning_phrase: Kona is a land beloved for its calm and pleasant weather.

hawaiian_phrase: Pili ka hanu; hāmau ka leo.
english_phrase: Suppress the breath; silence the voice.
meaning_phrase: Be as quiet as possible; utter no sound.

hawaiian_phrase: Pili ka hanu o Wailuku.
english_phrase: Wailuku holds its breath.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is speechless or petrified with either fear or extreme cold. There is a play on luku (destruction). Refers to Wailuku, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Pili kāpekepeke.
english_phrase: Insecure relationship.
meaning_phrase: Signifying an abundance of food. Thrashing about in the water drives fish into the nets.

hawaiian_phrase: Pili kau, pili hoʻoilo.
english_phrase: Together in the dry season, together in the wet season.
meaning_phrase: Said of loving companionship.

hawaiian_phrase: Pili ke kua me ke alo.
english_phrase: The back meets the front.
meaning_phrase: Said of a very thin person.

hawaiian_phrase: Pilikia hoʻi kau a lohe mai.
english_phrase: Troubles that [do not] hear.
meaning_phrase: Serious trouble indeed.

hawaiian_phrase: Pili ʻohā, he kamau mai ma waho.
english_phrase: A taro-offishoot relationship added to the outside of the corm.
meaning_phrase: One who was not a relative, yet is a member of the household.

hawaiian_phrase: Pili pono ka lā i Kamananui.
english_phrase: The sun is very close to Kamananui.
meaning_phrase: A play on Ka-mana-nui (The-great-power). When the person in power becomes angry, everyone around him feels uncomfortable, as in the scorching, blistering sun.

hawaiian_phrase: Pili pono ka lā i Papaʻenaʻena.
english_phrase: The sun concentrates its heat at Papaʻenaʻena.
meaning_phrase: Said of the heat of temper. A play on ʻenaena (red-hot).

hawaiian_phrase: Pili pū i ka paia.
english_phrase: Pressed hard against the wall.
meaning_phrase: Deep in trouble.

hawaiian_phrase: Piliwale ka iʻa o Piliwale.
english_phrase: The fish of Piliwale press together.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who attaches himself to another. Piliwale was a fishpond at Molokaʻi. When fresh sea water came in at the sluice gate the fish pressed together there. Once, a chief on Kauaʻi fled from the battlefield, followed by his pursuers. He found refuge in Maniniholo cave, but his pursuers discovered his place of concealment and entered. He fled, and, seeing a large rock, pressed himself against it with the hope that he would escape detection. But he was seen and killed. The rock against which he pressed himself was called Piliwale.

hawaiian_phrase: Pio ke kukui, pōʻele ka hale.
english_phrase: When the light goes out, the house is dark.
meaning_phrase: Said of one whose sight is gone — he dwells in darkness. Also said when life goes and the darkness of death possesses.

hawaiian_phrase: Pīpī holo kaʻao.
english_phrase: It is sprinkled, the tale has fled.
meaning_phrase: This is used at the end of a tale to indicate that it is finished.

hawaiian_phrase: Pipī ka wahie, hoʻonui ka pulupulu.
english_phrase: If the firewood burns slowly, add more tinder.
meaning_phrase: Keep trying until you succeed.

hawaiian_phrase: Pipili i ka hana makamaka ʻole, hoʻokahi nō makamaka o ke kaunu a ka manaʻo.
english_phrase: Sticks to the work in which friends are ignored; only one friend is considered, the desire of the heart.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is in love and pays no attention to anyone except the object of his affection.

hawaiian_phrase: Pipili mau ʻia e ka pīʻoeʻoe.
english_phrase: Always clung to by barnacles.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is a constant attraction to the opposite sex.

hawaiian_phrase: Pipili no ka pīlali i ke kumu kukui.
english_phrase: The pīlali gum sticks to the kukui tree.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who remains close to a loved one all the time, as a child may cling to the grandparent he loves.

hawaiian_phrase: Pōʻalo maka.
english_phrase: To gouge out the eyes.
meaning_phrase: Said of an ungrateful person who repays kindness with unkindness, especially by stealing a mate.

hawaiian_phrase: Poʻe hoʻohāhā paʻakai.
english_phrase: Salt gatherers.
meaning_phrase: A derogatory expression for people who do nothing that requires courage or stamina. Salt-gathering is an easy task that even a child can do.

hawaiian_phrase: Pōʻele ka ʻāina o Puna.
english_phrase: The land of Puna is blackened [by lava flows].
meaning_phrase: An expression of annoyance toward one who disturbs the night with noise.

hawaiian_phrase: Poʻe no Kūkiʻi.
english_phrase: People of Kūkii.
meaning_phrase: A play on kū (stand) and kiʻi (image). Said of those who stand about and offer no help.

hawaiian_phrase: Pōhai ka manu ma luna, he iʻa ko lalo.
english_phrase: When the birds circle above, there are fish below.
meaning_phrase: Strong words are a sign of wrath. Fishermen at sea watch where the noio birds gather, for that is a sign that the aku fish are near.

hawaiian_phrase: Pōhai ka neki lewa i ka makani.
english_phrase: Surrounded by the reeds that sway in the breeze.
meaning_phrase: Said of one handsome and graceful of movement.

hawaiian_phrase: Pohā i ke alo o Kaʻuiki.
english_phrase: A loud, explosive sound before the presence of Kaʻuiki.
meaning_phrase: Said of the drawing up of an aku fish from the water to the chest of the fisherman.

hawaiian_phrase: Pohā ka ʻauwae i ka ʻala.
english_phrase: A hard rock smacked the chin.
meaning_phrase: He got what was coming.

hawaiian_phrase: Pohā ka lae o ke kolohe.
english_phrase: Slapped was the brow of the mischief maker.
meaning_phrase: The rascal got his just deserts.

hawaiian_phrase: Pohā ke au ke piʻi nei ka lena.
english_phrase: The gall bladder has burst, the yellow color is spreading.
meaning_phrase: It is obvious now that ill will has been harbored.

hawaiian_phrase: Pōhaku ʻai wāwae o Malama.
english_phrase: Feet-eating rocks of Malama.
meaning_phrase: Said of sharp ʻaʻā rocks that make walking with bare feet very painful. This saying comes from a chant by Pa oa, friend of Lohiʻau, who went to Kīlauea to seek his friendʻs lava-encased remains.

hawaiian_phrase: Pōhaku ʻelekū.
english_phrase: A dark lava rock.
meaning_phrase: A dark-skinned person

hawaiian_phrase: Pōhaku kaomi moena.
english_phrase: A stone that holds down the mat.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who stays at home most of the time. A pōhaku kaomi moena is a large smooth stone used to hold the strands of lauhala in place while plaiting.

hawaiian_phrase: Pōhakupili wanawana.
english_phrase: Thorny Pōhakupili.
meaning_phrase: An epithet for the kauā of Pōhakupili, Molokaʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Pohāpohā i ke keiki o Kaʻakēkē.
english_phrase: Smacked by the lad of Kaʻakēkē.
meaning_phrase: Kaʻakēkē was a maika-rolling field at Ualapuʻe, Molokaʻi, where champions often met in ancient days. Said in admiration of any Molokaʻi lad outstanding in sports.

hawaiian_phrase: Pohāpohā ka ihu o ka waʻa i ka ʻale o ka Mumuku.
english_phrase: The prow of the canoe is slapped by the billows in the Mumuku gale.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person buffeted by circumstances or of one who has received many blows by the fist.

hawaiian_phrase: Pō Hilo i ka ua Kanilehua.
english_phrase: Hilo is darkened by the Kanilehua rain.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is weighted by sorrow and grief.

hawaiian_phrase: Pohō i ka mālama i ko haʻi keakea!
english_phrase: A waste of effort to take care of someone elseʻs semen!
meaning_phrase: Usually said in anger by one who cares for the children of another. Also expressed Pohō i ka mālama i ko haʻi kūkae!

hawaiian_phrase: Poho pono nā peʻa heke a kū ana.
english_phrase: A well-filled topsail helped him to arrive.
meaning_phrase: Said of a fast traveler.

hawaiian_phrase: Pohu ka nohona, ua lulu kohekohe.
english_phrase: All is calm, even the kohekohe grass is not moved by a breeze.
meaning_phrase: A person of poisonous nature.

hawaiian_phrase: Pōʻino nā lāʻau aʻa liʻiliʻi i ka ulu pū me ka puakala aʻa loloa.
english_phrase: Plants with fine roots are harmed when left to grow with the rough, long-rooted thorny ones.
meaning_phrase: Weak-willed persons are often overcome and influenced by the wicked.

hawaiian_phrase: "Pokeokeo, pokeokeo," wahi a ka pelehū.
english_phrase: “Gobble, gobble,” says the turkey.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who has received a sizeable sum or is financially secure. A play on pōkeokeo, which refers to the turkeyʻs gobble as well as to a substantial amount of money.

hawaiian_phrase: Pōkiʻi ka ua, ua i ka lehua.
english_phrase: The rain, like a younger brother, remains with the lehua.
meaning_phrase: Said of the rain that clings to the forest where ʻōhiʻa trees grow.

hawaiian_phrase: Pōkole ka naʻau.
english_phrase: The intestine is short.
meaning_phrase: Said of a short-tempered person.

hawaiian_phrase: Poliʻahu, ka wahine kapa hau anu o Mauna Kea.
english_phrase: Poliʻahu, the woman who wears the snow mantle of Mauna Kea.
meaning_phrase: Poliʻahu is the goddess of snows; her home is on Mauna Kea.

hawaiian_phrase: Pololei a ka waha o ke ʻahi.
english_phrase: Straight to the mouth of the ʻahi fish.
meaning_phrase: Directly to the point. Used in a fishermanʻs prayers to the gods to take the hook and bait directly to the mouth of the fish.

hawaiian_phrase: Pō nā maka i ka noe, i ka pahulu i ke ala loa.
english_phrase: The eyes are blinded by the mist that haunts the long trail.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is deceived.

hawaiian_phrase: Poʻohū ka lae i ka ʻalā.
english_phrase: The forehead is swollen by the smooth waterworn stone.
meaning_phrase: The price is so high that it feels like a lump on the forehead. ʻAlā is often used to refer to money.

hawaiian_phrase: Poʻohū ka lae kahi i ka pōhue.
english_phrase: When the forehead lumps, rub it with a gourd.
meaning_phrase: Find the remedy for the problem.

hawaiian_phrase: Pōpoki hūnā kūkae.
english_phrase: Excreta-hiding cat.
meaning_phrase: Usually said in anger of one who wonʻt reveal his own or other peopleʻs wrongdoings.

hawaiian_phrase: Pua aʻela ka uahi o ka moe.
english_phrase: The smoke seen in the dream now rises.
meaning_phrase: The trouble of which we were forewarned is here.

hawaiian_phrase: Puaēa ka manu o Kaʻula i ke kai.
english_phrase: The bird of Kaʻula expires over the sea.
meaning_phrase: Said of utter destruction, as of birds that drop dead while flying over the sea.

hawaiian_phrase: Pua ka lehua.
english_phrase: The lehua is in bloom.
meaning_phrase: Said by the people of Kawaihae when the aku fish appear in schools. It was considered unlucky to speak openly of going fishing.

hawaiian_phrase: Pua ka neneleau, momona ka wana.
english_phrase: When the neneleau blooms, the sea urchin is fat.
meaning_phrase: The neneleau blooms about the time when the hala fruit ripens. These were signs for uplanders that the sea urchins were ready to be gathered.

hawaiian_phrase: Pua ka uahi he ahi ko lalo.
english_phrase: Where smoke rises there is fire below.
meaning_phrase: Where there are strong words the fire of wrath lies beneath.

hawaiian_phrase: Pua ka uahi o kāʻeʻaʻeʻa moku o Hina.
english_phrase: Up rose the smoke of the experts of the island of Hina.
meaning_phrase: Said of the quickness of the athletes of Molokaʻi — they were so fast that they smoked.

hawaiian_phrase: Pua ka uahi o ko a uka, manaʻo ke ola o ko a kai.
english_phrase: When the smoke [from the fires] of the upland dwellers rises, the shore dwellers think of life.
meaning_phrase: Shore dwellers depended on the uplanders for poi.

hawaiian_phrase: Pua ka uahi o Manuokekula.
english_phrase: The smoke of Manuokekula rose.
meaning_phrase: Said when one goes off with all speed. Manuokekula was a steamer in olden days; smoke was seen from her stack as she departed.

hawaiian_phrase: Pua ka wiliwili nanahu ka manō; pua ka wahine uʻi nanahu ke kānāwai.
english_phrase: When the wiliwili tree blooms, the sharks bite; when a pretty woman blossoms, the law bites.
meaning_phrase: A beautiful woman attracts young men — sharks — who become fierce rivals over her. The law prevents the rivalry from getting out of hand — it can “bite.” It is said that when the wiliwili trees are in bloom the sharks bite, because it is their mating season.

hawaiian_phrase: Pua ke kō, kū ka heʻe.
english_phrase: When the sugar cane tassels, the octopus season is here.
meaning_phrase: The sugar cane tassels in late October or early November.

hawaiian_phrase: Pua ke kō, neʻe i ka heʻe hōlua.
english_phrase: When the sugar cane tassels, move to the sledding course.
meaning_phrase: The tops of sugar cane were used as a slippery bedding for the sled to slide on.

hawaiian_phrase: Pua lehua i ka lawaiʻa.
english_phrase: A lehua blossom in fishing.
meaning_phrase: An expert in catching fish.

hawaiian_phrase: Pūʻali kalo i ka wai ʻole.
english_phrase: Taro, for lack of water, grows misshapen.
meaning_phrase: For lack of care one may become ill.

hawaiian_phrase: Pūʻali o Ka-hau-nui ia Ka-hau-iki.
english_phrase: Big-hau-tree has a groove worn into it by Little-hau-tree.
meaning_phrase: Said when a child nearly wears out the patience of the adult in charge of him, or of a large company of warriors discomfited by a small one. Kahaunui and Kahauiki are places just east of Moanalua, Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: Pua mai nei hoʻi ka lehua.
english_phrase: The lehua is blossoming.
meaning_phrase: The faces are red from drinking beer.

hawaiian_phrase: Puanaiea ke kanaka ke hele i ka liʻulā.
english_phrase: A person who goes after a mirage will only wear himself out.
meaning_phrase: Be prepared.

hawaiian_phrase: Pūanuanu ka hale noho ʻole ʻia e ke kanaka.
english_phrase: Cold is an uninhabited house.
meaning_phrase: Said of an empty house, which lacks the warmth of love, or of the body after life is gone.

hawaiian_phrase: Pua ʻohi.
english_phrase: Flower picking.
meaning_phrase: Chitchat.

hawaiian_phrase: Puehu ka hulu o ka manu.
english_phrase: The feathers of the bird are scattered.
meaning_phrase: The person has gone off with haste.

hawaiian_phrase: Puehu ka lehu i nā maka o ka mea luhi.
english_phrase: Ashes fly into the eyes of the toiler.
meaning_phrase: One must endure the unpleasant in order to gain the pleasant, just as the cook at a fireplace gets ashes into his eyes when he blows on the fire.

hawaiian_phrase: Puehu liʻiliʻi ka lehu o kapuahi.
english_phrase: The ashes of the fireplace are scattered in every direction.
meaning_phrase: Said of an angry person whose temper makes everybody scatter.

hawaiian_phrase: Pue i ke anu o Hauaʻiliki.
english_phrase: Crouch in the cold of Hauaʻiliki.
meaning_phrase: Said of an intense cold. A play on hau (ice) and ʻiliki (strike) in the place name Hauaʻiliki.

hawaiian_phrase: Pueo maka ʻalaʻalawa.
english_phrase: Owl with eyes glancing here and there.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who looks about to see what he can steal.

hawaiian_phrase: Pūhā hewa ka honu i ka lā makani.
english_phrase: The turtle breathes at the wrong moment on a windy day.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who says the wrong thing at the wrong time and suffers the result.

hawaiian_phrase: Pūhā ka honu, ua awakea.
english_phrase: When the turtle comes up to breathe, it is daylight.
meaning_phrase: Said when a person yawns. Sleeping time is over; work begins.

hawaiian_phrase: Puhalu ka ihu, nānā i ke kāʻao.
english_phrase: When the scent reaches the nose, one sees the overripe hala fruit [fallen to ihe ground].
meaning_phrase: One only notices the many good things a person does when it is too late to show appreciation.

hawaiian_phrase: Puhi lapa i kaʻale.
english_phrase: Eel active in the sea caverns.
meaning_phrase: Said of an overactive person, like a child with too much energy.

hawaiian_phrase: Puhi niho wakawaka.
english_phrase: An eel with pointed teeth.
meaning_phrase: A fierce and fearless warrior.

hawaiian_phrase: Puhi okaoka.
english_phrase: An eel [that chews] into bits.
meaning_phrase: An epithet applied to a kahuna versed in all branches of kahuna lore. He is not a person to be trifled with.

hawaiian_phrase: Puhipuhi lāʻau a kahuna, ka maunu loaʻa a ka pupuka.
english_phrase: By blowing the medicine given by a kahuna, can the ugly gain his desire.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who resorted to the prayers and ceremonies of a kahuna hana aloha to gain the love of his desired one. The person consulting the kahuna ate pilimai and manulele sugar cane after the kahuna had dedicated them to Makanikeoe, the love god. Then he blew in the direction of the desired person. The god, who also had a wind form, bore the mana along, and when it touched the one desired he or she became very much in love with the sender. When used with evil intent — for revenge or to humiliate — the sender is spoken of as an ugly person who has no charm of his own, hence he must resort to sorcery.

hawaiian_phrase: Puʻipuʻi a ka lawaiʻa.
english_phrase: Stout fishing lad.
meaning_phrase: Said of an energetic fisherman. ʻUmi was so called because of his skill in fishing.

hawaiian_phrase: Pūʻiwa i ka lāʻau pākuʻikuʻi a ka lawaiʻa.
english_phrase: Frightened by the splashing stick of the fisherman.
meaning_phrase: Said of those who are suddenly frightened and flee in panic, like fish driven into the net by the stick that beats the water.

hawaiian_phrase: Puka ka lā, puka pū me ka hana, i ʻike ʻia ka lālā maloʻo me ka lālā maka.
english_phrase: When day arrives, work time arrives too, for it is then that dry branches can be distinguished from green ones.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is caught in wrong-doing and quickly begs pardon to avoid due punishment.

hawaiian_phrase: Puka ka maka i waho, loaʻa ka hale kipa aku, kipa mai.
english_phrase: A [new] face appears out [of the mother], someday to be a host as all visit back and forth.
meaning_phrase: Said of the baby of a relative or friend — it will someday host visiting relatives.

hawaiian_phrase: Pūkākā nā lehua o Mānā, ʻauwana wale iho nō i ka ʻauwai pakī.
english_phrase: Scattered are the warriors of Mānā, who go wandering along the ditch that holds little water.
meaning_phrase: A boast after winning a battle.

hawaiian_phrase: Puka kūkae wai o Kalihi.
english_phrase: Through an anus appears the water of Kalihi.
meaning_phrase: An expression of derision for Kalihi, Honolulu. In Kalihi Stream is a stone that resembles the human backside. When the stream is low, water pours out of the hole. First uttered by a visiting chief.

hawaiian_phrase: Puka maila ʻoe, ua kala kahiko i Lehua.
english_phrase: Now that you have come, [what we had] has long departed to Lehua.
meaning_phrase: Said to one who comes too late to share what his friends have had.

hawaiian_phrase: Puka ma ka ʻapua.
english_phrase: Escaped through the handle.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who barely escapes. Luhia, who was part lizard and part human, used to go outside of the houses of his neighbors to see what they were eating. When he found that they were to have ʻoʻopu fish cooked in ti leaves, he would wait until the flsh were ready to be eaten, then he would cry, “Escape through the handle, my brothers!” The place where the ti leaf bundle was tied would break open, and out would scamper lizards instead of ʻoʻopu fish, to the terror of those who were about to eat. The lizards would then run back to the streams and become ʻoʻopu fish again.

hawaiian_phrase: Pukana wai o Kahuku.
english_phrase: The water outlet of Kahuku.
meaning_phrase: Refers to the outlet of an underground stream that once flowed from Kahuku to Waipahu, Oʻahu.

hawaiian_phrase: Pūkoʻa kani ʻāina.
english_phrase: A hard rock of the land.
meaning_phrase: Said of a strong fighter who destroys others but is himself impossible to destroy.

hawaiian_phrase: Pula kau maka ʻino loa.
english_phrase: A very bad mote in the eye.
meaning_phrase: A person who is much disliked. Pula kau maka denotes something that is constantly on oneʻs mind.

hawaiian_phrase: Puleileho ke kai o Kāʻelo.
english_phrase: A rough sea in the month of Kāʻelo.
meaning_phrase: When the seaweed breaks loose and is borne shoreward, fish that feed on it are drawn there. So a rough sea can be good for the fishermen.

hawaiian_phrase: Pulelo ke ahi haʻaheo i nā pali.
english_phrase: The firebrand soars proudly over the cliffs.
meaning_phrase: An expression of triumph. Referring to the firebrand hurling of Kauaʻi, or to the glow of volcanic fire on Hawaiʻi.

hawaiian_phrase: Pulelo ke ahi o Makuaiki.
english_phrase: The firebrand of Makuaiki rises triumphant.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who rises from obscurity or gains a victory.

hawaiian_phrase: Pulu ʻelo i ka ua Kanilehua.
english_phrase: Drenched in the Kanilehua rain.
meaning_phrase: Drenched by the rain or thoroughly drunk.

hawaiian_phrase: Pulu ʻelo i ka ua o ka hoʻoilo.
english_phrase: Drenched by winter s rain.
meaning_phrase: Filled with grief.

hawaiian_phrase: Pulu ihola i ka wai a ka nāulu.
english_phrase: Drenched by the water from the rain clouds.
meaning_phrase: Drunk.

hawaiian_phrase: Pulu i ka wai lohi o Maleka.
english_phrase: Soaked by the sparkling water of America.
meaning_phrase: Drunk.

hawaiian_phrase: Pulu i ka wai naoa a ke kēhau.
english_phrase: Wet by the icy cold dew.
meaning_phrase: Drunk.

hawaiian_phrase: Pulupulu ahi.
english_phrase: A fire-starter.
meaning_phrase: Said of one whose temper flares easily.

hawaiian_phrase: Pumehana ka hale i ka noho ʻia e ka makua.
english_phrase: Warm is the home in which a parent lives.
meaning_phrase: A friendly exterior only.

hawaiian_phrase: Puna, ʻāina ʻawa lau o ka manu.
english_phrase: Puna, land of the leafed ʻawa planted by the birds.
meaning_phrase: Punaluʻu, Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi, is said to be the place where the sea dances to delight visitors.

hawaiian_phrase: Puna, kai nehe i ka ulu hala.
english_phrase: Puna, where the sea murmurs to the hala grove.
meaning_phrase: Gone to get nehu for bait. Gone to get her man; that is, gone to get the bait that will get him.

hawaiian_phrase: Punaluʻu, i ke kai kau haʻa a ka malihini.
english_phrase: Punaluu, where the sea dances for the visitors.
meaning_phrase: Punaluʻu, Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi, is said to be the place where the sea dances to delight visitors.

hawaiian_phrase: Puna, mai ʻOkiʻokiaho a Mawae.
english_phrase: Puna, from ʻOkiʻokiaho to Mawae.
meaning_phrase: The extent of Puna is from ʻOkiʻokiaho on the Kaʻū side to Mawae on the Hilo side.

hawaiian_phrase: Puna maka kōkala.
english_phrase: Puna of the eyelashes that curve upward like the thorns of the pandanus leaves.
meaning_phrase: The placenta of a newborn was buried under a pandanus tree so the childʻs eyelashes would grow long like the pandanus thorns.

hawaiian_phrase: Puna paia ʻala i ka hala.
english_phrase: Puna, with walls fragrant with pandanus blossoms.
meaning_phrase: Puna, Hawaiʻi, is a place of hala and lehua forests. In olden days the people would stick the bracts of hala into the thatching of their houses to bring some of the fragrance indoors.

hawaiian_phrase: Pūʻolo waimaka a ke aloha.
english_phrase: Tears [are] bundles of love.
meaning_phrase: Love brings tears to the eyes.

hawaiian_phrase: Pupuhi ka heʻe o kai uli.
english_phrase: The octopus of the deep spews its ink [into the water].
meaning_phrase: Said of one who goes off in secret or on an errand that rouses unsatisfied curiosity in others. The octopus escapes from its foes by spewing its ink and darkening the water.

hawaiian_phrase: Pupuhi ka iʻa o Ukoʻa.
english_phrase: The fish of Ukoʻa is gone.
meaning_phrase: Ukoʻa is a famous pond in Waialua, Oʻahu. Said of one who takes flight or of something quickly and secretly taken.

hawaiian_phrase: Pupuhi ka ʻulu o Keʻei; ua koe ka ʻaʻaiole.
english_phrase: The breadfruit of Keʻei are gone; only those blown down by the wind are left.
meaning_phrase: Said when something mysteriously vanishes. A konohiki of Keʻei in Kona, Hawaiʻi, was placed in charge of a fine breadfruit grove. In spite of his watchfulness, the fruit were stolen as soon as they matured. Secretly he asked all of his relatives to help him watch for the culprit. However, some were related to the thief as well, who learned about the watch and evaded capture. Long after, a slip of the tongue revealed the thief.

hawaiian_phrase: Pupuhi ka umu, moʻa pala ka ʻai.
english_phrase: When the umu smokes, the food is underdone.
meaning_phrase: Not enough steam remains inside to cook the food. Said of one who does a lot of enthusiastic talking but canʻt knuckle down to business.

hawaiian_phrase: Pupuhi kukui — malino ke kai.
english_phrase: Spewed kukui nuts — calm sea.
meaning_phrase: To calm the water, fishermen chewed kukui nuts and spewed them. It has the same meaning as, “Pour oil on troubled waters.”

hawaiian_phrase: Pupuhi kukui o Papalaua, he ʻino.
english_phrase: Light the candle of Papalaua, the weather is had.
meaning_phrase: Said of Papalaua, Molokaʻi, where the sun shines for only part of the day. When the weather was bad the valley became dark before the day was gone, and candles had to be lighted. Sometimes said facetiously when a day is gloomy and a light is required to see.

hawaiian_phrase: Pupuka auaneʻi, he inoa ʻala.
english_phrase: Homely he may be, but his name is fragrant.
meaning_phrase: He bears an honorable name.

hawaiian_phrase: Pūpūkahi i holomua.
english_phrase: Unite in order to progress.
meaning_phrase: A powerful warrior. The niuhi shark was dreaded because of its ferociousness. It was believed that a chief or warrior who captured this vicious denizen of the deep would acquire something of its nature.

hawaiian_phrase: Pupu ke kai i ka ʻalalauwā.
english_phrase: The sea is so thick with ʻalalauwā fish that it is difficult to make a passage.
meaning_phrase: Said of a situation where it is difficult to make progress.

hawaiian_phrase: Pupule puhi ahi.
english_phrase: Crazy person who sets fires.
meaning_phrase: A humorous expression applied to one with an overabundance of energy who does just as he pleases without fear of being criticized. Such a person has so much generosity that he is likeable, even if he sometimes goes to extremes.

hawaiian_phrase: Pupuʻu hoʻolei loa, a noho ana!
english_phrase: A humping up and a fling, and there he was!
meaning_phrase: Said of one who traveled very swiftly — as though he had flung himself through the air.

hawaiian_phrase: Pūpū wahi kūʻōʻō ka mahiʻai o uka, ola nō ia kini he mahiʻai na ka ʻōiwi.
english_phrase: When the upland farmer gathers small, broken sweet potatoes there is life for many, though he only farms for himself.
meaning_phrase: A farmer shares with beach dwellers.

hawaiian_phrase: Puʻua i ka hala o Kekaha.
english_phrase: Choked on the hala fruit of Kekaha.
meaning_phrase: Pregnant.

hawaiian_phrase: Puʻu auaneʻi ka lae i ka ua o Kawaupuʻu.
english_phrase: The forehead may he given a lump hy the rain of Kawaupuu.
meaning_phrase: One is likely to get into trouble.

hawaiian_phrase: Puʻupuʻu lei pali i ka ʻāʻī.
english_phrase: An imperfect lei, beautifed by wearing.
meaning_phrase: Even an imperfect lei looks beautiful when worn around the neck — as beautiful as flowers and greenery on the slope of a hill.

hawaiian_phrase: Puʻuwai hao kila.
english_phrase: Heart of steel.
meaning_phrase: Fearless.

hawaiian_phrase: Pū wā iʻa nā hoa makani.
english_phrase: The wind companions cause a commotion among the fishes.
meaning_phrase: Oneʻs conduct causes a scandal.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua ahu ka imu, e lāwalu ka iʻa.
english_phrase: The oven is ready, let the fish wrapped in ti leaves be cooked.
meaning_phrase: All preparations have been made; now let us proceed with the work.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua ʻai au i kāna loaʻa.
english_phrase: I have eaten of his gain.
meaning_phrase: Said with pride and affection by a parent or grandparent who is being cared for by the child he reared.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua ʻai i ke kāī-koi o ʻEwa.
english_phrase: He has eaten the kāī-koi taro of ʻEwa.
meaning_phrase: Kāī is Oʻahu’s best eating taro; one who has eaten it will always like it. Said of a youth or a maiden of ʻEwa, who, like the kāī taro, is not easily forgotten.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua ʻailolo.
english_phrase: Eaten the brain.
meaning_phrase: Said of an expert, or of anyone who is well trained in an art.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua aʻo a ua ʻailolo.
english_phrase: He trained until he ate brains.
meaning_phrase: He became an expert. In ancient days, the person who finished a course of study ate some of the brain of the hog or fish offered to the god of his art.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua aʻo Hawaiʻi ke ʻōlino nei mālamalama.
english_phrase: Hawaiʻi is enlightened, for the brightness of day is here.
meaning_phrase: Hawaiʻi is in an era of education.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua ʻawa ka luna o Uwēkahuna.
english_phrase: Bitterly cold are the heights of Uwēkahuna.
meaning_phrase: Said of the wrath of a chief. From a chant by Lohiʻau when he saw the wrath of Pele as she sought to destroy him.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua ʻeha ka ʻili i ka maka o ka ihe.
english_phrase: The skin has been hurt by the point of the spear.
meaning_phrase: Said of a warrior who has been wounded in war. This was said with pride and affection, for it meant that he had been faithful to his chief.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua ʻelepaio ʻia ka hana.
english_phrase: The work has [been spoiled by an] ʻelepaio.
meaning_phrase: Said of any task that has to stop before completion. The ʻelepaio is always the first of the birds to awaken and call, thus telling the supernatural workers of the night, such as the menehune, that day approaches. Any incomplete work is then deserted.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua ʻelepaio ʻia ka waʻa.
english_phrase: The ʻelepaio has [marked] the canoe [log].
meaning_phrase: There is an indication of failure. Canoe makers of old watched the movements of the ʻelepaio bird whenever a koa tree was hewed down to be made into a canoe. Should the bird peck at the wood, it was useless to work on that log, for it would not prove seaworthy.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua hala ka hoʻoilo, ua mālie.
english_phrase: Winter is gone; all is calm.
meaning_phrase: Trouble is gone; peace now abides.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua hala ka ʻino, ua kau ka mālie.
english_phrase: The storm has passed; calmness is here.
meaning_phrase: A weather sign.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua hala ka wawā i Hāʻupu.
english_phrase: The loud talking has gone to Haupu.
meaning_phrase: The gossip is now widespread.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua hānau ʻia paha i Nana, ke māʻau ala.
english_phrase: Perhaps he was born in Nana, for he wanders about.
meaning_phrase: In the month of Nana, fledglings left the nests.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua heʻe i ka ua o ka Hoʻoilo.
english_phrase: Routed by the wintery rain.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who fled from an unpleasant situation.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua hihina wale i Moeawakea.
english_phrase: Fallen down at Moeawakea.
meaning_phrase: A play on the place name Moe-awakea (Sleep-at-noon). A humorous saying applied to those who fall asleep in the daytime or pass out in a drunken stupor.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua hiki maila ʻo Keʻinohoʻomanawanui.
english_phrase: Keʻinohoʻomanawanui has arrived.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is disliked because of his trouble-making. This is a play on ʻino (bad). Ke-ʻino-hoʻomanawanui (Patient-bad-fellow) is a character in the legend, “Opele-ka-moemoe” (Opele-the-sleepy-head).

hawaiian_phrase: Ua hiki ʻole ka ihu o ka puaʻa ke ʻeku a peu.
english_phrase: The snout of the hog can no longer root and prod.
meaning_phrase: Said of a man who has lost his sexual potency.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua hilo ʻia i ke aho a ke aloha.
english_phrase: Braided with the cords of love.
meaning_phrase: Held in the bond of affection.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua hoʻi ka noio ʻau kai i uka, ke ʻino nei ka moana.
english_phrase: The seafaring noio bird returns to land, for a storm rages at sea.
meaning_phrase: A weather sign.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua hoʻi ka ʻōpua i Awalua.
english_phrase: The cloud has returned to Awalua.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who has gone home.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua hoʻi ka ʻōpū o ka honua.
english_phrase: Returned to the womb of the earth.
meaning_phrase: Dead.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua hoʻomakua ka lāʻau.
english_phrase: The plant has become a tree.
meaning_phrase: Said of a habit that might once have been easily overcome but has now gained a good stronghold.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua hopu hewa i ka uouoa.
english_phrase: Accidentally caught an uouoa fish.
meaning_phrase: A play on uō (to howl). Said of one who has gotten himself into something distressing.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua ʻia kāua e ka ua; hikikiʻi kāua i kānana!
english_phrase: We are rained upon by the rain; let it pour as it wills!
meaning_phrase: Two men were traveling in the mountains on Kaua’i when it began to rain. The first man found a small dry place under an overhanging rock. The second man’s place leaked, and so he cried out these words. Hearing this, the first man was lured away from his dry rock and ran toward his companion, who sneaked under the dry place and rested. The first man now stood shivering in the rain. This saying is used when someone is foolish enough to give up what he has.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua Ikapoka, ua hala ka nani o ka Ikelaʻela.
english_phrase: It is Ichabod, for the glory of Israel has departed.
meaning_phrase: It is too late to do anything about it. Also expressed simply Ua Ikapoka.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua ʻike nō kā he hewa ke wikiwiki lā ka waha i ka mihi.
english_phrase: He knows it is wrong so the mouth hastens to repent.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is caught in wrong-doing and quickly begs pardon to avoid due punishment.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua ʻike paha i ka makapaʻa.
english_phrase: Perhaps he saw a one-eyed person.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who meets with bad luck. It is considered unlucky to meet a blind person on one’s way.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua kaʻa ʻia e Hakaio.
english_phrase: Rolled over by Hakaio.
meaning_phrase: Said of a woman with a beautiful figure. Hakaio was the name of a supematural tapa beater that rolled itself over the legendary heroine Keamalu to beautify her figure after her bath.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua kaʻa niniau i ka wili wai.
english_phrase: Swirled about by the eddying waters.
meaning_phrase: Dizzy from being madly in love. Also, intoxicated.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua kāhea kua ʻia.
english_phrase: Called just after he started to depart.
meaning_phrase: It was considered an omen of disappointment to be called back just after starting out.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua kanaka.
english_phrase: Is with a person.
meaning_phrase: Pregnant.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua ka ua i Papakōlea, ihea ʻoe?
english_phrase: When it rained in Papakōlea, where were you ?
meaning_phrase: The reply of a sweet-potato grower on Papakōlea to one who asks for some of his crop. If one answered that he had been there when the rain fell to soak the earth for planting, and had not planted, then he was lazy and would be given no potatoes.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua ka ua, kahe ka wai.
english_phrase: The rain rains, the water flows.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who has attained a high position. Used in hula chants and songs.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua ka ua, ola ka nohona o ka ʻāina kula.
english_phrase: The rain pours, life comes to the plains.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who has attained a high position. Used in hula chants and songs.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua kau i ka hano hāweo.
english_phrase: Reached the peak of honors.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who has attained a high position. Used in hula chants and songs.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua kau ka mauli lele i ka muku.
english_phrase: Life is placed where it can take only a brief flight.
meaning_phrase: Said of a hopeless situation in which there is only a brief respite, then disaster or death.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua kohu ke kaunu ana i Waialoha.
english_phrase: Lovemaking at Waialoha is suitable.
meaning_phrase: The match is good; the course of true love should be encouraged.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua kū i kahi hāiki.
english_phrase: Standing in a narrow place.
meaning_phrase: Said of one in a precarious position.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua kuluma ke kanaka i ke aloha.
english_phrase: Love is a customary virtue with man.
meaning_phrase: Man encounters love daily.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua laʻi ka makani Hoʻolua.
english_phrase: The Hoʻolua gale has calmed.
meaning_phrase: One’s wrath has ceased. Also, the trouble is now passed.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua laʻi ka nohona i ke alo pali.
english_phrase: There is tranquility before the face of the cliff.
meaning_phrase: Perfect peace.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻUala liʻiliʻi o Kalepolepo.
english_phrase: Small potatoes from Kalepolepo.
meaning_phrase: Said of a stupid person.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻUala neʻeneʻe o Kohala.
english_phrase: Neʻeneʻe potato of Kohala.
meaning_phrase: A person who hangs around constantly. Neʻeneʻe, a variety of sweet potato, also means “to move up closer.”

hawaiian_phrase: Ua laulau.
english_phrase: Is a wrapper.
meaning_phrase: Said of a pregnant woman. She is the wrapper of the new life within her.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua lawa pono nā poʻohiwi.
english_phrase: The shoulders are well supplied.
meaning_phrase: Said of a strong person who can do any kind of hard work.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua lehulehu a manomano ka ʻikena a ka Hawaiʻi.
english_phrase: Great and numerous is the knowledge of the Hawaiians.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is distracted by an insignificant matter or goes away on any excuse.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua lele ka manu i Kahiki.
english_phrase: The bird has flown to Kahiki.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who has gone somewhere and cannot be found.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua lilo i kai kuewa nā kai kapu i hoʻomalu ʻia.
english_phrase: The protected sea [shores] have become sea [shores] for wanderers.
meaning_phrase: Cherished daughters have been led astray.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua lilo i ke koli kukui a maluhi.
english_phrase: Gone lamp-trimming until tired.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who has gone on an all-night spree. When the top kukui nut on a candle was bumed out, it was knocked off and the next nut on the stick allowed to burn.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua lilo me ka iʻa o ka lauwiliwili.
english_phrase: Gone off with a fish called lauwiliwili.
meaning_phrase: A play on lauwili (confusing). Said of one who is confused or befuddled.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua lilo paha i ke kini o Waiʻāpuka.
english_phrase: Taken, perhaps by the inhabitants of Waiʻāpuka.
meaning_phrase: A play on ’āpuka (to cheat) in the place name Wai’āpuka. Said when someone has been cheated of his possessions.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua loaʻa akula ka iʻa o ka ʻūʻū.
english_phrase: The ʻūʻū fish is now caught.
meaning_phrase: A play on ʻū (to sigh or grieve) in the name of the fish. One now has cause to grieve.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua loaʻa i ka heu o ka pānini.
english_phrase: Caught by the fuzz of the cactus fruit.
meaning_phrase: Has something to be irritated about.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua lohaloha nā hulu ʻekekeu i pili paʻa i ke kēpau.
english_phrase: The wing feathers [of the bird] droop, because the bird is caught by [the snarer’s] gum.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is caught in mischief.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua loha nā hui o Hāʻupu.
english_phrase: The flippers of Hāʻupu droop.
meaning_phrase: Said poetically of an aged person. The ridges on both sides of Hā’upu hill on Kaua’i go down gradually, with a rise here and there, but none is as high as Hā’upu itself.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua lupeʻa ʻia i ka wai ʻona.
english_phrase: Fully possessed by liquor.
meaning_phrase: Dead drunk.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua mālie, ke au nei koaʻe.
english_phrase: The weather is clear, the koaʻe are leisurely flying.
meaning_phrase: All is peaceful now, for wrath is gone.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua malino ke kai o Paikaka.
english_phrase: The sea of Paikaka is calm.
meaning_phrase: All is peaceful now, for wrath is gone.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua maloʻo ka pua hue.
english_phrase: The gourd blossom has withered.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person withered with age.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua maloʻo ka wai.
english_phrase: The water is dried up.
meaning_phrase: Said of inhospitality.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua mau ke ea o ka ʻāina i ka pono.
english_phrase: The life of the land is preserved in righteousness.
meaning_phrase: A favorite joke uttered when a black-skinned person is seen.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua moʻa ka maiʻa, he keiki māmā ka Hina.
english_phrase: The bananas are cooked, [and remember that] Hina has a swift son.
meaning_phrase: Let’s finish this before we are caught. This saying comes from the legend of Māui and the mudhens. For a long time he tried to catch them in order to learn the secret of making fire. One day he overheard one of them saying these words. He caught them before they could hide and forced them to yield the secret of fire.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua nahā nā moku.
english_phrase: Broken away are the islands.
meaning_phrase: Said when the islands are out of sight.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua nā ka lua o ka inaina.
english_phrase: The pit of wrath is satisfied.
meaning_phrase: Said when one has had enough to eat.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua nīkiʻi ʻia i ke olonā o Honopū.
english_phrase: Tied fast with the olonā cord of Honopū.
meaning_phrase: Honopū, Kaua’i, was said to produce excellent olonā in ancient days.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua noa ke kai kapu, ua ʻaʻe ʻia e ke kuewa.
english_phrase: The forbidden sea has heen trespassed by a vagrant.
meaning_phrase: Said of a girl well raised by her parents who has now been won by a ne’er-do-well.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua noi i ke ao ua ʻole.
english_phrase: Asked a rainless cloud.
meaning_phrase: Asked a favor of a hard person who refused to grant it. First uttered by Hi’iaka, who asked two surly lizard gods to permit her and her friends to cross Wailuku River in Hilo. The request was refused and battle was offered instead.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua ola loko i ke aloha.
english_phrase: Love gives life within.
meaning_phrase: Love is imperative to one’s mental and physical welfare.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua ola nō i ka pane a ke aloha.
english_phrase: There is life in a kindly reply.
meaning_phrase: Though one may have no gift to offer to a friend, a kind word or a friendly greeting is just as important.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua ola nō ʻo kai iā kai.
english_phrase: Shore dwellers find subsistence in the sea.
meaning_phrase: A fisherman lives by his own efforts. This thought uttered by a farmer is Ua ola nō ʻo uka iā uka.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua paʻa ka houpo.
english_phrase: The diaphragm is made firm.
meaning_phrase: Hunger is gone and the stomach is filled.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua paʻa ka ʻīlio i ka ʻōhao.
english_phrase: The dog is tied by the neck.
meaning_phrase: All is safe.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua pae i kula.
english_phrase: Landed ashore.
meaning_phrase: The work is all done.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua pae ka waʻa i Nānāwale.
english_phrase: The canoe landed at Nānāwale.
meaning_phrase: Said of disappointment. To dream of a canoe is a sign of bad luck. A play on nānā-wale (merely look [around at nothing]).

hawaiian_phrase: Ua paʻi a paʻi ma ka hana.
english_phrase: Equals in working.
meaning_phrase: One’s wrongdoings exceeded the the limit. Also, one was fed up.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua pā kanaka.
english_phrase: Touched by man.
meaning_phrase: Said of a girl who has lost her virginity.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua pale ka pono.
english_phrase: Success was warded off.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who has failed.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua pau koʻu lihi hoihoi i ka nani o Poka ʻAilana.
english_phrase: I havent the slightest interest in the beauty of Ford Island.
meaning_phrase: Said when one has lost interest. This is a line from a chant.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua piha a hū ke kīʻaha.
english_phrase: The glass was filled to overflowing.
meaning_phrase: One’s wrongdoings exceeded the the limit. Also, one was fed up.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua piʻi paha i ka ʻulu o Maunawili.
english_phrase: Gone up, perhaps, to fetch the breadfruit of Maunawili.
meaning_phrase: A play on wili (twist, turn about). Said of one who is confused.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua pili ka manu i ke kēpau.
english_phrase: The bird was caught by the gum.
meaning_phrase: The one desired has been snared.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua pio ke kukui.
english_phrase: The light is extinguished.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who has fallen asleep and is no longer aware of anything.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua poʻeleʻele, e nalowale ai ka ʻili o kānaka.
english_phrase: [It is] so dark that the skin of people vanishes.
meaning_phrase: Signifying an abundance of food. Thrashing about in the water drives fish into the nets.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua puka a maka.
english_phrase: Face is seen in the world.
meaning_phrase: Said of a child who by his birth cements the relationship of his father’s family with his mother’s. As long as the child lives, the families recognize their kinship with each other.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua puʻu.
english_phrase: Lumped.
meaning_phrase: An impolite epithet for one who is pregnant.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua ʻuo ʻia a paʻa.
english_phrase: Tied fast together.
meaning_phrase: Married. ʻUo is to tie feathers together in preparation for lei making.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua wela ka lā, ke ʻoni nei kukuna o ka hāʻukeʻuke.
english_phrase: The sun is too warm, for the spikes of the hāʻukeʻuke are moving.
meaning_phrase: Anger is growing, and those near the angry one are moving out of the way. The hauke’uke is a sea urchin.

hawaiian_phrase: Ua wela ka nuku o Nuʻuanu i ka hole ʻia e ke āhole.
english_phrase: Heated is the Nuuanu gap, by the āhole fish that go to and fro.
meaning_phrase: A vulgar expression referring to sexual intercourse.

hawaiian_phrase: Uha nui.
english_phrase: Big gut.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who lacks strength or stamina. His only bigness is a gut filled with food.

hawaiian_phrase: Uhi mai ka lani pō.
english_phrase: Darkness from the sky spreads out.
meaning_phrase: Ignorance grows.

hawaiian_phrase: Uhiuhi lau māmane ka wai o Kapāpala.
english_phrase: Covered with māmane leaves is the water of Kapāpala.
meaning_phrase: The stream in Kapāpala, Kaʻū, often becomes very muddy. The people used to place māmane branches in the water to help the mud settle so that some drinking water could be obtained. This saying applies to a person who tries to cover up the wrongdoings of another.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻUʻina ka wai o Nāmolokama.
english_phrase: The water of Nāmolokama falls with a rumble.
meaning_phrase: Nāmolokama Falls, Kauaʻi, is famous in chants and songs.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻUʻina pōhaku a Kāne.
english_phrase: The stone of Kāne rolled with a rumble.
meaning_phrase: Said of thunder.

hawaiian_phrase: Uʻi nō ke kanaka; maikaʻi nō ka ʻōlelo.
english_phrase: Handsome is the man; good are his words.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is both good-looking and courteous.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻUkuliʻi ka pua, onaona i ka mauʻu.
english_phrase: Tiny is the flower, yet it scents the grasses around it.
meaning_phrase: Said of a small person who gives happiness to others.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻŪlili alualu huʻa kai.
english_phrase: Wandering tattler that chases after sea foam.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who runs here and there for trivial things.

hawaiian_phrase: Uliuli kai holo ka manō.
english_phrase: Where the sea is dark, sharks swim.
meaning_phrase: Sharks are found in the deep sea. Also applied to men out seeking the society of the opposite sex.

hawaiian_phrase: Uliuli kai pali o Kahikinui, kokolo mai ka ʻohu he ʻino.
english_phrase: Dark are the sea cliffs of Kahikinui; when the mists creep, it is a sign of a storm.
meaning_phrase: Trouble is approaching. This is taken from a chant in the legend of Pāmano, who saw his own death approaching.

hawaiian_phrase: Ulu ka hoi.
english_phrase: The hoi vine grows.
meaning_phrase: There is interest in what is going on. A play on hoihoi (interest).

hawaiian_phrase: Ulu kukui o kaukaweli.
english_phrase: Kukui grove of terror.
meaning_phrase: Sometimes mentioned in connection with Lahainaluna School, where this grove was found. It was so called because of the short temper of the Reverend John Pogue, an instructor, and because of the skeletons stored in a nearby building for the study of anatomy. It was in this grove that hō’ike, exhibitions of what students had learned, were held.

hawaiian_phrase: Ulu kukui o Lilikoʻi.
english_phrase: Kukui grove of Lilikoʻi.
meaning_phrase: This kukui grove, in Makawao, Maui, was much visited by travelers, for it was a favorite spot of the chiefs. The nuts gathered from the trees produced a fragrant, tasty relish.

hawaiian_phrase: Ulu o ka lā.
english_phrase: Growth of the sun.
meaning_phrase: Said of the light of sunrise just as the sun’s rim touches the horizon.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻUlu pilo.
english_phrase: Stinking breadfruit.
meaning_phrase: A term of contempt for the kauā of Puna, Hawaiʻi, comparing them to rotted breadfruit.

hawaiian_phrase: Umauma nahā.
english_phrase: Broken chest.
meaning_phrase: A hunger that causes discomfort.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻUme i ka ihu.
english_phrase: Pulls on the nose.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who weeps with disappointment. With the flowing of tears, the nose runs.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻUmeke piha wai o Mānā.
english_phrase: A calabash full of water is Mānā.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Mānā, Kauaʻi, whieh is flooded during the rainy season.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻUmia ka hanu.
english_phrase: Hold the breath.
meaning_phrase: Be patient. Don’t give up too easily.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻUmia ka hanu! Hoʻokahi ka umauma ke kīpoʻohiwi i ke kīpoʻohiwi.
english_phrase: Hold the breath! Walk abreast, shoulder to shoulder.
meaning_phrase: Be of one accord, as in exerting every effort to lift a heavy weight to the shoulder and to keep together in carrying it along.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻUmi ka hanu i ka houpo.
english_phrase: Hold back the breath in the chest.
meaning_phrase: Bear with utmost patience.

hawaiian_phrase: “Unele! Unele!” wahi a ka nēnē.
english_phrase: “Honk! Honk!” says the goose.
meaning_phrase: A play on nele (a lack, poverty), this saying implies a going without, a lack of success, chagrin, and so forth.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻUnu mai a hoʻonuʻanuʻa ke kilu o Kalamaʻula, hoʻoleʻaleʻa i ke kaha o Kaunalewa.
english_phrase: Bring all the kilu for amusement at Kalamaʻula to make merry on the field of Kaunalewa.
meaning_phrase: To come together for a gay time and bring whatever you have to add to the fun. There is a play on lewa, whieh refers to the swinging of the hips in hula.

hawaiian_phrase: Unu pehi ʻiole.
english_phrase: Pebble to pelt rats with.
meaning_phrase: A person of no consequence.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻUo ʻia i ka mānai hoʻokahi.
english_phrase: Strung [like flowers] on the same lei needle.
meaning_phrase: Married.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻUpepe maʻi nui.
english_phrase: Flat nose [but] big genitals.
meaning_phrase: The humorous retort of a man who is called flat-nosed.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻUpu mai nei ke aloha.
english_phrase: A sudden yearning to see a loved one.
meaning_phrase: Said of those who do the dirty work by which others reap the benefit.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻUʻuku ka hana, ʻuʻuku ka loaʻa.
english_phrase: Little work, little gain.
meaning_phrase: When one does little work, he should expect little gain.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻUʻuku nō ka ʻuwiki, pipī nō ka ʻā ana.
english_phrase: When the wick is small it gives a tiny light.
meaning_phrase: When one does little work, he should expect little gain.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻUā a haʻalele wale.
english_phrase: Shouted till they left off.
meaning_phrase: Shouted themselves hoarse.

hawaiian_phrase: Uē ka hoʻi ka naonao iā ʻoe!
english_phrase: So the ants will cry for you!
meaning_phrase: A sarcastic remark meaning, “You think you are so important that even the ants will cry for you.”

hawaiian_phrase: Uē ka lani, ola ka honua.
english_phrase: When the sky weeps, the earth lives.
meaning_phrase: When it rains the earth revives.

hawaiian_phrase: Uene ke kolopā.
english_phrase: The crowbar lifts quickly.
meaning_phrase: The effort is a success.

hawaiian_phrase: Uē ʻo Kānepūniu i ka wela a ka lā.
english_phrase: Kānepūniu complains of the heat of the sun.
meaning_phrase: Said when someone complains of the heat. From a chant by Hiʻiaka, who saw Kāne-pūniu (Kāne-of-the-coconut), a supernatural tree at Wai’anae, O’ahu, on a very warm day.

hawaiian_phrase: Uē waimaka.
english_phrase: Cry tears.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who weeps with unhappiness.

hawaiian_phrase: ʻUī ka niho o ka ʻiole.
english_phrase: The rat gnashes the teeth.
meaning_phrase: The culprit has been caught and put where he can do nothing more than gnash his teeth.

hawaiian_phrase: Waʻawaʻa-iki-i-ka-naʻauao; Waʻawaʻa-iki-i-ka-naʻaupō.
english_phrase: Little-clever-fool; Little-stupid-fool.
meaning_phrase: The Wa’awaʻa brothers are characters in a series of stories that contrast the stupidity of one brother with the cleverness of the other.

hawaiian_phrase: Wae aku i ka lani.
english_phrase: Let the selecting be done in heaven.
meaning_phrase: Take life as it comes.

hawaiian_phrase: Wae ʻia aʻela ma ka liko, koe no ka lāʻele.
english_phrase: Only the leafbuds are selected and the coarse leaves left behind.
meaning_phrase: Only the select few were invited.

hawaiian_phrase: Waha koʻu.
english_phrase: Clucking mouth.
meaning_phrase: One who talks too much.

hawaiian_phrase: Waha lama ʻoe, puʻu mai ka waha i waho.
english_phrase: You are rum-mouthed; the mouth protrudes.
meaning_phrase: Said to one who talks as foolishly as a drunkard.

hawaiian_phrase: Waha okooko.
english_phrase: A slanderous, venomous mouth.
meaning_phrase: Before one feels elated and makes plans he should first secure his “fish.”

hawaiian_phrase: Wāhi ka niu.
english_phrase: Break open the coconut.
meaning_phrase: The breaking open of a young fresh coconut for the gods was a sign of piety in ancient times.

hawaiian_phrase: Wāhine hulu pelehū.
english_phrase: Turkey-feathered women.
meaning_phrase: Prostitutes who carry on with sailors in order to obtain finery to adorn themselves.

hawaiian_phrase: Waiakea pepeiao pulu ʻaha.
english_phrase: Waiakea of the ears that hold coconut-fiber snares.
meaning_phrase: Snares for small fish, shrimp, or crabs were made of a coconut midrib and the fiber from the husk of the nut. When not in use the snare was sometimes placed behind the ear as one does a pencil. This saying is applied to one who will not heed — he uses his ears only to hold his snare.

hawaiian_phrase: Waialua, ʻāina kū pālua i ka laʻi.
english_phrase: Waialua, land that stands doubly becalmed.
meaning_phrase: Said in admiration for Waialua, O’ahu, where the weather was usually pleasant and the life of the people tranquil.

hawaiian_phrase: Wai ʻapu lau kī.
english_phrase: Water in a ti-leaf cup.
meaning_phrase: When one goes to the upland and needs a cup to dip water from the stream or spring, he folds a ti leaf to form a dipper.

hawaiian_phrase: Waiehu, mai ka pali o Kapulehua a ka pali o ʻAʻalaloa.
english_phrase: Waiehu, from the cliff of Kapulehua to the cliff of ʻAʻalaloa.
meaning_phrase: The boundaries of the district of Waiehu, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Waiho akāka ke kula o Kaiolohia.
english_phrase: The plain of Kaiolohia lies in full view.
meaning_phrase: Said of something obvious.

hawaiian_phrase: Waiho i Kaea ka iwi o kamahele.
english_phrase: Left in Kaea, the bones of the traveler.
meaning_phrase: The two sisters Kihalaninui and Kapapakuʻialiʻi went to Hawai’i to seek Konakaimehalaʻi, the husband of the former. They took with them a small daughter of Kihalaninui and a wooden image named Pili. They landed at Pololū in Kohala and went to Kahuwā, where the child died. There the child and the image were laid away together. īn lamenting, Kapapakuʻialiʻi cried these words. This saying is now applied to anyone who dies away from his homeland.

hawaiian_phrase: Waiho kāhelahela o Kalaupapa.
english_phrase: Kalaupapa lies in full view.
meaning_phrase: Said of anything that is very obvious or lies exposed.

hawaiian_phrase: Waiho kāhela i ka laʻi a ahiahi ehuehu mai.
english_phrase: There he lies in the calm, but when evening comes he will he full of animation.
meaning_phrase: He is quiet now, but by and by you’ll find him full of life.

hawaiian_phrase: Waiho wale kahiko.
english_phrase: Ancients exposed.
meaning_phrase: Old secrets are now revealed.

hawaiian_phrase: Waikahi o Mānā.
english_phrase: The single water of Mānā.
meaning_phrase: When schools of ’ōpelu and kawakawa appeared at Mānā, Kaua’i, news soon reached other places like Makaweli, Waimea, Kekaha, and Poki’i. The uplanders hurried to the canoe landing at Keanapuka with loads of poi and other upland products to exchange for fish. After the trading was finished, the fishermen placed their unmixed poi in a large container and poured in enough water to mix a whole batch at once. It didn’t matter if the mass was somewhat lumpy, for the delicious taste of fresh fish and the hunger of the men made the poi vanish. This single pouring of water for the mixing of poi led to the expression, “Waikahi o Mānā.”

hawaiian_phrase: Waikapū i ka makani kokololio.
english_phrase: Waikapū of the gusty wind.
meaning_phrase: Refers to Waikapū, Maui.

hawaiian_phrase: Wailuku i ka malu he kuawa.
english_phrase: Wailuku in the shelter of the valleys.
meaning_phrase: Wailuku, Maui, reposes in the shelter of the clouds and the valley.

hawaiian_phrase: Waimea, i ka ua Kīpuʻupuʻu.
english_phrase: Waimea, land of the Kīpuupuu rain.
meaning_phrase: Waimea, Hawai’i, is famed in old mele for its cold Kīpuʻupuʻu rain.

hawaiian_phrase: Wai o kaunu.
english_phrase: Water of love.
meaning_phrase: The thrilling effects of being in love.

hawaiian_phrase: Wai ʻōpū nui.
english_phrase: Big stomach water.
meaning_phrase: A humorous term applied to the water of a brackish pool. A stranger, unaccustomed to brackish water, often drank too much of it in attempting to quench his thirst.

hawaiian_phrase: Waipahē wale.
english_phrase: As gentle as still water.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who is genial and kind.

hawaiian_phrase: Wai peʻepeʻe palai o Waiakekua.
english_phrase: The water of Waiakekua that plays hide-and-seek among the ferns.
meaning_phrase: Waiakekua is in Mānoa.

hawaiian_phrase: Waipiʻo kīmopō.
english_phrase: Waipiʻo of the secret rebellion.
meaning_phrase: An epithet for the people of Waipi’o, O’ahu. After the death of Kahāhana, the chiefs of Waipi’o plotted to murder the chiefs of Maui, who were then in ʻEwa. Someone warned the Maui chiefs and all but one escaped. To throw off suspicion, the Waipi’o chiefs claimed that the one was killed by someone from Kaua’i. Later Kahekili learned that Elani, chief ofʻEwa, was in the plot, so he launched a massacre that choked the streams of Niuhelewai and Makāho in Palama with the bodies of the dead.

hawaiian_phrase: Wā ʻōlelo i Kaunakakai.
english_phrase: Loud talking at Kaunakakai.
meaning_phrase: Said of much boisterous talking. The chiefs liked to play games such as kōnane at Kaunakakai, and their shouts and laughter could be heard for some distance.

hawaiian_phrase: Wawā ka menehune i Puʻukapele ma Kauaʻi, puoho ka manu o ka loko o Kawainui ma Oʻahu.
english_phrase: The shouts of the menehune on Puukapele on Kauai startled the birds of Kawainui Pond on Oʻahu.
meaning_phrase: The menehune were once so numerous on Kaua’i that their shouting could be heard on O’ahu. Said of too much boisterous talking.

hawaiian_phrase: Wawā nā manu o Kaʻula.
english_phrase: Noisy are the birds of Kaʻula.
meaning_phrase: A lot of gossip is going around.

hawaiian_phrase: Wehe ʻia ma luna o Hīhīmanu.
english_phrase: Bared on the summit of Hīhīmanu.
meaning_phrase: A humorous reference to a person whose bald head is fringed with hair — like a bare mountaintop above a circle of mist.

hawaiian_phrase: Wehe i ka mākāhā i komo ka iʻa.
english_phrase: Open the sluice gate that the fish may enter.
meaning_phrase: This was uttered by Kaleopuʻupuʻu, priest of Kahekili, after the dedication of the heiau of Kaluli, at Pu’uohala on the north side of Wailuku, Maui. A second invasion from Kalaniʻōpuʻu of Hawaiʻi was expected, and the priest declared that they were now ready to trap the invaders, like fish inside a pond. The saying refers to the application of strategy to trap the enemy.

hawaiian_phrase: Wehe ka piko lā, e ka hoahānau.
english_phrase: Undone is the navel string, O kinsman.
meaning_phrase: A family relation is severed. Said by Keopuolani to Kekuaokalani when she attempted to quell a rebellion, meaning that the tie of kinship between the two cousins, Liholiho and Kekuaokalani, was being severed by the latter’s refusal to be reconciled.

hawaiian_phrase: Wehe ke akule i ka hohonu.
english_phrase: The akule fish takes off to the deep.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who removes himself from the scene of trouble.

hawaiian_phrase: Wehe ʻo Uahi.
english_phrase: Uahi went off.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who is quickly gone from sight, like the smoke (Uahi) from the stack of a fast-moving ship.

hawaiian_phrase: Wehe pau i ka hohonu.
english_phrase: Took off to the depths.
meaning_phrase: Said of one who goes and forgets to return, like fish going off to the deep sea.

hawaiian_phrase: Wehe pau ka pāpale!
english_phrase: Away went the hat!
meaning_phrase: He put on his hat and offhe went.

hawaiian_phrase: Wela ka hao!
english_phrase: (Strike while) the iron is hot!
meaning_phrase: Hurray! This expression, first used by the workers at Honolulu Iron Works, is translated from the English saying.

hawaiian_phrase: Wela ke kai o Hoʻohila.
english_phrase: Warm is the sea of Hoʻohila.
meaning_phrase: Praise for a fearless warrior, or a warning that danger is near. It is said that the presence of a shark is indicated by the warmth of the sea.

hawaiian_phrase: Welawela ke kai o ka moa.
english_phrase: Hot is the broth of the chicken.
meaning_phrase: Said of a person who is potent in love. He is like hot chicken broth — very tasty, but not to be gulped too quickly. There is always a desire for more.

hawaiian_phrase: Welehu ka malama, liko ka ʻōhiʻa.
english_phrase: Welehu is the month [when] the ʻōhiʻa trees are putting forth leaf buds.
meaning_phrase: Not worth troubling about. Maiʻa can refer to either the fruit or the plant.

hawaiian_phrase: Weli ke kai.
english_phrase: A phosphorescent glow [spreads] over the sea.
meaning_phrase: A person going fishing does not like to discuss it beforehand nor to be asked where he is going lest mischievous ghosts hear and precede him to the beach, where they may cast a phosphorescent glow in the water to keep the fish away.

hawaiian_phrase: Weliweli Puna i ke akua wahine.
english_phrase: Puna dreads the goddess.
meaning_phrase: Puna dreads Pele. Said of any dreaded person.

hawaiian_phrase: Welo ka huelo kū.
english_phrase: The standing tails sway.
meaning_phrase: Said of young vines that appear in the month of Welo and have not yet spread. Owls sometimes mistake them for rats and pounce on them.

hawaiian_phrase: Welo ke aloha i ka ʻōnohi.
english_phrase: Love flutters to and fro before the eyes.
meaning_phrase: Said of a longing to see a loved one whose image is constantly in mind.

hawaiian_phrase: Welo kīhei a ke Aʻeloa.
english_phrase: The shoulder covering fluttered in the Aʻeloa wind.
meaning_phrase: Traveled with speed. The runner went so fast that his kīhei stood straight out behind as he ran against the Aʻeloa wind.

hawaiian_phrase: Wī ka niho o ke kolohe.
english_phrase: The mischief-maker now grinds his teeth.
meaning_phrase: Now the rascal is put where he can do no more harm — all he can do is grind his teeth.

hawaiian_phrase: Wili i ke au wili o Kāwili.
english_phrase: Swirled about by the swirling Kāwili.
meaning_phrase: Said of a confusing, bewildering situation. Kā-wili (Hit-and-twist) is a current at Kalae, Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi, that comes from the Kona side and flows out to the ocean. It is the rougher of the two currents that meet off Kalae.

hawaiian_phrase: Wili ka puahiohio, piʻi ka lepo i luna.
english_phrase: The whirlwind twists, and up goes the dust.
meaning_phrase: With wrath, out come words that are unpleasant to hear.

hawaiian_phrase: Wili Koʻolau.
english_phrase: The Koʻolau wind twists about.
meaning_phrase: Said of any hurried work — a twist here, a turn there, and you are finished!

hawaiian_phrase: Wini ʻiʻo nō!
english_phrase: How pointed!
meaning_phrase: Said of a too-bold person who questions his elders, intrudes where he is not wanted, or talks out of tum.
